body_text.text: Abcore, LLC is a provider of quality antibody products and immunochemistry services. Additionally, in partnership with Oxford Expression Technologies (OET), we provide recombinant baculovirus protein expression products and services including VLP production. Abcore also performs ascites production in mice and produces custom antibodies in rabbits, chickens, goats, and llamas. Anton Paar produces high-quality measuring and analysis instruments for laboratory, research and industrial applications. In the fields of density and concentration measurement we are the established world leader. Our product portfolio also includes viscometers, rheometers, polarimeters, refractometers, instruments for X-ray structure analysis, microwave synthesis and microwave synthesis and microwave decomposition. Applied Photophysics (APL) supplies highperformance stopped-flow, laser-flash and circular dichroism (CD) spectrometers that enable highquality research into biochemical and protein kinetic and structural studies. APL provide the means to drive your research to new heights with its information-rich, label-free solutions designed to probe and understand the behaviour of many systems in equilibrium and pre-equilibrium states.

body_text.text: Bio-Logic USA is the leading supplier of complete stopped-flow, quench-flow, and freeze quench systems for rapid kinetic studies in chemistry and molecular biology. Mixing and optical systems are designed for the highest performance, flexibility, and versatility. Sophisticated hardware and software designs allow experiments to be designed easily from the keyboard, and the instruments to be configured for new applications in minutes. BioSilta produces and markets the novel EnBase® media, which are available in ready-to-use tablets and can be used from microwell plates to shake flasks to SUBs. EnBase media provide a cultivation environment with glucose control, pH maintenance and inhibition of growth-limiting metabolites for E. coli and other bacteria and yeast organisms. FASEB MARC Program provides a variety of activities to support the training of minority students, postdoctorates, faculty and scientists in the biomedical and behavioral sciences. We offer travel awards for scientific meetings, research conferences, and student summer research opportunities programs. We also sponsor Career Development Programs including grantsmanship training seminars. ForteBio markets the Octet and BLItz platforms for label-free, high-throughput and micro-volume analysis. The platforms include instruments, 14 biosensor chemistries, and software to measure affinity, kinetics, and concentration in crude or purified samples. These real-time, "dip and read" methods allow simpler, faster and more cost-effective workflows in drug discovery and academic applications compared to SPR, ELISA and HPLC. The Polaron Reader is the cost-effective imaging solution for cell-based assays and multiplexed detection, serving applications in all phases of biomedical research, pharmaceutical development, biologicals manufacturing, and immunodiagnostics. Molecular Dimensions supplies a wide range of products and tools for protein crystallography including: modern crystallization screens and reagents, bacterial growth expression media, crystallization (96-well and 24-well) plates and crystallography products for protein structure determination by X-ray crystallography; ESRF/ EMBL sample changer kits and accessories. We also supply crystal growth incubators and automated solutions for crystal growth imaging and analysis with, UV fluorescence, and dynamic light scattering (DLS). Owing to our comprehensive range of products we are widely recognised as the world leader in membrane protein crystallization. Novoprotein is a protein-centric biotech firm providing custom recombinant protein production services and off shelf recombinant protein products. Its well established four expression systems include mammalian cells, E.coli, yeast and baculovirus/insect cells and their capacity has reached gram scale. Novoprotein has a proven track record over 8 years in business with an impressive 85% success rate. PharmaDiagnostics is the first company to enable label-free, plate-based, solution-phase SPR assays using a standard absorbance plate reader for both end-point and kinetic assays. We provide kits and services based on our unique SoPRano™ technology to academic institutions and companies involved in basic protein and antibody research, and the discovery of both small molecule and protein therapeutics. Promega Corporation is a leader in providing innovative solutions and technical support to the life sciences industry. Promega Corporation's 2,000 products, consisting of kits and reagents, enable scientists worldwide to advance their research in the life sciences, particularly in genomics, proteomics, and cellular analysis. Rigaku Corporation provides the world's most complete line of X-ray diffraction and X-ray fluorescence instruments and components, including benchtop XRD and XRF systems, X-ray optics and detectors, single crystal diffractometers for chemical crystallography, multi-purpose diffractometers with SAXS and in-plane capabilities, and high-powered WDXRF spectrometers. Sierra Sensors GmbH is a global supplier of realtime, label-free interaction analysis systems. By combining proprietary microfluidics with highsensitivity biosensor detection and flexible surface chemistry, we provide robust, high-performance analytical instruments for all research levels. Our systems are ideal for characterization of proteins, antibodies, DNA/RNA, cells, membranes, and small molecules. With advanced technology, and unparalleled customer support, TA Instruments is the world leader in microcalorimetry, thermal analysis, and rheology. We offer ultrasensitive, high precision instruments for life, pharmaceutical, and materials sciences. Our microcalorimetry products include the NanoITC Standard and Low Volume, NanoDSC Autosampler System, and TAM III.

body_text.text: The Protein Society of the claims, products, or services offered. BLItz is a versatile protein analysis instrument that performs rapid identification, quantitation and characterization of expressed proteins from a very low volume of sample. BLItz has the advantage of analyzing unmodified proteins, thus eliminating potential perturbation of the interactions being studied, and avoiding the time-consuming and expensive steps required by the use of labels. BLItz is rapidly gaining popularity as a reliable, yet simple method for analyzing proteins, antibodies and other biomolecules. This presentation provides an overview discussing BLItz, its applications, hardware and software features and Dip and Read biosensors. Detailed knowledge of molecular interactions is important for unraveling biological processes involved in signaling, activation, and regulation. The ability to observe these processes at the molecular level using biophysical techniques facilitates methods for intervention, particularly if these processes are involved in disease. This presentation will discuss specific signaling cascades and demonstrate how Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC), Isothermal Titration Calorimetry (ITC), and Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) have been used to characterize binding interactions, determine active concentrations, and indicate thermal stability. Assay design and methodology will be highlighted. Various signaling pathways of note will be cited during the presentation. The following is a summary of insights gained by employing both calorimetry and SPR technologies. First, the mechanism of action of how TCR-pMHC complexes dictate T cell response will be investigated using ITC. Next, mutagenesis studies of papain-like cysteine proteinases by SPR will demonstrate that active concentration analysis can increase confidence in kinetic values. Small molecule inhibitor screening of Human Poly-(ADP-ribose)-polymerases (PARPs) via SPR has led to the discovery of possible binders specific for PARP 15. Lastly, epidermal growth factor-like calcium binding and domain stabilization can be quantified using ITC and DSC. Alternative inclusion of exons increases the functional diversity of proteins. Among alternatively spliced exons, tissue-specific exons play a critical role in maintaining tissue identity. This raises the question of how tissuespecific protein-coding exons influence protein function. Here, we investigate the structural, functional, interaction and evolutionary properties of constitutive, tissue-specific and other alternative exons in human. We find that tissue-specific protein segments often contain disordered regions, are enriched in post-translational modification sites and frequently embed conserved binding motifs. Furthermore, genes containing tissuespecific exons tend to occupy central positions in interaction networks, display distinct interaction partners in the respective tissues and are enriched in signaling, development and disease genes. Based on these findings, we propose that tissue-specific inclusion of disordered segments that encode binding motifs rewires interaction networks and signalling pathways.

body_text.text: In this way, tissue-specific splicing may contribute to functional versatility of proteins by increasing the diversity of interaction networks across tissues. Intrinsic disorder in proteins is increasingly being recognized as biophysically and biologically important. However, the structural complexity of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) raises challenges and the need for new tools for such studies. Along these lines, I will discuss our use of single-molecule tools to study dynamic structural features of a couple of IDP systems that are important in biology and health. We obtained novel insights into protein dynamics and the complex Macromolecular traffic between the nucleus and cytoplasm of cells is mediated by karyopherins and is gated at nuclear pores (NPCs) by intrinsically-disordered proteins featuring phenylalanine-glycine repeats-the FG nucleoporins. Despite their dynamic nature, we find that these FG nups adopt distinct categories of disordered structure with unique functions. Some are collapsedcoil globules that stick to each via FG repeats, and others are highly-extended coils that repel each other.
body_text.section: Advanced Tools for SPR Analysis

body_text.text: Remarkably, these structures are segregated within FG nups and at NPCs to create a quaternary gating structure that appears suspended in the middle of the nuclear pore termed the transporter or plug. We describe how this 'ghostly' structure, whose existence has been debated for decades, is naturally formed by more than one hundred intrinsically-disordered proteins acting collectively. We will focus the discussion on how the distinct categories of disordered structures serve different functions in karyopherin-mediated transport. This work was supported by NIH grant #GM077520. Proteins serve as switches in signaling networks and their switch-like behavior is often controlled by inputs such as ligand binding, post-translational modification, and light irradiation. Disordered proteins and domains, which are prevalent in eukaryotic proteomes, often serve as hubs within signaling networks. Motifs within disordered protein regions mediate their multifarious interactions, and these interactions are often regulated by post-translational modifications. However, folded proteins also participate in signaling networks and exhibit switch-like behavior. Interestingly, we have observed that some folded proteins function as signaling switches through transitions to disordered states due to ligand binding or post-translational modification-a phenomenon we term "regulated unfolding". It is well appreciated that many proteins that are disordered in isolation fold upon binding their biological targets. We have observed that these proteins, in their functional, bound states, also exhibit regulated unfolding as a mechanism of signaling. We will discuss several examples of regulated unfolding from the realms of both folded and disordered proteins. Observations from us and others suggest that the biological palette of protein disorder is more diverse than currently understood and that the opportunity for regulated order-to-disorder transitions within folded proteins is a means to increase their functional complexity. RNAs and proteins share the feature that they both encode information at the level of their higher-order structure. This seminar will outline recent work from our lab --primarily focused on the mechanisms of and predictions for RNA folding --that nonetheless reveals unanticipated and striking interrelationships between RNA and protein structure. Our laboratory is blending new RNA chemistries, largely directed at the ribose 2'-hydroxyl group, with quantitative interpretation to make possible facile and highly accurate RNA structure analysis. These RNA-directed chemical and structural biology approaches share critical similarities with studies that probe protein dynamics, especially NMR-based deuterium exchange experiments. We then apply these technologies to important, and otherwise intractable, problems in biology. We have developed working models for the architectures of intact viral RNA genomes, which have revealed connections between mRNA structure and the proteins that they encode. In addition, unusual conformations at single nucleotides can dictate folding of a large RNA, much in the same way that a few peptide residues can govern folding of a protein domain. The information for synthesizing the molecules that allow organisms to survive and replicate is encoded in genomic DNA. In the cell, DNA is copied to messenger RNA, and triplet codons (64) in the messenger RNA are decoded -in the process of translation -to synthesize polymers of the natural 20 amino acids. This process (DNA RNA protein) describes the central dogma of molecular biology and is conserved in terrestrial life. We are interested in re-writing the central dogma to create organisms that synthesize proteins containing unnatural amino acids and polymers composed of monomer building blocks beyond the 20 natural amino acids. I will discuss our invention and synthetic evolution of new 'orthogonal' translational components (including ribosomes and aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases) to address the major challenges in re-writing the central dogma of biology. I will discuss the application of the approaches we have developed for incorporating unnatural amino acids into proteins and investigating and synthetically controlling diverse biological processes, with a particular emphasis on understanding the role of posttranslational modifications.
