body_text.text: Building synthetic pathways for production of advanced biofuels Michelle Chang Chemistry and Molecular & Cell Biology, University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA Living systems have evolved the capacity to carry out many chemical transformations of interest to synthetic chemistry if they could be redesigned for targeted purposes. However, our ability to mix and match enzymes to construct de novo pathways for the cellular production of small molecule targets is limited by insufficient understanding how chemistry works inside a living cell. Our group is interested in using synthetic biology as a platform to study how enzymes function in vivo and to use this understanding to build new synthetic pathways for the production of pharmaceuticals, nanomaterials, and fuels using living cells.

Photosynthetic organisms contain a light-harvesting antenna system that absorbs solar photons and transfers energy to the reaction center complexes where photochemistry takes place and the energy is stored ultimately in high-energy compounds such as biomass.

Both the antennas and reaction centers are pigmentprotein complexes, in which multiple protein subunits interact with many noncovalently attached cofactors such as chlorophylls, carotenoids and quinones. Many of the antenna complexes and all known reaction center complexes are integral membrane proteins. This collection of properties makes these systems very challenging to study using most techniques of protein analysis. We have been utilizing modern methods of mass spectrometry to investigate these systems in the native state. Native mass spectrometry has made possible a new approach for the characterization of intact protein complexes. Topological investigations of complexes provide stoichiometry and structural information complementary to that from X-ray and NMR. With these new methods, intact protein complexes from different photosynthetic organisms can now be transferred into the gas phase and interrogated. Examples will be discussed, including the Fenna-Matthews-Olson antenna protein isolated from green sulfur bacteria (1, 2) , the peridinin-chlorophyll antenna protein from dinoflagellate algae and the photoreaction center from purple photosynthetic bacteria. Chemical labeling and H/D exchange protein footprinting methods coupled with mass spectrometry studies have also been used to investigate the larger scale architecture of the supercomplexes that form between antenna and reaction center complexes (1, 3 As a class of therapeutics, antibodies have grown from a non-existent market in 1997 to more than $50 billion in sales in 2011. It is estimated that by 2015, antibodies will encompass 7 of the top 10 selling pharmaceuticals of all classes. We will review why antibodies open up previously undruggable targets and the protein engineering techniques that made therapeutic antibodies a reality. Currently, the vast majority of FDA approved antibodies are naked IgG that rely on modulating target biology and/or engaging antibody effector functions for their therapeutic effect. We will review exciting new approaches to increase therapeutic efficacy of antibodies including antibody drug conjugates, the use of antibody combinations and bispecific antibodies, and enhancing antibody effector functions. Both apolipoprotein E (apoE) and amyloid-β (Aβ) undergo self-association but differ with respect to the association mechanism and extent: apoE associates to oligomers, mostly tetramers at μM concentrations, while Aβ forms aggregation intermediates prior to forming high molecular weight fibrils. As we will discuss, the oligomerization of both proteins relates to their biological function. There are three isoforms of apoE (apoE2, apoE3 and apoE4) that differ only by single amino acid changes. ApoE3 is the common isoform but ApoE4 is the major risk factor for the development of late-onset Alzheimer's Disease. While apoE was recognized early for its role in lipoprotein and cholesterol metabolism the ability to bind lipid does not appear to differ markedly between isoforms. In the brain, however, an important pathological role appears to relate to the ability of apoE to bind Aβ, the major protein constituent of amyloid plaques. While the mechanism of binding of Aβ to apoE is unclear, considerable evidence suggests that Aβ clearance, the movement of intracellular Aβ to the extracellular space, may be apoE isoform dependent. We show here that apoE isoforms do differ with respect to interactions with Aβ aggregation intermediates and we discuss how structural differences between apoE3 and apoE4 may be responsible for this difference. We ask the question as to whether it would be possible to find therapeutic agents that would alter the behavior of apoE4 to that more similar to apoE3.

Department of Biochemistry, Carver College of Medicine, Univ. of Iowa, Iowa City, IA Nature creates biological switches of great complexity, responsiveness and beauty by making parsimonious use of small differences between similar macromolecules. Thermodynamic and structural variations in the alpha and beta chains of hemoglobin allow for positive cooperativity and proton regulation to arise in a tetramer of subunits having the same "myoglobin fold". These biophysical principles are also manifest in the division of labor between domains of dimeric bacteriophage lambda cI or cro repressors and variations in cooperativity within the tripartite right and left operator regions of lambda DNA that control its lysogenic-to-lytic growth switch. Statistical thermodynamic modeling by the Ackers laboratory provided groundbreaking insights into the biophysical mechanisms of allostery in both these systems. Many branches of calcium-mediated signal transduction pathways use variations on these allosteric themes to respond to their molecular environment and control physiological behavior. These allosteric multimers include calcium-regulated voltage-dependent sodium channels that control essential processes in nerves and muscles. Related channelopathies include several forms of epilepsy, cardiac syndromes, pain insensitivity, and other defects in the generation and propagation of action potentials. Most channels respond to calcium via regulation by calmodulin (CaM), an essential eukaryotic calcium sensor comprised of two highly homologous domains connected by a regulatory linker -a monomeric "dimer of dimers" reminiscent of hemoglobin, with a physical architecture similar to that of cI repressor. To determine how CaM translates changes in intracellular calcium levels into conformational work, and how it regulates multiple isoforms of related channels, we are determining the distinct roles of CaM domains using NMR and biosensors encompassing the IQ motif region of the NaV1.x family of sodium channels. Determining the abundant states of each channel-CaM complex and the rules for transition between them will yield the partition function that governs phenotypic differences in different tissue types. NIH R01 GM57001.
body_text.section: Allosteric Calmodulin Domains Grasp and Remodel Ion Channels Madeline Shea

body_text.text: Protein electrostatics: new insights into a challenging old problem Bertrand Garcia-Moreno Biophysics, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD

The structural and physical basis of the Bohr effect of human hemoglobin was one of the many problems that fascinated Gary Ackers throughout his life. The Bohr effect refers to the preferential binding of H+ by deoxygenated hemoglobin. It ensures the efficient delivery of O2 in exercised tissues, where the pH is usually lower than in tissues at rest. Using his deep understanding of linkage thermodynamics Ackers developed experimental strategies to measure the energetics of the Bohr effect and to attempt to explain its microscopic origins. Understanding the Bohr effect is a problem in protein electrostatics because H+ binding is determined by the pKa values of ionizable groups and Coulomb and hydration forces govern the pKa values. Despite substantial progress in our understanding of determinants of pKa values and improvements in our ability to calculate pKa values from structure, this old problem remains very challenging and interesting. It is especially relevant now that it is recognized that many macromolecular assemblies are pH sensitive and that this pH sensitivity is often a key element in biological regulation. Prof. Chien Ho made substantial contributions to our understanding of the origins of the Bohr effect by using NMR spectroscopy to measure pKa values of ionizable groups in both liganded and unliganded forms of hemoglobin. What remains missing is an understanding of molecular determinants of these pKa values. This is a problem we have studied systematically by exploiting the same basic concepts of linkage thermodynamics that Ackers used so successfully in his dissection of functional thermodynamics in hemoglobin and in the molecular switch of phage lambda. I will present results from two different projects in protein electrostatics. I will describe unusual properties of ionizable groups that can result from cooperative interactions in clusters of ionizable groups. I will also discuss the highly anomalous pKa values and the unusual properties that ionizable groups can have when buried in dehydrated environments such as the protein interior or at interfaces between proteins. I will illustrate novel insights emerging from an approach that combines X-ray crystallography, NMR spectroscopy, equilibrium thermodynamic measurements, and structure-based calculations. The physical insights emerging from our studies is already being used by many groups help guide improvement For clinical applications, we need synthetic molecules with novel amplifying mechanisms for homing to diseased tissues. Activatable cell penetrating peptides (ACPPs) are polycationic cell penetrating peptides (CPPs) whose cellular uptake is minimized by a polyanionic inhibitory domain and then restored upon proteolysis of the peptide linker connecting the polyanionic and polycationic domains. Local activity of proteases able to cut the linker causes amplified retention in tissues and uptake into cells. ACPPs sensitive to matrix metalloproteinases-2 and -9 attached to dendrimers labeled with Cy5 and Gd-DOTA enable whole body magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (Olson et al (2010) PNAS 107: 4311-4316) followed by fluorescence-guided surgery. Such fluorescence guidance illuminates tumor margins and improves tumor-free survival in two animal models (Nguyen et al (2010)
Astbury Centre for Structural Molecular Biology, University of Leeds, Leeds LS2 9JT
body_text.section: Molecular insights into deadly protein self-assembly Sheena Radford

body_text.text: Most proteins fold efficiently to their native structures in vivo, assisted by molecular chaperones. It is now widely known, however, that proteins do misfold and that misfolding events can result in conformational disease. Work in our laboratory aims to elucidate the mechanisms by which proteins fold or misfold and aggregate, so as to provide information key to the development of therapeutics against misfolding disease. In the lecture I will discuss the nature of protein folding and misfolding landscapes and discuss recent data from our laboratory that have focused on developing an armoury of biochemical and biophysical methods to elucidate the mechanism of amyloid formation at a structural molecular level. In particular, focusing on the protein, beta-2-microglobulin, I will discuss our new insights into the structural molecular mechanism of amyloid assembly and describe recent data from our laboratory which suggest that amyloid fibrils may be more than just the inert end products of protein fibrillation.
body_text.section: Molecular insights into deadly protein self-assembly Sheena Radford

body_text.text: Longitudinal measures of proteostasis in live neurons: Features that determine fate in models of neurodegenerative disease Steven Finkbeiner Neurology and Physiology, Gladstone and UCSF, San Francisco, CA One feature of the major adult-onset neurodegenerative diseases is that abnormal protein deposits accumulate in the brain. Another common characteristic of these diseases is that only certain neurons die. How an aggregation-prone protein selectively kills neurons is unclear, particularly in cases caused by gene mutations in which the offending protein is widely expressed. We have developed primary murine and human neuron models of Huntington's disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, and Alzheimer's disease as tools to understand mechanisms of neurodegeneration and to identify and validate therapeutic targets. To study these models, we have constructed automated microscopes that can identify and follow individual neurons over their lifetimes and measure factors during their lives that predict their fate. From studies of several models of neurodegenerative disease, protein dyshomeostasis has emerged as one of the best predictors of neurodegeneration. The visible protein deposits, called inclusion bodies, that are often hallmarks of these diseases are not required for cell death. In some cases, the formation of an inclusion body is associated with improved survival, suggesting it can be a coping response. Rather, intracellular levels of malfolded monomers and possibly oligomers significantly predict whether and when individual neurons will die. To complement studies aimed at understanding toxic species of misfolded proteins, we have developed methods, such as optical pulselabeling, to assess the response of individual neurons to protein misfolding. We find that neurons recognize and destabilize several disease-causing aggregation-prone proteins. Surprisingly, the extent of destabilization of the identical polypeptide varied significantly among neurons, indicating differences in capacity to clear the polypeptide. In our most extensively studied model of Huntington's disease, these cell-specific differences predicted each neuron's longevity and explained a portion of the cell-selective vulnerability to mutant huntingtin. Thus, differences in turnover capacity may contribute to cellular susceptibility to toxic proteins, and efforts to bolster proteostasis could be neuroprotective. Supported by NINDS, NIA, the Taube The conformational properties of soluble α-synuclein, the primary protein found in patients with Parkinson's disease, are thought to play a key role in the structural transition to amyloid fibrils. A recent study has suggested that α-synuclein purified from red blood cells, as well as neuronal and non-neuronal cell lines is acetylated at the N-terminus. The role of N-terminal acetylation is poorly understood but has been suggested to affect the kinetic or thermal stability of proteins. Here, we discuss the influence of N-terminal acetylation of α-synuclein on conformation and dynamics, and on the mechanism of aggregation. Using NMR, mass spectrometry and other biophysical and biochemical approaches we report that recombinant 100% N-terminal acetylated α-synuclein purified under mild physiological conditions presents as a primarily monomeric protein. We show that N-terminal acetylation has short and long-range conformational and dynamic effects in regions known to be important in metal binding, in association with membranes, and in regions known to affect fibril formation rates. In addition, we show that N-terminal acetylation not only changes the distribution of the intrinsically disordered monomeric conformers within the structural ensemble of αsyn, but that this co-translational modification disfavors fibril formation presumably caused by the conformational redistribution of the monomeric protein.
Influence of temperature on primordial chemistry and the course of enzyme evolution Richard Wolfenden University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC

In the absence of enzymes, biological reactions proceed with half-lives as long as 1026 seconds. Yet life is believed to have taken hold within the first 25% of Earth's history. How could cellular chemistry, and the enzymes that make life possible, have arisen so quickly? All reactions are accelerated by an increase in temperature, but very slow reactions have an unexpectedly steep dependence on temperature, much steeper than the whole known rule of thumb, by which the rate of a reaction is multiplied by a factor of 2 to 4 if the reaction temperature is raised by 10 °C. For example, the hydrolysis of polysaccharides (t1/2 108 y at 25 °C) is accelerated 190,000-fold when the temperature is raised from 25 to 100 °C, while the rates of hydrolysis of phosphate monoester dianions (t1/2 1012 y) and sulfate ester monoanions (t1/2 1018 y) increase more than 10,000,000-fold. Moreover, the slowest reactions tend to be the most heat-sensitive. These tendencies collapse, by as many as five orders of magnitude, the time that would have been required for early chemical evolution in a warm environment. The sensitivity of slow reactions to temperature also suggests some likely properties of an evolvable catalyst and a plausible scenario for its evolution. If the catalytic effect of a primitive "protoenzyme" were mainly to reduce a reaction's enthalpy of activation, then the resulting rate enhancement would increase automatically as the environment became cooler on a primitive earth, quite aside from structural improvements that might be introduced by mutation and natural selection. No such behavior would be expected for a purely entropic catalyst, as indicated in the figure below. It may never be possible to establish whether enzymes evolved in this manner. However, several primitive but powerful nonenzymatic catalysts of slow biological reactions-notably pyridoxal phosphate (for amino acid decarboxylation) and the ceric ion (for phosphate monoester and diester hydrolysis)-are shown to meet this criterion, in that their effects in lowering the reaction's free energy of activation arise entirely from a reduction in the enthalpy of activation. And in fact, their effects on the reaction's entropy of activation are slightly unfavorable. These properties, consistent with an important role for polar enzyme-substrate interactions in transition stabilization, seem to be shared by most modern enzymes. A striking exception is the peptidyl transferase site of the ribosome, a relatively weak catalyst that renders the entropy of activation more favorable, consistent with a role for desolvation or juxtaposition in catalysis. These proposals, if correct, greatly reduce the time that would have been required for early chemical evolution, countering the view that not enough time has passed for life to have evolved to its present level of complexity.
How do proteins evolve? Dan Tawfik Department of Biological Chemistry, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot 76100, Israel

In spite the robustness and perfection of their mechanism of action, proteins posses a remarkable ability to rapidly change and adopt new functions and functions. I will describe experimental work aimed at reproducing the evolution of new proteins in the laboratory and unraveling how they evolve. I will discuss laboratory pursued trajectories leading the new enzymatic functions and reconstructed ancestors of natural enzymes. These experiments support the divergence of enzyme functions from multi-functional, 'generalist' progenitors, and thereby a mechanism of divergence prior to duplication. As early as 1930 Peters envisaged the cell to comprise "an organised network of protein molecules, forming a three dimensional mosaic" (1) . Despite this inspirational idea and the efforts of Srere and others, the nature of intracellular protein assemblies has been largely neglected. Recent attempts to monitor proteins inside cells have revealed that many proteins cannot be detected by in-cell NMR spectroscopy. Although a model protein for in vitro NMR cytochrome c (cyt c) does not yield an in-cell spectrum when over expressed in E. coli. In a bid to understand intracellular assemblies we have used size exclusion chromatography to investigate the interactions of cyt c in E. coli cell lysates (2). The effects of NaCl, the physiologically-relevant salt potassium glutamate, and charge inversion mutants on cyt c interactions were also studied. We show that protein stickiness and the formation of high molecular weight complexes limit the application of in-cell NMR spectroscopy. Current efforts are focused on the fusion protein DTat-GB1 and ion effects on the interactions with E. coli cytosolic proteins will be reported. The structural characterisation of low affinity protein-ligand complexes is also relevant to improving our understanding of intracellular protein assemblies. Here, we show how p-sulfonato-calix [4] arene explores the surface of cyt c by the formation of several dynamic complexes involving Lys side chains (3) . The implications for protein surface recognition will be discussed. We gratefully acknowledge the support of Science Foundation Ireland (grant 10/RFP/BIC2807) Although dilute solution conditions have served protein science well for over a century, understanding proteins function under more physiologically-relevant conditions is the ultimate goal for protein chemists and biophysicists. In-cell NMR has emerged as a valuable means to provide protein structure and other biophysical properties inside living cells at atomic resolution. Incell NMR has gone significantly advances recently, but its application is still limited due to the lack of high resolution NMR spectra. The resolution of in-cell NMR spectrum is poor for many proteins, mainly due to the sample inhomogeneity, the size limitation (<30 kDa ) of solution NMR, the huge background signals from other molecules inside cells and the cellular effects on protein dynamics. Here, we first examine critical parameters for the resolution of in-cell NMR spectroscopy, then we use 19F NMR to measure the cellular associated dynamics and the apparent viscosity in Escherichia Coli cytoplasm .

Computational design of binding proteins: inhibitors of influenza hemagglutinin and remaining challenges Sarel Fleishman Biological Chemistry, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel Molecular recognition underlies all biological phenomena. We recently described a novel computational method with which we designed two proteins that bound tightly and inhibited hemagglutinin from several highly divergent influenza strains, and other proteins which bound three other unrelated targets. The method is based on the finding that natural proteins encode structural elements that rigidify functional sites, precluding rearrangements that might lead to reduced affinity and off-target binding. Initial experimentally determined affinities of the designed proteins to their targets were low, requiring optimization through experimental affinity maturation. We have now identified similar interaction domains from several other regulatory proteins -including some LIM-homeodomain proteins thereby setting up alternate complexes using the same domains. Despite very low levels of sequence identity, these interaction domains appear to bind the identical faces of their targets in a very similar manner. We are using a combination of mutagenic, biophysical and structural studies to investigate how these proteins target subsets of partners in an apparently specific way, how they build up cell specific transcription and other regulatory complexes, and are trying to exploit differences in binding preferences to regulate complex formation.

Appropriately engineered proteases could be used for a variety of applications ranging from molecular biology research reagents to human therapeutics. The latter could be envisioned as catalytic replacements for antibodies, provided the therapeutic target is a serum accessible protein. Key to the successful application of engineered proteases will be the ability to alter substrate specificity in precise fashion while maintaining a high level of overall catalytic activity. We have been developing a range of protease engineering strategies over the past decade with an emphasis on directed evolution approaches that incorporate a high throughput screen based on catalytic turnover. Protease engineering presents unique and daunting technical challenges due to the lethal threat posed by an active, recombinant protease with untamed specificity in a host organism.
body_text.section: Univ. of Texas at Austin

body_text.text: Most of our work has incorporated E. coli as host and a fluorescence activated cell sorting (FACS) based method for library screening. Using the model protease OmpT, we have been able to alter both the P1 and P1' substrate specificity in a surprisingly general way while maintaining a relatively high level of substrate specificity as well as high overall catalytic activity. Key to this success has been the incorporation of simultaneous selection and counterselection strategies into our protease library screening technologies. We have also used directed evolution to generate OmpT variants specific for substrates with modified amino acids such as nitro and sulfo tyrosine. In addition to the E. coli based strategies, we have begun to explore the use of other host organisms and proteases. We recently were able to alter the P1 specificity of the TEV protease by over 5000-fold in a single round of directed evolution. We develop and apply computational prediction and design methods to engineer proteins as molecular parts with altered and new functions (1) . I plan to describe two recent stories: In the first, we borrow mathematical formulations from the field of robotics to predict and "reshape" protein conformations with atom-level accuracy (2). In the second, we experimentally reengineer protein function to create orthogonal interfaces (3)
body_text.section: Univ. of Texas at Austin

body_text.text: A single-molecule view of protein action at a distance Rob Phillips Biophysics and Biology, Caltech, Pasadena, CA Abstract: Decision making as a result of changing environmental conditions is a signature feature of all living organisms. One of the most common ways in which cells implement these decisions is through proteins regulating the process of transcription. An impressive array of quantitative measurements now make it possible to query the transcription process in exquisite detail and as a result have raised the bar on what it means to understand transcription. After giving an overview of the "by the numbers" approach to transcription, I will then highlight a three-pronged strategy for the study of this crucial part of the central dogma based upon theoretical modeling using the tools of statistical mechanics, single-molecule approaches which allow us to watch transcription factors one at a time and single-cell approaches which permit systematic measurements of the level of gene expression for a number of different regulatory architectures. Tail-anchor (TA) proteins represent an important and diverse class of membrane proteins that are unable to be targeted via the co-translational SRP pathway. Instead, recent discoveries have identified factors directly involved in targeting these proteins to the ER. In yeast, these proteins form the GET pathway. Our lab has focused on structural and mechanistic studies of these proteins. The pathway as we posit begins with cytoplasmic chaperones that deliver the TA-proteins to Sgt2, which routes the proteins to Get3 via a Get4/Get5 hetero-tetramer. Get3 then forms a stable complex with the TA and delivers the proteins to the ER membrane.

We have begun characterizing these complexes using structural biology and biochemistry. I will frame a discussion of the pathway from our unique structural perspective presenting new results on parts of the pathway.

Human islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP, also known as amylin) is the major component of the pancreatic islet amyloid deposits associated with type 2 diabetes. IAPP is one of the most aggressive amyloidogenic naturally occurring sequences, forming amyloid even more rapidly than the abeta polypeptide. IAPP has been identified in all mammalian species examined and is a member of the calcitonin-like family of peptides. IAPP is secreted in response to the same stimuli that lead to insulin secretion and acts as an endocrine partner to insulin, but aggregates, via an unknown mechanism, to form islet amyloid in type-2 diabetes. Aggregates of the human polypeptide are toxic to cultured beta-cells, suggesting that IAPP amyloid or the process of amyloid formation by IAPP contributes to islet beta-cell death in type 2 diabetes. Increasing evidence argues that IAPP amyloid formation also plays an important role in the failure of islet cell grafts in islet transplantation. The mechanism of IAPP toxicity is not known and the nature of the toxic species produced during IAPP amyloid formation is still unresolved. New fluorescence probes and two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy are being used along with more conventional biophysical methods to elucidate the mechanisms of IAPP self assembly and to probe the mode of action of compounds which inhibit amyloid formation and which remodel preformed IAPP amyloid. This work in combination with time dependent toxicity studies and the analysis of a range of designed IAPP mutants is used to define the most toxic species populated during IAPP amyloid formation. (1), based on high-throughput single-molecule fluorescence experiments, which is specifically geared towards tracing the dynamics of folding in the presence of a plethora of intermediates. In our experiment protein molecules are labeled at two sites for FRET, and then encapsulated within lipid vesicles that are tethered to a glass surface. This facilitates collecting single-molecule trajectories from individual molecules with minimal perturbation. We employed this method to characterize the folding reaction of a three-domain protein, adenylate kinase (AK). We measured several single-molecule data sets, each taken at a different concentration of a chemical denaturant and containing ~1000 trajectories. Transitions between intermediate states of the protein were clearly seen in the trajectories. We then used hidden Markov modeling to analyze the trajectories, identify metastable states and extract the rates of interconversion between them. Six metastable states were found on AK's folding landscape, and we could delineate the most probable pathways connecting them.

Remarkably, it was found that the kinetic connectivity of the intermediates depends on denaturant concentration. Thus, at high denaturant concentration the most probable pathway from the folded to the unfolded state proceeds sequentially through the intermediate states.

However, at low denaturant concentration multiple intersecting folding pathways co-exist. We anticipate that the methodology introduced here will find broad applicability in the study of folding of large proteins, and will provide a more realistic scenario of their conformational dynamics. Focusing on other members of the family, I will also present recent data on ErbB3 suggesting that -rather than being 'kinase-dead' -it retains a level of tyrosine kinase activity that may be important for cellular signaling. Finally, I will describe how our understanding of another RTK, called ALK, can aid patient treatment decisions in neuroblastoma.

the role of pH and protein environment in modulating protein function and ionization state of key residues. We will discuss studies that provide basic benchmarks for the approach and compare with experimental pKa values in both "normal" protein systems as well as those from buried charge groups, as studies experimentally by Garcia-Moreno and co-workers recently. We will also illustrate the use of CpHMD to elucidate the pH sensing mechanisms in the small bacterial chaperone protein HdeA, where drops in pH trigger protein dissociation and chaperone activity, while relaxation of the pH toward normal cellular levels facilitates substrate release. Finally, we will present findings for the pHdependent maturation of the virus protein capsid in the T=7 viral capsid of HK97.
Elucidating the structure and mechanism of the influenza M2 proton channel using solid-state NMR Mei Hong Department of Chemistry, Iowa State University, Ames, IA

The folding of membrane proteins into their functional structure ensembles requires the appropriate environment of phospholipid bilayers. The M2 protein of the influenza virus, which forms a drug-sensitive tetrameric proton channel in the virus envelope, provides an especially illuminating case of the sensitivity of membrane protein structure to the environment. We describe our recent studies, using magic-angle-spinning solid-state NMR spectroscopy, to determine the conformation and dynamics of the M2 transmembrane (TM) domain bound to lipid bilayers. SSNMR chemical shifts, internuclear distances and dynamic order parameters indicate that the proton-selective residue, a TM histidine, forms a CH-π stacked tetrad at high pH, which obstructs proton current. But at low pH the four histidines are pushed apart due to backbone conformational changes, and undergo small-angle reorientations on the microsecond timescale with an activation energy that is consistent with the proton conduction barrier. 15N NMR spectra directly show histidine-water proton exchange on the same timescale as the ring motion, indicating that M2 conducts protons by a shuttling mechanism rather than a water-wire mechanism. The four pKa's of the histidine tetrad were determined and gave quantitative estimates of the relative single-channel conductivity of the various charged states. M2 is the target of the antiviral drug, amantadine. To elucidate the inhibition mechanism, we have determined the binding site of amantadine through protein-drug distance measurements and chemical shift perturbation. The results indicate that a high-affinity, pharmacologically relevant, binding site exists in the N-terminal channel pore, while a previously proposed binding site on the lipid-facing surface of the protein has low affinity and is occupied only when the drug is in excess. Interestingly, the pore-binding site can be lost under very high membrane curvature, which is prevalent in detergent micelles. The result shows the importance of the solvent environment on M2 structure. In addition to amantadine, paramagnetic Cu(II) also inhibits M2, but in a different way, as elucidated by paramagnetic relaxation NMR. This suggests that it may be possible to develop new drugs to inhibit amantadine-resistant M2 variants, by targeting the Cu(II) binding site.
Examining the mechanisms underlying error-free cell division Tarun Kapoor Laboratory of Chemistry and Cell Biology, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY

The accurate placement of the cell division plane during cell division is essential for error-free genome propagation. I will discuss two mechanisms that may contribute to this process. One involves a spatial Aurorakinase dependent phosphorylation gradient that extends across the spindle midzone, an interdigitating array of anti-parallel microtubules that forms during anaphase. The second involves PRC1 (MAP65/Ase1), a nonmotor microtubule crosslinking protein required for spindle midzone formation and successful cytokinesis in eukaryotes. I will discuss our findings from biophysical and structural studies that suggest PRC1 functions as a dynamic tracker of antiparallel microtubule overlap, analogous to +TIP proteins that track plus-ends of growing microtubules. This functional specialization in a non-motor microtubule-associate protein could help 'mark' nano-scale geometric features in self-organizing cytoskeletal networks. Such 'marks' can recruit enzymes, such as kinases, to specific intracellular sites and establish micron-scale spatial patterns that may provide positional cues for proper cell cleavage. In vitro directed evolution allows biomolecules with new and useful properties to be engineered-mimicking natural evolution on an experimentally accessible time scale by creating large libraries of DNA mutants using PCR and then carrying out a high-throughput assay for variants with improved function. To provide a breakthrough in the complexity of libraries that can be readily searched experimentally, my laboratory is engineering S. cerevisiae so that both the mutagenesis and selection steps of directed evolution can be carried out entirely in vivo, under conditions of sexual reproduction. I will describe chemical complementation, which provides a selection for chemical transformations beyond those natural to the cell using themes and variations on the yeast two-hybrid assay. Then I will present a heritable mutagenesis system, which allows for targeted mutagenesis via homologous recombination and crossing of beneficial mutations through mating and sporulation. Finally, the generality of this approach is explored for enzyme, antibody, and cell engineering. properties. The only genetic information they contain is the synthetic chromosome, including all designed identifying watermark sequences, gene deletions, and polymorphisms. After approximately 20 doublings, all macromolecules in a progeny cell will be products specified by the synthetic genome. For this reason we like to refer to a cell controlled by a synthetic genome as a "synthetic cell". In the course of this work methods have been developed for the construction, cloning, and installation of large DNA assemblies. It is possible to assemble segments of natural or synthetic DNA up to several hundred kilobases enzymatically, in vitro. Natural and synthetic DNA greater than one megabase can be assembled and cloned by natural recombination in yeast. These methods will facilitate experimental definition of the minimal genetic requirements for cellular life, and should aid in the design of new bacterial strains with useful properties.

Center for Systems and Synthetic Biology, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX One of the basic tenets of synthetic biology posits that the transcriptional and translational regulatory elements, enzymes, and even whole organisms can be reduced to a series of interacting, programmable parts similar to the components on a printed circuit board. However, this level of programmability is similar to saying that ENIAC was programmable because it had lots and lots of different vacuum tubes. While at some level this is true, this level of biological abstraction is ultimately a kludge. One of the shortcomings in this line of thinking is the non-programmable nature of interactions between proteins and to a lesser extent the interactions between proteins and nucleic acids. Since proteins are the biomolecular workhorses of the cell the ability to program their interactions with one another could prove useful in developing novel biochemical and regulatory pathways within a cell. However, in order for synthetic biology to be a discipline that incorporates elements of actual programmability, it must learn from the only biomolecules that are capable of anything akin to programmability: nucleic acids. However, nucleic acid machines (ribozymes) are not nearly robust enough to enable modern metabolism (proteins won this war about 3 billion years ago), therefore imbuing proteins with the ability to function in a programmable fashion similar to nucleic acids would advance the field of synthetic biology and facilitate programming at the organismal level. The Ellington lab has undertaken to engineer aminoacyl tRNA synthetases to incorporate four additional amino acids into the genetic code with novel nucleobase sidechains encoding G, A, T, and C. Progress towards this goal includes the development of novel, orthogonal amino acyl tRNA synthetase:tRNA pairs, the development of new selection systems for these orthogonal pairs, and the use of computational design to engineer aminoacyl tRNA synthetase variants with basal activities towards these novel nucleobase amino acid substrates. These advances have been abetted by access to (and control of) in-house high-throughput DNA synthesis capabilities. For example, we have been able to 'fab' a variety of genes and circuits, and quickly express them both in vitro and in vivo. As new amino acids are introduced into the genetic code, the organism must be accommodated to accept these amino acids on a proteome-wide basis. Older work from our and other labs suggests this is far from a trivial process. Unsurprisingly, many of the aminoacyl tRNA synthetase variants that we have created have profound fitness effects, including eliminating themselves because of cross-charging of tRNAs or cross-utilization of amino acids. In the end, though, the payoffs from empowering proteins to function like nucleic acids should be great. Chargoff's rules for nucleotide base-pairing as instantiated in DNA nanotechnology has given us some indication of what can be achieved through rule-based programmability. Complex structures can be generated from simple architectures. In addition, we have shown that programmable reaction diffusion networks can be created that allow nanoscale reactions to play out at a level visible to the naked eye. We envision similar 'amorphous computations' will be possible into the future with proteins and cells. Systematic affinity purification combined with mass spectrometry analysis of N-and C-tagged cytoplasmic Hsp70/Hsp110 chaperones was used to identify new roles of Hsp70/Hsp110 in the cell. This allowed the mapping of a chaperone-protein network consisting of 1227 unique interactions between the 9 chaperones and 473 proteins, and highlighted roles for Hsp70/Hsp110 in 14 broad biological processes. Using this information, we uncovered an essential role for Hsp110 in spindle assembly and, more specifically, in modulating the activity of the widely conserved kinesin-5 motor Cin8. The role of Hsp110 Sse1 as a nucleotide exchange factor for the Hsp70 chaperones Ssa1/Ssa2 was found to be required for maintaining the concentration gradient of kinesin-5 motors within the spindle, which is, subsequently, required for bipolar spindle assembly in S-phase. The data suggest a model whereby the Hsp70/ Hsp110 chaperone complex modulates the directionality of Cin8 movement on microtubules by affecting Cin8 oligomeric state. Small heat shock proteins (sHSPs) are intimately linked to protein homeostasis and cell survival under conditions of stress. sHSPs act at an early stage of the stress response, serving as "holdases"-ATPindependent protein chaperones that recognize partly unfolded, aggregation-prone proteins and maintain these as soluble species to promote cell survival.
body_text.section: Synthetic biology and programmability Andrew Ellington

body_text.text: Depending on the fate of the cell, rescued proteins ("clients") are delivered either to an ATP-dependent chaperone for folding or to the proteasome for degradation. Failed sHSP function is associated with multiple diseases, e.g., cataract, cardiomyopathies, motor neuropathies, and numerous neurodegenerative diseases. Conversely, overexpression of the human sHSPs αB-crystallin or HSP27 in cancer cells confers resistance to chemotherapy and is correlated with poor clinical outcomes. Despite a growing appreciation for the importance of sHSPs, an understanding of how they perform their cellular functions has been stymied by a lack of structural information. Progress has been limited by the fact that the proteins exist as dynamic oligomeric assemblies that resist crystallization and are too large for conventional solution-state NMR. We used solution-NMR and solid-state magic-angle spinning NMR, small angle x-ray scattering, and single particle electron microscopy to determine the first atomic-level model of a mammalian sHSP oligomer, αB-crystallin ("αB"). The model of an αB 24-mer suggests ways in which the distribution of oligomeric species observed by tandem mass spectrometry (24-mers to 32-mers) are assembled. A second challenge in the study of sHSPs has been the difficulty in detecting weak, transient interactions involving aggregation-prone proteins. We will present results in which client/sHSP interactions are detected by NMR, providing the first residue-level information regarding a mode of recognition by sHSPs.
body_text.section: Synthetic biology and programmability Andrew Ellington

body_text.text: The molecular architecture of the eukaryotic chaperonin TRiC/CCT Judith Frydman Biology, Stanford University, Stanford, CA TRiC/CCT is a highly conserved and essential chaperonin that uses ATP cycling to facilitate folding of approximately 10% of the eukaryotic proteome. This 1 MDa hetero-oligomeric complex consists of two stacked rings of eight paralogous subunits each. Previously proposed TRiC models differ substantially in their subunit arrangements and ring register. Here, we integrate chemical crosslinking, mass spectrometry and combinatorial modeling to reveal the definitive subunit arrangement of TRiC. In vivo disulfide mapping provided additional validation for the crosslinkingderived arrangement as the definitive TRiC topology. This subunit arrangement allowed the refinement of a structural model using existing X-ray diffraction data.

The new structure explains all available crosslink experiments, provides a rationale for previously unexplained structural features and reveals a surprising asymmetry of charges within the chaperonin folding chamber. Generating biofuels from cellulosic material may mitigate the detrimental environmental effects of current production schemes. Common agricultural byproducts and algal feedstocks are cellulosic in nature, providing more biomass than grain sources while minimizing agricultural intensification. Employing cellulosic feedstocks, however, requires the use of relatively expensive cellulases, enzymes capable of cleaving cellulose into fermentable sugars. One method of reducing cellulase cost relies on an idea encapsulated in the Arrhenius equation, that reaction rates increase as temperature increases. Employing thermostable cellulases would not only minimize process time, but would also reduce the amount of enzyme necessary per gallon of synthesized fuel.

We are currently computationally engineering hyperthermostable variants of Cel5A from the fungus Hypocrea jecorina (Hj_Cel5A), one of the most heavily employed cellulases in the biofuels industry. To obtain a starting scaffold for design purposes, we have recently solved the structure of this enzyme. When compared to a thermostable homolog, the Hj_Cel5A structure demonstrates long, solvent-exposed loops. As such, we are combining traditional core-repacking algorithms with loop truncation software to generate thermostable variants. To ensure loop truncation does not disrupt protein stability, we utilize an algorithm to predict loop trajectories around the mutated sites, and then perform sequence optimization on the new structure.
body_text.section: Biofuels (56)

body_text.text: Here we present the crystal structure of H. jecorina Cel5A to 2.1 Å, data demonstrating the robustness of our design methodology, and preliminary designs that await biochemical testing. This work was made possible through funding from the National Science Foundation. Despite many histidine-rich proteins (motifs) are found to exert important physiological functions in metabolism, a systematic and comprehensive study of the distribution and the potentially conserved functions are overlooked. Herein, we examine a representative set of 675 prokaryotic genome sequences, to map the distribution of histidine (His)-rich proteins (motifs) in the prokaryotic genomes and inspect their physiological functions. Statistically HRMs are essentially absent from host-associated species but present with high frequency in the genomes of relatives of Rhizobiales and Burkholderiales, which were mostly found in the soil, indicating a close connection between the biased gene distribution of HRMs and the similar environmental habitats of the prokaryotes. The majority (96%) of the identified HRM-containing proteins with annotated function are involved in metal homeostasis, participating in metal uptake, the metal centre incorporation and metal efflux. The conserved function of HRMs suggests that the enrichment of histidine in the gene sequence was probably due to positive selection and reasonably it could confer service for the cell habitation. Furthermore, we investigate the in vivo metal susceptibility of a global His-rich protein with an extremely high content of histidine and found they partially protect the host cells against the metal toxicity and the cellular metal content in the host cells are 3-5 fold higher than control groups, which implies the His-rich protein are coordinated to the free toxic free metal ions so as to behavior like a metal ions "sponge". We propose the detoxification function of HRMs supports the cells to survive in soils and sediments with high concentration of toxic free metal ions and that is the reason the high occurrence of HRMs in the genomes of prokaryotes which habitat in the soils. Our results unveiled the relationship between the gene distribution of HRMs and the conserved functions. More importantly, this strategy we used in here could be promisingly and generally applied to search, analyze and characterize other single, double or triple-amino acid rich motifs of interest in microbial proteomes.
body_text.section: Biofuels (56)

body_text.text: The dynamic stator stalk of rotary ATPases Alastair Stewart 1, 2 The proteasome is the central machinery for targeted protein degradation in archaea, actinobacteria, and eukaryotes. It consists of a regulatory ATPase and a proteolytic core particle. The interaction between both components is governed by the HbYX motif at the C-terminus of the ATPase, which stimulates gate opening of the proteasomal α-subunits. We present a systematic sequence analysis of the C-termini of archaeal AAA ATPases, uncovering the presence of the proteasome-interaction motif in AAA proteins of the BphI-BphJ is an aldolase-dehydrogenase complex from Burkholderia xenovorans LB400, a bacterium which is able to degrade polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). BphI, the aldolase, cleaves 4-hydroxy-2oxoacids to pyruvate and an aldehyde while BphJ, the dehydrogenase, transforms the aldehyde to acyl-CoA using NAD+ and CoA as cofactors. This complex is able to channel aldehyde from the active site of the aldolase directly to the dehydrogenase without export to the bulk solvent. This process, known as substrate channeling, is beneficial to the cell as it sequesters the reactive, toxic and volatile aldehyde and overcomes the high Km of exogenous aldehyde ensuring conversion to a CoA ester. It has previously been shown that acetaldehyde, the enzyme's native substrate, can be channeled with 95% efficiency while aldehydes up to 6 carbons long can be channeled with greater than 80% efficiency. Residues in the aldolase which are important for channeling have previously been identified and a mechanism has been proposed. In addition, it has been shown that the aldolase is activated by the dehydrogenase when in the presence of dehydrogenase cofactors. Here, residues in the dehydrogenase suspected of being involved in channeling are being investigated. The crystal structure of a homologous enzyme complex implicate three hydrophobic residues located at the exit of the channel as gating residues, regulating aldehyde entry into the dehydrogenase active site. Isoleucine 195 was replaced with tryptophan and isoleucine 171 was replaced with phenylalanine in an attempt to block this gate. Asparagine 170, which was proposed to interact with NAD+ was replaced with alanine and aspartate. A 166° rotameric shift of this residue upon NAD+ binding was proposed to alter the position of I171, leading to the opening of the channel. The substitution of I195 and I171 with larger residues and N170 with alanine led to only a modest reduction in channeling efficiency. Surprisingly I171A and N170A variants were significantly compromised in their ability to activate the aldolase. The results presented here indicated that these residues do not have a role in aldehyde channel gating but rather influence the overall reaction through allosteric activation. This research is supported by Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada.

Designed peptides with nucleic acid bases for control of DNA G-quadruplex structures depending on protease activity Arisa Okada 1 It has been elucidated in the last few decades that DNA secondary structures modulate a variety of cellular events. Guanine-rich nucleic acid sequences can adopt non-canonical four-stranded secondary structures called G-quadruplex. It is assumed that G-quadruplex structures also regulate various important events in the cells such as transcription, translation and telomerase elongation [1] . G-quadruplex-targeting ligands can alter the stability of G-quadruplex structures by binding to G-rich sequences. Therefore, many ligands have been described so far including phthalocyanine derivatives [2], porphyrine derivatives and others [3] . However, the next-generation ligands should have more G-quadruplex sequence specificity, more efficient ability of altering the structural thermodynamic properties and a greater degree of functionality including on-off-switching.

In this study, we attempted to construct a system to regulate G-quadruplex structure forming with on-offswitching module depending on a particular cellular environment by using peptides with nucleic acid bases. First of all, a peptide conjugated with nucleic acid bases, Lmyc, was designed. It consisted of guanine peptide nucleic acid (PNA)-rich sequences for induction of DNA to form G-quadruplex structures and a switching module depending on activity of a particular protease as the cellular environment. Thus, this system would induce DNA to form G-quadruplex structures when the protease would not be expressed in cells, and once expressing the protease, the peptide would be digested and simultaneously loose the induction ability. After synthesis of the peptides by Fmoc chemistry, we checked the G-quadruplex structure induction by CD spectroscopy, etc. Then, we demonstrated the switch function depending on the protease activity by UVmelting or fluorescence spectroscopy. Throughout this study, we achieved a control system for forming DNA G-quadruplex structures depending on protease activity using designed small proteins. It is obvious that these peptides would be able to one of the promising tools for regulation of important cellular events toward cell engineering and tissue engineering. The first structure of a 4-hydroxy-4-methyl-2oxoglutarate (HMG)/4-carboxy-4-hydroxy-2oxoadipate (CHA) aldolase, a class II divalent metal ion dependent aldolase, from Pseudomonas putida F1 has recently been solved. The HMG/CHA aldolase shares structural homology, with minimal sequence homology (~25% identity), to a group of conserved bacterial proteins termed the regulators of ribonuclease E (RNase E) activity A (RraA). These proteins share a common αββα sandwich fold, but the RraA's are significantly shorter with their monomers truncated at the N and C-terminal ends by ~30 and 40 residues, respectively. The RraA from Escherichia coli has been observed to bind to RNase E, inhibiting the ribonucleases RNA degradation ability in vitro. A structure of a protein from Thermus thermophilus has been solved with a putative annotation as an RraA (TtRraA). However, T. thermophilus appears to lack a defined RNase E, making the proteins RraA annotation questionable. Thus, to elucidate the relationship between the HMG/CHA aldolases and the RraA proteins, we have undertaken an investigation into the TtRraA. We have shown that the TtRraA has aldolase activity, with activity and substrate specificity comparable to that of the HMG/CHA aldolase. The TtRraA differs from that of the HMG/CHA aldolase in that its divalent metal ion specificity favors Co2+ and Ni2+ opposed to Mg2+ and Mn2+ in the P. putida F1 enzyme. Oxalate acts as a competitive inhibitor for the HMG cleavage reaction in both the HMG/CHA aldolase and TtRraA enzymes. Crystals of the TtRraA cocrystallized with Co2+ and oxalate have been obtained and the structure has revealed that binding of oxalate in the TtRraA is analogous to pyruvate binding in the HMG/CHA aldolase structure and supports a common catalytic mechanism between the enzymes. Conserved residues between the enzymes provide insight into the catalytic mechanism of the aldolase reaction and highlight the evolutionary relationship between the divergent proteins.

Engineering a dimeric transmembrane protein nanoconduit Shiksha Mantri 1 Engineered protein nanopores, such as α-hemolysin (αHL), have found wide use in studying single molecule chemistry, small molecule detection, and DNA sequencing. Coupling other proteins with αHL covalently can extend the scope of the nanopore technology. The absence of native cysteines, robustness to mutagenesis and a flat cap surface make αHL an ideal substrate for protein engineering. We have engineered a new dimer complex, (α7)2, of the αHL heptamer (α7) linked via disulfide bridges in a cap-to-cap orientation. We validated the composition of (α7)2 by heating it up to 95°C, and by treatment with β-mercaptoethanol. The single channel electrical conductance and the currentvoltage (I-V) characteristics were consistent with a longer pore and a symmetric structure of (α7)2. As compared to molecular adapter γ-cyclodextrin (γ-CD) binding to the α7 β-barrel when added to the trans side of the lipid bilayer only, γ-CD could bind to (α7)2 from both cis and trans sides of bilayer, implying the presence of two β-barrels in (α7)2. The kinetic parameters obtained empirically for γ-CD binding and insertion in liposomes were in good agreement with those predicted by an electrical model, which also quantified the leak conductance through (α7)2. We have also shown that the two transmembrane β-barrels of (α7)2 can insert in two bilayers simultaneously, and small molecules can be transferred from a pico-litre liposome to the other side of a planar lipid bilayer. Vesicles have been modelled as minimal cells when used in conjunction with α7 pores by allowing small molecule exchange with the external buffer. (α7)2 could be used to connect vesicles to build multi-compartment cellular assemblies/ prototissues. Protein fractions (albumin, globulin, glutelin, and prolamin) were sequentially prepared from Brassica napus (canola grade), Sinapis alba, and two industrial canola meal samples, according to the classical Osborne method (OSB), based on their solubilities in water, 5% NaCl, 0.1 M NaOH and 70% ethanol. These extracts were then compared to the glutelin fraction obtained by direct alkaline extraction method (DIR) in terms of protein yield, recovery, and residual antinutritional components. The OSB method was found to be more effective for protein extraction which resulted in a higher cumulative protein yield and recovery of watersoluble protein fractions, although the DIR method produced a glutelin fraction of higher protein content or purity. Disregarding of extraction method used industrial toasted meal had significantly low protein extractability. Phenolic compounds were observed in all the extracted protein fractions although sinapine, the major phenolic compound in canola, was present only in the albumin fractions. Glucosinolate content of all extracts was below the detection limit (<3 μmol/g). The breakdown products of glucosinolates were minimal in extracts from canola grade meal (1.28 ± 0.16 µmol/g or less), in comparison to those prepared from Sinapis alba meal which, in general contained higher level of residual antinutritional components. Residue-specific incorporation of non-canonical amino acids (ncAAs) into cellular proteins allows discrimination of new proteins from old; labeled proteins can be selectively conjugated to purification tags, enriched by affinity chromatography, and identified by mass spectrometry. This method, termed bio-orthogonal non-canonical amino acid tagging (BONCAT), is an attractive approach for the selective identification of proteins produced by a cell in response to biological cues. In this work we combined the BONCAT approach with stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture (SILAC), to develop a proteomic technique capable not only of enriching but also of quantifying the subset of newly synthesized proteins produced during an ncAA pulse. Armed with this method, we conducted a proteomic search for direct regulatory targets of the E. coli small RNA CyaR, a Crp-activated regulatory RNA involved in cell metabolism and quorum sensing. Following expression of either CyaR or a negative RNA control, we pulse-labeled cultures with azidohomoalanine (Aha), a methionine surrogate, for 15 minutes. Aha-labeled proteins were conjugated to an alkynyl-biotin affinity tag by copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition, purified on streptavidin resin, and analyzed by LC/MS-MS. By comparing the relative abundances of proteins produced in the CyaR and control cultures, we identified three known CyaR protein targets and a set of 26 candidate proteins as significantly up or down-regulated. A regulatory RNA assay with target-GFP fusions verified a subset of the candidate proteins as directly regulated by CyaR. Support for this work was provided by the National Institutes of Health.

Development of photoactivated nitric oxide donors as anticancer drugs Sweta Kumari, Niroshini Giles, Emilie Billaud, Gregory Giles Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand Nitric oxide (NO) is one of the smallest known signaling molecules and plays a vital role in cancer, where it has been found that a high NO concentration (>1μM) causes cell death. Therefore, NO donor molecules have the potential to be effective anti-cancer agents. Currently available NO donor drugs are limited in therapeutic potential due to a lack of organ or tissue specificity and stability. These limitations have stimulated great interest in the development of compounds that can generate NO in a controlled and sustained manner. Therefore, we designed the photosensitive S-nitrosothiol drug molecule tert-dodecane S-nitrosothiol (TDSNO), with half life of greater than 3 hours depending on the photoactivation. As NO possesses tumoricidal activity, we hypothesised that upon selective photoactivation TDSNO would cause cytotoxicity with no adverse effects on non malignant cells in the absence of a photostimulus. We therefore evaluated the sustained generation of NO from TDSNO by modulating the dose of light (ranging from 0 -350 W/m2). NO release kinetics were determined by direct real time electrochemical measurement using a NO sensing electrode. Our data revealed a steady state concentration of NO upon photoactivation ranging from 0-15 µM, depending on the TDSNO concentration and the light dose i.e. a steady state concentration of 8 µM ± 2 NO could be obtained upon photoactivation (350 W/ m2) of 100 µM TDSNO for 30 minutes. Furthermore we also investigated the concentration dependent cytotoxicity of TDSNO on the A549 lung cancer cell line. Our data revealed a 50 % increase in cytotoxicity with 100 µM TDSNO following 1 hour photoactivation. In conclusion, our study suggests that photoactivated TDSNO has the potential to be a promising novel chemotherapeutic agent. Recent advances in bacterial cell division research have shown that the perturbation of the assembly dynamics of bacterial cytoskeleton protein, FtsZ induces bacterial cell death. FtsZ is one of the major machineries, which regulate the cell fate of the prokaryotes. During cytokinesis, FtsZ forms a scaffold for the organization of other cell-division associated proteins and a concerted mechanism of action ensures the survival of the cell. Therefore, FtsZ is now being considered to be a putative target for the development of antibacterial drugs. In the present work, the mechanism of action of a naturally occurring naphthoquinone, plumbagin on FtsZ assembly has been studied. Plumbagin inhibited the proliferation of Bacillus subtilis 168 and Mycobacterium smegmatis cells but had no effect on the Gram negative Escherichia coli cells. Further, plumbagin induced filamentation in B. subtilis 168 cells by perturbing the assembly of Z-ring without having any effect on the nucleoids indicating that it may target FtsZ assembly in bacteria. In vitro studies with purified BsFtsZ showed that plumbagin inhibited the assembly and GTPase activity of FtsZ in a concentration dependent manner. Binding studies demonstrated that plumbagin interacted directly with BsFtsZ and the dissociation constant of its interaction to mutated FtsZ (Y273W) was 20.7 ± 5.6 µM. Interestingly, plumbagin had no detectable effect on the assembly of EcFtsZ suggesting that FtsZ from different bacteria may have different ligand binding abilities. Further using docking studies, we identified the putative binding site of plumbagin on BsFtsZ and three mutants R191A, D199A and V307R were designed to explore the interaction of plumbagin and BsFtsZ. In vitro studies of the mutants with plumbagin revealed that while V307R and D199A showed resistance towards its inhibitory effect, R191A was found to be sensitive indicating that D199 and V307 may be involved in the binding of plumbagin and BsFtsZ. The study provides an insight on the plumbagin binding site on BsFtsZ, which may help to design FtsZ-targeted antibacterial agents. Cancer cells undergo tumor hypoxia in the earlier stages of growth. Hypoxic tumors generally have poor prognosis and can become resistant to radiation and chemotherapy treatments. Hypoxic tumors exhibit a high concentration of adenosine and adenosine A2A receptors. The goal of this project is to design small molecules to target the human A2A adenosine receptor and conjugate a nanoparticle, fluorescent tracer or fluorine radioisotope for imaging hypoxic tumors through x-ray, CT scanning and positron emission tomography. Utilizing molecular modeling tools on the recently solved crystal structures (PDB 3EML and 3QAK) of the human A2A adenosine receptor, information about agonist and antagonist binding can be studied to identify the residues involved in ligand binding. Other computational tools such as THEMATICS and POOL, developed by our group at Northeastern University, are two highly effective predictors of binding sites in protein structures. These tools have provided useful information to help guide specific ligand design for binding sites important catalytic and binding residues. In silico docking studies yield important information about interaction between the ligands and the receptor. Molecular dynamics gives information about the conformational changes that give flexibility to the active site. The starting core ligand structure is based on the natural affinity of caffeine for adenosine A2A receptors. Certain modifications for the addition of functional groups to the structure emerge from the modeling studies and improve binding affinity to the target. The in silico docking identifies the top candidate molecules to be targeted for synthesis. The computational studies also help to identify potential conjugation sites on the ligand molecule where imaging agents may be attached that do not interfere with the binding affinity to the target. In order to validate the docking method, functional binding assays (in vitro and in vivo) were performed on a selected set of small molecules to identify the best binding ligands. The compound that gave the best results will be conjugated to a fluorescent tracer or fluorine radioisotope for further investigation in imaging studies. This work is supported in part by the NSF MCB division and by an NSF-GRFP. Since the discovery of antibiotics in the 1920's there has been an increase in bacterial resistance to antimicrobials, which has resulted in a struggle to develop antimicrobials at a faster rate than bacterial resistance. Our goal is to design and optimize a system for screening potential inhibitors for two E. coli enzyme systems: Tryptophan Synthase (TrpS) and Indole-3-Glycerol Phosphate Synthase (IGPs). These enzymes are part of the TIM-barrel family of proteins that share an eight-stranded (beta/alpha) motif that is found in 10% of all proteins. TrpS and IGPs are located within the tryptophan biosynthetic pathway, which is found in plants and bacteria (but not humans) for producing the aromatic amino acid tryptophan. Gene knockout studies in the laboratory have shown that bacteria require tryptophan for survival in minimal growth media. Inhibitors designed against these enzymes should have relatively minute side effects since humans do not possess enzymes from this pathway. IGPs is found near the end of the tryptophan biosynthetic pathway and functions to convert (1-(2-carboxyphenylamino)-1deoxy-D-ribulose 5-phosphate) into indole-3-glycerol phosphate. TrpS is a bifunctional enzyme that converts indole-3-glycerol phosphate to tryptophan. The α subunit of TrpS converts indole-3-glycerol phosphate (created from IGPs) into indole, while the β subunit combines the indole ring with serine to form tryptophan. We have expressed and purified both TrpS and IGPs using a pET expression system and have designed two 96 well plate in vitro assays to assess activity for both systems and screen effects of inhibitors. We have also incorporated computational modeling software for quick screening of the binding capability of potential inhibitor compounds.

We have screened small compound fragments using both in vitro and in silico studies from a first generation library that were generated based on the substrates of IGPs and TrpSα, which resulted in establishing inhibitor candidates for both systems. Future studies will consist of constructing a second generation library that compiles information from the first library to combine these small fragments and screen for inhibitory characteristics and the potential emergence of successful lead compounds.
