body_text.text: Development and validation of a target-based, highthroughput assay for drug screening in pyruvate carboxylase Elise Pellmann, Martin St. Maurice Biological Sciences, Marquette University, 816 N. 14th St. #23, Milwaukee, WI, 53233 This project is a discovery-based initiative aimed at developing a tool for identifying chemical compounds that alter the activity of pyruvate carboxylase (PC, E.C. 6.4.1.1). PC is a biotin-dependent, anaplerotic enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate (OAA). Modulation of PC activity may have clinical applications: a drug used to inhibit or activate PC may be useful in the treatment of cancer, type II diabetes, or other metabolic disorders. In addition, there are no known potent and specific PC activators or inhibitors; either, if discovered, would be a valuable research tool. We have designed a fixed-time, colorimetric assay based on the chemical reaction between oxaloacetate and the diazonium salt Fast Violet B (FVB). FVB couples with OAA to produce a complex that is a chromophore at 530 nm. The formation of this complex, as measured by absorbance at this wavelength, is linear with respect to OAA concentration. This assay is a quantifiable measure of OAA formed in the PC reaction, and thus it may be used to screen PC activity in the presence of potential activators or inhibitors. The assay format comprises four steps before measurement: 1) a 10-minute, forward PC reaction, 2) enzyme inactivation at low pH, 3) addition of FVB, and 4) stabilization of the FVB-OAA complex at cold temperature. The assay has been developed and validated as a high-throughput screen utilizing a 96-well plate format.

Ligands-induced catalytically relevant structural transitions of ADP-dependent glucokinase in the crystalline state and in solution Victoria Guixé 1 , Jaime Andrés Rivas-Pardo 1 , Alejandra Herrera-Morandé 2 , Francisco Fernández 2 , María-Cristina Vega 2 1 Departamento de Biología, Universidad de Chile, Facultad de Ciencias, Santiago, Casilla 653, Chile, 2 Centro de Investigaciones Biológicas, CSIC, Madrid, Spain ADP-dependent glucokinases represents a new family of kinases that belongs to the ribokinase superfamily. Some crystallographic structures of these enzymes are available in different conditions of ligands; nonetheless, there are no agreement about the magnitude of the ligands-induced structural transitions and if they are meaningful to the enzyme function. We used the ADPdependent GK form T. litoralis (TlGK) as a model to evaluate the structural transitions observed in crystal structures with that determined in solution in order to understand their interplay with the GK function. To achieve this goal we employed an integrated approach including enzyme kinetics, small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) and crystal structure determination. The enzyme presents a sequential ordered mechanism where MgADP is the first substrate to bind to the enzyme and MgAMP the last product to be release. This binding of ligands is correlated with the structural transitions experienced by the enzyme in solution, as observed by SAXS. In the absence of ligands (apoenzyme) the radius of gyration is 29.0 Å, which is not modified in the presence of glucose, as expected from the kinetic mechanism. In contrast, in the presence of MgADP, the radius of gyration diminishes to 25.9 Å and formation of the ternary complex (E-MgADP-βS-D-glc) implies an additional decrease to 24.0 Å. Ab initio models constructed from SAXS data, shows how the small domain change its position and finally occluded the active site in the ternary complex. Determination of the crystallographic structures of the TlGK enzyme in its Apo form and in the presence of MgADP-βS-D-glc (ternary complex), supports the domain arrangement induced by binding of substrates described for the enzyme in solution. The results show a sequential binding of substrates to TlGK. Binding of the first substrate, MgADP, provokes the major structural transition, in contrast with the suggestion of other authors. We demonstrated that structural transitions observed in solution, as well as in the crystalline state, are catalytically relevant for TlGK catalysis. ( Phosphofructokinase-2 (Pfk-2) from E. coli is a homodimer that catalyzes the MgATP dependent phosphorylation of fructose-6-P to fructose-1,6-bisP. Allosteric binding of MgATP to Pfk-2 results in the inhibition of the enzymatic activity, which is enhanced by the specific binding of monovalent cations such as K+. Moreover, Pfk-2 is able to form a tetramer in presence of MgATP, but this process seems not to be required for allosteric inhibition. Pfk-2 has a K+ binding site located on a loop that contacts both dimers in its tetrameric conformation, which is close to the allosteric MgATP binding site present in each subunit. In this work we explore the relationships between K+ binding and the dimer-tetramer transition induced by the metalnucleotide complex by means of kinetic assays, MgATP binding experiments measured by intrinsic fluorescence and limited proteolysis by trypsin treatments. To isolate the dimer-tetramer equilibrium from the inhibitory effect, a single-point mutant unable to reach the tetrameric state was used. The presence of K+ enhances the MgATP inhibition and was found to be independent of the dimer-tetramer equilibrium; the wild type and the single mutant show similar regulatory parameters. Interestingly, the apparent affinity for MgATP and sigmoidicity of the saturation curve for wild-type Pfk-2, observed by intrinsic fluorescence, was increased by the presence of K+, while the mutant did not show significant variations of the isothermal MgATP binding upon increasing the K+ concentration. Furthermore, limited proteolysis digestion of the wild type enzyme and the mutant unable to form tetramers, show that the MgATPdimer complex is partially protected from trypsin cleavage, protection which is enhanced upon tetramer formation. These results suggest that the binding of K+ favors the dimer-tetramer transition induced by MgATP and enhances the allosteric inhibition produced by the nucleotide in the dimeric enzyme. Acknowledgements: Supported by Fondecyt 1090336, Conicyt, Chile Lymphoid tyrosine phosphatase (Lyp) is a 105-kDa Class I protein tyrosine phosphatase (PTP) encoded by the PTPN22 gene and is expressed exclusively in immune cells. Lyp is known to potently inhibit T cell receptor signaling by dephosphorylating several substrates, including the Src family kinases Lck and Fyn, ZAP70, and TCRzeta. Lyp has recently emerged as a key player in a range of human autoimmune diseases including type I diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, Graves' and Addison's disease. The basis for Lyp's involvement in autoimmune disease is a single nucleotide polymorphism in PTPN22 that results in an amino acid change from Arg620 to Trp620 in the non-catalytic C-terminal domain of Lyp. The result is an increase in phosphatase activity although the molecular basis is not well understood. To reverse the pathogenic effect of this Lyp-W620 variant, small molecule inhibitors are desired for therapeutic treatment of autoimmune disorders. The objective of the work presented here is to develop small molecule electrophiles that can function as Michael acceptors to reversibly inactivate Lyp activity in vitro and in vivo. Kinetic results show that these compounds inhibit Lyp in a time-and concentration-dependent manner under pseudo-first order conditions, and that Lyp activity does not return after extensive buffer exchange. Furthermore, the compounds appear to bind in the active site, as inhibition is reduced by co-incubation of the enzyme with a known competitive inhibitor of PTPs. Mass spectrometry data show the presence of adduct formation and digest experiments to elucidate the modification site are underway. Further characterization to gain more information on selectivity among other members of the PTP family is also in progress.

We describe a novel non-phosphate small molecule partial agonist of the protein kinase A (PKA) RIα heterodimer complex. The agonist promotes the dissociation of the regulatory subunit from the kinase, allowing catalytic activity, likely by binding at the cAMP site. To find the agonist, a series of 1364 small molecules from the NCI Diversity Set II were screened computationally using a relaxed complex docking computation. Briefly, a molecular dynamics trajectory was collected on both the PKA RIα heterodimer and two crystal structures of the dissociated, cAMP or cGMPbound regulatory subunit. The trajectories were RMSD clustered separately on both cAMP binding subdomains, for a total of five sets of protein conformers. A total of 79 representative confirmations were selected for the docking computation. Docking calculations were performed with Autodock Vina and 25 compounds with good docking scores at all the cAMP binding sites were selected for testing. The compounds were screened in vitro for their ability to promote dissociation of the PKA holoenzyme in a high throughput LiReC assay and a partial agonist with an EC50 of 10 μM was identified. Unlike other agonists that promote dissociation of the holoenzyme complex, the compound is not a cAMP analog. It can potentially offer unique insight into the allosteric mechanism of the PKA regulatory subunit dissociation. Supported by: NIH grants GM34921 Firefly luciferase is widely used as an optical reporter both in vitro and in vivo. Despite the power of bioluminescence for imaging and high-throughput drug discovery, light emission from luciferase is fundamentally limited by the properties of the luciferin substrate. Compared to fluorescence, bioluminescence offers the advantages of low background and phototoxicity, but suffers from a restricted palette of reporters and limited opportunities for multiplexing of signals. Based on a hypothesis that links the luciferin structure to the emission wavelength, a series of synthetic luciferin substrates were created which exhibit light emission at longer wavelengths than D-luciferin, with peak emission ranging from 598 nm up to 646 nm, beyond that of any known luciferase. Mutation of the luciferin binding pocket of firefly luciferase was found to allow efficient and selective light emission with synthetic luciferins, both in vitro and in live mammalian cells. Highly discriminating mutant luciferases were also identified that have 2-3 orders of magnitude greater light output with a subset of synthetic luciferins compared to the native D-luciferin. Together, these synthetic luciferin substrates and mutant luciferases reveal that the scope and application for luminogenic probes is much broader than previously realized, and can serve as the basis for the generation of orthogonal luciferase-luciferin pairs with different emission wavelengths for multiplexed bioluminescence assays and imaging. This work was supported by the NIH (EB013270). ( (Angkawidjaja et al., 2010) . Ca1 represents the catalytically essential single Ca2+ ion (Amada et al., 2000) . Ca1 is hexacoordinated with the side chain carboxyl oxygen atoms of Asp157 (bidentate) and Asp153, the side chain amide oxygen of Gln120, and the main chain carbonyl oxygen atoms of Thr118 and Ser144. Ca1 stabilizes the open conformation by neutralizing the surrounding closely-located negative charges of lid1. Previous study had shown that by mutating Asp157 to Ala, Ca1 site was lost and the mutant did not exhibit lipase activity (Kuwahara et al.,2008) . In this study, in search of PML mutants that can exhibit activity in the absence of Ca2+ ions, we mutated Asp157 and Asp153 to Arg and Lys. Among four mutant proteins, D153R-PML is the only one that showed lipase activity upon screening with tributyrin plate and activity assays using triglycerols and fatty acid monoesters in various chain lengths. D153R also shows a partial interfacial activity, in which the enzymatic activity increased as substrate concentration increased beyond the critical micellar concentration (CMC), in a different manner compared to that of wild-type PML. By providing a positive charge to interact with the negative charges in the Ca1 binding site, D153R-PML may be able to promote the full opening of lid1 without the presence of calcium. In overall, we successfully engineered a calcium-independent active lipase by changing the negatively charged Asp153 to Arg. This work was supported in part by a Grant (21380065) Two component signal transduction systems, comprised of a histidine kinase (HK) and a response regulator (RR), are a prevalent bacterial mechanism for sensing and responding to the environment. Many histidine kinases are bi-functional, as they can both phosphorylate and dephosphorylate their cognate RR substrate. In both reactions the proteins specifically recognize each other via a subset of amino acids located in alpha helices. To understand how these residues determine the specificity of kinase-substrate interactions, we rationally engineered the interaction interface of a Thermotoga maritima two-component system, HK853-RR468, to match that found in a different two-component system, PhoR-PhoB. We replaced five residues in HK853 and four residues in RR468; the resulting mutant proteins carry out the phosphorylation and dephosphorylation reactions at rates comparable to the wild type proteins. However, when either mutant protein is paired with a wild type partner, both reactions are compromised. To better understand the role of the interfacial residues in the kinase-substrate interaction, we solved a crystal structure of the mutant HK in complex with the mutant RR. There are few structural changes outside the HK-RR interface, suggesting that two-component signaling specificity is locally determined. We also performed a systematic analysis of all mutational intermediates between the wild type and fully rewired protein complexes. These data suggest that a functional HK-RR interaction relies on proper and tight packing at the alpha helical protein-protein interface. The mutagenesis data explain how mutations in the rewired complex compensate for one another to enable a different, but equally productive, interface. We anticipate that our approach and conclusions regarding signaling protein interfaces in bacteria will prove useful in other studies of protein-protein interactions, protein evolution, and in the design of novel protein interfaces. The catalytic triads and oxyanion holes of naturally occurring esterases and proteases are critical to catalysis, but it is difficult to parse out their contributions independently and to understand the evolution of these highly optimized active sites. Here we explore the minimal requirements for esterase activity by building up artificial catalysts using catalytic dyads and oxyanion holes. We found much higher success rates using designed oxyanion holes formed by backbone NH groups rather than by sidechains or bridging water molecules and obtained four active designs in different scaffolds by combining this motif with a Cys-His dyad. Following active site optimization, the most active of the variants exhibited a catalytic efficiency (kcat/Km) of 400 M-1s-1 for the cleavage of a p-nitrophenyl ester. Kinetic experiments indicate that the active site cysteines are rapidly acylated as programmed by design, but the subsequent slow hydrolysis of the acyl-enzyme intermediate limits overall catalytic efficiency, and the Cys-His dyads are not properly formed in crystal structures of the designed enzymes. These results highlight the challenges that computational design must overcome to achieve high levels of activity. A critical step in the generation of binding molecules is their selection from a naive library. When many binders need to be generated (e.g. for proteomic applications), the time required for each selection and validation accumulates, making this step into a daunting task. Each new binding molecule usually binds its target in a different way and, due to the different structure of the targets and the different binding modes, each selection has to be done independently and cannot take advantage of the information from the binders previously obtained. While a constant binding mode towards different protein surfaces is unlikely to be achieved, peptides and unstructured regions of proteins constitute better candidates as target for general recognition. It is therefore our aim to generate a geometrically optimized scaffold based on Armadillo Repeat Proteins (ArmRP), which can bind peptides in extended conformation. In this way, a modular binding mode where every repeat unit of the ArmRP is binding specifically two amino acids of the peptide would solve this bottleneck of selection processes against peptides. Two approaches were applied to construct designed ArmRP, including a sequence based consensus design and a structural based computational design. For the second approach, a combination of geometrical parameterization of natural armadillo repeat proteins and the structure calculation software ROSETTA were used. In both cases, libraries with well folded proteins could be produced and build the start point for selection against a variety of targets by ribosome display. To explore the detailed architecture of the scaffold, several crystal structures could be solved for unselected consensus design ArmRP. The structures confirmed the right handed helix fold -similar to natural ArmRP -providing a uniform scaffold with a binding surface for peptides. Dehydrogenases are potential catalysts for the production of many different compounds including chiral compounds and pharmaceutical precursors [1, 2] . Catalytic use of dehydrogenases has been limited due to the need to supply NAD(H) to the reaction in stoichiometric amounts or regenerate it [1, 2] . Electrochemical regeneration promises to be a lowcost method for regenerating NAD+. An efficient, lowcost catalytic system would require the enzyme and cofactor to be immobilized for reuse in an orientation that maintains activity. Our long term goal is to produce dihydroxyacetone (DHA) from glycerol using Thermotoga maritima glycerol dehydrogenase [3] (TmGlyDH) in an electrochemical reactor. Methods of immobilizing NAD+ were explored and kinetic parameters of TmGlyDH were determined. The N6 amino group of NAD+ was modified to introduce a terminal carboxyl group and facilitate bonding to an amino-terminal linker molecule at the electrode surface. To determine appropriate reactor operating conditions and enzyme immobilization conditions, TmGlyDH's apparent kinetic parameters were determined for glycerol, DHA, and NAD(H) at different pH values at 50°C. The Michaelis-Menten equation was not a good fit to the kinetics data on glycerol and DHA because of apparent negative allostericity, thus kinetic data for these substrates were fit to the Hill equation. The optimum pH for glycerol oxidation was 8.5 with apparent Vmax, K0.5 for glycerol, and n (cooperativity constant) of 6.0 ± 0.3 μmol min-1 mg-1, 87 ± 14 mM, and 0.63 ± 0.04, respectively. Specific activity with 200 μM N6carboxymethyl-NAD+ (N6-CM-NAD+) was 0.028 ± 0.007 μmol min-1 mg-1 or about 1% of the activity with NAD+. Mutations K157N, V44A, and I154A were generated to increase TmGlyDH's activity with N6-CM-NAD+. Mutations K157N and V44A increased TmGlyDH activity with N6-CM-NAD+ 4-and 2-fold, respectively. Combinations of mutations are under study. TmGlyDH has been characterized for use as a catalyst for DHA production, N6-CM-NAD+ has been synthesized for easy cofactor immobilization, and TmGlyDH has been engineered for increased activity with N6-CM-NAD+. This project was supported by NSF grant CBET 0756703. 1. Adv. Biochem. Engin./Biotechnol., 2005 . 92:225-260. 2. Adv. Biochem. Engin./Biotechnol., 2010 . 120:195-242. 3. Leave-one-out GFP: Folding, Stability and Design Derek Pitman 1 , Yao-ming Huang 1, 2 , David Rosenman 1 , Donna Crone 1 , Chris Bystroff 1 1 Biology, RPI, 110 8th St, Troy, NY, 12180, 2 Department of Bioengineering and Therapeutic Sciences, UCSF, San Francsicso, CA Circularly permuted and truncated "leave-one-out" green fluorescent proteins (LOO-GFPs) do not glow, but reconstitute fluorescence when they bind the missing segment. LOO-GFPs are partially unfolded in the unbound state, leading to oligomerization and aggregation. Several avenues have been explored for improving the stability and solubility of these LOO-GFPs so that they may serve as templates for computationally designed peptide biosensors. A loop containing a cis peptide bond, whose isomerization is known to be the slow step in GFP's three-phase folding kinetics, was remodeled into a slightly longer loop with all trans peptide bonds ("all-trans" GFP). The crystal structure of all-trans was solved to 2.6Å resolution and matches well with the designed structure. Stopped-flow refolding showed the wild-type fast and medium phases, but the slow phase (t1/2 ~200 s) has been completely eliminated in all-trans GFP. In further design experiments, disulfide bonds were introduced into two of the loop regions surrounding beta strands 7 and 8, believed to be the site of the first unfolding events according to GeoFold (Ramakrishnan et al, Proteins, 2012) , locking down these structures and potentially decreasing the unfolding rate. Surprisingly, refolding kinetics data shows that these designs, called "C-link" GFP, have the same three kinetic phases as the wild-type if only one loop is linked, but have a significantly lower fraction of the fast folding phase when both disulfide bonds are present. Unfolding rates are being determined. Other modifications, such as "supercharging" and daisy-chaining, have also been applied to LOO-GFP to increase solubility and affinity. The end result is a fasterfolding, more stable and more soluble LOO-GFP which is more readily utilized in biosensor design applications.

The role of stereoelectronics in kinases Jean Summerton 1 Catalysis of reactions involving high energy phosphate bonds is central to cellular energy metabolism, motility and the generation of transmembrane potentials. While much has been written about high energy bonds, such as those in ATP and phosphocreatine, traditional analyses of the chemistry have not fully explained their reactivity. Anomeric bond destabilization is a stereoelectronic effect involving transfer of electron density from electron lone pairs into an anti-bonding orbital in a correctly-oriented distal bond. Our group recently showed that anomeric bond destabilization is strongly correlated with bond length and experimental energies of hydrolysis in a wide array of "high energy" phospho-metabolites, including ATP and phosphocreatine. Current research follows two avenues in parallel. One examines by statistical cluster analysis whether nucleotide-containing PDB entries tend to have enzyme-substrate atomic interactions with geometries that might favor anomeric bond destabilization for scissile bonds. The second avenue uses density functional theory and Natural Bond Orbital analysis to explore stereoelectronically-mediated effects of solvent and active site residues on model compound methyl triphosphate. This report will analyze preliminary evidence of the potential role of active site coordination in stereoelectronically modulating the stability of individual phosphoanhydride bonds important in the reactions of energy metabolism and signaling. This work was supported in part by NIH R01GM77643 (MSC) and by pre-doctoral fellowships from the American Heart Association (Pacific Mountain Affiliate, predoctoral fellowship 09PRE2020112 ) and Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc. (JCS).

Directed Evolution of Beta-galactosidase from Geobacillus stearothermophilus Christiann Hill, Nicholas Panasik Biology, Claflin University, Claflin University 400 Magnolia Street, Orangeburg, SC, 29115 Lactose intolerance is defined as the inability of the body to digest lactose, a sugar found in milk and milk products. This occurs due to reduced levels of β-galactosidase, leading to a variety of abdominal symptoms. The regular treatment of adding the enzyme directly to the milk is not very effective as the enzyme has an optimum temperature of 37degC, and loses its activity when stored in the refrigerator, at 4degC. The lactose therefore still remains undigested. The aim is to engineer β-galactosidase with a wider temperature profile; such that its activity would not be halted when stored in the refrigerator. β-galactosidase derived from the theromophilic bacterium, Geobacillus Stearothermophilus has an α/β barrel structure. 10% of all proteins have α/β barrel structures. Error prone PCR is used to introduce random errors to the β-galactosidase gene. The expression of the gene was observed at specific lower temperatures with a chromogenic substrate used as a screen. Manganese was used to control the mutation rate. Changes in the manganese sulfate were used to generate 2.7 and 3.5 mutations per 1000 base pairs. After mutagenesis was completed the PCR product was ligated into a pUC derived vector that had its alpha fragment removed. This was followed by transformation into E.coli JM109 competent cells. The cells were then plated at a selection temperature of 37degC using Luria Bertani (LB), ampicillin, IPTG (Isopropyl β-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside) and X-gal (5-bromo-4-chloro-indolyl-galactopyranoside).

Two rounds of directed evolution were done. The first round, using a mutation rate of 3.5 mutations per 1000 base pairs produced over 64,000 colonies; but none demonstrated activity at 37degC. The second round of directed evolution however, at 2.7 mutations per 1000 base pairs, produced over 9000 colonies, with 2 mutants demonstrating activity at 37degC and 30degC. The mutants were sequenced and results showed that mutant 2, bgal-CH-2, had three different nucleotide changes and three different amino acid changes. The nucleotide changes were T434A, T1197A and G2014A. The corresponding amino acid changes were a valine to an aspartic acid, an aspartic acid to a glutamic acid and a valine to an isoleucine. Currently steps are being taken to ligate each of the mutated β-galactosidase genes into the expression vector pET28a, as well as determine which amino acid change from mutant 2 was responsible for the cold activity.
Kenneth Woycechowsky, Hsiao-Nung Chen Department of Chemistry, University of Utah, 315 South 1440 East, Room 2020, Salt Lake City, UT, 84112
body_text.section: A Designed Protein Capsid Assembly Switch for in vitro Enzyme Encapsulation

body_text.text: Icosahedral protein capsids are often used in Nature for the storage, transport, or regulation of encapsulated cargo molecules. These structures are attractive for various applications in bionanotechnology, such as drug delivery and catalysis. Towards these ends, the usefulness of protein capsids will depend upon an understanding of their supramolecular chemistry.
body_text.section: A Designed Protein Capsid Assembly Switch for in vitro Enzyme Encapsulation

body_text.text: Lumazine synthase from Aquifex aeolicus (AaLS) self-assembles into a 60-subunit dodecahedral capsid and provides an appealing scaffold for engineering novel encapsulation systems. However, an inability to control AaLS capsid assembly has presented a major obstacle for cargo loading in vitro. Here, we present a redox switch for the assembly of a pentameric AaLS variant into 60-subunit capsids that resemble those of the wild-type protein, as assessed by size-exclusion chromatography and electron microscopy. The capsid assembly process involves the formation of a covalent adduct between a unique cysteine in the variant (C37A/ R40S/H41S/I125C-AaLS) and thiophenol. This modification adds non-polar surface area at position 125, presumably recapitulating a key feature of the isoleucine present at this position in the wild-type protein, and triggers the non-covalent assembly of the pentamers into capsids. Further, we have used this assembly switch to encapsulate the enzyme horseradish peroxidase, which remains active inside the capsid. The thiophenol switch thus enables the encapsulation of enzymes and other molecules in vitro, which should prove useful in the construction of novel drug delivery and catalytic systems. Cells convert a diversity of extracellular signals (like hormones) into physiological responses by activating G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) to trigger mainly G protein-and/or β-arrestin-mediated signaling pathways. This pleiotropic activity of GPCRs is enabled by their multiple distinct conformations each of which may be attributable to a specific functional state of the receptor. Many GPCRs exhibit measurable levels of basal activity in the absence of any extracellular stimuli. As a first step to understand GPCR activation, this study focuses on the conformational changes that underlie the basal activity of the CB1 cannabinoid GPCR by designing mutants that activate an inactive receptor or inactivate an active receptor. The modulation of this "basal conformationalfunctional landscape" by extracellular stimuli can then provide a more complete picture of GPCR activation. The GTPγS assay data have shown that mutation of the threonine residue to alanine at position 210 of the constitutively active CB1 receptor makes the wild-type (WT) receptor inactive, whereas the T210I or the L207A mutant displays high constitutive activity. We used a de novo GPCR structure prediction methodology to predict the structures of the WT receptor and its three mutants (T210A, T210I and L207A). The resulting structures, that are consistent with known conformational changes during GPCR activation, showed that a novel ionic lock (salt bridge interaction) between transmembrane (TM) helices 2 and 6 keeps the T210A mutant inactive. This observation was then used to design two active double-mutant receptors lacking the TM2+TM6 ionic lock, based on the inactive T210A mutant. The GTPγS assay data showed that these double mutants gained constitutive activity. The active L207A mutant that lacked the TM2+TM6 ionic lock was then used to design an inactive double-mutant receptor that had that ionic lock. The inactivity of this double mutant was also confirmed by the GTPγS assays. Designing active mutant forms from the inactive receptor and vice versa has provided a much clearer understanding of the critical conformational changes that occur upon the basal activation of the CB1 receptor. This has important relevance for the activation of other GPCRs and also sets the stage to understand how various ligands (from inverse agonists to agonists) can modulate this conformational landscape to disrupt or enhance receptor activation. Understanding and engineering protein oligomerisation is a long-standing problem that has been approached from various perspectives. Common to them all is their primary focus on the biophysics and evolution of protein interfaces. However, in a protein with multiple interfaces, the evolutionary constraint that conserves its interactions cannot be a simple sum of constraints on the individual interfaces -a constraint on their relative geometric positions is also expected. We describe a set of structural parameters that define the differences in protein geometry and in turn the difference of relative positions of interfaces. We find that mutations affecting inter-subunit geometry via indirect mechanisms are as important for the evolution of protein oligomeric states as interface sequence changes. This work investigates how the evolutionary dynamics of complex geometry depends on the particular structural and functional features of a protein family. Sometimes the change in geometry is brought about by changes in one of the interfaces, when sequence changes in the interface do not significantly change the interface stability but rather the orientation of subunits. In other cases, the changes in geometry are caused by changes outside both interfaces, meaning that the two interfaces superimpose well but their relative positions change. In both cases, the mutations act allosterically, in the sense that they induce a conformational change that in turn affects the formation of a distal interface. We use a bacterial transcription regulation protein family, PyrR, to probe these allosteric mutations experimentally. In this family, the difference in oligomeric state is accompanied by a prominent difference in inter-subunit geometry, but without change in the tetrameric interface itself. We reconstruct the ancestral sequence, and then use biophysical techniques and crystallography to predict a correct order of mutations that caused change in the intersubunit geometry, followed by change in the oligomeric state. Our results suggest that there is a diversity of mechanisms through which allosteric mutations can impact oligomerisation via conformational changes. This diversity should be taken into account in efforts to improve the engineering of protein interactions and in further studies of evolutionary pathways that generate them.
body_text.section: A Designed Protein Capsid Assembly Switch for in vitro Enzyme Encapsulation

body_text.text: Detecting and measuring the influence of functional coupling on protein fitness Loretta Au 1, 2 Proteins in the same family share many structural and functional motifs, but differences in primary structure exist between them; this influences how closely-related proteins differ in fitness, such as in their ability to fold into a stable structure or their affinity to bind with a target partner. Distinct positions interact to varying degrees in maintaining protein structural and functional integrity; an understanding of how individual positions in a protein may be coupled can thus provide insight on the biophysical reasons that some mutational effects are minimal, while others may drastically alter protein stability or function. We present a protocol for identifying and interpreting these multifaceted relationships, by defining the extent that side-chain substitutions are able to improve or diminish different aspects of fitness (demonstrated here on structural stability and binding affinity.) Our methodology explores all low-energy sequences and their corresponding structures, by adapting well-established computational protein design algorithms to systematically mutate a protein; we focus on heterotrimeric G-proteins, a family that is involved in many cellular pathways, and has an abundance of structural and biochemical information available for it that can be used in the interpretation of our computational results. Using the energetic and structural data from our approach, we are able to quantify the relevance of interactions made by every position in the protein and how cooperative effects can arise between them, under different fitness contexts.

TEM-1 and PSE-4 are well characterized structurally similar class A β-lactamases, which provide bacteria with resistance to penicillin-type antibiotics. Sharing 40% sequence identity, these β-lactamases were used to create a series of TEM-1/PSE-4 chimeras using structurebased recombination [1] . This project aims to understand the effect of this recombination on the properties of the resulting artificially-evolved enzymes. Specifically, we investigated whether the kinetic, structural and dynamic properties of TEM-1 and PSE-4 are conserved in different functional chimeras sharing between 64% to 94% sequence identity to TEM-1. Chimeras cTEM-17m and cTEM-19m (respectively having 94% and 92% sequence identity to TEM-1) differ by only two substitutions (Met68 and Met69) neighbouring the catalytic nucleophile Ser70. The turnover rate of cTEM-17m is native-like, indicating that its 17 mutations are functionally tolerated. However, the additional 2 mutations of cTEM-19m decreased the turnover rate by more than 20-fold relative to cTEM-17m. In order to isolate the energetic contribution these two substitutions, as well as to probe for synergistic or additive effects, we generated and kinetically characterized deconvolution mutants in both the chimeric and wild-type TEM-1 contexts. Double mutant cycle analysis revealed that the immediate neighbour of the catalytic Ser70, Met69, was the main contributor to decreased turnover rate. High resolution crystal structures of the chimera cTEM-19m and a deconvoluted mutant were obtained to verify the structural impact of the Met69 substitution. The overall structure of the chimeras and the deconvoluted mutant were similar to the parents. However, two structures of the chimera obtained in similar crystallisation conditions showed different active site conformations, suggesting increased molecular dynamics. NMR relaxation experiments on a fast (ps-ns) and slow (µsms) time scales confirmed broadly distributed new molecular dynamics in the chimera cTEM-17m that were not observed in either the wild-type TEM-1 or PSE-4 β-lactamases. The characterization of these artificially-evolved chimeras demonstrated dynamic states tolerated by β-lactamases, maintaining their functionality and potentially facilitating their evolution with regard to hydrolysis of new β-lactam compounds. In general, proteins are composed of the 20 natural amino acids. However, the maximum number of these amino acids required for the creation of a functional protein remains unresolved. Thus, we tried to design an experiment to examine the function of primitive proteins composed of a limited set of amino acids using an in vitro selection approach. In a previous report, the characterization of random-sequence proteins containing five types of amino acids was studied (1) . However, there is no example describing the function of a primitive protein containing only four types of amino acids. Interestingly, it has been postulated by two different approaches that the most primitive protein could consist of four types of amino acids (i.e., glycine (G), alanine (A), aspartic acid (D) and valine (V)): 1) Eigen et al. (RNA world hypothesis) (2) ; and 2) Ikehara et al. (protein sequences analysis) (3) . So what function would a primitive protein have in an early translation system? The function of the first primitive protein would most likely be associated with the enhancement of RNA replication and the translation reaction. Furthermore, in the early stages of protein synthesis, the genotype-phenotype linking strategy, which is essential for molecular evolution, could become a virus-type, because the virus-type strategy is the most efficient for molecular evolution of a single function (4) . If the strategy of the virus-type is adopted, the interaction between RNA and protein is indispensable. Thus, we investigated the possibility of whether peptides consisting of these four amino acids could function to interact with RNA by in vitro protein selection (cDNA display technology) of a random four amino acid peptide library against tRNA. Then, some peptides were selected to interact with tRNA with low affinity (Kd ≈ 200∼300 μM). This shows that a primitive protein consist of four types of amino acids could evolve by the virus-type strategy in the early stage of emerging translation system. Steroid receptors (SRs) are ligand-regulated transcription factors that play critical roles in inflammation, development, and cancer progression. The SR family includes the estrogen, androgen, mineralocorticoid, glucocorticoid, and progesterone receptors, which are finely tuned to activation by their cognate endogenous hormones with high specificity. The SR family arose from a single evolutionary precursor that was activated by the aromatized 3-hydroxysteroid (3-HS) estrogen. Throughout a series of gene duplications, the reproduced genes lost the ability to bind and respond to aromatized 3-HSs, and gained the ability to bind and be activated by non-aromatized 3-ketosteroids . Currently, the molecular basis for this functional switch is not well understood. To understand the molecular basis behind this functional switch, the ancestral precursor to the modern-day androgen, progesterone, mineralocorticoid, and glucocorticoid receptors, Ancestral Steroid Receptor 2 (SR2) was resurrected. This protein represents the first protein to have lost estrogen sensitivity and gained specificity for nonaromatic 3-KS. We took a two-pronged approach to understanding ligand recognition and activation, using both biochemical and structural techniques. We show that SR2 binds and is activated by 3-KSs and binds, but is not activated by 3-HSs. Additionally, 3-KSs stabilize SR2 while 3-HSs decrease receptor stability. Using the crystal structure of SR2 in complex with progesterone, a 3-KS, we re-created key historical substitutions to reverse the specificity of the receptor from 3-KSs to 3-HSs. We showed that with two amino acid mutations (Q353E, M384L) in the ligand binding pocket of SR2 that we can reverse steroid preference from progesterone to estrogen, a feat that remained elusive using modern proteins. However, regaining full 3-HS specificity requires reversing an additional two amino acids near the D-ring of the hormone. We then wanted to investigate the mechanism behind this functional switch. We hypothesized that the basis of the increased activation by estrogen in the Q353E M384L mutant was due to the increased receptor-ligand complex stability. Chemical denaturation studies showed that the Q353E substitution conferred stability to the receptor. The M384L and Q353E substitutions decreased stability, but increased specificity. Thus, in the forward evolutionary trajectory, SR2 gained specificity while losing stability.

body_text.section: Directed evolution of an enhanced and highly efficient FokI cleavage domain for zinc-finger nucleases Thomas Gaj, Jing Guo, Carlos Barbas

body_text.text: Zinc finger nucleases (ZFNs) are powerful tools for gene therapy and genetic engineering. The high specificity and affinity of these chimeric enzymes are based on custom-designed zinc finger proteins (ZFPs). To improve the performance of existing ZFN technology, we developed an in vivo evolution-based approach to improve the efficacy of the FokI cleavage domain (FCD). After multiple rounds of cycling mutagenesis and DNA shuffling, a more efficient nuclease variant (Sharkey) was generated. In vivo analyses indicated that Sharkey is up to 15-fold more active than wild-type FCD on a diverse panel of cleavage sites and mammalian cell-based assay showed a three to sixfold improvement in targeted mutagenesis for ZFNs containing derivatives of the Sharkey cleavage domain. We also identified mutations that impart sequence specificity to the FCD that could be used in future studies to further refine ZFNs through cooperative specificity. Sharkey was observed to enhance the cleavage profiles of previously published and newly selected heterodimer ZFN architectures. This enhanced and highly efficient cleavage domain will increase the utility of ZFNs in a variety of applications throughout medicine and biology. This study was supported by U.S. National Institutes of Health grant R01GM065059 and The Skaggs Institute for Chemical Biology. The accumulation of amyloid fibril formed by soluble proteins that misfold and aggregate is associated with a number of devastating human diseases. Here, we employ Apolipoprotein C-II as a model system to investigate the structure and mechanism of amyloid fibrils. In the absence of lipid, apoC-II self associates into amyloid fibrils with a twisted ribbon morphology, while in the presence of low micellar concentrations of phospholipids, apoC-II forms fibrils with a distinct rod-like morphology. Based on experimental studies and molecular dynamic simulations, a novel 'letter G-like' β-strand-loop-β-strand conformation model is presented for apoC-II within twisted ribbon fibril. Here, we map the core-β structure of rod-like fibrils using H/D exchange measurements by solution-state NMR. Similarities and differences between apoC-II rod-like fibrils and twisted ribbon on their core-β sheet structure are compared. We further investigate the fibril growth rate and size distributions of twisted ribbon fibrils formed by apoC-II derivatives. Ion pair effects on mutant apoC-II fibril formation and stability are also discussed. A better understanding of the general structure and the mechanism by which amyloid fibrils are formed will lead to new approaches to treat amyloid diseases.
body_text.section: Directed evolution of an enhanced and highly efficient FokI cleavage domain for zinc-finger nucleases Thomas Gaj, Jing Guo, Carlos Barbas

body_text.text: Thioamides: Minimalist Labels for Studying Protein Dynamics Jacob Goldberg, E. James Petersson Department of Chemistry, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA Quenching of protein fluorescence can be used to monitor protein dynamics or biomolecular associations. This quenching can be interpreted to afford valuable structural information with a structural resolution that depends on the size of the quenching probe used. We have shown that backbone thioamides effectively quench a variety of fluorophores, including cyanophenylalanine, tryptophan, tyrosine, methoxycoumarin, and acridone, in a distance-dependent manner. We have used this method to monitor the binding of thioamide-containing peptides to the protein calmodulin, protein unfolding in the villin headpiece subdomain, aggregation of α-synuclein, and protease activity. Since thioamide analogs of the natural amino acids can be incorporated at any position in the peptide backbone, they can function as a valuable, minimally-perturbing probe of protein dynamics. This work is supported by funding from the University of Pennsylvania, the National Science Foundation (CHE-020205 to E.J.P.), and the Searle Scholars Program (10-SSP-214 to E.J.P.).

Intramolecular collapse during the folding of staphylococcal nuclease monitored by fluorescence resonance energy transfer Takuya Mizukami 1 , Ming Xu 2 , Heinrich Roder 2, 3 , Kosuke Maki 1 1 Department of Physics, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Aichi, Japan, 2 Fox Chase Cancer Center, Philadelphia, PA, 3 Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA Many proteins fold from the unstructured unfolded state to the native state via compact, partially structured intermediate states. However, whether the condensation of the polypeptide chains is driven by non-specific hydrophobic interactions or by more specific local and tertiary interactions remains unclear. We studied the folding of staphylococcal nuclease, focusing on the condensation occurring in the early stages of the folding. This 149-residue protein consists of an N-terminal β-barrel and a C-terminal α-helical domain. Previous pulsed H/D exchange results and kinetic studies of the single-Trp variants on the microsecond time scale indicated that a loosely packed hydrophobic core comprising a large fraction of the β-barrel domain with weak hydrogen bonds in the turn region of the strands II and III is formed during early stages of folding. In the present study, the formation of tertiary interactions within the β-barrel domain and between the two domains during folding was followed by means of fluorescence resonance energy transfer. Two variants with a single Trp as a donor and a single AEDANSmodified Cys as an acceptor located within the β-barrel domain (W27/C64-AEDANS and W27/C97-AEDANS) showed an increase in the apparent energy transfer efficiency in the sub-millisecond time range. In contrast, a variant with a single Trp as a donor and a single TNBmodified Cys as an acceptor located in the α-helical and β-barrel domains, respectively, (W140/C64-TNB) showed virtually no change in the apparent energy transfer efficiency in the sub-millisecond time range and an increase only after 100 ms time range during the folding reaction. These results indicate that a specific collapse within the β-barrel domain occurs on the sub-millisecond time scale while the α-helical domain becomes structured only during the rate-limiting step of folding. Together with previous pulsed H/D exchange and protein engineering data, these results indicate that chain condensation during early stages of folding can involve specific structural events.

Exploring In Vitro and In Vivo Aggregation of a β-Clam Protein Mylene Ferrolino 1 , Anastasia Zhuravleva 1 , Zoya Ignatova 2 , Lila Gierasch 1 1 Molecular and Cell Biology Program, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Amherst, MA, 2 Biochemistry, University of Potsdam, Potsdam, Germany Protein aggregation has been implicated in a wide variety of neurodegenerative diseases, and its complexity has also become a major obstacle in large-scale production of protein-based therapeutics. The tendency of proteins to form aggregates has been quite well characterized in defined media but is poorly understood in the complex intracellular environment. Furthermore, only very few globular proteins have known aggregation mechanisms. We are developing approaches to tackle these challenges using a predominantly β-sheet protein whose in vitro folding has been explored in detail: cellular retinoic acid-binding protein I (CRABP 1) and E. coli as a cellular model. We have identified many point mutations that increase the aggregation propensity of CRABP 1. To explore the mechanisms that drive aggregation in these CRABP 1 variants both in vitro and in vivo, we determined the structures of CRABP 1 aggregates using DMSO-quenched hydrogen-deuterium exchange NMR (HDX NMR). We found the core structures of in vitro and in vivo-derived aggregates to be the same, suggesting a conserved mechanism of aggregation inside and outside the cell. We have also observed that aggregates from variants with different aggregation propensities share similar aggregation core regions, and that these cores correlate with several predicted aggregation hotspots. Analysis of the aggregation cores of CRABP 1 reveal that a possible near-native precursor visited by the protein in the absence of a ligand may lead to aggregation. Equilibrium unfolding experiments in low denaturant followed by NMR support our hypothesis that the population of a dynamic near-native species increases CRABP 1's aggregation propensity. Our data point to the potential risks of aggregation created protein dynamics. [Supported by NIH grant OD-000945 to LMG] 97 Evaluation and optimization of discrete state models of protein folding Elizabeth Kellogg 1 , Oliver Lange 2 , David Baker 1 1 biochemistry, university of washington, J Wing, Health Sciences Building, Seattle, WA, 98195, 2 Chemistry, Technische Universität München, Munich, Germany

The space accessed by a folding macromolecule is vast, and how to best project computer simulations of protein folding trajectories into an interpretable sequence of discrete states is an open research problem. There are numerous alternative ways of associating individual configurations into collective states, and in deciding on the number of such clustered states there is a tradeoff between human interpretability (smaller number of states) and accuracy of representation (larger number of states). We utilize a novel trajectory likelihood measure and cross-validation procedure for assessing alternative groupings of individual configurations into states, and use this measure to assess the general predictive-ness of alternative methods of grouping configurations and the minimum number of states required to accurately model folding. We apply this method to analyze the 200 microsecond MD simulations of the WW-domain (Shaw et. al.) We find that widely used RMSD-based clustering methods require large numbers of initial states and a second agglomeration step based on kinetic connectivity to produce models with high predictive power; this is the approach taken in elegant recent work with Markov State Models of protein folding(Lane, Noe). In contrast, we find that grouping of states based on secondary structure pairings and contact-maps, when refined with kmeans clustering, preserves kinetic relationships with up to two orders of magnitude fewer initial states and, surprisingly, models constructed purely from geometry based groupings can be as predictive as those produced by kinetic clustering, quantitatively and qualitatively. We use the most predictive contact map representation to study the folding transitions of the WW domain observed in very long molecular dynamics simulations (Shaw et al.) , and we observe previously Membrane proteins are essential for life. Their structures are needed to their functions. Their 3-dimensional structures are unique, in particular α-helical integral membrane proteins. Although the information of the structure is determined by x-ray diffraction and solidstate NMR, the method is difficult and takes a long time to determine them. The purpose of the present work is to predict the 3-dimenstional structure of α-helical membrane proteins by computer simulation. The procedure is as follows. At first, we extract transmembrane amino acid residue from membrane proteins. Then, the ideal helix structure is formed from the region of amino acid residue. The replica-exchange Monte Carlo method and a simple implicit membrane model to represent restrictions of membrane proteins from membrane environment are applied. The Monte Carlo move sets include backbone torsion angle for the deformation of helix structures from ideal helix form. Our implicit membrane model represents the restriction of trans-membrane helices within the membrane regions. A principal component analysis is used to examine the simulation trajectory and divide structures into localminimum free energy states. Trans-membrane α-helices in integral membrane proteins such as glycophorin A and bacteriorhodopsin are applied. In this poster presentation, we show the results of these structure predictions.

Soluble expression, purification, and proper refolding of intractable proteins in the E. coli expression system are facilitated by hyper-acidic FATT-tag with a generalized protocol Takeshi Sangawa, Sanae Tabata, Kei Suzuki, Takuro Yasuda, Junichi Takagi Institute for Protein Research, 3-2 Yamadaoka, Suita, 565-0871, Japan

Protein purification is a central technique for the biochemical sciences. Affinity chromatography methods that are generally employed in isolating target proteins from crude cell lysate, such as nickel-chelete, glutathione or immunoaffinity chromatography, are both high cost and unsuitable for large scale protein production. We established a novel hyper acidic tag "FATT", consisting of the extracellular acidic region of the amyloid precursor protein (APP). Because this negatively-charged tag makes the total isoelectric point of these fusion proteins very low, FATT-tag fusion proteins can be easily purified from cell lysate with anion exchange chromatography in one step. In addition, heterologous expression of FATT-tag fusion proteins in Eschericia coli results in robust enhancement of protein solubility. Extracellular enzymes and single-chain antibodies that are entirely expressed in insoluble forms could be completely recovered from the soluble fraction when expressed as a FATT-tag fusion. Furthermore, extracellular proteins and single-chain Fvs that have intramolecular disulfide-bonds in their native structures were successfully refolded into their functional forms using a single protocol without any case-specific condition optimization. The mechanism of this refolding-assistance property is not clear, but in size-exclusion chromatographic analysis, the large Stokes radius that FATT-tag demonstrates in aqueous buffer indicates an extended, unstructured conformation for the tag. It is likely that FATT-tag does not act as a chaperone in protein refolding, but rather, it prevents protein aggregation by increasing electrostatic repulsion over a large dynamic radius. Multidimensional infrared spectroscopy is a recentlydeveloped technique that measures protein structure and dynamics with ultrafast time resolution. Amide-I two-dimensional infrared (2DIR) spectroscopy reveals the couplings between backbone carbonyl stretching modes and reports on the secondary structure of the protein. We present a new spectroscopic method to study transient protein structure, conformational dynamics and folding based on a combination of 2DIR spectroscopy, electrostatic maps, and Markov state models (MSM) derived from molecular dynamics simulations. MSMs provide an intuitive "chemical reaction" interpretation of the folding process while retaining much of the structural heterogeneity and diversity of folding pathways. Electrostatic frequency maps are used to calculate frequencies of the individual amide units which are subsequently used to generate 2DIR spectra, thus providing the critical link between structure and spectra. The rapid unfolding and re-folding of NTL9, a 39-residue mixed α/β protein, is studied with temperature-jump 2DIR on timescales ranging from 100 ns to 50 ms. A unfolding response is observed on the ~250 µs timescale and re-folding/equilibration occurs within 2.5 ms. Transient 2DIR spectra reveal a series of well-defined unfolding events, starting with a weakening of hydrogen bonds on the sub-100 ns, unraveling of the beta-sheet on the µs timescale and unfolding of the α-helix on the 100 µs to ms timescale. The experimentally-informed folding pathways of NTL9 are further interpreted in the context of Markov state models.

An Amino Acid Packing Code for α-helical Structure and Protein Design Hyun Joo, Archana Chavan, Jamie Phan, Ryan Day, Jerry Tsai Chemistry, University of the Pacific, Stockton, CA This work demonstrates that all packing in α-helices can be simplified to repetitive patterns of a single motif: the knob-socket. Using the precision of Voronoi Polyhedra/ Deluaney Tessellations to identify contacts, the knobsocket is a 4 residue tetrahedral motif: a knob residue on one α-helix packs into the 3 residue socket on another a-helix. The principle of the knob-socket model relates the packing between levels of protein structure: the intrahelical packing arrangements within secondary structure that permit inter-helix tertiary packing interactions. Within an α-helix, the 3 residue sockets arrange residues into a uniform packing lattice. Inter-helix packing results from a definable pattern of interdigitated knobsocket motifs between 2 α-helices. Furthermore, the knob-socket model classifies 3 types of sockets: 1) free: favoring only intra-helical packing, 2) filled: favoring inter-helical interactions and 3) non: disfavoring α-helical structure. The amino acid propensities in these 3 socket classes essentially represent an amino acid code for structure in α-helical packing. Using this code, a novel yet straightforward approach for the design of α-helical structure was used to validate the knob-socket model. Unique sequences for 3 peptides were created to produce a predicted amount of α-helical structure: mostly helical, some helical, and no-helix. These 3 peptides were synthesized and helical content assessed using CD spectroscopy. The measured α-helicity of each peptide was consistent with the expected predictions. These results and analysis demonstrate that the knobsocket motif functions as the basic unit of packing and presents an intuitive tool to decipher the rules governing packing in protein structure. X-ray crystallographic structure determination observes a low-energy molecular conformation of a target molecule embedded within a periodic macroscopic crystal. Improving technology, accelerated via structural genomics efforts, and increasing access to synchrotrons are two notable factors in the radical acceleration of the process of obtaining crystals and datasets suitable for structure determination. However, any resulting structure provides a limited snapshot or handful of snapshots into the ensemble of relevant molecular conformations. Furthermore, not all molecules of interest can be coaxed into forming a crystal. Here, we demonstrate a method for crystallographic structure determination that observes the conformation for target molecules of interest embedded, piecewise, within homologous protein structures. To demonstrate this new method we have solved the structure of 21 synthetic cytochrome P450 chimeras, as well as two natural cytochrome P450s from Bacillus subtilis. We demonstrate a high level of accuracy for piecewise crystallographic structure determination with unique advantages with respect to traditional crystallography.

Structural refinement of predicted models of biological macromolecules using atomistic or coarse-grained molecular force fields having various degree of error are investigated. The goal of this analysis is to estimate what is the probability for designing an effective structural refinement based on computations of conformational energies using force field, and starting from a structure predicted from the sequence (using template-based, or template-free modeling), and refining it to bring the structure into closer proximity to the native state. Here an analysis of noise in an artificially introduced scoring function is investigated for a model of an ideal sampling scheme, where the underlying distribution of RMSDs is assumed to be Gaussian. Sampling of the conformational space is performed by random generation of RMSD values. We demonstrate that whenever the random noise in a force field exceeds some level, it is impossible to obtain reliable structural refinement. We study also the effect of normal modes on protein structural refinement. Elastic Network Models represent protein dynamics as vibrations of a network of nodes (usually represented by positions of the heavy atoms or by the Cα atoms only for coarse-grained representations) in which the spatially close nodes are connected by harmonic springs. These models provide a reliable representation of the fluctuational dynamics of proteins and RNA, and explain various conformational changes in protein structures including those important for ligand binding.
body_text.section: High Resolution Models from Low Resolution Data: Recombination of Fragments for Crystallographic

body_text.text: We study the problem of protein structure refinement by analyzing thermal motions of proteins in nonnative states. We represent the conformational space close to the native state by a set of decoys generated by the I-TASSER protein structure prediction server utilizing template-free modeling. The protein substates are selected by hierarchical structure clustering.
body_text.section: High Resolution Models from Low Resolution Data: Recombination of Fragments for Crystallographic

body_text.text: The main finding is that thermal motions for some substates, overlap significantly with the deformations necessary to reach the native state. Additionally, more mobile residues yield higher overlaps with the required deformations than do the less mobile ones. These findings suggest that structural refinement of poorly resolved protein models can be significantly enhanced by reduction of the conformational space to the motions imposed by the dominant normal modes. Leptin plays key roles in regulating energy intake/ expenditure, metabolism and hypertension. It folds into a four-helix bundle that binds to the extracellular receptor to initiate signaling. A prominent feature that has been overlooked is the unique knotting of the helical bundle as a result of a 50-residue disulphide bonded loop through which two of the helices must thread. We term this heretofore undescribed feature a cysteine knotted helical bundle. The role of the knot in leptin function is an open question. We used a combined theoretical and experimental approach to investigate the free energy landscape of leptin in silico and in vitro together with activity assays in vivo. The N-terminal region 'threads' through the disulphide-bonded covalent-loop to reach the geometrically complex native state. Reducing the disulphide breaks the covalent-loop into an unknotted protein with less constrains in its denatured state. Even though the complexity added by knot formation is structurally important, the free energy landscape appears to be very similar. In contrast to previous reports, we find that formation of the disulphide bridge is not necessary for receptor binding and activation of the JAK/STAT signaling pathway. However, the reduced, unknotted conformation is less active and less stable than the disulphide bonded knotted bundle. Therefore, the formation of the cysteineknotted helical bundle is essential for optimal function of leptin. Interestingly, the threading is implicated in both states and the folding mechanism is overall conserved. Taken together our results indicate that the unique cysteine-knotted conformation stabilizes the protein and 'prevents' it from unfolding both by thermodynamics and by creating kinetic difficulties. Fungal infections still remain a widespread population problem, especially in hospitals. Candida albicans is the main causative agent of invasive fungal infections in an expanding population of immunosuppressed patients with associated high morbidity and mortality rate. As many strains of C. albicans have acquired multiresistance against the current therapies, the necessity of developing new anti-fungal strategies against this pathogen is growing. One efficient way of inhibiting these pathogens is to target enzymes involved in RNA maturation. The poly(A) polymerase (PAP) is an enzyme implicated in the addition of the poly(A) tail to nascent mRNAs, which plays a critical role in mRNA stability, export and translation. In order to get new insights about the interactions implicated in the selection and the binding of the nucleotide substrate (ATP), we first generated a 3D model of the C. albicans PAP. This model provided instructive findings on the interactions between specific amino acids and the ATP substrate. We also evaluated the incorporation and the inhibitory potential of a large collection of purine analogs. Surprisingly, few analogs were incorporated as efficiently as the natural substrate, ATP. Using this novel in vitro RNA polyadenylation system, we evaluated the impacts of a modified poly(A) tail on mRNA translation. First, we monitored the potential of an mRNA with a modified 3'-end encoding the luciferase reporter gene to be translated in rabbit reticulocytes and in HEK293 cells. We next mesured the direct binding of the human poly(A) binding protein (PABPC1) to poly(A) modified RNAs. Then, the stability of the modified luciferase mRNAs was addressed in vitro against a specific human deadenylase, Ccr4, and in cellulo by qPCR assays. Briefly, this study establishes a scaffold for the rational design of what could represent a novel class of inhibitors against fungal pathogens like Candida albicans. (1) and is mainly associated with lowdensity lipoprotein (LDL) and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in human plasma. Lp-PLA2 is considered as a risk factor, a potential biomarker, and a target of therapy in the treatment of cardiovascular disease. Several lines of evidence suggest that the level of Lp-PLA2 in plasma is associated with the risk of future cardiovascular and stroke events. The differential location of the enzyme in LDL/HDL lipoproteins has been suggested to affect Lp-PLA2 function and/or its physiological role and an abnormal distribution of the enzyme may correlate with diseases. Although mutagenesis studies suggest that a surface helix (residues 362-369) may mediate the association between Lp-PLA2 and HDL, the molecular mechanism of association is still unknown. We have now employed DXMS to characterize the interaction between Lp-PLA2 and human HDL. We have found that specific residues 113-120, 192-204 and 360-368 likely mediate HDL binding. Residues 113-120 have been shown to be important for Lp-PLA2-liposome interactions in our previous study (2). Residues 192-204 show decreased deuteration levels when Lp-PLA2 is associated with apoA-I, but not apoA-II, the most abundant protein components in HDL. Our results suggest that apoA-I and lipid membranes may play an important role in Lp-PLA2 association with HDL. Kyoto Pref. body_text.section: High Resolution Models from Low Resolution Data: Recombination of Fragments for Crystallographic

body_text.text: The side-chain conformations of amino acids in the hydrophobic core are important for the protein folding and function. It is well-known that a protein is fluctuated in solution, which is critical for the expression of function. Although great numbers of static or averaged protein structures have been determined using the recent techniques such as X-ray and NMR, it is still difficult to determine the dynamic properties of proteins. The previous NMR study showed that a mutant protein of c-Myb R3, I155L/I181L, has multiple conformations, which is considered to be attributed to increasing the sidechain conformational entropy upon the mutation of Ile to Leu. This protein is a good target to analyze the dynamic property, and the role of side-chain conformation for the structure and function. A transcriptional activator c-Myb specifically binds to DNA, and its DNA-binding domain consists of three imperfect 51-or 52-residue repeats. The last two repeats, R2 and R3, are sufficient for the recognition of the specific DNA sequences. In addition to the three Trp residues in each repeat, Val103, Ile118, Cys130 and Ile155, Ile169, Ile181 are involved in the hydrophobic cores of R2 and R3, respectively. In this study, we analyzed the thermodynamic effects of multiple conformations on the stability and bindingfunction, using R2R3 I155L/I181L mutant and its control proteins. The CD and DSC measurements showed that the mutation of I155L had little effect on the stability, while the I181L mutation significantly destabilized the protein. This is in good agreement with the NMR results that I155L mutation has little effect on the tertiary structure, suggesting that the contribution of side-chain conformational entropy upon the Leu-substitution depends on the environment around the substituted site. It should be noted that the decreased stabilities of I181L mutants were mainly due to the decreased entropy change. In addition, the specific DNA-binding affinity of I155L/I181L mutant was lower than that of wildtype, which was due to the decreased binding entropy change. Taken together, upon the I181L mutation, the conformational fluctuation would be increased, and as a result, the multiple conformations are observed in the NMR time scale. The increased conformational fluctuation could increase the entropy term either in the native state or in the DNA-unbound state, resulting in the decreased stability and DNA-binding affinity. Human acidic fibroblast growth factor (hFGF-1) belongs to a superfamily of 22 fibroblast growth factors (FGFs) that have a high affinity for heparin. It is a 16kD protein, which is involved in many cellular functions, such as, cell proliferation, cell differentiation, angiogenesis, tumor growth, and wound healing. FGF-1 exhibits its cell proliferation activity by binding to cell-surface tyrosine kinase receptors (FGFRs). The binding of FGF-1 to FGFRs results in dimerization of the receptor, which in turn, leads to its activation. Heparin is proposed to have two functions: it protects FGFs from degradation by proteases and from thermal denaturation, and it induces FGF oligomerization resulting in the interaction with and activation of FGFRs. However, it remains undetermined whether or not heparin is required for both purposes. In this study, we attempt to understand the structural role of heparin in the FGF signaling process. In this context, several mutations within the heparin-binding region of FGF-1 were constructed. Some of the mutants in the heparinbinding pocket completely knocked out the binding affinity of FGF to the proteoglycan. The structural and functional consequences of the mutations in the heparinbinding pocket have been examined using a variety of biophysical techniques. Finally, cell proliferation assays were performed to determine the activity of wild-type FGF-1 compared to the mutants exhibiting decreased heparin-binding affinity. Although some mutants were less active, all showed activity. This suggests heparin's role is to stabilize FGF-1, and it is not required for FGF-FGFR signaling.
body_text.section: Physical Properties of Proteins

body_text.text: Asymmetrical roles of zinc fingers in dynamic DNAscanning process by the inducible transcription factor Egr- Egr-1 is an inducible transcription factor that recognizes 9-base pair target DNA sites via three zinc finger domains and activates genes in response to cellular stimuli, such as synaptic signals and vascular stresses. Using spectroscopic and computational approaches, we have studied structural, dynamic, and kinetic aspects of the DNA-scanning process in which Egr-1 is nonspecifically bound to DNA and perpetually changes its location on DNA. Our NMR data indicate that Egr-1 undergoes highly dynamic domain motions when scanning DNA. In particular, the zinc finger 1 (ZF1) of Egr-1 in the nonspecific complex is mainly dissociated from DNA and undergoes collective motions on a nanosecond timescale, while zinc fingers 2 and 3 (ZF2 and ZF3, respectively) are bound to DNA. This was totally unexpected because the previous crystallographic studies of the specific complex indicated that all of Egr-1's three zinc fingers are equally involved in binding to a target DNA site. Mutations that are expected to enhance ZF1's interactions with DNA and with ZF2 were found to reduce ZF1's domain motions in the nonspecific complex, suggesting that these interactions dictate the dynamic behavior of ZF1. By experiment and computation, we have also investigated kinetics of Egr-1's translocation between two nonspecific DNA duplexes. Our data on the wild-type and mutant proteins suggest that the domain dynamics facilitate Egr-1's intersegment transfer that involves transient bridging of two DNA sites. These results shed light on asymmetrical roles of the zinc finger domains for Egr-1 to efficiently scan DNA in the nucleus. This work was supported by Grant MCB-0920238 from the National Science Foundation, Grant 12BGIA8960032 from the American Heart Association, and Grant 2010424 from the United States -Israel Binational Science Foundation Insulin is known to precipitate upon reduction of the disulfide bonds that link A and B chains. Redox states in various cellular compartments are tightly regulated to prevent oxidative stress and damage to proteins. Endoplasmic reticulum stress, a prominent feature in pancreatic β-cells associated with type 2 diabetes, results in a reduced redox environment. The extent to which insulin is reduced within storage granules is currently unknown, as are strategies employed by cells to minimize insulin reduction and precipitation. We show in the present study that significant amounts of insulin can be reduced in vitro at the redox state previously reported for secretory pathway. As zinc is found at high levels within insulin storage granules and is both coordinated and bound by insulin hexamers, we investigated the effect of zinc on precipitation of insulin upon reduction. Zinc specifically decreased the precipitation of insulin in vitro upon treatment with DTT or the non-thiol-containing reducing agent TCEP. Other divalent cations including copper, magnesium, calcium, and manganese were unable to prevent insulin precipitation. While zinc slowed the reduction of insulin as determined by tricine SDS-PAGE, it did not prevent the complete reduction of insulin, suggesting the effect of zinc on insulin precipitation is independent of insulin reduction. In addition, zinc had no effect on reduction of DTNB. Our results suggest that zinc may be able to mitigate potential reduction and precipitation of insulin within storage granules, thus presenting a role for zinc that was previously unknown. Further studies must be completed to determine the biochemical basis by which zinc prevents insulin precipitation and to determine in vivo relevance.

Revisiting the structure of Lactate Dehydrogenase from Spiny Dogfish Abhishek Kumar, Karen Knapp, Kurt Krause, Craig Marshall Department of Biochemistry, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand Lactate dehydrogenase-A (LDH-A) from Spiny Dogfish (Squalus acanthias), is an enzyme that catalyses the inter-conversion of L-lactate and NAD+ to pyruvate and NADH, and has been extensively characterised. The current crystal structure of Spiny Dogfish LDH-A (PDB code: 1LDM) in the Protein Data Bank was solved at a resolution of 2.10 Å (Zapatero et al., 1987) , and from this structure the amino acid sequence was derived. Interestingly, the Spiny Dogfish LDH-A amino acid sequence derived from the crystal structure is significantly different from that of other vertebrates. Furthermore, the structure derived sequence differs to the cDNA derived amino acid sequence of Spiny Dogfish LDH-A by approx. 5% (Stock & Power, 1995) . The cDNA sequence of Spiny Dogfish LDH-A is more similar to other known vertebrate LDH-A sequences. To address the amino acid sequence discrepancies we have revisited the Spiny Dogfish LDH-A crystal structure. We have determined crystal structures of Spiny Dogfish LDH-A in both apo and holo forms to 1.80-1.90 Å resolution. The apo (space group I422) and holo (space group P21212) forms of Spiny Dogfish LDH-A revealed well-defined electron density for the entire LDH-A polypeptide chain. Furthermore the holo form revealed well-defined electron density for NAD and oxamate within the active site. The previous Spiny Dogfish LDH-A structure (PDB code: 1LDM) was found to be in poor sequence agreement, in the regions where there are amino acid discrepancies, with the electron density maps generated in this study. The catalytic centre of the LDH-A protein was found to be very similar in all structures and significant structural differences were restricted to surface loops. The Spiny Dogfish LDH-A structures presented in this study are in agreement with the published cDNA sequence.

Exceeding the limit of dynamics studies on proteins using NMR spectroscopy David Ban 1 , Alvar Gossert 2 , Karin Giller 1 , Stefan Becker 1 , Christian Griesinger 1 , Donghan Lee 1 1 NMR based Structural Biology, Max-Planck Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Am Faßberg 11, Göttingen, 37077, Germany, 2 Institute for BioMedical Research, Novartis, Basel, Switzerland

Internal motions of proteins are tightly related to their particular function. These motions occur in a broad range of timescales from picoseconds to seconds and slower. Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) is a powerful spectroscopic tool capable of detecting motions within this broad range of timescales using a variety of different type of experiments that probe different NMR observables. One type of experiment, called relaxation dispersion, is uniquely sensitive to the kinetics and amplitude of motions that occur within the micro-millisecond timescale that manifest themselves within the residual line-width of peaks. Within relaxation dispersion, rotating-frame transverse relaxation (R1ρ) experiments function by modulating the strength of spin-lock pulses to effectively quench this residual linewidth. However, the strength of the applied spin-lock pulse is directly related to the fastest kinetics that can be observed, and due to hardware limitations, motions faster than 40 μs could not be detected.
