Yet, motions between the globular rotational correlation time (4 ns) and the 40 μs, deemed the supra-τc range, has recently been proposed to play a role in molecular recognition (Lange et al. Science 320 1471 (2008 ). So far, it could only be accessed by lowering the temperature dramatically, thus slowing the kinetics down that they were within the detectable range for R1ρ experiments (Ban et al. Angew. Chemie 50 11437(2011) ). Therefore, we have set out to exceed our view into this time window by generating large spin-lock pulses that could be used to observe faster kinetics. Using a cryogenically cooled NMR probe, a tool commonly found in many NMR laboratories, we have been able to exceed our resolution into motions that could occur as fast as 25 μs, 10 μs, and 4 μs for 15N, 13C, and 1H nuclei, respectively. We demonstrate that large spin-lock pulses can be applied without damaging the integrity of the probe nor heat the sample, and validate their use for R1ρ experiments. In addition, sensitivity to smaller amplitude motions is observed, and the detection of motion within the sidechains of ubiquitin with kinetics that are within the supra-τc range is presented but slower than predicted from MD simulations on BPTI (Shaw et al. Science 330 341-346(2010) ). This technique allows for the observation of faster motions in proteins and the accurate characterization of parameters that define the dynamic process.

S-nitrosylation of a major detoxification enzyme: molecular mechanism and modulation of protein stability David Balchin 1 , Stoyan Stoychev 2 , Heini Dirr 1 1 Molecular and Cell Biology, University of the Witwatersrand, 7 Gill Street Observatory, Johannesburg, 2198, South Africa, 2 Biosciences, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, Pretoria, South Africa S-nitrosylation is a post-translational modification of cysteine residues critical to the stress response in eukaryotic cells. Although hundreds of S-nitrosylation sites have been identified in vivo, very little is known about the mechanism or molecular consequences of the modification. Glutathione transferase (GST) P1-1 is a cytosolic enzyme involved in xenobiotic detoxification and regulation of cell proliferation. GSTP1-1 is nitrosylated in vivo under conditions of oxidative stress and is therefore a model for studying protein regulation by S-nitrosylation. Recombinant human GSTP1-1 was nitrosylated in vitro by reaction with S-nitrosoglutathione, confirmed by ESI-MS and UV-difference spectroscopy. Two nitrosylation sites per monomer were identified by mass-based sequencing. In addition, a single-nitrosylated isoform was generated by occluding one site with a ligand. S-nitrosylation severely destabilises domain 1 of GSTP1-1 and reduces unfolding cooperativity, with the effect more pronounced for the double-nitrosylated protein. Further, a folding defect is introduced, with hysteresis apparent in the refolding of domain 2 of double-nitrosylated GSTP1-1 and domain 1 of the single-nitrosylated isoform. From the unfolding kinetics, it is apparent that S-nitrosylation modulates the unfolding pathway of GSTP1-1, causing reduced (double-nitrosylated) or enhanced (single-nitrosylated) kinetic cooperativity. Despite this, far-UV circular dichroism, fluorescence and acrylamide quenching show no substantial changes to native protein structure upon S-nitrosylation. Quenching of denatured state fluorescence reveals, however, that domain 1 of the nitrosylated protein is significantly more compact than the reduced protein in 8 M urea, suggesting that the energy landscape is altered by stabilisation of the denatured-state. We are currently probing the mechanism of S-nitrosylation by transient kinetic methods based on intrinsic protein fluorescence. Preliminary results suggest that S-nitrosylation of GSTP1-1 at each site involves at least two steps, with rapid cysteine nitrosylation followed by a very slow (k2 = 0.015 s-1), essentially irreversible protein conformational change. These data reveal novel facets of GSTP1-1 regulation and expand our understanding of the molecular basis of protein S-nitrosylation and redox signalling in general. This work was supported by the National Research Foundation. Determining the positions of hydrogen atoms is essential to understanding protein structure and function. However, experimental validation by neutron or ultrahigh resolution x-ray crystallography cannot be applied for most proteins studied. We present a computational method, HyP (Hydrogen Prediction), for detecting hydrogen atom positions by quantitative sampling of x-ray crystallographic electron density maps. This method is sensitive at resolution ranges up to 1.6 angstroms, which includes 12% of all protein structures in the PDB. In a data set of structures up to 1.0 angstroms, our method detects electron density peaks at rotameric positions for 51% of 649 alanine residues, consistent with hydrogen atoms. In the resolution ranges of 1.0-1.19, 1.2-1.39, and 1.4-1.59 angstroms, HyP detects potential hydrogen atoms at rotameric positions for 56, 56 and 50% of alanine residues from a total of 2025, 1202, and 3269 alanine residues, respectively. We also compare our predictions with neutron and ultrahigh resolution x-ray crystal structures.

ATPase by GB2 a biflavonoid purified from kolaviron Temitope Ayeotan 1 The Ca2+ uptake by sarco/endoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ATPase (SERCA) regulates muscle relaxation, and the apoptosis and proliferation of non muscle cells. We report in this study the effect of Garcinia biflavonoid 2 (GB2), a biflavonoid complex extracted and purified from the seeds of Garcinia kola and used as medicine against gastrointestinal infection and hepatitis, in Nigeria and other African countries. At an ATP concentration of 2mM, the biflavonoid inhibited SERCA1a with an IC50 value of 17µM. At a fixed concentration (40µM), GB2 reduced the maximum activity (Vmax) of SERCA by 65.6% with no effect on the affinity. We found that interaction of GB2 with ATPase gave rise to an appreciable rise in florescence at 515nm after FITC labelling of the protein at Lys-515. Thus the biflavonoid increased fluorescence intensity of the modified protein by 4.8%, 8.9%, 12.3%, 14.03%, 16.4%, 17.8%, 19.5% and 19.8% at 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, 50,70 and 90µM GB2, respectively in the E2 conformation. Furthermore, the addition of 0.1-0.5mM Ca2+ did not abolish this increase in the presence of GB2. These results suggest GB2 binds to the Ca2+-ATPase both in the E1 and E2 state with equal affinity and thus may slow down the conformational transitions accompanying ATP hydrolysis by interacting with a cytosolic binding site. Keywords: sarco/endoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ ATPase, GB2, biflavonoid. This research is being funded by IscU from E. coli, the scaffold protein for iron-sulfur cluster biosynthesis and transfer, populates two conformational states that interconvert with lifetimes on the order of 1 s [1] . One state (S) is structured, and the other (D) is dynamically disordered, but both play functional roles [2] . We report here that all four prolyl residues of apo-IscU (P14, P35, P100, and P101) are trans in the S-state, but that two (P14, P101) become cis in the D-state. We labeled IscU selectively by biosynthetic incorporation of [13C,15N]-Pro and [15N]-Ala. Because the prolyl residues are located in three dipeptides (P14R, P35A, P100P101) this labeling pattern enabled us to identify the spin system of P35 from the P35Cα-A36N connectivity, the spin systems of P100 and P101 from the P100Cα-P101N connectivity, and the spin system of P14 by difference. The 2D 1H-13C spectrum collected at pH 8.0 and 25 C, where both the S-and D-states are populated, revealed two spin systems for P101 and three spin systems for P14. To assign spin systems to S-state, we added Zn2+, which constrains the protein to the S-state, and collected data at 25 C. To assign spin systems to the D-state, we collected data at 45 C, where the protein is fully D-state. 3D HCCH TOCSY data allowed us to determine the chemical shifts of the 13C atoms of each prolyl residue. When the protein was in the S-state, the chemical shift difference (13Cγ − 13Cβ) for all four prolyl residues was ~5 ppm, indicating that they are all trans. However, when the protein was in the D-state, the chemical shift difference was ~5 ppm for P35 and P100 but ~ 10 ppm for P14 and P101, indicating that the latter are cis. Two cis spin systems were observed for P14 in the D-state as a consequence of splitting of the 1H signal of that residue. NOE data confirmed the expected connectivities. We conclude that the S/D interconversion involves a concerted trans/cis change of the N13-P14 and P100-P101 peptide bonds and that the D-state, although lacking secondary structure, stabilizes two high-energy cis peptide bonds. This work was supported by NIH grants (R01 GM58667 and U01 GM94622) and was a collaboration with the National Magnetic Resonance Facility at Madison with support from NIH grants 5P41RR002301-27, RR02301-26S1, and 8 P41 GM103399-27.
body_text.section: Inhibition of sarco/endoplasmic reticulum Ca2+

body_text.text: Recognition of linkage-specific polyubiquitin chains by two A20-type zinc finger-containing proteins Donghyuk Shin, Seungsu Han, Hoon Choi, Sangho Lee Biological Sciences, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon, Republic of Korea Polyubiquitination with different linkages plays crucial roles in regulating many proteolytic and non-proteolytic functions in cell. A20-type zinc finger domains (A20_ZFs) in animals reportedly recognize ubiquitin, either mono-or poly-ubiquitin. While monoubiquitin recognition by animal A20_ZFs has been extensively characterized biochemically, studies on polyubiquitin recognition lag behind. An A20_ZF from A20, a protein involved in NF-κB signaling, was shown to selectively bind K63-linked polyubiquitin. However, it remains elusive if A20_ZFs in homologous proteins exhibit similar linkage-specificity in polyubiquitin binding. Also, it is unclear whether A20_ZFs in plants perform similar roles. To address these questions, we employed A20_ZFs from bovine Rabex-5 and Arabidopsis stress associated protein 5 (AtSAP5) to explore linkagespecific polyubiquitin recognition by the two A20_ZFcontaining proteins. Rabex-5 regulates endosomal trafficking via its tandem ubiquitin binding domains (A20_ZF and MIU). AtSAP5 is involved with abiotic stress response in plants and contains A20_ZF and AN1type zinc finger domain. GST pulldown assay reveals that the N-terminal fragment of Rabex-5 harboring A20_ZF and MIU, termed Rabex-5(9-73), shows similar preference for linear, K63-linked, and K48-linked polyubiquitin binding while AtSAP5 less preference for K48-linked one. Mutagenesis analysis indicates that the A20_ZF domain of AtSAP5 is sufficient for linkagespecific polyubiquitin recognition. In contrast, A20_ZF of Rabex-5(9-73) appears dispensable for linkagespecific polyubiquitin binding. The dialipathic patch in AtSAP5, distinct from the conserved diaromatic patch in Rabex-5, seems to be responsible for K48-linked polyubiquitin binding. Taken together, our results suggest that A20_ZFs in Rabex-5 and AtSAP5 show linkage-specific preferences distinct from that of A20. We also establish that A20_ZF in plants participates in polyubiquitin recognition just like its counterparts in animals.

Physics, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan Photolyase/cryptochrome blue-light photoreceptors contain the enzymes that repair UV lesions in DNA by photo activated electron transfer reaction. For instance, cyclobutane pyrimidine dimer (CPD) photolyases recognize the double-stranded DNA that contain CPD. They repair these lesions by the cyclic electron transfer reaction between flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH-) and CPD. However, the reaction mechanism has been not reserved yet. Recently, we performed a computational study on the electron transfer reaction of the CPD photolyase derived from A. nidulans. We identified an important amino acid residue, Met-353, at which busy traffic of electron tunneling current was observed (Y. Miyazawa et al., 2008) . Interestingly, we found that the residue is perfectly conserved in the sequences of Class I CPD photolyase subfamily. On other hand, this residue substituted by the other amino acid, Gln-395, in Cry-DASH derived from Arabidopsis. Cry-DASH repairs CPD lesions like CPD photolyase does; however, Cry-DASH enzymes have photolyase activity only for single-stranded DNA. Unfortunately, the electron transfer mechanism of Cry-DASH remains unresolved. Recently, Pokorny et al. detained the structure of Arabidopsis Cry-DASH with an in siturepair CPD substrate in single-strand DNA. In this study, we investigated electron-tunneling pathways of the forward electron transfer (FET) and the back electron transfer (BET) in CPD photolyase and CRY-DASH. We performed molecular dynamics simulation of the CPD photolyase of A. nidulans and the Cry-DASH of Arabidopsis. We employed an extended Hückel approach to analyze the thermal fluctuation of electron transfer pathways in the proteins for a large number of conformational samples extracted from the molecular dynamics simulation trajectories. As a result, it is indicated that the Gln-395 site in the Cry-DASH plays an important role like the Met-353 site in the CPD photolyase does. Long-range information transfer within proteins, specifically from the substrate binding site to a distant surface site, plays a vital role in regulation of its activity. Understanding this allosteric modulation of protein activity is expected to aid in designing drugs that can achieve high specificity to the target protein. Exactly how the information is transferred from the allosteric site to the substrate-binding site is not well understood. We present a novel computational method based on atomic stresses and molecular dynamics simulation for identifying allosteric sites and the respective pathways. We demonstrate the method here using the PDZ domain. Tracing the path with highest stiffness from the substrate binding site through the protein core revealed a pathway that shows significant overlap with that previously inferred from evolutionarily conserved residues, and other computational methods. The method presented here is a general approach for visualizing the propagation and redistribution of stress within a protein during a simulation, which is likely to provide more insight into the key mechanisms responsible for protein allostery. Analytical methods designed to resolve total and effective surface-interaction charge characteristics of active protein components are now commonly used as quality control mechanisms for verification of consistency in biological manufacturing processes. The charge-resolved profiles yielded by methods such as gel and capillary isoelectric focusing (IEF, CIEF) and ion-exchange chromatography (IEx-HPLC) can also be utilized in a "fingerprint" fashion to verify the identity of a specific protein species. These methods are also more direct and robust to variability than other analytical methods such as peptide mapping, and therefore stand as good candidates for quality release testing of protein reagent identity. For application toward identity verification amongst many (>100) antibody and antigen protein species typically produced at a single manufacturing site in the in-vitro immunodiagnostics industry, these methods must ideally display unique results, or fingerprints, for each protein species. We have examined charge-based profiling methods for potential application to both quality control testing and R&Dphase support needs. Results from gel-IEF, CIEF and IEx-HPLC analyses will be presented to demonstrate the capability of each method as a sole or complimentary method for verification of identity amongst several antibody proteins species produced through very similar growth culture and purification processes. These methods have also found use in identification of multiple protein species within an expected single monoclonal product. We will also show how changes in the manufacturing process can affect the charge profile results, and discuss how this may impact the specificity of these methods for confident identification.
body_text.section: Electron Transfer Reactions by Photolyase/ Cryptochrome Blue-Light Photoreceptors: A Computational Analysis Ryuma Sato, Yamato Takahisa

body_text.text: Dual role of C2H2 zinc fingers in nuclear trafficking of transcription factor Sp1 Jun Kuwahara Doshisha Women's University, Kodo, Kyotanabe, 610-0395, Japan

Zinc finger proteins are among the most abundant proteins in eukaryotic genomes and extraordinarily diverse functions including DNA recognition. In particular, the classical C2H2 zinc fingers possess the characteristics of tandem repeats of zinc-binding module which consensus sequence is as follows:

n (n = 2~37), and vary in function, which ranges from DNA to RNA binding. We are interested in versatility of this type of motif and have been searching novel role of the motif. Sp1 is a human ubiquitous transcription factor involved in the early development of an organism and comprises three tandem repeats of C2H2 zinc finger motif and binds directly to a GC-rich upstream element DNA (GC box). Bidirectional traffic between the nucleus and the cytoplasm is routed through the nuclear pore complex (NPC) embedded in the nuclear envelope. Nuclear import of globular proteins of greater than 60 kDa in size is an active process that requires the presence of a suitable nuclear localization signal (NLS) and is mediated by a related family of shuttling transport factors, importins, which can recognize NLS. Although Sp1 is supposed to be actively transported into the nucleus due to its molecular mass (95/105 kDa), none of NLS for Sp1 has been reported. Subcellular localization of Sp1 was examined. We found that C2H2 zinc fingers of Sp1 serve as NLS and can recognize nuclear transport factors, importins. Possible protein interaction of the zinc finger domain was detected. Quantitative approach would be examined. [ The in vivo environments in which proteins normally function are much more crowded than the in vitro solutions usually used for in vitro studies of these molecules. Although there has long been interest in the question of how the structural, dynamic and functional properties of proteins might be affected by macromolecular crowding, there is as yet relatively little direct experimental evidence on this subject. To address these questions we are using small-angle X-ray and neutron scattering (SAXS and SANS) to study mixtures of folded and unfolded proteins at high concentrations. In earlier work, SANS was used to measure the effects of crowding on an intrinsically disordered protein, the N protein of bacteriophage λ (λ N), using 2 H labeling and solvent contrast matching to selectively detect the unfolded protein in the presence of high concentrations of a small globular protein, bovine pancreatic trypsin inhibitor (BPTI). These studies demonstrated the feasibility of the approach and indicated a small degree of compaction of λ N by BPTI at concentrations up to 130 mg/mL. More recently, we have carried out additional experiments with λ N and BPTI and with λ N and equine myoglobin, at concentrations up to 200 mg/mL. Refinement of the experimental conditions have enabled more definitive measurements, which indicate that there is virtually no change in the overall dimensions of the intrinsically disordered protein in the presence of either globular protein. These results are in striking contrast to the predictions of theoretical models based on scaled-particle theory and related treatments, suggesting that the underlying assumptions of these models should be re-examined. Aggregates of amyloid-β (Aβ) peptides have been implicated in the etiology of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Among the different forms of Aβ aggregates, low-molecular weight (LMW) ones ranging between ~2 and 50mers, also called 'soluble oligomers,' have emerged to be the species responsible for early synaptic dysfunction and neuronal loss. Emerging evidence suggests that the neurotoxic oligomers need not be formed along the obligatory nucleation-dependant fibril formation 'on-pathway'. Previously, we have reported the isolation of one such 'off-pathway' 12-18mer species of Aβ42 generated from fatty acids, called LFAOs (large fatty acid-derived oligomers) (Kumar et al. 2011, PLoS one). Next, we have characterized and studied the physiochemical properties of these LFAOs using biophysical techniques like size exclusion chromatography (SEC), dynamic light scattering (DLS), atomic force microscopy (AFM) & analytical ultracentrifugation (AUC). We have discovered that LFAOs are a replicating strain of oligomers that recruit Aβ42 monomers and quantitatively convert them into LFAO assemblies at the expense of fibrils. We also observed that in the presence of hexanebuffer or chloroform-buffer interfaces, LFAOs are able to associate with themselves to form larger, yet non-fibrillar, aggregates. This association property of LFAOs can provide valuable insight about potentially similar behavior of endogenous LMW oligomers in physiological environments. These results further support the fact that LMW oligomers can be generated via non-fibril formation pathways.

Department of Structural Biology, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA Aggregation of polyglutamine (polyQ) containing proteins plays a key role in a class of protein misfolding diseases characterized by the expansion of CAG repeats. Recent work in our lab has implicated β-hairpin formation as a critical step in the nucleation mechanism for simple polyQ amyloid formation. If this hypothesis is correct, we expect the flanking sequences of the polyQ sequence might have significant effects on aggregation nucleation due to their stabilizing or destabilizing effects on β-hairpin/nucleus formation. In our standard sequence motif for simple polyQ aggregation studies, we add flanking pairs of Lys residues to the N-and C-terminus of the polyQ in order to improve solubility and allow in vitro studies. These Lys residues might be expected, however, to introduce some destabilizing charge repulsion in a β-hairpin conformation and hence modify kinetics and nucleation mechanisms. Here, we explore the effects of various charge combinations of flanking residues on the nucleation kinetics of a short polyQ peptide. We designed six mutants that vary both in total charge and in the net attraction/repulsion between termini, potentially allowing us to identify which of these factors plays a greater role in a given peptide's ability to aggregate. We determined the concentration dependence of spontaneous amyloid assembly kinetics, the seeded elongation kinetics, and the molar concentrations of the elongation competent seed preparations, in order to extract the following parameters: the critical nucleus n*, the second order elongation rate constant, and the nucleation equilibrium constant (Kn*). We also characterized aggregate morphologies by electron microscopy. We found significant differences in aggregation kinetics in the charge variants analyzed, but only modest effects on aggregation mechanism. We also observed some atypical aggregate morphologies in some experiments. Some of these are likely due to charge effects on aggregate structure formation, while others may reflect introduction of additional assembly mechanisms at the high, non-physiological concentrations required for these studies. Our preliminary conclusion is that attraction/repulsion between termini plays a modulating role on β-hairpin closure and hence aggregation kinetics in this series of polyQ peptides. R01AG019322-11 It is now well appreciated that disordered proteins and domains are prevalent in eukaryotic proteomes and that disorder is critically linked with their regulation and functionality. However, our recent observations with the multi-domain protein, nucleophosmin (Npm), suggest that the biological palette of disorder is more diverse than currently understood. The N-terminal oligomerization domain of Npm (NpmN) can be transformed from a folded, pentameric structure to a monomeric, disordered state through changes in solution ionic strength and, importantly, through physiologically relevant post-translational modifications. Interestingly, this polymorphic behavior is not detected using standard secondary structure and disorder prediction algorithms, which show NpmN to be folded into beta strands, consistent with the structure of the pentameric form. We have used a combination of computational and biophysical tools, including molecular mechanics energy calculations, circular dichroism and NMR, to test the hypothesis that the polymorphic behavior of NpmN can be understood on structural and energetic grounds. We have identified unfavorable energetic 'hot-spots' within the NpmN structure which coincide with experimentally observed sites of post-translational modification. Based on these observations, we propose that NpmN has evolved energetic switches within its structure to enable transformation to a disordered state through phosphorylation. We further propose that the transformation process associated with control of Npm's multiple cellular functions is triggered by sequential phosphorylation of solvent exposed sites of posttranslational modification followed by exposure and modification of additional, but initially buried sites to completely shift the equilibrium to the disordered state.
body_text.section: Flanking Charges Can Modulate Aggregation Nucleation of Polyglutamine Model Peptides Elizabeth Landrum, Karunakar Kar, Ravindra Kodali, Ronald Wetzel

body_text.text: The chaperonin GroEL plays an essential role in promoting protein folding and in protecting against misfolding and aggregation in the cellular environment. In this study, we report that both GroEL and its isolated apical domain form amyloid-like fibrils under physiological conditions, and that the fibrillation of the apical domain is accelerated under acidic conditions. We also found, however, that despite its fibrillation propensity, the apical domain exhibits a pronounced inhibitory effect on the fibril growth of b2-microglobulin. Thus, the analysis of the behaviour of the apical domain reveals how aggregation and chaperone-mediated antiaggregation processes can be closely related. Mixed lineage leukemias are characterized by the generation of a chimeric fusion protein where MLL is fused in frame to over 60 different fusion partners, particularly leading to dysregulation of HOX gene expression. AF9 is one of the most common MLL fusion partners and the mechanism by which AF9 regulates normal transcription and contributes to dysregulated transcription in MLL-AF9 leukemia is poorly understood. We have shown that the C-terminal domain of AF9 binds to four different proteins, two of which (Dot1L and AF4), are transcriptional activators, whereas the other two (BcoR and Pc3) are transcriptional repressors. Adding another layer of complexity, we have also shown that the C-terminal domain of AF9 is an intrinsically disordered protein (IDP) which undergoes coupled folding and binding upon interacting with each of these four proteins to form structured complexes. In order to gain a deeper understanding of the functionality of AF9 and its binding partners in the context of mixed lineage leukemia, we have solved separate NMR solution structures of three complexes (AF4, Dot1L, PC3) with AF9. Surprisingly, these three complexes adopt comparable structures and utilize a similar binding interface on AF9 implying that there is mutual exclusivity between each of the AF9 binding partners. We propose that the IDP nature of the C-terminal domain of AF9 allows the protein to act as a signaling hub in transcriptional regulation allowing for sequential recruitment of its binding partners. Furthermore, each of these different interactions allows the function of AF9 to be altered by the nature of the proteins that associate with its C-terminus. It is controversial as to which of these protein-protein interactions with AF9 is critical for MLL-AF9 leukemogenesis. Our previous work has shown that specifically blocking the AF4-AF9 interaction leads to a loss of transformation of hematopoetic progenitor cells. We plan on using our structural data from the Dot1L-AF9 and Pc3-AF9 complexes to run classic structure-function studies in order to characterize the role of these interactions in mixed lineage leukemia. It is recognized that neurodegeneration is accompanied by the disturbance in protein turnover in neural tissues leading to the accumulation of insoluble deposits from aggregated abnormal proteins (amyloids). Diverse amyloid components are characterized by abnormal conformation, loss of function, propensity to aggregation, and cytotoxicity. The cargo of protein aggregates correlates with decreased efficiency of intracellular proteases. Proteolytic system in lysosome compartment participates in autophagy of cellular proteins and organelles, proteasome responsible for protein quality control and elimination of damaged proteins in cytosol, and calpains and caspases mediate necrotic and apoptotic pathways of cell death. Cell survival/death (and also a death pathway) depends on orchestrated work of proteolytic systems. In model animals was shown that amyloidinduced neurodegeneration as well as physiological ageing is accompanied by (1) reliable changes in concentration, localization, and enzymatic activity of lysosomal cathepsins B, D, L, (2) decreased rate of proteasome complex assemblage, (3) hyperactivation of Ca2+-dependent proteolysis in cytosol, and (4) upregulation of proapoptotic proteases. Calpains being highly selective processing proteases regulate other components of cellular proteolytic machinery and calpain-dependent hydrolysis is frequently considered as initiating step. Both amyloid-induced and senile neurodegeneration led to disturbance in normal calpain regulation. Calpastatin (endogenous calpain inhibitor) content is stable in damaged brain regions whereas the inhibitor and protease are spatially separated. Calcium (calpain activator) level sharply increases in the areas of degeneration provoking excessive hydrolysis of the substrates of cell death. It raises a problem of neuron loss and neuroinflammation. By the other hand, calpains are solely capable to disassemble supramolecular complexes such as fibrils and pathological protein aggregates that are inaccessible for proteasome due to steric hindrance. Thus, calpain hyperactivation is a crucial problem in neurodegeneration, and some proposed pathways to overcome this problem include the decrease in calcium input to cytosol, synthetic calpain inhibitors, etc. This work was supported by RFBR The transcription factor, NFκB, plays a key role in the regulation of several cellular events including proliferation, apoptosis, inflammation, and responses to stress and infection. Pathological deregulation of the NFκB pathway is implicated in a variety of cancers as well as chronic inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. Specifically, defects in the NFκB inhibitor protein, IκBα, have been implicated in these diseases, and it was recently demonstrated that IκBα is deleted in 25% of glioblastoma cancers. Previous experiments have suggested IκBα exhibits conformational disorder, especially in ankyrin repeats 5 and 6, and this conformational disorder appears to be involved in IκBα's ability to strip NFκB from DNA. In order to better understand the role that dynamics plays in IκBα's function, NMR relaxation experiments were used to measure the dynamics of the wildtype IκBα construct containing ankyrin repeats 1-6 and two IκBα constructs with stabilizing mutations. In addition, residual dipolar couplings were measured for the three IκBα constructs in order to compare their time-averaged structures. The results suggest that the stabilizing mutations made to IκBα do not change the time-averaged structure of the protein, but do alter the protein's flexibility. The stabilizing mutations restrict the dynamics of IκBα, which in turn inhibits IκBα's ability to strip NFκB from DNA. Funding was provided by the UCSD Molecular Biophysics Training Grant and the NIH.

Functional principles of the permeability barrier that guards vertebrate nuclear pore complexes Aksana Labokha, Dirk Goerlich Cellular Logistics, Max-Planck Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Am Fassberg 11, Goettingen, 37077, Germany Nuclear pore complexes (NPCs) control all exchange between nucleus and cytoplasm. They suppress an intermixing of nuclear and cytoplasmic contents, which is a prerequisite for the ordered course of gene expression. Thus, inert molecules larger than 5 nm in diameter are excluded from passive translocation, whereas selected cargos, whose size can reach 40 nm in diameter, can traverse the NPCs in a facilitated manner. This selectivity has been explained by NPCs containing a sieve-like hydrogel barrier that is composed of Phe-Gly (FG)-rich domains. FG repeat domains are intrinsically disordered protein stretches that adopt a certain structure upon interaction with other FG domains within the central channel of NPCs. Indeed, it was previously demonstrated that yeast FG domains are able to assemble into sieve-like FG hydrogels with NPC-typical permeability. It was, however, unclear if this ability is conserved to higher life forms and in how far the NPC barriers differ between lower and higher eukaryotes. We now observed that also vertebrate FG domains are cohesive and form highly selective FG hydrogels. In contrast to yeast, however, the barriercritical inter FG contacts appear not to be formed by N/Q-rich amyloid-like beta structures, but instead by other structural principles. We also found an unexpected role of the so far mysterious GlcNAc-modifications of vertebrate nucleoporins in controlling the permeability of FG hydrogel-based barriers. NOTCH receptors are transmembrane glycoproteins of a highly conserved signaling pathway that is crucial in regulation of multiple cell differentiation and developmental processes in multicellular organisms. There are four NOTCH receptors in higher eukaryotic organisms and aberrant signaling in any of these receptors is associated with many types of cancers and other diseases. NOTCH receptors exhibit a highly conserved modular architecture, which includes in their extra-cellular domain a Negative Regulatory Region (NRR) composed of three tandem LIN-12/Notch-Repeats (LNRs) and the Heterodimerization Domain (HD). Proper NOTCH activation requires a tightly regulated ligand-dependent proteolytic processing of this NRR at a metalloprotease cleavage site (S2) nestled within the compact hydrophobic core of HD. The direct interaction between the LNR and the HD masks this S2 site and maintain the receptor in its resting conformation prior to ligand binding. The HD consists of an intimately intertwined α/β sandwich containing five β -strands and two α-helices connected by several conserved loops and a short helix. The secondary structural elements of the HD fold around a conserved hydrophobic core which is a hotspot for many disease inducing point mutations. Untimely ligand independent cleavage as a result of such mutations in the HD of NOTCH1 is noted in about 50% of T-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (T-ALL) cases, underscoring their role in weakening the structural integrity of the HD. This project aims to evaluate the hypothesis that vulnerability to ligand independent cleavage results from changes in the secondary structure and/or the stability of the HD due to these point mutations. For this work, we used circular dichroism, size exclusion chromatography, and mass spectrometry to study two representative mutant constructs with point mutations on either an α-helix or β-strand defining the hydrophobic core of the HD. Our results indicate that the major compromise of such point mutations is to the stability of the domain rather than to its secondary structure. These findings are critical in delineating the mechanism of action for the cancer causing point mutations in inducing ligand-independent activation of the NOTCH signaling pathway.

Investigating the effects of a chemical probe on the native structure and misfolding of human lysozyme Minkoo Ahn 1 Fibril formation of human lysozyme variants has been associated with hereditary non-neuropathic systemic amyloidosis. Understanding the mechanism of lysozyme aggregation is, therefore, of crucial importance. However, elucidating details has been challenging due to a lack of adequate methods or techniques for monitoring this process on a molecular level. In this study, we investigate whether the introduction of a site-specific chemical modification to wild-type human lysozyme results in changes to the biophysical properties of the protein. We have successfully introduced a sitespecific biotin moiety to Lys33 in wild-type lysozyme, and using an array of biophysical techniques, we have demonstrated that this modification does not alter native-state structure and/or stability, nor does it alter in vitro fibril formation. In addition, we demonstrate the applicability of the biotin probe incorporated into lysozyme. By exploiting the specific affinity of biotin to streptavidin, we could obtain structural details of the fibrils formed from the biotinylated wild-type lysozyme using fluorescence microscopy techniques. Due to the wide availability of various probes attached to succinimide esters, the site-specific modification protocol presented in this study will allow us to introduce other chemical moieties which can be used for further experimental studies. We shall discuss how these methods can help us to gain further insight into the dynamic properties of lysozyme folding and misfolding.

Islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP, Amylin) is responsible for amyloid formation in type 2 diabetes and in islet cell transplants. The mechanism of IAPP toxicity is poorly understood. Here we identify and characterize the toxic species produced during amyloid formation by human IAPP. Using a combination of time-dependent biophysical and biological assays, we show that the transiently populated pre-fibrillar intermediates formed in the early phase of amyloid formation are toxic and they are loosely packed with very modest amounts of secondary structure. The only known natural mutation found in mature human IAPP is a Ser20-to-Gly missense mutation, which appears to be associated with an increased risk of early-onset type 2 diabetes. We demonstrate that the mutant accelerates amyloid formation under physiologically relevant conditions. We rationally design another variant at residue 20, S20K-IAPP, which is much slower to aggregate with an 18-fold longer lag phase and inhibits wild type amyloid formation. The pronounced effects of the Ser20 mutants highlight the sensitivity of amyloid formation to the identity of position 20. By comparing the kinetics and toxicity profiles of the two Ser20 mutants to wild type IAPP, we demonstrate that changes in the length of the lag phase directly correlate with changes in the onset and the duration of toxicity. Our findings provide direct evidence that the toxic species are transient intermediates and have implications for the treatment of type 2 diabetes and other amyloid related diseases. This work was supported by NIH grants GM078114 to D.P.R. and F32 DK089734-02 to A.A. The Bax to Bcl-2 protein ratio can determine whether cells will die via apoptosis or be protected from apoptosis. Bcl-2 inhibits programmed cell death in a variety of cell types, whereas Bax promotes apoptosis. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effects of carotenoids derived from saffron on expression of the oncoproteins Bcl-2 and Bax, and caspase activity in two cell lines: AGS Human gastric cancer cells and HFSF-PI3 normal human fibroblast cells. Cell viability was determined using the MTT assay. Both crocin and crocetin reduced cell viability and accelerated apoptosis in a concentration-and time-dependent manner in AGS cells. Western blotting revealed an increase the Bax:Bcl-2 ratio in AGS cells treated with carotenoids, due an upregulation of Bax and downregulation of Bcl-2 protein expression. However, crocetin induced more apoptosis than crocin, which correlated with the effects on cell viability, as crocetin was more cytotoxic than crocin. The apoptosis induced by crocetin and crocin in AGS gastric cancer cells was associated with increased caspase activity. Neither crocetin nor crocin affected Bcl-2 or Bax protein expression in HFSF-PI3 cells. These results suggest that, under experimental conditions, the carotenoids crocetin and crocin can induce apoptosis in AGS cells, via altering the Bax:Bcl-2 protein ratio and activating caspases. Additionally, we conclude that crocetin is a more potent inhibitor of cell proliferation than crocin, as crocetin had more marked effects on the expression of oncoproteins and caspase activity. AGS cells were more sensitive to saffron carotenoids than HFSF-PI3 cells. The findings of this study may prove useful for guiding future clinical applications of these herbal agents for the treatment and prevention of gastric cancer.

Kari Tanaka, Heather Pinkett Northwestern University, 2145 Sheridan Dr, Evanston, IL, 60208 A wide range of antibiotics and antifungal medications have been developed to treat infections. Unfortunately, bacteria and fungi are acquiring drug-resistance and are quickly rendering many of these drugs ineffective. In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, this mechanism is defined as pleiotropic drug-resistance (PDR). Overexpression of drug efflux pumps is controlled by two major transcriptional regulators, Pdr1p and Pdr3p. Homologous PDR pathways have been identified in other species, such as Canadida albicans and Aspergillus fumigatus. In the PDR pathway, Pdr1p and Pdr3p coordinate the expression of certain ABC transporters by binding to consensus motifs called pleiotropic drug response elements (PDREs). Pdr1p and Pdr3p are zinc finger transcription factors that form dimers to recognize a series of CGG repeats in the promoter region of target PDR genes. Interestingly, these transcriptional regulators can tolerate sequence variation within the binding site and recognize variant PDRE sites. The regulatory mechanism for how canonical and variant PDREs lead to differential PDR gene expression has yet to be explored. Differences in the PDRE motifs and in the DNA-binding domains (DBDs) of Pdr1p and Pdr3p must allow for differential regulation, making this a unique system for investigation and a possible drug target. This has been studied using two approaches: (1) Determine the individual binding affinities of Pdr1p and Pdr3p DBDs for canonical and variant PDRE binding sites using fluorescence anisotropy and surface plasmon resonance.
body_text.section: Controlling Drug Resistance in Fungal Systems

body_text.text: (2) Structurally resolve the molecular interactions between Pdr1p and Pdr3p DBDs in complex with canonical and variant PDRE sites using x-ray crystallography. Funding source: The project described above was supported by Grant Number T32GM008382 from the National Institute of General Medical Sciences and the PEW Foundation. Vaccinia virus, a member of the poxvirus family, is a model organism for the research on virus host interactions as it possesses numerous strategies to inhibit the innate immune response of host cells and organisms in the answer to infection. The importance of such processes for both virus and host demands their deep understanding, however, the majority of them have not been clearly studied. A large part of inhibitory mechanisms involve virus-encoded proteins that target the pathogen signal transduction pathway from the plasma membrane to the nucleus, and finally prevent production of proinflammatory and antiviral cytokines. Our main goal is to define mechanisms of inhibition of NFκB (the central transcriptional factor during an antiviral response) activation by certain vaccinia proteins by solving their structure and structural mechanisms of interaction with cellular proteins. The vaccinia virus A46 protein, 240 amino acids long, is predicted to have a TIR fold and, thus, interact with TIR-domain containing cellular proteins. To such targets belong important players of innate immune response such as adaptor proteins MyD88, MAL, TRAM and cytosolic domains of TLR receptors. We generated a number of full-length and truncated constructs of A46 with and without solubilization tags for overexpression in bacteria. The MBP-A46 fusion and HIS-tagged N-terminal truncated version of the protein allowed the isolation of samples suitable for the crystallization studies. A limited proteolysis experiment of the fulllength construct suggested the possible presence of two subdomains in the structure of the A46 protein. We conducted characterization of the oligomeric state of protein variants and their mutational analysis. During static light scattering experiments, A46 full-size protein behaved as a mixture of tetrameric and dimeric forms, in contrast, N-terminal truncated protein showed only a dimeric profile. A large number of crystallization screens with A46 protein were established and microcrystals were obtained, however, further optimization is required. To test the interactions between A46 and its probable binding partner, the C-terminal part of the murine MyD88 protein, comprising the TIR domain (146-296 a.a.), was expressed with a GST-tag and purified. We are now studying the A46 and MyD88 interactions via pull-down assays, isothermal titration calorimetry and NMR, as well as crystallization of the purified complex. Prion diseases are fatal neurodegenerative diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) in humans, scrapie in sheep, and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) in cattle. They are caused by the conformational conversion of normal cellular prion protein, PrPc, into an abnormally folded, β-sheet rich isoform, PrPSc, which can be infectious. Prions replicate and spread from peripheral entry sites into the central nervous system (CNS), where they induce neuronal injury and death. However, some prion strains which are conformational variants of PrPSc spread to the CNS inefficiently and do not cause clinical signs of disease. We recently characterized the histological and biochemical features of several mouse-adapted prion strains that efficiently or poorly invade the CNS after peripheral entry. We found that highly neuroinvasive prion strains formed predominantly diffuse aggregates in the brain that were sensitive to enzyme digestion at lower chaotrope concentrations, and were less resistant to heat and SDS denaturation. These strains generated PrPSc from PrPc efficiently over a short incubation period. In contrast, the poorly neuroinvasive strains formed dense amyloid aggregates that were more stable to chaotropes and SDS thermal denaturation. These results indicate that the most neuroinvasive prion strains are highly unstable, and suggest that the efficient generation of PrPSc templates may be a key property of their rapid invasion of the CNS. (Lombardi et al., 2009; Mikovits et al., 2010) , a recent study has indicated that xenotropic murine leukemia virus-related virus (XMRV) arose through recombination following passaging human tumors in mice (Paprotka et al., 2011) . Nevertheless, XMRV, which is very closely related to Moloney murine leukemia virus (Mo-MLV), provides a legitimate example of a replication-competent gammaretrovirus capable of infecting human cells. Despite a wealth of information derived from in vitro site-directed mutagenesis studies, the single-chain gammaretroviral reverse transcriptase (RT) has been less studied in structural terms than the counterpart p66/p51 heterodimeric enzyme from HIV-1 and -2, and thus is deserving of more attention. The ribonuclease H (RNase H) domain of retroviral reverse transcriptase (RT) plays a critical role in the life cycle by degrading the RNA strands of DNA/RNA hybrids. In addition, RNaseH activity is required to precisely remove the RNA primers from nascent (-) and (+) strand DNA. We report here three crystal structures of the RNase H domain of xenotropic murine leukemia virusrelated virus (XMRV) RT, namely (i), the previously identified construct from which helix C was deleted, (ii), the intact domain, and (iii), the intact domain complexed with an active site a-hydroxytropolone inhibitor. Enzymatic assays showed that the intact RNase H domain retained catalytic activity, whereas the variant lacking helix C was only marginally active, corroborating the importance of this helix for enzymatic activity. Modeling of the enzyme-substrate complex elucidated the essential role of helix C in binding a DNA/RNA hybrid and its likely mode of recognition. The crystal structure of the RNase H domain complexed with β-thujaplicinol clearly showed that coordination by two divalent cations mediates recognition of the inhibitor. Islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP, also called amylin) is a 37-residue, natively-unstructured, amyloidogenic peptide hormone that is strongly implicated in the progression of Type II diabetes (T2D). The selfassembly of IAPP in a membrane environment is thought to be central to the development of cytotoxicity and to the mechanisms of amyloid fibril formation. We have recently characterized membrane-bound dimeric states of IAPP using a combination of intermolecular single-pair Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) and constrained Monte Carlo simulations [Nath, Miranker & Rhoades. (2011) Angew. Chemie. Intl. Ed. 50 (46):10859]. In order to validate the resulting structural models, and to provide insight into the mechanisms of IAPP cytotoxicity, we used computational docking and statistical inference approaches to identify small molecules from large commercial libraries (>100,000 compounds) that bind selectively to membrane-bound dimers of IAPP. Active compounds were assayed for effects on membrane binding using fluorescence correlation spectroscopy (FCS), for effects on IAPP conformation using FRET, and for effects on IAPPmediated toxicity in cell culture. Diverse compounds have been identified that potentiate or ameliorate cytotoxicity. These small molecules may serve as useful reagents to dissect the mechanisms of IAPPmediated membrane disruption, as well as potential lead compounds for new classes of therapeutics for the treatment of T2D. Fibroblast growth factors (FGFs) are ~ 16 kDa heparinbinding proteins that regulate key cellular processes such as angiogenesis, differentiation, morphogenesis, wound healing and tumor growth. FGFRs consist of three extracellular ligand-binding domains (D1, D2, D3), a single transmembrane helix, and cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase domain. Cell surface-bound HSPGs (heparan sulfate proteoglycans) supported dimerization or polymerization of the FGFRs are thought to be required to activate the signaling pathway. The D2 domain is suggested to bind with both HSPGs and FGFs to form a ternary complex. Heterozygous mutations in the D2 domain have been attributed to the cause of Kallmann syndrome, Apert syndrome and Pfeiffer syndrome. The mechanism of action for previous studied disease causing mutations includes enhanced FGF binding affinity, FGF independent dimerization and decreased FGF binding specificity. We have recently analyzed mutations in the D2 domain that are associated with diseases causing craniosynostosis. The disease causing mutations we have selected to are located in the D2 domain. The biophysical characterizations of these diseases have shown a decrease of the receptor stability and lower affinity to both FGF and heparin. The structural consequences of these mutations will be further discussed. 1 Centre for Protein Engineering, University of Liège, Allée du 6 Août, 13, Liège, 4000, Belgium, 2 Structural Biology Brussels, Free University of Brussels, Brussels, Belgium, 3 Centro Ricerche Interdipartimentale Biotecnologie Innovative, University of Padua, Padua, Italy Nine neurodegenerative diseases, called polyQ diseases, are associated with the formation of intranuclear amyloid-like aggregates by nine different proteins containing a polyQ tract above a threshold length (35-45 residues). The formation of these aggregates could play an important role in the pathogenesis. The polyQ expansion is the only common feature among the involved proteins, suggesting it might be responsible for the aggregation phenomenon. Understanding the molecular mechanism by which the polyQ expansions promote aggregation is therefore crucial for the development of new therapeutic strategies. Most of the nine proteins associated with polyQ diseases are difficult to express recombinantly. In order to get further insights into the mechanism by which polyQ tracts promote aggregation, we have therefore decided to insert polyQ sequences into a well-studied protein, the betalactamase BlaP from B. licheniformis. We have created chimeras containing 23, 30, 55 and 79 glutamines either into the loop between helices 8 and 9 of BlaP or near the active site of the enzyme. We have investigated the effects of these insertions on the activity, the structure, the stability of BlaP as well as on its aggregating properties. The results of these studies indicate that the aggregating properties of the BlaP chimeras recapitulate phenomena characteristic of proteins associated with polyQ diseases and show how the protein context can influence the aggregation process. Therefore BlaP is a relevant host protein to investigate the aggregation of polyQ proteins. In order to better understand the interplay between the propensity of the polyQ tracts to trigger the aggregation and the modulating effects of the protein context, we have performed limited proteolysis experiments and transglutaminase-catalyzed reactions on BlaP and its chimeras. The results of these studies allowed us to correlate the dynamics of the proteins and the flexibility of the different polyQ tracts with the aggregating properties of the various chimeras. In parallel, we have generated a series of more than 20 camelid-single domain antibody fragments (VHHs) raised against BlaP or its chimeras. We are using these VHHs as structural probes to understand, at the molecular level, the mechanism of amyloid fibril formation by polyQ proteins, and as possible inhibitors of the aggregation process.
body_text.section: Controlling Drug Resistance in Fungal Systems

body_text.text: Probing site specific conformational differences in α-Synuclein and its Parkinson's Disease associated mutants using intrinsic fluorescence Shruti Sahay, Dhiman Ghosh, Paulami Dutta, Samir Maji Department of Biosciences and Bioengineering and Wadhwani Research Centre, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India

Aggregation of human neuronal protein α-Synuclein (α-Syn) into amyloid has been pathologically linked to Parkinson's Disease (PD). Three mutants of α-Syn (A30P, E46K and A53T) which are linked to early onset familial forms of PD have been reported to show altered aggregation kinetics in vitro. A53T and E46K have faster whereas A30P has slower aggregation kinetics as compared to wild type (WT) α-Syn. How these PD linked mutations drastically alter the aggregation kinetics of α-Syn is not yet known. We hypothesize that some site specific structural differences may exist in the soluble form of WT and mutant α-Syns that cause the alteration of aggregation kinetics. Here we studied the site specific structural differences in the low molecular weight (LMW) and fibrillar form of different α-Syns using intrinsic tryptophan (Trp) fluorescence and aggregation was monitored using other biophysical techniques such as Circular Dichroism (CD), Thioflavin T (ThT) binding and electron microscopy.To perform our study, Trp residue was substituted by site-directed mutagenesis in WT and mutant α-Syns at positions 3, 71 and 140. Fluorescence quenching and anisotropy studies indicate that site specific structural differences exist in the LMW and fibrillar forms of WT and mutant α-Syns. In the LMW form, Trp3 and Trp71 were mostly solvent exposed in E46K and A53T as compared to that in WT and A30P. Trp3, Trp71 and Trp140 in all α-Syns showed blue shift upon aggregation of the proteins into amyloid fibrils. However, fluorescence quenching studies and analysis of site specific stability of fibrils using guanidium hydrochloride denaturation reveal that [Trp71]E46K and [Trp71]A53T fibrils were considerably more solvent protected and stable as compared to [Trp71]WT fibrils. These results suggest that the mutations E46K and A53T cause more solvent exposure of sites in the N-terminal and central region of α-Syn which might facilitate interaction between these regions in individual protein molecules and thus increase aggregation kinetics. Similarly slightly more solvent protected sites in A30P might be responsible for its slow aggregation kinetics. More solvent protected environment and stability of Trp71 (situated in the core region of fibrils) in E46K and A53T fibrils might also correspond to increased fibril forming propensity of these mutants.Source of Research support-DBT,India.

Structural studies and inhibitor development of the transcription factor ERG in prostate cancer Michael Regan 1 , Dan Freed 2 , David Cafiso 2 , John Bushweller 1, 2 1 Deptartment of Biological Physics, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, 2 Department of Chemistry, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA Prostate cancer is the second leading cancer killer of men in the United States, and an estimated 28,000 men will die from it this year. Improved diagnostic methods have improved detection rates, but therapy development has lagged; indeed, widely-used hormone therapies are frequently overcome by the cancer, highlighting the desperate need for a novel therapeutic target. The transcription factor ERG (Ets-Related Gene) is the subject of a chromosomal translocation in more than half of all prostate cancers, leading to ERG's over-expression under the promoter of the androgenregulated gene TMPRSS2. While the DNA-binding domain of ERG is highly conserved, we have identified auto-inhibitory regions flanking this domain which are not as highly conserved and thus could serve as docking sites for targeted small molecules. The prospect of designing small molecules that can stabilize an autoinhibited conformation of ERG, thereby reducing its DNA binding activity, makes ERG an intriguing target in prostate cancer therapy. We have screened a 1000-compound fragment library and identified several lead compounds that not only preferentially bind an auto-inhibited ERG protein construct, but which also show minimal activity against related proteins. Using a fluorescence polarization assay we developed, we will be expanding our screen to a 150,000 compound library and validating hits by time-resolved FRET (HTRF) and NMR methods. Our NMR-derived structure of autoinhibited ERG allows for not only the optimization of lead compounds, but has also enabled a detailed study of the dynamics of this protein molecule. This work has the potential to greatly improve patient outcomes by developing high-affinity, high-specificity small molecules to be used in targeted prostate cancer therapy. The innate immune system provides the first line of defense against infectious agents. Essential to this response are cellular mechanisms that recognize, sequester and eradicate these invading organisms. Toll-like receptor 3 (TLR3), a transmembrane receptor found in endosomes, is stimulated by the viral genomic material double stranded RNA (dsRNA), initiating a signaling cascade that leads to the production of type 1 interferon and pro-inflammatory cytokines. Critical to this pathway is a proposed kinase complex, NAP1 (NAK associated protein 1) -TBK1 (Tank Binding Kinase 1) -IKKepsilon (IkappaB kinase), which upon activation, leads to the phosphorylation of the transcription factor, IRF3/7 (interferon regulatory factor), and production of IFNbeta. To control this activity, SIKE (suppressor of IKKepsilon) acts as an endogenous inhibitor of IKKepsilon and TBK1 through a previously undefined mechanism. The objective of this study was to define the mechanism by which SIKE inhibits type I interferon production and the regulatory release mechanism of SIKE upon viral infection. The studies presented here show that SIKE is a mixed-type inhibitor, regulating the kinases through competitive and non-competitive modes of inhibition. Through kinase assays, immunoblot and mass spectrometry analyses, post-translational modifications that affect SIKE inhibitory activity have been identified. As these post-translational modifications coincide with kinase complex activation, we hypothesize that they mediate SIKE's release from the NAP1-TBK1-IKKepsilon complex allowing for IRF3/7 activation. Using site-directed mutagenesis to alter post-translation modification sites, SIKE inhibitory activity and interactions with kinase complex components were analyzed. From these data we propose a model for regulation of the type I interferon response. This research was funded through the Jeffress Memorial Trust. Over-expression of lipoxygenase-12 (LOX-12) leading to overproduction of leukotrienes is involved in development and progression of breast cancer. This study was performed to design and synthesize novel structurebased peptide inhibitors for LOX-12 and evaluate their anti-tumor activity in vitro and in vivo in breast cancer. Ten peptides were designed and synthesized by solid phase peptide synthesis and analyzed in vitro for enzyme inhibition using the conjugated diene method of enzyme assay. Affinity of the interaction of peptides with LOX-12 was analyzed by Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) technique. MTT assay for cytotoxicity, Annexin-V binding for apoptosis and FITC-labeling of peptides for intracellular localization were performed to evaluate the in vitro antitumor activity of peptides on MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cell lines. In vivo antitumor activity of the peptide was evaluated in swiss-albino mice after tumor induction with EAT cell line. Tumor induction and its size were observed after 30 days. All work was performed with the approval of the Ethics Committee of All India Institute of Medical Sciences where the work was performed. Out of the 10 peptides, YWCS showed significant inhibitory effects in different assays. The dissociation constant (KD) was found to be 3.39 x 10-8 M and 8.6 x 10-8 M for YWCS and baicalein (positive control), respectively. The kinetic constant Ki was 72.45 x 10-7 M as determined by kinetic assay. The peptide significantly reduced the cell viability of breast cancer cell lines MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 with IC50 of 75μM and 400μM, respectively. In addition, the peptide induced 49.8% and 20.8% apoptosis in MCF-7 and MDA-MB 231 respectively. A concentration of upto 358μM of the peptide lysed only 22% human erythrocytes which was significantly lower (p<0.001) than Gentamycin (positive control). in vivo activity of YWCA showed that it could significantly suppress (p<0.017) the growth and initiation of tumor in mice. However, untreated mice showed progressive increase in tumor volume. Our results suggest that YWCS is an effective peptide inhibitor of human LOX-12 and can be used as a lead compound to complement the ongoing efforts to develop different therapies for breast cancer. This work was supported by research grant Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by plaque buildup in the brain and decreased levels of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine. Decreased levels of acetylcholine lead to decreased cell communication, which is thought to result in the manifestation of dementia, a characteristic of AD. Butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE) is a key enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of acetylcholine in healthy tissue and increases the aggregation of Aβ peptides into fibrils, contributing to AD pathogenesis. Studies have shown that BuChE activity is increased in patients suffering from AD, making this enzyme one of the primary biochemical targets for treating Alzheimer's symptoms. Unfortunately, the number of potential inhibitors is very large and the molecular basis of enzyme inhibition remains largely undescribed. To address this, we employ computer modeling and massively parallel molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of fully solvated enzyme-inhibitor complexes, which allow us to study the physical and chemical nature of enzyme-inhibitor complexation and to identify the chemical characteristics necessary to effectively and accurately target the BuChE active site. The dialkyl phenyl phosphate (DAPP) family of inhibitors has been shown to effectively target BuChE with varying efficacy. We report here our study of the binding interactions and affinities of a number of DAPP's using the Folding@Home Distributed Computing Network to collect thousands of all-atom MD simulations, including the enzyme sans inhibitor and with three chemically similar docked DAPP inhibitors of varying alkyl chain length. Several mechanisms have been suggested to describe the mechanism of enzymesubstrate complex formation and equilibrium including the "Lock and Key" and "Induced Fit" models, as well as the more contemporary "Conformational Shift" model, which assumes that a protein takes on multiple native conformations from which a given substrate can select the thermodynamically optimal conformation for docking. In this latter model, that conformation is most energetically beneficial and, thus, most populated after binding by that specific substrate. The simulated ensemble is used to evaluate the applicability of these mechanistic models and to assess the energetics of binding, the equilibrium dynamics within the enzymesubstrate complex, and the role of the solvent in these interactions. Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a devastating degenerative disease affecting 5.5 million people in the United States alone and 35 million people world-wide. From a functional perspective, we know how AD affects a person externally, but the internal processes are still somewhat of a mystery. The Konkle Lab, along with the Menze and Nathan Lab, is exploring the interacting roles of oxidative stress products 4-hydroxyl-2-nonenal (HNE), age, estrogen, and the protein ApoE in the progression of Alzheimer's. Ex vivo mouse neuronal mitochondria were treated with HNE and the function analyzed by oxygen uptake while the structures of mitochondrial proteins were analyzed by Western blotting. Additionally, tissues from in vivo experiments that encouraged the endogenous production of HNE were similarly analyzed.

Physics, Wake Forest University, Winston Salem, NC DNA mismatch repair proteins (MMR) maintain genetic stability by recognizing and repairing mismatched bases and insertion/deletion loops mistakenly incorporated during DNA replication, and initiate cellular response to certain types of DNA damage. The MutSα complex recognizes and initiates the repair of base-base mismatches and small insertion/deletions. We performed molecular dynamics simulations on mismatched and damaged MutSα-DNA complexes. A comprehensive DNA binding site analysis of relevant conformations shows that MutSα proteins recognize the mismatched and platinum cross-linked DNA substrates in significantly different modes. Distinctive conformational changes associated with MutS? binding to mismatched and damaged DNA have been identified and they provide insight into the involvement of MMR proteins in DNA-repair and DNA-damage pathways. Stability and allosteric interactions at the heterodimer interface associated with the mismatch and damage recognition step allow for prediction of key residues in MMR cancer-causing mutations.
body_text.section: Insights into protein -DNA interactions and communication: Computational studies of MutSα-DNA recognition complexes Freddie Salsbury, Lacramioara Negureanu

body_text.text: Aβ40 and Aβ42 fibrils efficiently cross-seed the opposite monomers without propagating structural details Ravindra Kodali 1, 2 , Saketh Chemuru 1, 2 , Ronald Wetzel 1, 2 1 Structural Bilogy, University of Pittsburgh, 3501 5th Ave, Pittsburgh, PA, 15213, 2 PIND, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA One of major unanswered questions of amyloid fibril formation is the specificity with which primary sequence dictates details of amyloid structure. Cross-seeding, which is generally efficient between homologous sequences but inefficient between non-homologous sequences, is often found, at least in the former case, to occur with retention of structure between seed and fibril product. It was previously shown that Alzheimer's disease related Aβ40 fibrils of varying polymorphic structures are able to propagate their structures with high fidelity through seeded growth of Aβ40 monomers. Here we inquire whether fibril structure is retained in the seemingly very conservative cross-seeding between Aβ40 and Aβ42 sequences. The fibrils of these two peptides, grown under 37 °C/quiescent conditions, exhibit similar structures in electron micrographs but significantly different substructures as assessed by critical concentration (Cr), FTIR, and hydrogenexchange protection (HX-MS). The expected kinetic compatibility between these two sequences was confirmed. Thus, in cross-seeding of non-identical monomers with preformed fibrils of either Aβ40 or Aβ42, at 8% w/w to monomers, and at 37 °C under quiescent conditions, the lag phases exhibited in the unseeded reactions are completely eliminated, and aggregation is complete within a few hours. Furthermore, the observed fibril elongation rates are very similar between comparable homologous and heterologous seeding reactions, also consistent with efficient seeding between systems. Surprisingly, however, the Cr values, FTIR spectra, and HXMS protection data reveal that the structures of the products of the cross-seeded reactions are more similar to the fibrils normally produced in the spontaneous aggregation of the monomer, and not, as expected, to the fibril seeds. Furthermore, when some Aβ40 polymorphic fibrils are used to seed Aβ42 monomer fibrillization, the resulting fibrils exhibit some structural properties that are uniquely different from both the fibril seeds and normal Aβ42 fibrils. These observations show that seeding can remove the normal nucleation barrier for monomer fibril formation without necessarily dictating the full details of fibril product structure. Our findings reveal new insights into the complexity of amyloid fibril formation and suggest that appropriate caution should be exercised when using seeded elongation to amplify small amounts of fibrils for structural studies. Prolactin is a 23 kDa peptide hormone that has many roles in various biological functions and has been linked to pathological conditions ranging from breast and prostate cancer to obesity and anorexia nervosa. It is also present as a truncated 16 kDa N-terminal cleavage product of the 23 kDa form. While prolactin is detectable in circulation in humans, the two different isoforms exhibit properties that have been shown to be in direct opposition each other. For example, the 16 kDa form appears less mitogenic than the 23 kDa in activity bioassays, but with angiogenesis, the 23 kDa form promotes while the 16 kDa form inhibits. Prolactin exists in a number of different isoforms, though quantitative tests do not distinguish between them. In this study, focused on peptides from the 16 and 23 kDa isomers, a multiple reaction monitoring mass spectrometry (MRM-MS) method was developed to measure the absolute abundance of six tryptic prolactin peptides in human serum using stable isotope-labeled internal standards for quantitation. This study provides a quick and robust method for quantitation of the prolactin isoforms, and allows for the expansion of sample processing to be developed into a high-throughput platform. A promising therapy for patients with B-cell lymphoma is based on the use of idiotype antibodies as vaccines. This kind of vaccines are based on the use of immunoglobulins having a variable region with epitopes exclusively expressed by a lymphoma. Since these epitopes are different for each tumor, a specific idiotype vaccine has to be produced for each patient. Expression of immunoglobulins for human use often requires the use of mammalian cells because these cells are able to provide appropriate post-translational modifications that cannot be obtained with other systems. Production of proteins for clinical use can be greatly improved by the use of stable cell lines that can be scaled up to reach the desired level of production. We have used a noncytopathic Semliki Forest virus (ncSFV) RNA vector to generate stable cell lines expressing the murine follicular lymphoma-derived idiotype antibody A20. We designed an expression cassette that consists of sequences encoding the following components: (1) Puromycin N-acetyl-transferase; (2) foot-and-mouth disease virus 2A autoprotease; (3) A20 light chain with its own signal peptide; and (4) A20 secretable heavy chain under the control of either a second subgenomic promoter or an IRES sequence. These cassettes were cloned into the ncSFV vector. Both recombinant ncSFV vectors allowed rapid and efficient selection of stable BHK cell lines with puromycin. These cell lines expressed A20 in supernatants with a proper quaternary structure, as evidenced by non-reducing SDS-PAGE. Expression levels reached 8 mg/L/24h, although they were about ten-fold lower when heavy chain expression was driven by the IRES element. Protein expression and yield were improved by incubation of cells at 33 degrees without serum. Importantly, A20 was highly glycosylated and showed a pattern similar to the same antibody produced by a murine hybridoma. These results indicate that the ncSFV vector has a great potential for the production of recombinant antibodies in mammalian cells. For several decades, immunoglubulinG (IgG) had been studied for engineering its specificity and binding affinity toward variable ligands and widely used in biological researches, clinical diagnostics and therapeutic applications. Nonetheless, there are difficulties in the development and use of antibody due to high expression cost, large molecule size and established patents. In these reasons, desires of non-IgG based binding protein were gradually increasing for alternating antibody. Based on modular property of leucine-rich repeat (LRR) proteins, we have engineered a variable lymphocyte receptor (VLR) by consensus design and fusion with N-terminal region of internalin B (InlB). The designed scaffold, Repebody, has remarkable properties such as high melting temperature, modularity and prokaryote expression with large amounts. In order to verify whether Repebody acts as a universal molecular binder, we carried out the directed evolution of Repebody by saturation mutagenesis of concave surface and phage display technology for selection of ligand binders. The resulting binder D3 exhibits the nanomolar binding affinity for Interleukin-6 with target specificity. For general and practical applications, we further designed repeat module-based approach for affinity maturation of Repebody. Through the method, high affinity binders were successfully isolated from additional module library and the best clone D3E8C4 exhibits about 50fold binding affinity improvement with a dissociation constant (K D ) of 397pM, and which shows inhibition of IL-6 activity in human monocyte at low doses (0.1ug/ ml). These results suggest that Repebody acts as not only an alternative scaffold but also a potential therapeutic agent as the artificial antibody and that module-based engineering method is effective for library design and affinity maturation of repeat proteins. The severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus (SARS-CoV) was responsible for a largescale epidemic in 2002, which caused 8,400 infections with over 800 deaths. Although it was contained after several months through public health quarantine measures, the potential for recurrence exists. The SARS-CoV papain-like protease (PLpro) is essential for SARS-CoV replication, and is hence a good antiviral drug target. We applied a novel approach based on synergistic fragment and known inhibitor binding to better understand inhibitory mechanisms. We have previously developed two alternative scaffolds that inhibit PLpro with sub-micromolar IC 50 values, and have also explored the conformational changes accompanying inhibitor binding. We subsequently screened a fragment-like library in combination with four previously developed potential inhibitors and identified several fragment-like compounds that synergistically enhance the inhibitory activity of the known inhibitors by approximately an order of magnitude. Docking studies suggest that these fragment-like compounds may bind adjacent to the active site, and further stabilize the inhibitor-bound state. Details of this mechanistic stabilization will be discussed. Supported by NIH grant AI089535.

Department of Biological Science, Kongju National University, College of Natural Sciences 182 Gongju, Chungnam, Gongju, 314-701, Republic of Korea Withaferin A (WFA), a natural withanolide, has shown various properties including anti-tumor, antiinflammation, anti-oxidant, and immunemodulatory activity. Although it is suggested to have a large of effects, the defined mechanisms of action have not yet been explored. We investigated the effects of WFA on dedifferentiation and inflammation. WFA increased reactive oxygen species (ROS), suggesting the induction of oxidative stress, in a dose-dependent manner. Also, we indicated that WFA dramatically caused dedifferentiation and inflammation as determined by the expression of type II collagen and COX-2, and reduced the synthesis of sulfated proteoglycan and caused the synthesis of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) in a dose-and time-dependent manner. Treatment of N-Acetyl-L-Cystein (NAC), an antioxidant, was inhibited WFAinduced a loss of type II collagen and an increase of COX-2. WFA led to an increase in phosphorylation of both Akt and p38. Inhibition of PI3kinase and p38kinase with LY294002 or SB203580 in WFAtreated cells recovered the expression of type II collagen and suppressed the expression of COX-2. These results demonstrated that WFA regulates dedifferentiation and inflammation via PI3 kinase and p38 kinase in rabbit articular chondrocytes. Monoclonal antibodies and nanoparticles are two promising classes of therapeutics that have shown great potential for the treatment of cancer. However, they suffer from transport limitations during systemic administration: [i] antibody distribution, which is rate limited by extravasation, is heterogeneous in solid tumors, and [ii] nanoparticles targeted against cancer cell markers show no improvement in biodistribution over their nontargeted counterparts, which is problematic due to accumulation of nanoparticles in the liver and spleen. Using an engineered knottin peptide (EETI2.5F), that binds to αvβ3, αvβ5, and α5β1 integrins, which are tumor endothelial markers, we have developed multiple tumor vasculature targeting strategies designed to enhance the transport of both antibodies and nanoparticles to solid tumors. We are currently investigating the ability of an EETI2.5F-Fc-interleukin 2 fusion for potentiating the delivery of antibodies in vivo.
