By causing increased vascular permeability specifically at the tumor vasculature, we would ideally improve the extravasation rate of a concurrently administered antibody and thus improve its distribution throughout a solid tumor. In addition, we are performing studies to validate EETI2.5F conjugated liposomes as having a favorable biodistribution in vivo compared with traditional tumor cell targeted liposomes. By being able to specifically target the tumor environment with these large particles, we will reduce the side toxicity of any chemotherapeutic payloads. These two approaches will hopefully be able to establish a platform for the improved delivery of antibodies and nanoparticles. All work was performed with the approval of the institutional review board of the sponsoring institution. This work was supported by The Protein Maker is an automated purification system developed by Emerald Bio for high-throughput parallel purification of proteins and antibodies. This instrument allows multiple load, wash and elution buffers to be used in parallel along independent lines for up to 24 individual samples. To demonstrate its utility, purification of five recombinant PB2 C-terminal domains from various subtypes of the influenza A virus is described. Three of these constructs crystallized and one diffracted X-rays to sufficient resolution for structure determination and deposition in the Protein Data Bank. Methods for screening lysis buffers for a cytochrome P450 from a pathogenic fungus prior to upscaling expression and purification are also described. The Protein Maker has become a valuable multi-target processing asset within the Seattle Structural Genomics Center for Infectious Disease (SSGCID) and hence is a potentially valuable tool for a variety of high throughput protein purification applications. The active fragment of tumstatin T8 (residues 69-95, T8) is an efficient inhibitor of angiogenesis in a number of tumor models as T8 binds integrin αVβ3 on the surface of proliferating endothelial cells and promotes their apoptosis. However, αVβ3 is also expressed on breast cancer (BC) cells, and, when activated, supports BC cell attachment and metastasis. We suggested that peptide T8, disrupting αVβ3-mediated adhesion and signaling, could be advantageous in the therapy of breast cancer. The aim of the present study was to study therapeutic potential of T8 in two different transplanted mouse models of human BC. BLRB mice (1st model) were inoculated with syngeneic BC cells; 3 weeks later advanced BL-BC tumors (9±1mm) were treated intratumorally with 2 mkg of T8 daily for 10 days. A/Sn mice (2nd model) were inoculated with A-BC tumor cells; 5 weeks later palpable tumors (2±1mm) were treated peri-tumorally with the same amount of T8 by the same schedule. Control mice were treated by the same manner with saline. Tumor growth rate and survival was followed individually up to 3 months. Treated BLRB mice with advanced tumors at the treatment start did not show any tumor burden decrease but their survival was significantly improved. In the 2nd model, treated A/Sn mice with small tumors did not show any tumor growth decrease, and only survival of 20 mkg-T8 treated group was improved. To reveal drug effect our subgoupping approach was used. Slowly growing tumor subgroups were revealed in control, 2mkg-T8, and 20mkg-T8 treated groups (54, 72, and 36%, respectively). Only 20mkg-T8 subgroup showed significant tumor burden decrease and 100% survival 3 months after BL-BC inoculation versus 54 and 43% survival in control and 2mkg-T8 treated subgroups, respectively. Post mortem gross examination revealed increase in lung metastasis nodules in 2mkg-T8 treated mice. As a conclusion, peptide T8 showed clear antitumor effect in both models used, although metastasis promotion was registered in the 2nd model. Peri-tumor 20mkg-T8 treatment reduced tumor burden in 36% of treated mice when applied at the start of palpable tumor manifestation and did not influence tumor growth but significantly improved average survival being applied intra-tumorally (2mkg-T8) to advanced tumors in the 1st mouse model. Obtained results warrant further studies to optimize T8 application schedule and reveal underlying mechanism(s) involved. Lignin is one of the defining characteristics of vascular plants and is an important factor that impedes biofuel production. The heterogeneous nature of lignin prevents its degradation and the economical conversion of cellulose into liquid fuels. Studies have shown that novel monolignols can be readily incorporated into lignin and that the polymer is robust against many changes in monomer composition. Better understanding of the phenylpropanoid P450s involved in lignin precursor synthesis will provide a launching pad to develop novel monolignols to alter the polymer and facilitate efficient conversion of plants into liquid fuels. Currently, no crystal structures or extensive structure-function studies of the plant phenylpropanoid P450s exist. The low sequence identity of phenylpropanoid P450s (20-35%) to P450s of known crystal structure, precludes confident modeling. Here, we present two novel sets of protein chimeras, combining large fragments from each parental protein, which allow us to test functional elements in the context of a complete protein. The first set is made between cinnamic acid 4-hydroxylases (C4H) of two diverse plant species. C4H is the second enzyme and the first P450 of the phenylpropanoid pathway and para-hydroxylates cinnamic acid. A set of 64 chimeras between C4H enzymes of A. thaliana (AtC4H) and S. moellendorffii (SmC4H) which share 70% sequence identity, contain a large number of active proteins and allows us to build a functional model of C4H activity based on fragment identity. A later P450 in the phenylpropanoid pathway, ferulic acid 5-hydroxylase (F5H), hydroxylates a downstream product of C4H at the 5-position. The second chimeric library is an analogous set of inter-protein chimeras between AtC4H and A. thaliana F5H (AtF5H), which share 30% sequence identity. In contrast, very few of these proteins are active. To address the reasons for inactivity, we have also constructed a small set of chimeras containing subfragments between AtC4H and AtF5H to determine the limits of substitution. This research highlights the utility of chimeric protein libraries while shining light onto the sequence and functional constraints of the phenylpropanoid P450s. Designing protein molecules that can assemble into ordered materials is a challenging task for protein engineers. Successfully designed protein assemblies are not only intellectually intriguing, but they can also find important applications in nanotechnology, material science and medicine. A strategy to design protein molecules that can self-assemble into defined shapes or patterns was proposed by our group a decade ago. By fusing naturally occurring, symmetric protein homooligomers in pre-determined orientations, sophisticated protein architectures can emerge through self-assembly.
body_text.section: Withaferin A-induced generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) regulates dedifferentiation and inflammation through p38kinase, JNKinase and PI3kinase pathways in rabbit articular chondrocytes Songja Kim

body_text.text: Here we report the first crystal structures of an artificial protein cage that was designed by the symmetricoligomer fusion strategy. The self-assembled protein cage contains 12 copies of the designed subunit, arranged into a tetrahedral shape roughly 16 nm in diameter. Analysis of the crystal structures illustrates some interesting features that were not conceived when the strategy was first proposed. The successful determination of the crystal structures encourages the use of the symmetric-oligomer fusion strategy to implement other protein-based cages and extended materials. Other related protein assembly design strategies and their recent successes will be highlighted as well. References Spider dragline silk, used by spiders as safety line and web frame, is exceptionally strong, elastic, and biocompatible. These features make it attractive for a large number of applications. Spider silk proteins, spidroins, are highly modular, with long repetitive sequences rich in alanine and glycine flanked by nonrepetitive amino-and carboxy-terminal domains of about 100 amino acids. The objective of the study was to purify a recombinant miniature spidroin, RepCT, derived from the nursery-web spider Euprosthenops australis. To facilitate chromatographic purification the miniature spidroin was fused to a solubility protein and affinity tagged resulting in HisSolRepCT. After induced protein expression in E. coli, harvesting using centrifugation, cell lysis , and clarification, the clarified lysate was immediately loaded onto an immobilized metal ion affinity chromatography (IMAC) column, captured and eluted using step gradients with increasing concentrations of imidazole. Following proteolytic tag removal and desalting, the miniature spidroin, RepCT, was subjected to a polishing step consisting of anion exchange chromatography. This purification strategy resulted in a purity of RepCT exceeding 95 % and a recovery of 60 %. Biological activity of RepCT was confirmed by the induced ability to assemble into macroscopic fibers. However, RepCT in aqueous solutions has a tendency to form amorphous aggregates before fiber formation. Herein, several low molecular weight compounds were investigated for their ability to delay this tendency.
body_text.section: Synthetic Biology (158)

body_text.text: The Transcarbamoylase (ATCase) from Escherichia coli has become a textbook example of an enzyme that exhibits allosteric regulation. The enzyme is feedback inhibited by CTP and by UTP only in the presence of CTP. Recent studies using a fluorescent non-natural amino acid suggest that the binding of CTP and UTP are independent. In order to understand the mechanism of the synergistic inhibition of UTP in the presence of CTP a series of X-ray structures of the enzyme have been determined including the enzyme with CTP (2.1 Å resolution, R factor /R free = 20.43/24.00), the enzyme with dCTP (2.1 Å resolution, R factor /R free = 18.31/22.14), the enzyme with CTP and UTP (1.9 Å resolution, R factor /R free = 20.36/24.48), and the enzyme with dCTP and UTP (2.1 Å resolution, R factor /R free = 16.59/21.51). In addition, kinetic experiments have been preformed to verify that dCTP inhibits the enzyme similar to CTP, and the synergistic inhibition by UTP is similar with CTP and dCTP. The structure of the enzyme in the presence of dCTP and UTP clearly shows that the allosteric site of each regulatory chain of ATCase is composed of two nucleotide binding sites, a primary site to which CTP or dCTP bind and a secondary site to which UTP binds. Furthermore, full occupancy requires a divalent cation, such and Mg 2+ , to neutralize the charges of the phosphates of the two nucleotides that are opposed to each other. Analysis of these structures provides a molecular level understanding of the synergistic inhibition of ATCase by UTP in the presence of CTP. Nitric oxide signaling is required for regulating smooth muscle relaxation, platelet aggregation, neurotransmission, the immune response and related physiological activities. The nitric oxide receptor is soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC), a 150 kDa heterodimeric protein that catalyzes synthesis of cGMP, a secondary messenger. Binding of NO to the sGC heme in the β-subunit leads to the activation of catalysis by 100-200 fold. Compound YC-1, a small molecule allosteric stimulator of sGC, was discovered to work synergistically with NO for stimulating catalysis and has provided the starting point for the development of potential drugs in clinical trial for the treatment of hypertension. However, little is known about where these compounds bind to sGC and how they function to stimulate catalysis. We have established recombinant expression of sGC from Manduca sexta (hawkmoth) for biophysical studies and previously reported that YC-1 binding occurs in the N-terminal two-thirds of the protein and leads to a closing of the heme pocket. We now provide data indicating the α-subunit PAS domain is the likely binding site for this class of molecules. Expression of the domain leads to a soluble protein with apparent YC-1 binding. Removal of the domain leads to an sGC heme domain that does not respond to YC-1 but retains tight binding of NO and CO. Taken together with our related cross-linking and small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) measurements, our results suggest a direct interaction between the α-subunit PAS domain and the β-subunit H-NOX domain regulates NO binding and signal transduction to the catalytic domain, with YC-1 binding disrupting this interaction. Small crystals of the PAS domain have been obtained and may soon lead to clarification of the PAS domain role in YC-1 binding. (endoND), and a C-terminal dsRNA-binding domain (dsRBD). With other RNase III enzymes, Rnt1p shares the mechanism of dsRNA cleavage. Unlike other RNase IIIs, which cleave dsRNA without sequence specificity, Rnt1p specifically cleaves dsRNA hairpins capped with an AGNN tetra-loop, in which the guanosine is conserved, 14 base pairs distant from the tetra-loop. Models for the substrate selection have been proposed based on NMR solution structures of RNA hairpins (capped with either an AGAA or an AAGU tetra-loop) in complex with the dsRBD of Rnt1p. However, the mechanism by which the full-length enzyme binds and cleaves its RNA targets remains unclear. Here, we report the crystal structure of the endoND-dsRBD fragment of Rnt1p in complex with an RNA cleavage product at 2.5-angstrom resolution. This is the first structure of the catalytic complex of any eukaryotic RNase III. The structure reveals the active center assembly of Rnt1p immediately after the cleavage of an RNA hairpin substrate, providing detailed structural insights into the mechanism of substrate recognition and processing by the enzyme. The structure shows that Rnt1p recognizes the conserved guanosine in the second position of the AGNN tetra-loop with a novel helix-turn-helix (HTH) motif near the C-terminus of dsRBD. The guanosine recognition not only provides the substrate specificity of Rnt1p, but also helps position the substrate for accurate processing by the endoND. Based on the newly discovered HTH motif, novel features or substrate profiles of dsRNA-processing proteins can be obtained by rational modification of their dsRBDs, which could be developed into novel research or therapeutic tools. Indeed, the results presented here explain how RNase III may recognize a specific structural motif, provide a framework for in-depth functional analysis of RNase III and other dsRBD-containing proteins, and lay the basis for re-engineering the enzyme as tools for the regulation of gene expression. indicates that it has 87% identity (at amino acid level) to the VP1 of AGMPyV. We solved crystal structures of VP1 from both HPyV-9 and AGMPyV. The overall structure of the VP1 protein(s) from both viruses are similar and match the characteristics of VP1 of other known polyomaviruses (e.g. SV40). We also solved structures of VP1 from both viruses with their likely carbohydrate receptor ligands. In both cases, the ligand binds to a similar cavity on the outer surface of the VP1 protein. Small differences in the binding pocket may contribute to the different host ranges of HPyV-9 and AGMPyV. Our analysis also provides a structural basis for understanding the serological cross reactivity between the two polyomaviruses. References Post-translational modifications (PTMs) play critical roles in mediating protein-protein interactions, where they often act as specific recognition sites for a diverse set of PTM-binding domains. To complicate matters, many proteins have heavily modified regions of primary sequence prompting the question -how do interacting proteins recognize one or more PTMs in a complex environment of modifications? We have developed an approach to answer this question using peptide microarrays. Using the highly modified histone tails as a model, we synthesized and spotted several hundred highly-purified biotinylated peptides carrying different combinations of PTMs onto streptavidincoated surfaces. These peptide arrays were probed with recombinantly-expressed PTM-binding domains and evaluated to uncover new patterns of PTMs that altered binding. Importantly, we have found evidence that these combinatorial interactions are also important in vivo. Lastly, we have begun to extend this technology to the development of new diagnostic tools for histone PTMs and to understand combinatorial modifications in several other important proteins.

The ErbB family of receptors are fundamental drivers of many cellular processes. Often playing a major role in developmental biology and pathologic conditions such as cancers, a lot of research has gone into the development of therapeutics to alter the signaling via this receptor family. Signaling by the ErbB receptors requires receptor dimerization induced by ligand binding. This family contains 13 ligands with unique binding properties to the receptors as well as differential signaling and phenotypic outcome. These ligands exist as pro-forms on the cell surface and are released by proteases for autocrine/paracrine activation. Presently, the only existing methods for analyzing ErbB ligand autocrine loops are destructive, do not permit spatial resolution, high temporal resolution nor live-cell measurements. In this project I seek to develop sensors for the quantitative analysis of the ErbB autocrine loop with high spatial and temporal resolution. To reach this goal, I harness the power of yeast surface display to obtain ErbB ligand binders based on the human 10th fibronectin 3 (FN3) domain conjugated with environment sensitive fluorescent probes. I hypothesize that this new technology will provide the temporal and spatial resolution necessary to study the EGFR family autocrine and paracrine loops in vitro and in vivo and allow a better understanding of the extracellular signaling network. Metal resistant bacteria are a public health threat because of the rising use of metals as biocides. This work focuses on copper and silver, two metals which are commonly used as biocides in clinical and industrial settings. Previous work has identified genes and proteins involved in copper and silver resistance in Escherichia coli; the Cue and Cus protein systems are the primary effectors of copper and silver resistance. Previous microarrays suggest many genes significantly change expression upon copper stress; it is possible that these copper-responsive genes could influence metalresistance. The objective of this work is to investigate the metal-induced expression changes of proteins in E. coli. Because of the microarray data, we first investigated protein changes on a whole-cell level. To examine global protein changes, one-dimensional and two-dimensional SDS-PAGE were used to compare cell lysates of metal-stressed cultures to non-stressed. These gels showed no global protein expression changes upon copper or silver stress. The focus then turned to investigating changes in the expression levels of the CusCFBA efflux pump. First, Western Blotting was performed to measure in vivo CusF and CusB concentrations after metal stress. Copper and silver both induce expression of Cus proteins. To measure protein expression levels, quantitative Western Blotting was performed. Although microarrays suggest many genes change expression upon copper stress, we found no evidence for widespread protein expression changes. Cus proteins do significantly change expression upon copper and silver stress. Patterns are inherent in the nature. Repetitive and predictable arrangements of basic units define the patterns. Recognition of patterns is not new to scientific discoveries. For example, the specific and repetitive patterns of hydrogen bonds organize amino acid residues into very distinctive arrangements that represent protein secondary structure such as α-helices and β-sheets [1] . Effectively, hydrogen bonds provide the basic unit that defines the secondary structure patterns in proteins. Similarly, a basic unit to define protein packing would produce the next level of insight into protein structure. Many attempts have been made to categorize the tertiary structure of proteins in terms of distinctive and recognizable patterns; however, discovery of a descriptive basic unit of protein packing has eluded the field for years [2, 3] . Very recently, we identified a fundamental unit of tertiary packing named as 'knobsocket' motif in a study and design of helix packing [4]. The 'knob-socket' is a four residue tetrahedral motif, where the knob residue from one secondary structure element packs into a 3 residue socket on another secondary structure element. The residue composition involved in the knob-socket motif essentially represents an amino acid code for packing of protein structure. Applied to an analysis over 16,000 helical-sheet proteins' residue contacts calculated using Voronoi Polyhedra/Delauney Tessellations, the current work extends the knob-socket model to describe the packing at helix-sheet interface in proteins [5] . In addition to amino acid composition of sockets, the patterns of sockets that pack against each of the 20 amino acid knobs are investigated. These socket patterns that surround the knob-residues demonstrate unique preferences when characterized for helices versus for sheets. In general, helices mainly exhibit simple pockets consisting of 1 or 2 sockets, whereas pockets for sheets indicate denser packing with larger patterns of many sockets. These findings have direct implication on protein structure prediction and design. References Ras is a small GTP-binding protein (G protein) that functions as a molecular switch on the plasma membrane. The first 86 residues comprise lobe 1, which is conserved across Ras isoforms as well as other G proteins. Residues 87 to 166/7 comprise lobe 2 which interacts with the plasma membrane via a hyper variable region. Lobe 1 contains two important regions termed switch 1 (residues 24 to 40) and switch 2 (residues 57 to 75) which are responsible for binding to effectors. Many groups have provided evidence for Ras existing in two distinct GTP bound conformations: state 1 and state 2. In state 1, Ras has a weak ability to bind effectors despite being bound to GTP and in state 2 Ras has a strong ability to bind effectors. It is often assumed that Ras binds to Raf kinase only when in the active (GTP bound) conformation and not the inactive (GDP bound) conformation. Crystallographic studies have shown that Raf kinase will bind to GDP bound Ras, but this does not result in effector activation. We have explored the interactions of cancer causing Q61H-Kras in both state 1 and state 2 with the Ras binding domain (RBD) of Raf kinase to determine if it is sensitive to these putative Ras states. We have found that RafRBD does discriminate between state 1 and state 2. In addition to the formation of explicit hydrogen bonds between residues R89 and K84 on RafRBD with D38 and D33 on Kras, we have also determined that RafRBD becomes highly mobile when bound to state 2 Kras. Therefore, we suggest that the conformation of RafRBD is truly sensitive only to a very specific Ras conformation and the binding of GTP bound Ras alone may not be enough to fully activate RafRBD. Therefore, the discovery of small molecule inhibitors for Ras should be centered on identifying such Ras conformations and ligands that bind to them. Excitatory amino acid transporter 1 (EAAT1) plays an importance role in uptaking glutamate from the synaptic cleft and keeping the extracellular glutamate concentration under the neurotoxic level. The reentrant helical hairpin (HP) 1 is part of the intracellular gate of the transporter. Opening of this intracellular gate, the transporter releases sodium and substrate to the cytoplasm. However the mutual movement relationship between HP1 and transmembrane domain (TM) 4 during the transport cycle is not clear yet. We used paired cysteine mutagenesis to verify the proximity of residues located at HP1 and TM4 of EAAT1. A strong inhibition of transport by Copper(II) (1,10-Phenanthroline)3 (CuPh) is observed in the double mutant A243C/S366C, but not in the corresponding single mutants. Transport by the mutant A243C/S366C also was inhibited by Cd2+. When the sodium-containing medium was either supplemented with glutamate or replaced by potassium, conditions that increase the proportion of inward-facing transporters, the inhibition by CuPh was reduced. This suggests that the cysteine residues are far apart in the inward-facing conformation. The non-transportable substrate analogue D,L-threo-β-benzyloxyaspartate (TBOA) increases the proportion of outward-facing transporters. TBOA caused a clear potentiation of the cross-linking effect of CuPh. This suggests that the cysteines are indeed closer together in the outwardfacing conformation. Our results suggest that substrate and analogue can induce a relative movement between HP1 and TM4 of the glutamate transporter EAAT1 during the substrate transport, and the spatial relationship between HP1 and TM4 is changing during the transport cycle. Funding: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant 31170734 to SQ) , and the International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology (Grant CRP/CHN11-01 to SQ).

body_text.text: The chymotrypsin C-sensitive Leu81-Glu82 peptide bond in human cationic trypsin exhibits unusual thermodynamic stability Andras Szabo, Miklos Sahin-Toth Department of Molecular and Cell Biology, Boston University, Boston, MA

The digestive enzyme chymotrypsin C (CTRC) promotes inactivation of human cationic trypsin by cleaving the Leu81-Glu82 peptide bond in the calcium-binding loop of trypsin. Our aim was to investigate the thermodynamic properties of the Leu81-Glu82 peptide bond hydrolysis reaction as preliminary observations suggested this peptide bond may exhibit unusually high stability. Recombinantly expressed CTRC and human cationic trypsinogen were purified to homogeneity using affinity chromatography. Trypsinogen was activated to trypsin with enteropeptidase. The trypsin constructs contained the S200A inactivating mutation, which eliminates the catalytic serine residue. Trypsin digestion by CTRC was followed by SDS-PAGE. Kinetic parameters of CTRC were determined using the Suc-Ala-Ala-Pro-Phe-pNA substrate. We found that digestion of trypsin at Leu81 by CTRC did not proceed to completion but an equilibrium was attained, which in the presence of 5 μM calcium contained 60% uncleaved and 40% cleaved trypsin forms. This unusual thermodynamic equilibrium was confirmed by demonstrating that the cleaved Leu81-Glu82 peptide bond was re-synthesized by CTRC to reach the same equilibrium as observed in the forward cleavage reaction. Mutagenesis of the calcium coordinating glutamic acid (Glu82 and Glu85) residues to alanine shifted the equilibrium toward full digestion, indicating that structural integrity of the calcium binding loop is essential for the high thermodynamic stability of the Leu81-Glu82 peptide bond. On the other hand, mutations of Glu79 to alanine or lysine further stabilized the peptide bond and shifted the equilibrium towards the uncleaved form. Finally, using kinetic analysis of competitive inhibition, we found that trypsin cleaved at Leu81 had higher affinity (Ki: 0.3 µM) towards CTRC than intact, uncleaved trypsin (Ki: 2.9 µM). In conclusion, the chymotrypsin C-sensitive Leu81-Glu82 peptide bond in the calcium binding loop of human cationic trypsin exhibits high thermodynamic stability; favoring the uncleaved form in the presence of calcium. Although this phenomenon seems extraordinary, it may indicate that thermodynamically stable peptide bonds may be more widespread than previously appreciated.

Insights into eukaryotic translation initiation: rearrangement of proteins eIF1, 1A, and 5 on 43S complex mediates response to correct start codon recognition Jagpreet Nanda, Adesh Saini, Alan Hinnebusch, Jon Lorsch Biophysics and Biophysical Chemistry, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, 108 W 39th street, Baltimore, MD, 21210

Eukaryotic translation initiation factor (eIF) 5 acts as a GTPase activating protein for eIF2 that carries the first tRNA onto the ribosome. Recent data have shown that eIF5 antagonizes eIF1, enhancing its release from the PIC in response to start codon recognition. eIF1 release promotes the conversion of the PIC from open conformation that scan the mRNA to closed one arrested on the start codon. Recent data indicate that an interaction occurs between eIF1A and eIF5 upon start codon recognition by PIC. We observed fluorescence energy transfer (FRET) between fluorescently labeled derivatives of eIF1A and eIF5 within the PIC that is strongly enhanced upon start codon recognition. Our data indicate that the C-terminal tail (CTT) of eIF1A moves closer to the N-terminal region of eIF5 upon start codon recognition. This conformational change is involved in stabilizing the closed state of PIC. The kinetics of this FRET change mirror the kinetics of eIF1 release from the PIC on start codon recognition, suggesting two events are coupled. Mutations in eIF1A CTT that decrease the fidelity of start codon recognition in vivo uncouple eIF1 release from eIF1A CTT movement towards eIF5 NTD as well as from release of inorganic phosphate from eIF2. Our results suggest a model in which eIF1 release from PIC promotes movement of the eIF1A CTT towards eIF5 NTD that in turn promotes Pi release from eIF2, converting it to its inactive, GDP-bound state. Rheb (Ras homology enriched in brain) is a Ras GTPase that is controlled via cycling between a biologically active GTP form and an inactive GDP-bound form, similar to most Ras proteins. However, Rheb also has unique biological functions in cell cycle regulation relative to other Ras proteins. The biological activity of Rheb is controlled in part by an important protein interaction with the GTPase-Activating Protein (GAP) Tumor Suppressor Complex (TSC2) that stimulates cell growth, particularly by regulating the mammalian Target Of Rapamycin (mTOR) pathway, which is essential to cell growth, energy and nutrient levels. Yet, molecular details of the interaction between Rheb and TSC2 are largely unknown. A truncated 218 amino acid GTPasebinding derivative of TSC2 has shown activity towards Rheb. We are using NMR spectroscopy, isothermal titration calorimetry, as well as biochemical assays to characterize important features of the protein interaction that help regulate TSC2GAP-stimulated activity. We expect to translate our findings into a more pertinent biological understanding of this Ras-protein interaction and its role in cell signaling activity involving the mTOR pathway. Heparin is a glycosaminoglycan with many biological activities linked to its ability to interact with numerous proteins. Our preliminary studies have shown the ability of heparan sulfate and a Heparin mimic, sucrose octasulfate (SOS), to bind to TSC2-218, but not to Rheb. We present characterization studies outlining the TSC2-218:heparin interaction using biophysical techniques such as such as NMR and circular dichrosim (CD) spectroscopy, isothermal titration and differential scanning calorimetry (ITC and DSC, respectively). In addition, biochemical approaches such as in-vitro binding, and digestive enzyme assays help to address structural and functional features of the TSC2-218:heparin interaction, as well as, outline how heparin might be used to help regulate the binding of Rheb to TSC2. To our knowledge, this is the first example of the use of heparin in the regulation of the Ras-related protein interaction. Both studies are expected to advance our understanding of important molecular features of a Ras protein interaction that can be targeted in the subsequent design of Rheb constructs with altered binding affinity to TSC2.

High selectivity purification screening of histidinetagged proteins using small sample preparation formats containing cobalt IMAC media Helena Hedlund, Maria Björner, Jon Lundqvist Life Sciences, GE Healthcare, Uppsala, Sweden

The histidine-tag is today the most commonly used tag to facilitate purification of recombinant proteins. For immobilized metal-ion affinity chromatography (IMAC) the most used metal ion is nickel. However, also cobalt has been shown useful in obtaining high purity with good yield of his-tagged proteins in IMAC applications. We have designed three formats containing cobalt IMAC media, convenient for rapid and simple smallscale purification and screening of his-tagged proteins. The formats, a gravity flow column, a spin column and a 96-well plate, allow efficient parallel purification of proteins in µg to mg scale within 40 minutes using fast and easy protocols to help ensure pure target proteins. His-tagged GFP expressed in E.coli protein was used as target protein to demonstrate the functionality of the formats. The results show that recovery and purity is > 80 % using all formats. The repeatability has proven to be high for all formats with a < 10 % difference from average for each run. A comparison between cobalt and nickel IMAC media was performed and our products containing cobalt IMAC media show higher purity compared to products containing nickel IMAC media while still maintaining a high yield.

Structural and functional roles of Daxx SIM phosphorylation in SUMO paralogue-selective binding and apoptosis modulation Tai-huang Huang, Mandar Naik, Chen-Chang Chang, Camy Kung, Hsiu-Ming Shih Institute of Biomedical Sciences, Academia Sinica, 128 Academia Rd. Sec. 2, Nankang, Taipei, 11629, Taiwan Small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) conjugation and interaction are increasingly associated with various cellular processes. However, little is known about the cellular signaling mechanisms that regulate proteins for distinct SUMO paralogue conjugation and interactions. Using the transcriptional coregulator Daxx as a model, we show that SUMO paralogue-selective binding and conjugation is regulated by phosphorylation of the Daxx SUMO-interacting motif (SIM). NMR structural studies show that Daxx 732E-I-I-V-L-S-D-S-D740 is a bona fide SIM that binds to SUMO-1 in a parallel orientation. Daxx-SIM is phosphorylated by CK2 kinase at residues S737 and S739. Phosphorylation promotes Daxx-SIM binding affinity toward SUMO-1 over SUMO-2/3, causing Daxx preference for SUMO-1 conjugation and interaction with SUMO-1-modified factors. Furthermore, Daxx-SIM phosphorylation enhances Daxx to sensitize stress-induced cell apoptosis via anti-apoptotic gene repression. Our findings provide structural insights into the Daxx-SIM:SUMO-1 complex, a model of SIM phosphorylation-enhanced SUMO paralogue-selective modification and interaction, and phosphorylation-regulated Daxx function in apoptosis. We also studied the interaction of poly-SUMO with RNF-4 poly-SIM and determined the binding constants of poly-SUMO with individual SIMs in RNF-4.

Designed peptide with peptide nucleic acids for addressable precipitation of silica on DNA Kenji Usui 1, 2 Biomineralization is site-specifically controlled precipitation of various inorganic compounds in exact shapes and sizes with high reproducibility and accuracy. Some proteins play important roles in biomineralization. In this decade papers described that inorganic compounds are accumulated using peptides derived from sequences of precipitating proteins have been increasingly reported [1, 2] , because peptides would be promising molecules for construction of organic-inorganic nano structure. However, there are few studies for well-controlled precipitation such as site-specific and homogeneously shaped precipitation, so far. Therefore, focusing on silica precipitation, we attempted to construct a silica addressable precipitation system using designed peptides with peptide nucleic acids (PNA) and DNAs. At first, we designed a silicaprecipitating peptide with PNAs (SPPP) consisting of two parts. One part was composed of a silicaprecipitating peptide sequence referred to the previous paper [3] . The other part was a PNA sequence, a binding module to a complementary DNA sequence. Thus, SPPP would interact with the DNA site-specifically, and then silica could precipitate only on the peptide not on the DNA, resulting in silica addressable precipitation. Using SPPP we checked silica precipitation by DLS, AFM, and SEM-EDX. As a result, SPPP showed similar silica precipitation to silica-precipitating peptides. Now we are trying to conduct and optimize the addressable precipitation of silica using SPPP with 1500 bp DNA including the complementary DNA sequence to the PNA sequence. These demonstrations would show examples of well-controlled inorganic precipitation systems using organic compounds. The system for addressable precipitation would be a promising powerful tool in nanobio and material fields. REFERENCES [1] H. Acar, R. Garifullin, M. O. Guler, Langmuir, 27, 1079 -1084 (2011 .
[2] I. A. Banerjee, L. Yu, H. Matsui, Proc. Natl. Acad .Sci., 100, 14678-14682 (2003) . [3] M. R. Knecht, D. W. Wright, Chem. Commun., 3038-3039 (2003) .

body_text.text: KB-Role: an online resource for the identification of predicted global and regional functions of protein A current challenge is to utilize all available information with regard to protein structure to assess function at different levels of granularity. Functions may be defined globally for an entire protein such the protein's cellular function or more regionally such as its ability to bind to small molecules. We will present a system that integrates comprehensive information attributed to protein structures as derived from the Protein Structure Initiative's Structural Biology Knowledgebase (PSI SBKB) and open biological resources. The types of information or annotations include protein domain assignments, the presence of structural motifs with defined functions, the presence of specific substructures, assignments to cellular and biochemical pathways, disease associations, small molecule interactions, the presence of defined pockets, and participation in proteinprotein interactions. Collectively these annotations are used to predict molecular functions as described in the Gene Ontology hierarchy and interactions with small molecules described in DrugBank. A searchable web interface to the results was created at the URL http: Here, we computationally identify residues at the interface of Arp3 and Arp2 in the Arp2/3 complex that dominate conformational changes during activation of the complex. Structural analysis, homology modeling, Evolutionary Trace calculations, and virtual alanine scan modeling were used to identify Arp3: R161, S226, and R447. The ARP3 mutation R161A reduces neurite formation but increases F-actin content in cell-culture. The ribosome is a complex macromolecule responsible for translation of the genetic code and protein synthesis. The ribosome has two unequal subunits of which the larger one contains the peptidyl transferase center (PTC), the enzymatic activity that forms peptide bonds. A 100 Å long tunnel from the PTC to the cytoplasm serves as a conduit for transport of nascent peptides to the cytoplasm or membrane translocon. The tips of the extended loops (also called tentacles) of two proteins, L4 and L22, contribute to the surface of the narrowest portion of Escherichia coli's exit tunnel. Previous researchers in the Lindahl-Zengel lab have identified mutations in the tentacles of these proteins which bestow resistance to a class of antibiotics referred to as macrolides. Although these mutants have the advantage of growing in the presence of the antibiotic, erythromycin, they have the disadvantage of growing slower than the wildtype.

The decreased growth rate may be caused by structural changes within the 23S component of the large subunit induced by non-optimal interactions between the mutant proteins and the rRNA. This in turn could affect ribosomal assembly and ultimately reduce the catalytic activity in the PTC. My research objective involves estimating to which degree the reduced cell growth rate can be attributed to (i) the rate of the peptide bond formation in the peptidyltransferase center, and (ii) the reduced rate of the ribosomal assembly. The objective of my research is to conduct functional and assembly analyses within the ribosome's large subunit of E. coli, which contains mutations within the L4 or L22 proteins. My results show a decrease in peptidyltransferase activity as well as assembly defects in all the mutants, and therefore, highlight the importance of the L4 and L22 proteins. The wrapping of DNA into nucleosomes functions both as a packaging mechanism and as a regulatory strategy. Histone variants and modifications regulate DNA transcription in vivo, however, the change in binding free energy necessary to 'loosen' a nucleosome and allow transcription has not been quantified. Here we present single molecule, optical tweezers measurements determining the force-dependent rates of nucleosome rewinding and unwinding for both wild-type and SWI/ SNF-independent (sin) mutant nucleosomes, yielding their absolute and relative binding free energies. Our measurements provide the first benchmark of the decrease in nucleosome binding free energy sufficient to allow transcription in vivo.

In this project, we investigate the relationship between the structure of a viral DNA translocation motor and its function. Tailed, double-stranded DNA bacteriophages rely on extreme internal pressures within their capsids to eject their genomes when infecting a host cell. A subset of DNA translocation motors has evolved to package these genomes into preassembled viral capsids. The Bacteriophage T4 packaging motor generates high forces >60pN and translocates DNA at rates exceeding 2000bp/s, though it exhibits an unusually wide variability in rates. Understanding these motors is important as they have many potential nanoengineering applications. Though much is known about the dynamic activity of these motors from both bulk and single molecule biophysical techniques, little is known about their structure and the structural details leading to their unique properties. Recently, Rao, Rossmann and coworkers obtained X-ray and cryo-electron microscopy structures of the ATPase responsible for DNA translocation, gp17, and have proposed a model for motor function based on interesting differences in the two structures. Key regions in this model include an interface between two subdomains lined with ion pairs, as well as a hinge region allowing for a ratcheting motion of the protein.

body_text.text: By combining single-molecule experimental techniques with the power of computational analysis, we have been able to test important aspects of this model.

body_text.text: Michael Thompson 1, 3 , Duilio Cascio 3, 4 Bacterial microcompartments (BMCs) are polyhedral protein assemblies that act as metabolic organelles in prokaryotes. Associated with numerous biochemical pathways, these elaborate protein complexes consist of a capsid-like shell surrounding a specific collection of interior enzymes. The proteinaceous shell, which assembles from many hexameric BMC-domain protein subunits, has a paradoxical function; it must remain permeable to substrates and cofactors required for the encapsulated metabolism, while simultaneously restricting the entry of competing small molecules and preventing the efflux of on-pathway intermediates contained within the lumen. Understanding how these protein shells achieve these two contradictory functions has been a longstanding goal. Recently, research efforts have focused on characterizing the tandem BMC-domain shell proteins, which assemble to form pseudohexameric trimers. In the case of these tandemdomain shell proteins, it appears that symmetrybreaking has an important functional consequence. A pair of crystal structures of the tandem BMC domain shell protein EutL from the ethanolamine utilization (eut) BMC in E. coli indicate that the protein undergoes a conformational rearrangement that dramatically alters the porosity of the BMC shell through the opening of a large central pore. The emphasis of the research presented here is directed toward understanding the mechanism and regulation of the conformational change observed in the EutL shell protein. MitoNEET is a newly discovered outer mitochondrial protein that has the ability to bind to the antidiabetic drug pioglitazone. The exact function of MitoNEET is unknown, but this homodimer contains a [2Fe-2S] complex that supports possible functions as an electrontransport protein or an iron-sulfur transfer protein.
body_text.section: The Protein Shell of the Ethanolamine Utilization Microcompartment is a Redox-Sensitive Barrier

body_text.text: MitoNEET is unique because it ligates the [2Fe-2S] cluster to the protein through one histidine and three cysteines. We expressed mitoNEET using bacterial cells and purified the mitoNEET protein using affinity chromatography. We investigated the reactivity and stability of the [2Fe-2S] cluster and key residues using chemical modification. The reactions and interactions of reactive organic molecules with the metal cluster were monitored using UV-Visible and circular dichroism spectrophotometry.

body_text.text: Cell-free generation and biochemical characterization of functional ErbB2 and EGFR supported by nanolipoprotein particle Wei He 1, 2, 5 Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and Erythroblastic leukemia viral oncogene homolog 2 (ErbB2, also known as Human Epidermal growth factor Receptor type 2, Her2) are cell surface tyrosine receptors associated with a number of cancers. Crystal structures of both EGFR and ErbB2 have been solved for the extracellular ligand binding domains of the proteins, but the whole receptor crystal structures are still not solved. We have developed a novel process of production of EGFR and ErbB2 supported by nanolipoproteins (NLPs) that allows the isolation of these proteins without the use of detergents that often results in less purity and loss of function. NLPs are discoidal structures of 10~20 nm diameter, arising from self-assembly of nanolipoproteins around phospholipid bilayers. These bilayers closely mimic the cell membrane and can support a variety of functional membrane proteins. Here we reported for the first time cell free synthesis of functional EGFR and ErbB2 as whole receptors supported by NLPs. The association of membrane proteins to NLPs were confirmed by nickel purification based on His-tagged apolipoproteins and followed western blot. The function of EGFR was confirmed by phosphorylation of he receptor. The function of ErbB2 was confirmed by binding of antibody that is specific to correctly folded extracellular domain of ErbB2, as well as specific phosphorylation of tyrosine 1248. Our method of NLP assembly allows for generating soluble and functional polytopic membrane proteins and providing a platform for structural and functional characterization of membrane protein such as EGFR and ErbB2. This work was supported funding from the NIH/NCI (grant RO1-CA155642-01A Caenorhabditis elegans is a small, free-living soil nematode. For several decades, this multi-cellular organism has been used to study intricate biological and molecular processes in fields ranging from developmental biology to neurobiology. In a complex eukaryote like C. elegans, cell and tissue heterogeneity restricts the usefulness of large-scale, mass spectrometrybased analysis of an organism's proteome. As worm cell lines are not available and enriching for specific cells or tissues is challenging, researchers cannot systematically identify low abundance proteins expressed in specifc cells or tissues from whole-worm lysates. To isolate protein from specific cells, we have engineered a family of mutant C. elegans phenylalanyl-tRNA synthetases capable of appending azide-or alkynyl-bearing analogs of phenylalanine to tRNAPhe. As these analogs are not substrates for any of the wild-type aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases in C. elegans, we achieved cell type selectivity by spatially restricting the expression of a mutant synthetase using cell type-specific promoters. Because proteins from those cells that express the mutant synthetase -and only those cells -contain the analogs, they can be enriched by treatment with alkyneor azide-functionalized biotin reagents and subsequent affinity chromatography for identification by LC/MS-MS.

Conservation of flexible residue clusters among structural homologues of the ribonuclease family Donald Gagne 1 , Laurie-Anne Charest 1 , Evgenii Kovrigin 2 , Nicolas Doucet 1 1 Institut Armand-Frappier, Institut National de la Recherche Scientifique, Laval, QC, Canada, 2 Chemistry, Marquette University, Milwaukee, WI Conformational flexibility between structural ensembles is an essential component of enzyme function. While the broad dynamical landscape of proteins is known to promote a number of functional events on multiple timescales, it is yet unknown whether structural and functional enzyme homologues rely on the same concerted residue motions to perform their catalytic function. It is hypothesized that networks of contiguous flexible residue motions occurring on the biologically relevant millisecond timescale evolved to promote and/ or preserve optimal enzyme catalysis. In this study, we use a combination of NMR relaxation dispersion and titration experiments to successfully capture and compare the role of conformational flexibility in two structural homologues of the pancreatic ribonuclease family: RNase A and ECP. In addition to conserving the same catalytic residues and structural fold, both homologues show similar, yet functionally distinct clusters of millisecond dynamics, suggesting that conformational flexibility can be conserved among protein folds displaying low sequence identity. The reduced conformational flexibility of ECP correlates with its lower catalytic activity, a result that can be dynamically and functionally reproduced in RNase A upon creation of a chimeric hybrid between the two proteins. These results support the hypothesis that conformational flexibility is partly required to catalytic function in homologous enzyme folds, further highlighting the importance of dynamic residue sectors in the structural organization of proteins. Many superresolution imaging microscopies using single-molecule fluorescence require the ability to change a dark fluorogen into a bright emitter. Our objective was to use an enzymatic reduction by the nitroreductase enzyme to convert a nitro-aryl fluorogen into a bright fluorophore. The red-emitting, push-pull product fluorophore was identified as a hydroxylamino derivative by synthesis of model compounds and optical spectroscopy. This emitter is bright enough to be detectable on the single-molecule level for fluorophores on a surface and inside of cells. Bulk kinetic analysis of the enzymatic reduction shows rate dependence on NADH and the fluorogen concentration, as expected. We used the enzymatic generation of fluorophores to extract subdiffraction information about the localizations of fluorophores and nitroreductase enzymes inside of cells. Turnover Activated Localization Microscopy is a complementary mechanism to blinking and photoactivation for controlling the emission of single molecules for superresolution imaging. This work was supported in part by Grant No. R01-GM086196 from the National Institute of General Medical Sciences.

Structural and kinetic investigations of the dynamic plasticity in the active site of the carboxyl transferase domain in pyruvate carboxylase Adam Lietzan, Martin St. Maurice Biological Sciences, Marquette University, 903 N 14th Street, Milwaukee, WI, 53233 Pyruvate carboxylase (PC, EC 6.4.1.1), a multifunctional biotin-dependent enzyme, is integral in gluconeogenesis and has an anaplerotic role in replenishing oxaloacetate (OAA) in the TCA cycle. PC catalyzes the carboxylation of pyruvate to OAA with the concomitant cleavage of MgATP. Biotin, which is covalently tethered to a conserved lysine residue located in the biotin carboxyl carrier protein (BCCP) domain, is carboxylated at the N1 position in the biotin carboxylase (BC) domain. Acting as a mobile carboxyl carrier, carboxybiotin physically translocates from the BC domain to a neighboring carboxyl transferase (CT) domain where it is decarboxylated. The carboxyl group is then transferred to the nucleophilic enolpyruvate, forming OAA. While much of the catalytic mechanism of PC has been well described, the details of how catalysis is coordinated between remote active sites remain unclear. For example, it has been demonstrated that substrates and substrate analogs can induce the translocation and subsequent decarboxylation of carboxybiotin in the CT domain, implying that substrate binding is necessary for the formation of the biotin-binding site in the CT domain. The molecular basis for this effect, however, has not been delineated. To gain insights into the formation of the biotin-binding site, we determined the X-ray crystal structures of the CT domain from Rhizobium etli PC in the presence and absence of its substrate pyruvate at 2.5 and 3.0 Å resolution, respectively. The most pronounced difference between the two structures lies within a flexible loop (Arg621-Asn630), which forms a portion of the CT domain active site. This loop assumes two distinct conformations depending on the presence or absence of pyruvate. When substrate is bound, the loop closes the active site through a hydrogen bonding interaction between Tyr628 of the loop and Asp590 located across the active site cleft. This interaction stabilizes the loop, creating a binding pocket for carboxybiotin. In the absence of substrate, the loop is displaced leaving the active site accessible to pyruvate. Steady state kinetic analysis of PC mutated at residues Tyr628 and Asp590 further support this finding. This is the first detailed description of plasticity in the CT domain of PC during catalysis. Allophanate hydrolase (AH) is a hydrolytic enzyme that belongs to the Amidase Signature (AS) family. AS family enzymes share a common catalytic mechanism, using a Ser-cisSer-Lys triad to hydrolyze the amide bonds in diverse substrates. In one context, AH serves as the terminal enzyme in s-triazine ring catabolism and is important in the bio-degradation of herbicides such as atrazine. In an alternate context, AH works in conjunction with urea carboxylase (UC), to break down urea into NH3 and CO2 in a subset of bacteria, algae and fungi. In Saccharomycetes, UC and AH are components of a single enzyme, urea amidolyase, a key virulence factor of Candida albicans. Insights gained into the structure and function of AH will further elucidate the molecular basis for catalysis in the AS enzyme family, and will offer the initial steps in the development of new therapeutics designed to combat systemic candidiasis. AH from Granulibacter bethesdensis was crystallized and the X-ray structure was solved to 2.2 Å resolution. The structure reveals a substrate analog, malonate, bound at the active site and confirms the Ser-cisSer-Lys catalytic triad in the active site. The structure also offers insight into substrate specificity determinants in AH. A comparison of AH with malonamidase (MAE2), an AS enzyme catalyzing hydrolysis on the very similar substrate, malonamate, reveals a loop in AH, absent in MAE2, that alters the substrate binding position. In addition, two residues conserved only in AH (Tyr299 and Arg307) are within hydrogen bonding distance of malonate. Studies using site-directed mutagenesis and steady-state kinetics reveal that the specificity constant (kcat/Km) ratio for allophanate compared to the analog, biuret, decreases ~200 fold for Y299F compared to the wild-type enzyme. In addition, the R307A and R307M mutants are nearly inactive. These results suggest a role for these residues in providing substrate and intermediate stabilization. Finally, the structure suggests the presence of an additional C-terminal domain unique to AH. Truncation of this domain does not influence the enzyme activity. It is hypothesized that the C-terminal domain may act as a functional linker between UC and AH. Future studies will focus on investigating the function of this domain, and the potential for substrate channeling and cooperactivity between UC and AH. Biochemical and structural studies of membrane protein usually require their stabilization in solution with detergents. Traditional detergents can be poor mimetics of the native lipid bilayer, and often purified membrane proteins show reduced activity and stability. Additionally, choosing the right detergent is often a time consuming process as one has to screen a large selection of available detergents to find a suitable candidate for the application. Lipopeptide detergents (LPDs) are a new class of amphiphiles that are engineered to from small micelles that mimic the lipid bilayer and act a universal class of detergent for membrane protein studies. An LPD molecule consist of a 25 amino acid peptide designed to form an α-helix with fatty acyl chains covalently attached to both ends . These molecules self-assemble into cylindrical micelles with a hydrophilic exterior and a hydrophobic interior made up of the fatty acyl chains. Previously, we have reported the crystal structure of LPD-12 at 1.2 Å which formed an octomer composed of 4 sets of antiparallel coiled-coil dimers. Here we report a new 2.1 Å structure of an LPD based on a different peptide sequence, resulting in a completely reorganized micelle. LPD5Q-14 assembles as a 9-mer made up of 3 trimers, each with with an "up-up-down" topology. The nine α-helices form a cylinder that encapsulates eighteen 14-carbon fatty acyl chains. The micelle has a 3-fold pseudo-symmetry and shows a more regular cylindrical packing relative to LPD-12.. We present a detailed analysis of LPD5Q-14 packing and compare the structures of the 2 LPD micelles. There is increasing experimental and theoretical evidence that G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) exhibit an ensemble of conformations, each of which could bind to different ligands and lead to different responses. At thermal equilibrium, the inactive conformation is energetically favorable, but binding to an agonist can stabilize the G protein-coupled state. For the cannabinoid CB1 receptor, mutating a threonine residue (T210) on the third transmembrane helix to an alanine changes the CB1 receptor to a fully inactive conformation that does not activate the G protein. However, the T210I mutation changes it to an activated conformation with dramatically increased constitutive activity (1) . To understand these experimental observations, we used the Gensemble Monte Carlo method to predict the ensemble of low-lying conformations of these three receptors. To validate these predicted conformations, we docked known ligands to them using the DarwinDock hierarchical docking method. Our results explain the site-directed mutagenesis data. We find that the inverse agonist rimonabant is anchored by two hydrogen bonds to W279, which explains the experimental importance of this residue. The agonist WIN55212-2 forms an aromatic stack with this W279 and F200, both of which have been shown experimentally to be important. We further investigated how the T210A or the WT conformations would change in the presence of an agonist with 20 ns of molecular dynamics (NAMD) using a fully solvated membrane. Neither of these receptors changed to resemble the active T210I mutant. The WT receptor formed the signature ionic locks found in the inactive T210A receptor. The computational docking results of agonist WIN55212-2 suggest that it prefers to bind to the receptor's inactive conformation. This is consistent with the recently crystallized beta 1 and beta 2 adrenergic receptors in the absence of G proteins with a bound agonist. This work was initiated with gifts from PharmSelex/Accelerator and finished with funding from NIH grants (R01NS071112, R01NS073115, and R01AI040567). 1. D'Antona A, Ahn KH, & Kendall DA (2006) Mutations of CB1 T210 produce active and inactive receptor forms: Correlations with ligand affinity, receptor stability, and cellular localization. Biochemistry 45 (17) The pathways for the synthesis of tetrahydrofolates form the core of one carbon metabolism. As such, these pathways are an excellent source of targets in the treatment of cancer. 5-formyltetrahydrofolate (5-formylTHF) is administered in these treatments, ether as a rescue agent or as an enhancer. The only enzyme known to use 5-formylTHF as a substrate is 5,10-methenyltetrahydrofolate synthetase (MTHFS). This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of 5-formylTHF to 5,10-methenyltetrahydrofolate in conjunction with the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP. To better understand the function of MTHFS, we have investigated the determinants of ATP binding the active site of the enzyme through site-directed mutagenesis followed by a circular dichroism spectroscopy and kinetics. Mutagenesis of aspartates at positions 124 and 154 to alanine (mutants D124A and D154A) resulted in no detectable activity while mutants of lysine (K3A), arginine (R7A and R125A), and tryptophan (W153A) substantially decreased MTHFS' affinity for ATP. Mutations of aspartates at positions 81 and 151 had little effect on the binding of ATP by the enzyme. Circular dichroism data was consistent with all mutants being folded. Taken together with published co-crystal data of MTHFS with its substrates, these results are largely consistent with a simple proximity model. The greater the charges in an interaction between a side chain and the ATP and the closer that interaction is to phosphate transferred from the ATP, the greater the effect mutation has on the activity of the enzyme.

The effect of protein shells on the antioxidant activity of protein-encapsulated platinum nanoparticles Kyeong Kyu Kim 1, 2 , Boi San 2 , Sang Hyun Moh 2 1 Molecular Cell Biology, Sungkyunkwan University School of Medicine, Suwon, Republic of Korea, 2 Sungkyunkwan Advanced Institute of Nanotechnology, Suwon, Republic of Korea Protein shells have been used as nanoplatforms for the synthesis of metallic nanoparticles for their biomedical and biocatalytic applications. However, it is challenging to maximize the catalytic activity of nanoparticles encapsulated by protein shells, as little research exists regarding their effect on the catalytic activities or physicochemical properties of nanoparticles. In this study, we used the following 3 proteins to synthesize platinum nanoparticles: aminopeptidase PepA, serine endoprotease DegP, and Clp protease. We then compared the catalytic properties of these proteinshelled platinum nanoparticles as scavengers of reactive oxygen species. These protein-shelled platinum nanoparticles displayed the catalase-and superoxide dismutase-like activities by quenching H2O2 and O2-, respectively. However, the resulting particle's size and activity depended on the particular protein shell. These results proved that the catalytic activity of proteinshelled platinum nanoparticles is greatly affected by the physicochemical properties of their protein shells. Collectively, current study indicates that protein shells are important determinants for the physical and catalytic property of PtNPs and it is necessary to screen protein shells to optimize nanoparticles. Furthermore, considering the reduced cell toxicity of protein-shelled platinum nanoparticles compared to those synthesized by chemical stabilizers, it is suggested that they serve as biocatalysts in medical treatments such as reactive oxygen species scavengers. Asparaginyl-glycine sequences have been observed to undergo deamidation, peptide bond isomerization and racemization. It has been suggested that the occurrence of the dipeptide may shorten the expected turnover rate of a protein. However, the dipeptide has also been observed to form apparently stable and functional 2-aminosuccinimide structures in at least one evolutionarily conserved protein family. The occurrence in some mollusc and arthropod protein sequences of asparaginyl-glycine dipeptide tandem repeats that are not readily susceptible to mass-spectrometric analysis suggests that these sequences may be spontaneously forming polymeric 2-aminosuccinimide structures. T-cell receptor (TCR) binding to specific peptidemajor histocompatibility complex (pMHC) is typically very low (micromolar) affinity, necessitating the use of multimeric pMHCs to label T lymphocytes stably. We report here a novel photocrosslinkable pMHC reagent, which, even as a monomer, can efficiently and specifically stain cognate T cells. We also use this reagent to probe T-cell activation, and find that a covalently bound pMHC is more stimulatory than an agonist pMHC on a planar lipid bilayer. This shows that serial engagement of TCRs with their pMHC ligands is dispensable for activation when a substantial fraction of TCR is stably engaged. Lastly, we find that pMHC-engaged TCRs rapidly migrate to the center of the immunological synapse upon activation, while most unengaged TCRs remain in the periphery, suggesting that ligand engagement enables a TCR/CD3 linkage to the cytoskeleton. This work was supported by a Cancer Research Institute postdoctoral fellowship (to J.X.) and by funding from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute In order to capture natural protein motions in protein designs, computational protein design must model backbone flexibility effectively. We have implemented a novel design algorithm termed "plastic design" to incorporate backbone and side chain dynamics. Preliminary studies suggest that designing proteins independently on multiple templates of a protein backbone lead to convergence of the design algorithm on different amino acid rotamers for different backbone conformations, implying unrealistic side chain dynamics. In our design algorithm, "parent" rotamers, chosen from a rotamer library generated from highresolution crystallographic protein structures, are allowed to vary by ±10° on any of the side chain χ torsion angles, producing "child" rotamers. Multiple conformations of the protein backbone are sampled from a molecular dynamics simulation and amino acid parent rotamers are selected in the context of the average energy across this set of backbone conformations using the optimal child rotamers of the selected parent rotamer. Previous models for backbone variability have included considering multiple states of the protein backbone when performing protein design (Allen and Mayo, 2010) or calculating backbone "backrub" motions by rotating the backbone between Cα atoms (Smith and Kortemme, 2008) . Our method both models backbone flexibility through the use of multiple templates but also enforces natural side chain movements by allowing slight side chain deformities between backbone conformations. We have found that plastic designs more closely resemble MD simulations and produce designs that are more amenable to natural, dynamic protein backbones. Ultimately, we hope that plastic multi-template design will produce protein designs that experimentally exhibit the designed properties more effectively and reliably than single template methods or multi-template methods that lack side chain deformability. One of the big promises of Computational Protein Design (CPD) is its potential for engineering "designer enzymes." A general framework to build enzymes is one of the biggest contributions that CPD can provide to synthetic biology. However, rate accelerations from computationally designed enzymes are several orders of magnitude below those of natural enzymes. Furthermore, attempts at computational design of certain, well-characterized reactions have so far produced only limited results. Chorismate mutase (CM) catalyzes the pericyclic rearrangement of chorismate to prephenate. Studies have shown that enzymatic catalysis is achieved by stabilizing the chair-like transition state through electrostatic interactions with sidechains. We have previously demonstrated that targeted ligand placement (TLP) can be used to place an ab initio transition-state structure into the active site of E. coli CM with the proper wild-type contacts. Though previous efforts have recapitulated the active site in a wild-type scaffold attempts to engineer CM activity into a non-native scaffold have not been reported. An ideal CM active site would preferentially bind the diaxial form of chorismate. This requires several catalytic contacts, making TLP in a new scaffold difficult. Increased computational resources allowing for large-scale TLP and the use of molecular dynamics (MD) as a prescreen have encouraged us to revisit this problem. We developed a partially automated workflow to find suitable scaffolds for the CM reaction. TLP was performed on a set of high-resolution crystal structures that had ligands of similar size to chorismate and that had a wild-type arginine in the binding pocket. Sequence design was performed on 485 decoys from successful active-site searches. MD was performed on 121 decoys from this set. Ten of these sequences, on 9 different scaffolds were suggested to be active. No CM activity was detected in both in vivo and in vitro assays. We obtained a crystal structure for one of our designs, based on the PDB scaffold 3QT9. The crystal structure showed divergence from the design primarily due to backbone movement at two adjacent arginines. Based on these results, we are currently creating a second set of designs within this same scaffold. This work is supported by the DARPA Protein Design Processes grant and a National Security Science and Engineering Faculty Fellowship award to S.L.M. Computational enzyme design is a very promising area of research. However, current computational design tools suffer from a serious limitation: they cannot reliably predict active sequences and thus produce a large number of false positives. Consequently, investigators have had to rely on screening hundreds of designs to find a few active ones. In addition, both protein dynamics and explicit solvation are important aspects of enzyme function and are therefore critical to predicting enzymatic activity. Unfortunately, protein design methodology rarely takes these factors into account. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, on the other hand, can model both. In this work, we develop a MD protocol that provides a reliable and computationally feasible way to pre-screen enzyme designs. Preliminary results have shown excellent agreement between experimental data and MD predictions. We tested the generality of the methodology on a larger and more diverse set of enzymes for which experimental data already exist. The method is general, sensitive (0.70) and specific (0.72). It also exhibits high negative predictive value (0.91) and promising computational performance, and will be useful for de novo computational enzyme design. This work was supported by a DARPA Protein Design Processes grant and a National Security Science and Engineering Faculty Fellowship awarded to S.L.M.

Dissecting the Determinants for Dimmanose Binding in Cyanovirin-N Brian Woodrum 1 , Ashini Bolia 1, 2 , Angelo Cereda 1 , Xu Wang 1 , Sefika Banu Ozkan 2 , Giovanna Ghirlanda 1 1 Chemistry and Biochemistry, Arizona State University, Physical Sciences Building, Room D-102, Tempe, AZ, 85287-1604, 2 Physics, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ Many viruses, including HIV, expropriate a host's cellular enzymes to glycosylate surface proteins as a method to escape detection of the host's immune response to infection. These glycans also facilitate viral transmission, and are therefore novel targets for entry inhibitors. Antiviral lectins have been proposed as agents to bind to the glycosylation of viruses and prevent viral entry into host cells. Our work focuses on cyanovirin-N, which has potent anti-HIV activity, mediated by binding to the N-linked oligosaccharide moiety of the envelope protein gp120. Cyanovirin-N has two binding quasi-symmetric binding domains, A and B. Work in our lab and others demonstrated that multivalent interactions through engagement of both domains, and/or through formation of domain swapped dimers, are necessary for potent antiviral activity; the activity can be further improved by designing covalent dimers of CVN. We have designed a covalent dimer to further explore the multivalent geometric requirements for antiviral activity, which can also act as a scaffold that will incorporate individually designed binding domains in a modular fashion to further enhance antiviral activity. In order to individually design the binding domains and to better understand the ability of cyanovirin-N to bind glycans with high specificity, we have used computational methods to dissect the determinants for affinity and specificity at the sequence level. Specifically, using Perturbation Response Scanning (PRS) analysis we predicted the affinity of point mutants of cyanovirin-N for the native ligand. Experimental characterization using an 1H-15N HSQC experiment confirmed the accuracy of the predictions. Currently, we are utilizing PRS to design more potent antiviral lectins based on cyanovirin-N by optimizing single oligomannose binding sites. Cytochrome c oxidase is a class of heme copper oxidases that reduces O2 to H2O and harvest energy at the end of respiration chain. [1] The catalytic CuB center contains a heme and copper ion coordinated with three histidines. Also there is a conserved tyrosine residue which forms a post-translational His-Tyr cross-link with one of the three histidines at CuB site.[2,3] Previously we have engineered CuB center in myoglobin by having two additional histidines beside the native distal histidine.
[4 ,5] By having another tyrosine around the site, CuB Mb is able to have O2 reduction activity.

[6] Here we use orthogonal tRNA/aaRS pair to incorporate an unnatural amino acid mimic of cross-linked His-Tyr. The new protein, termed imiTyr CuBMb was able to perform O2 reduction reaction three times as fast as previous mutant and only produce <6% of ROS in presence of copper.

[7] By mimicking all the features in the active site of native enzyme, we are able to have a myoglobin that can "breath". To further elucidate the role of His-Tyr crosslink in cytochrome c oxidase, especially the possibility to stabilize certain reaction intermediate by tuning the property of tyrosine, we are working to incorporate a series of unnatural tyrosine analogues in our model system. The design of novel protein binders to target a given protein interface is a fundamental challenge in protein engineering. The task of binder design is complicated by the many degrees of freedom inherent in the taskthe selection of binding epitope, the protein and binder backbone geometry, the position of the binder relative to the protein to be bound, and the selection of a binder sequence which is both compatible with the given backbone and promotes binding at the chosen epitope. Here we present our work using designability to narrow the search space to be explored in order to design a peptide binder to a given protein interface. We have selected the hemagglutinin protein from human influenza as a target for a peptide binder. Hemagglutinin is a key surface protein in the human influenza, instrumental in host cell identification, binding, and viral fusion. Recent design efforts have shown some success in designing key hot-spot residues and grafting these onto compatible backbone scaffolds. We propose using the concept of designability to simplify the design process, by first identifying backbone geometries compatible with the given epitope, followed by sequence selection that is compatible with the given interface and that will target the given epitope.
