body_text.section: Cold Activity of α/β Barrel Enzymes Through Directed Evolution Krystal Bowser, Nicholas Panasik

body_text.text: The largest class of all protein architecture is the eight stranded α/β barrel. This structure consists of eight repeating units of β strand-loop-α helix-turn. Structural hotspots identified on α/ β barrel enzymes that lead to cold activity may be applicable to other α/β barrel enzymes. We identify these hotspots through random mutagenesis on thermostable β-galactosidase. Chromogenic screening (blue white screening) is used to identify β-galactosidase that is active at lower temperatures. The goal of this project is to create a thermostable yet cold active β-galactosidase through random mutagenesis. At the same time, we want to identify the mutations that are responsible for the increased activity at those lowers temperatures and analyze how it altered the structure of the enzyme. Random mutagenesis was used on the gene that codes for β-galactosidase from Geobacillus stearothermophilus, a thermophilic bacterium. This thermostable β-galactosidase has optimal activity at 70°C and has little to no activity at 37°C. The chromogenic substrate X-gal was used to identify β-galactosidase activity, as indicated by blue E. coli colonies. Of 20,000 colonies that were screened at 37°C, only eleven exhibited activity. Those colonies were sequenced to identify the resulting amino acid mutations. Those amino acid changes were then individually screened using site directed primers in order to identify which of them lead to the cold activity. Anti-Human IgG is a commonly used antibody for recognizing all human IgG isotypes (IgG1, IgG2, IgG3 and IgG4). Anti-Human IgG antibody cysteinylation at one of complimentarity determining region (CDR) was found causing antibody potency or activity decrease. Therefore, using yeast display technology, we made mutant library targeting this CDR region and sorted the library, 28 unique mutations were identified that were free of Cysteine in which Cysteine to Serine mutation (C→S) represented 46.2% of all mutants that are still retain similar binding affinity. We then expressed antihuman IgG with C→S mutant in IgG2a and IgG2b scaffold. The ELISA analysis of the mutant antibody produced from CHO cells showed that IgG2b scaffold antibody had reduced reactivity compared to the parental hybridoma antibody. Further investigation showed that glycosylation was involved in interference with antibody activity. This suggested that differences in IgG2b glycosylation patterns between the hybridoma and CHO produced IgG2b mutant antibody influenced activity. We thus created an equivalent C→S mutant antibody using an IgG2a scaffold and expressed it in CHO cells. This antibody showed no impairment of immunoreactivity against human IgG isotypes as determined by EIA and Biacore studies. This study demonstrated that antibody cysteinylation and glycosylation have significant impact on recombinant anti-human IgG monoclonal antibody activity and affinity. Finally, a stable CHO cell line is generated to express the engineered antibody with secretion level of >200mg/L anti-Human IgG antibody.
body_text.section: Cold Activity of α/β Barrel Enzymes Through Directed Evolution Krystal Bowser, Nicholas Panasik

body_text.text: To study the ligand binding mechanism present in the L-lysine, L-arginine, L-ornithine binding protein unrestrained molecular dynamic simulations were used to analyse the conformational changes upon ligand binding. Our analysis has an excellent correlation with each of the two main movements described by principal component analysis (PCA), and indicated that this protein adopts slightly different closed conformations to make available specific hydrogen bond interactions for each ligand, allowing a single mechanism to attain multiple specificity. Furthermore, to advance in the molecular mechanism of ligand binding, we use Markov State Models (MSMs) built from atomistic simulations that increased the sampling for the conformational states along the trajectory. We show that our model can predict the bound state, binding free energy, and association rate of this system with reasonable accuracy. In particular, it was observed a dominant a role for the conformational selection to reach the encounter complex, previous to the induced fit to achieve the bound state. In this work we analyze the dynamical correlation maps, free energy landscape, hydrogen bond and contacts maps present in the encounter complex and were compared with the bound state to get a better undertanding of the molecular mechanism for ligand binding. This work was supported by PAPIIT grant IN215612 from UNAM, México to ASP. Catalytic promiscuity is defined as the ability of an enzyme to catalyse chemically distinct reactions besides its native activity. This latent promiscuity is considered to play an important role in enzyme evolution by providing possible evolutionary starting points for the emergence of new functions (Jensen, R. A., 1976) . The Alkaline Phosphatase (AP) superfamily is a case in point; its members often display crosswise catalytic promiscuity, i.e. the native (or primary) activity of one family member corresponds to the promiscuous activity of another (O'Brien, P. J. and Herschlag, D., 2001). This view has been significantly expanded with the characterization of Pseudomonas aeruginosa arylsulfatase (PAS) and Rhizobium leguminosarum phosphonate monoester hydrolase (RlPMH), two members of the AP superfamily (van Loo, B., et al., 2008) . These studies raise the following question: which are the mechanistic and structural features responsible for the evolution of specificity among AP superfamily members? To address this issue, we performed directed evolution to convert a sulfatase (PAS) into a phosphonate monoester hydrolase (PMH). Three rounds of neutral drift, followed by six rounds of selection for improved promiscuous activity resulted in 110 000-fold increase of PMH activity (k cat /K M = 1.6x10 3 M -1 s -1 ) whereas the native sulfatase activity only decreased by 400-fold (k cat /K M = 5.9x10 4 M -1 s -1 ). Moreover the promiscuous hydrolysis of phosphate diesters also improved by 16-fold (k cat /K M = 1.3x10 5 M -1 s -1 ); thus the evolved variant became a highly efficient promiscuous enzyme. Mutational analysis revealed the clustering of substitutions in loops that are originally absent in known PMH structures. Based on this lead, selections from semi-rationally designed loopdeletion libraries identified mutants tolerating up to 18 amino acids deletions and exhibiting altered specificity toward phosphonate monoesters. Structural and kinetic analysis of the evolutionary intermediates is providing insights into how these mutations triggered a switch in catalytic efficiency and specificity. Our results underline the versatility of promiscuous enzymes and their ability to quickly evolve a new activity via distinct mutational paths, including substitutions, insertions and deletions. This work is supported by the EU Marie-Curie networks ProSA and ENEFP.
body_text.section: The role of encounter complex in the Conformational Dynamics of L-lysine, L-arginine, L-ornithine Binding-Protein Alejandro Sosa-Peinado Biochemistry, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Kowloon, Hong Kong

body_text.text: Biochemistry, Brandeis University, Waltham, MA The substrate specificity of enzymes has been optimized through evolution over millions of years. Insights into this process can be used to inform the rational redesign of enzymes over a much smaller time scale. We are identifying the changes responsible for the switch in substrate specificity between the enzymes lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and malate dehydrogenase (MDH). LDH and MDH are homologous enzymes that share the same fold, but possess strict specificity for their respective substrates, pyruvate for LDH and oxaloacetate for MDH. LDH has evolved from MDH four separate times in their evolutionary history. One example is the evolution of Apicomplexan LDHs via a lateral gene transfer of a bacterial MDH. The most obvious difference between modern Apicomplexan MDHs and LDHs is a six amino acid insertion within the catalytic loop of LDHs. However, incorporating this insertion into a modern Apicomplexan MDH does not switch specificity and reduces oxaloacetate specificity only 70-fold. Using ancestral sequence reconstruction, we have identified the critical residues responsible for the evolution of pyruvate specificity in Apicomplexan LDHs from the ancestral MDH transferred from bacteria. The specificity switch is correlated with the six amino acid insertion in the catalytic loop as well as a mutation from Arg to Lys at position 102. In the ancestral MDH background, the six amino acid insertion is responsible for a 500-fold increase in pyruvate specificity with no loss in oxaloacetate specificity. Subsequently mutating the Arg at position 102 to Lys accounts for an additional 10-fold specificity increase toward pyruvate while reducing oxaloacetate specificity 630-fold. Pyruvate specificity of the doubly mutated ancestral MDH is only 10-fold less than the modern Apicomplexan LDH from P.falciparum LDH. The inability to switch specificity in the modern Apicomplexan MDH and the incomplete specificity switch of the mutated ancestor suggests that one or more additional, less obvious mutations are responsible for the complete switch in substrate specificity. Research Supported by NIH R01GM096053. Understanding the basis of enzymatic substrate specificity is a central problem in protein biochemistry. During the evolutionary history of the lactate and malate dehydrogenase (L/MDH) superfamily, substrate specificity has switched from malate to lactate four independent times, each time by a distinct mechanism. Hence the L/MDH enzymes are an ideal model system for exploring the biophysical basis of both substrate specificity and convergent evolution at the molecular level. In the trichomonads, an order of amitochondriate protists, an unusual LDH evolved from an MDH via a relatively recent gene duplication. The MDH in Trichomonas vaginalis has high malate activity and little lactate activity, while the LDH has both malate and lactate activity. In the L/MDH superfamily, residue 102 is generally accepted as a major contributor to substrate specificity. In MDHs, position 102 is an arginine, whereas in canonical LDHs it is a glutamine. It has been shown previously that the Q102R mutation in Bacillus stearothermophilus LDH converts the enzyme to a highly specific MDH. The Trichomonas LDH has a leucine at the 102 position, suggesting that it may similarly be responsible for the switch in substrate specificity. However, we have shown that mutation of the 102 residue in the Trichomonas proteins has relatively little effect. To further investigate what is responsible for the mechanistic basis of substrate specificity in Trichomonas enzymes, as well as how the divergence came about, we have reconstructed three ancestral proteins: the last common ancestor (LCA) of trichomonad LDHs, the LCA of trichomonad MDHs, and the LCA of the MDH and LDH proteins. Unlike the modern enzymes, mutation of residue 102 causes large changes in activity in the ancestral constructs. In addition, we have solved the crystal structure of the modern-day Trichomonas LDH. Comparison of this structure with other LDHs and MDHs and mapping of evolutionary changes onto it reveals other regions of the protein possibly responsible for substrate specificity. Domains are the structural building blocks of proteins capable of autonomous folding. Their modular recombination gives rise to proteins with different functions. We identified an archaeal protein family, which contains a β-clam domain in context not of a AAA protein but of a C-terminal domain that has no significant sequence similarity to known domains. Here, we present the biochemical and crystallographic characterization of open reading frame number 1500 from Pyrococcus horikoshii, revealing that the C-domain forms a homohexameric twelve-bladed β-propeller, which we therefore name HP12 (homohexameric propeller with 12 blades). The structural similarity of the blades of HP12 to the superfamily of WD40-repeat propellers (RMSD < 1.8 Å over 70 residues), and structure-based sequence alignments substantiate a homologous relationship to β-propellers. Additionally, the two blades of a monomer have retained traces of an ancient duplication event, suggesting that fully amplified monomeric β-propellers evolved via oligomeric intermediates encoded by single-bladed ancestors. This supports our scenario that folded domains themselves arose by repetition and recombination of a set of ancestral peptides, one of which is the four-stranded β-meander corresponding to a propeller blade. Furthermore, we show that HP12 forms a ternary complex with a translationally coupled type III endonuclease and DNA implying a function in base excision repair. Because HP12 resembles DNA sliding clamps in pore size, charge distribution, and symmetry, we propose that HP12 is a PCNA analog. The ability of HP12 to encircle DNA provides a functional reason for the evolution of this oligomeric propeller with the, to our knowledge, largest number of blades and size of the central pore among all β-propellers characterized so far. This work was funded by the Max Planck Society (to ANL).
body_text.section: Evolution of Pyruvate Specificity in Apicomplexan Lactate Dehydrogenases Jeffrey Boucher, Douglas Theobald

body_text.text: Protein Potential Energy Minimization Using Slice Chain Max-Sum Algorithm Naoto Inose 1 , Takahiro Shinozaki 2 , Shiqiao Du 1 , Sadaoki Furui 1 , Masakazu Sekijima 1 1 Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan, 2 Chiba University, Chiba, Japan

One of the most popular approaches with ab initio structure prediction is the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method.It formalizes the structure prediction problem as a minimum energy search problem in a potential landscape. However, it doesn't perform well for large molecules such as proteins since the search space expands exponentially with the increase of the number of atoms. In order to solve this problem, Slice Chain Max-Sum (SCMS) algorithm has been proposed. It represents a potential function by a factor graph, and combines MCMC sampling and optimal sample sequence selection by the max-sum algorithm. Although it has been shown that SCMS is more efficient than MCMC, a limitation is that it only considers inner-molecular forces. Another limitation is that it has a difficulty in finding the lowest potential energy state requiring very long time before escaping from local minima using a proposal distribution with a very small variance for the sampling process. In this work, we develop SCMS2.0 by incorporating van der Waals forces to SCMS and improving the sampling process by introducing a quasi-Newton method. Experimental results show that SCMS2.0 is more efficient than the MCMC and the conventional SCMS methods for large molecules. Right handed supersecondary structures are the dominant form in alpha helical and alpha/beta proteins. The predominance of right-handed beta-alpha-beta units over left-handed was originally explained in terms of thermodynamic and kinetic stability. Previously our lab proposed an alternative mechanism to explain this phenomenon (Cole & Bystroff, 2009 ). Our model, the phone cord effect can be observed whenever beta sheet contacts are made before the crossover helix is fully formed, and if the backbone angles of the forming helix follow the most favorable energetic path. Whenever this occurs, a torque is generated on the ends of the helix by its folding. We propose that this torque is responsible for stabilizing the right handed crossovers while destabilizing left handed crossovers. The formation of right handed supersecondary structures relieves some of the torsional stress; this mechanism also provides an explanation for the folding mechanism of knotted proteins. Here we use simplified molecular simulations with a structure-based Gõ potential to probe the torsional stress generated by the folding of a helix in a linear chain, in a circular chain with a pivot, and in a circular chain with no pivot. The simulated folding rates were compared with measured folding rates determined using NMR line-shape analysis of 15N labeled peptides derived from the ribosomal protein L9 (Kuhlman et al, 1997) . The constructs contain a strong helixforming sequence, and 0, 1 and 2 disulfide bonds at the ends of the chain. Knotted proteins are presented as a topological manifestation of the phone cord effect. In Gõ simulations using a knotted protein as the template, we showed that an increased stiffness of the polypeptide chain leads to an increased likelihood of successful knot formation if the knot forming step is late in the folding pathway and passes through a slip-knot intermediate.

is a central challenge in computational structural biology. The folding dynamics of proteins suggest that they hop between local minima in their corresponding energy surface during the folding process and many proteins even transition between a functionally diverse set of states under normal physiologic conditions. The high dimensionality of the conformational space and ruggedness of the corresponding energy surface limits simulations of this folding process and mapping of these functional states to characterizations of small systems. Only probabilistic search algorithms are computationally efficient enough to effectively extend to larger proteins. Description : Probabilistic search algorithms promise to generally address this problem on larger systems. We propose a novel probabilistic search framework to map the conformational space relevant for biologically activity by efficiently sampling local minima in the protein energy surface. The proposed framework falls in the category of basin hopping techniques which have been shown to be more effective than simulated annealing alone. The framework represents a unified strategy, combining approaches common to evolutionary computation, robotics, and computational biology. We define three major components of the framework which are combined to form a specific algorithmic realization.
body_text.section: Right handed supersecondary structures and the phone cord effect in silico and in vitro

body_text.text: (1) A greedy local search employing fragment-based assembly optimizes local minima. (2) A perturbation move jumps out of an already sampled local minima to a new, unexplored, region of the conformational space. (3) An ensemble selection mechanism maintains a balance of conformations corresponding to local minima which are both low in energy and cover a geometrically diverse set of structures. Conclusions : Experiments on diverse protein systems show that the framework effectively characterizes the conformational space populated by proteins at equilibrium. A detailed analysis of the framework shows how the proposed components bias sampling towards equilibrium conformations. Moreover, the energy minima obtained from the application of the framework to different protein systems correctly captures the known functional states of these systems. Phosphofructokinase-2 (Pfk-2) from Escherichia coli is a dimer showing an intriguing cold denaturation process that leads to a monomeric state with low content of secondary structure, as shown by sedimentation velocity and equilibrium CD, DLS and fluorescence experiments.
body_text.section: Right handed supersecondary structures and the phone cord effect in silico and in vitro

body_text.text: Although equilibrium experiments with different protein concentrations have demonstrated both dissociation and unfolding of the monomers upon cold denaturation, whether both processes occur simultaneously during kinetic unfolding remains unexplored. Amide hydrogen/ deuterium (H/ 2 H) exchange mass spectrometry has been successfully applied for understanding local structural properties of protein, changes in solvent accessibility upon folding and to study protein-protein interactions. We used this method to follow cold denaturation of Pfk-2 in deuterated water after various times of incubation at 4° C by measuring deuteron incorporation by MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry of 8 different regions of Pfk-2 (representing both the interface and representative regions of the structure) produced after pepsin digestion. Samples taken between 0-12 hours after exposure to low temperature show similar increases in exchange across all of the regions but lower than the maximum exchange expected for unfolded proteins, thus describing a globally expanded but not completely unfolded conformation. Fitting the maximum of deuterons incorporated for each peptide over time to an exponential function shows that the rate of unfolding for each peptide is similar, thus suggesting that coldinduced unfolding of Pfk-2 is a global process that leads to an increase in solvent accessibility and a consequent expansion of the protein. The rate of unfolding of Pfk-2 monitored by H/D exchange is, on average, 1.3x10 -4 ± 0.3x10 -4 s -1 . A similar rate was obtained by monitoring intrinsic fluorescence changes during cold denaturation. These results suggest that cold denaturation of Pfk-2 leads to a partially unfolded monomeric state reached by solvent penetration, where dimer dissociation and global unfolding occur simultaneously. Fondecyt 1090336 and 1110137. The energy-based refinement of protein structures to atomic-level accuracy remains a major challenge in structural biology. Energy-based refinement is mainly dependent on two components: (1) sufficiently accurate force fields, and (2) efficient conformational space search algorithms. Focusing on the latter, we developed a high-resolution Replica Exchange Monte Carlobased refinement algorithm called REMC-GRID. This method takes a three-dimensional protein structure as input and, employing an all-atom force field, attempts to improve the energy of the structure by randomly selecting residues and perturbing the backbone dihedral angles. GRID, another refinement algorithm that we had developed previously, similarly improves the energy of protein structures, but is deterministic and perturbs the backbone dihedrals and conformation of all the residues in a sequential fashion. We applied REMC-GRID and GRID to 10 high-resolution (≤ 2.8 Å) crystal structures from the Protein Data Bank and measured the energy improvements obtained and the computation times required to achieve them. REMC-GRID produced better energy improvements than GRID alone and was only moderately more expensive in the use of computational resources. In another set of experiments, we created decoy structures by randomly perturbing the backbone dihedrals, and then tested the ability of the two algorithms to return the structures back to the native conformation. REMC-GRID resulted in better recapitulation of the native conformation than GRID as measured by backbone RMSD. Unpaired cysteine residues in the hydrophobic core of proteins may impair their structure, dynamics, stability and function, and may present potential targets for selfassociation and undesired modifications. In therapeutic antibodies, the impact of incomplete disulfide bond formation raises concerns regarding efficacy and safety. Recently, an unformed disulfide bond between C22 and C96 was observed in 32% of the V H domain of Monoclonal Antibody A (MAb A). Alternatively, a variant of this domain containing V99G/V100S mutations (GS-MAb A) was found to fully form the disulfide bond. Standard biophysical methods have been applied to characterize the thermodynamic stability and kinetics of the folding of the MAb A and GS-MAb A V H domains. Both domains were found to fold via a threestate mechanism, consisting of a weakly cooperative native to intermediate transition (N↔I) and a highly cooperative intermediate to unfolded transition (I↔U). The high cooperativity of the I↔U transition is indicative of the burial of a large hydrophobic surface, which is reflected by the large change in free energy associated with this transition, roughly 7-10 kcal/mol. The high stability and cooperativity suggest the I↔U transition is the major step in the folding reaction of MAb A. The folding reaction of the U→I step in wild-type MAb A reveals two kinetic phases, both of which extrapolate to submillisecond folding times in the absence of denaturant while the analogous folding reaction of the GS-MAb A variant is slowed by at least 3 orders of magnitude. These results support the hypothesis that rapid folding from the unfolded form of MAb A may bury C22 and C96, preventing their oxidation by the disulfide redox machinery of the ER. Understanding the relationship between sequence, folding and disulfide bond formation in IgG domains could provide valuable insights for rational antibody design in pharmaceutical drug development. Alpha helices are one of the basic units of protein secondary structure, and the interaction between two helices is therefore crucial to understanding tertiary and higher-order folds. Structural and sequence motifs can help by precisely describing a specific type of helixhelix interaction and highlighting the crucial residues. Moreover, comparing subtle variations in these motifs between soluble and membrane proteins can shed light on the different constraints faced in each environment and elucidate the as-yet unsolved puzzle of membrane protein folding. To find recurring sequence-structure motifs, we constructed a helix-pair library from highquality non-redundant X-ray structures. Here we present about a dozen of sequence-structure motifs in various orientations and handedness, including soluble coiled-coil motifs and transmembrane small-residue motifs (GxxxG and GxxxxxxG) and non-small-residue ones. By studying the distributions of interhelical distance and crossing-angle, the geometries of soluble and membrane helix-helix interactions are compared. Besides conventional left-handed soluble coiled-coil motifs, right-handed ones in different sequence repeats are discovered. The influence of sequence context on the packing geometry of transmembrane small-residue motifs is investigated. Interaction between critical residues in non-small residue motifs are also marked. Transmebrane small-residue motifs show structural and sequence analogy to some soluble coiled-coil ones. Such characterization of the motifs will greatly improve our understanding of the sequence-structure-function relationship in helical proteins. They also provide structural basis for molecular modeling and rational templates for protein design. Δ98Δ and Δ78Δ are two functional all-β sheet variants of IFABP (intestinal fatty acid binding protein) that were generated by controlled proteolysis. These frameworks became useful to study the molecular determinants related to aggregation of β-barrel proteins. Albeit displaying increased conformational plasticity, these variants exhibit a native-like β-barrel topology and are able to support a cooperative folding behavior. Remarkably, although full length IFABP and Δ98Δ are monomers in solution (1,2), Δ78Δ adopts a stable dimeric structure (3) . Despite the fact that naturally occurring β-sheet proteins avoid edge-to-edge aggregation, the addition of the structure-promoting co-solvent 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol (TFE) can induce conformational changes that might trigger the onset of aggregation. With the aim of identifying the structural features involved in promoting or delaying aggregation, we compare here the effects of TFE on the structure and the propensity to aggregate of IFABP, Δ98Δ and Δ78Δ. In all cases, turbidity measurements at 350 nm revealed a maximum value at around 25% v/v. Furthermore, Congo Red and Thioflavin-T binding to the aggregates suggest an amyloid-like character, a fact consistent with data from transmission electron microscopy (TEM) that do not exclude their fibrillar morphology. In addition, substantial effects of TFE at various concentrations on the overall protein conformation were assessed by fluorescence and circular dichroism spectroscopies. The constructs share a common nucleation-elongation mechanism, whereby the population of stable dimeric nuclei occurs prior to the association of protein to the growing aggregates. Unexpectedly, the intrinsic conformational stability of IFABP and its truncated forms do not correlate with their tendency to aggregate. These findings appear at odds with the established notion that a perturbation of the native compact fold should necessarily favor the population of aggregationprone species. This work was supported by CONICET, ANPCyT and UBACyT. 1
body_text.section: Direct Observation Of Solvent Penetration During Cold Denaturation Of Pfk-2 By Amide Hydrogen/ Deuterium (H/ 2 H) Exchange Mass Spectrometry

body_text.text: Biochemistry & Microbiology, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ It has been known for some time that many and possibly all proteins can adopt an amyloid structure under appropriate solution conditions. It has been argued that the cross-beta structure characteristic of amyloid is the default for polypeptides, the native structure having been engineered by Nature to be marginally more stable under native conditions. Protein misfolding diseases arise when conformational excursions from the native form lead to amyloid type aggregation, Alzheimer's and Creutzfeld-Jacob Diseases being prominent examples. The transition to the amyloid conformation must entail dramatic changes in the interactions of the protein with solvent water. The expulsion of water of hydration from biomolecular surfaces when these surfaces come together usually leads to a volume increase. To probe these interactions and the role of water of hydration we have used capillary dilatometry to measure the change in volume of β-lactoglobulin when unpolymerized protein is mixed with pre-formed β-lactoglobulin amyloid seeds. The result is a large immediate decrease in volume followed by a very slow further decrease which is not complete after 18 hours. The ΔV of the fast phase, which is over in ~5 minutes, is -100 mL/ mol of protein polymerized. For amyloid to form, the protein must unfold, which causes a decrease in volume, following which the aggregation would be expected to yield a volume increase. The observed ΔV is the net result. The result is counterintuitive, as the high stability of the amyloid aggregate suggests tight packing and thus large interprotein surface contacts, which were expected to dominate the behavior. It is possible that considerable hydration remains. It is also possible that solvent contact of many peptide bonds through their π electrons affects the water differently from other average types of protein surface. Supported by the New Jersey Agriculture Experiment Station and an anonymous private source. Hydrogen Exchange Mass Spectrometry (HXMS) has great potential as an approach to explore native protein folding landscapes without unfolding the protein that requires a minimal amount of protein. This technique capitalizes on the ability of amide hydrogen atoms of proteins to undergo exchange with those in the surrounding solvent with a certain intrinsic rate constant (kint). Parameters that encode a protein landscape can easily be extracted from HX in two limiting regimes. When the folding rate constant (kf) is much less than kint (EX1), HX reports on the unfolding rate constant ku, while when kf is much greater than kint (EX2), HX reveals the unfolding equilibrium constant (ku/kf). However, for many proteins, accessing either regime requires significant perturbation of their landscape through changing pH, temperature and/or adding denaturant. Decoding protein folding landscapes in the regime intermediate between EX1 and EX2, known as EXX, is therefore critical for applying HXMS to native proteins under physiological conditions. Here we present numerical simulations modeling HXMS for a group of biophysically characterized proteins that provide the foundation for decoding landscapes undergoing EXX exchange. The ability to extract landscape parameters from HXMS regardless of regime will help us extend its potential to study proteins whose landscapes are not accessible by traditional techniques. Institute of Nanotechnology, KIT, Karlsruhe, Germany Evolution has selected a protein's sequence to be consistent with the native state geometry, as this configuration must be both thermodynamically stable and kinetically accessible to prevent misfolding and loss of function. In simple protein geometries, such as coiled-coil helical bundles, symmetry produces a competing, globally-different, near mirror image with identical secondary structure and similar native contact interactions. Experimental techniques like circular dichroism, which rely on probing secondary structure content, cannot readily distinguish these folds. Here, we want to clarify whether the native fold and mirror image are energetically competitive by investigating the free energy landscape of three-helix bundles. This study [1] employs the structure prediction forcefield PFF01/02, explicit solvent replica exchange molecular dynamics (REMD) with the Amber94 forcefield, and structurebased simulations (http://smog.ucsd.edu) based on energy landscape theory. We observe that the native fold and its mirror image have the similar enthalpic stability and are thermodynamically competitive. There is evidence that the mirror fold has faster folding kinetics and could function as a kinetic trap. All together, our simulations suggest that mirror images might not just be a computational annoyance but are competing folds which might switch depending on environmental conditions or functional considerations. [ Monoclonal antibody (MAb) IgG1 is composed of 12 classic β-sandwich immunoglobulin domains. Each domain has a highly conserved intra-chain disulfide bond, suggesting an important role of this disulfide in antibody structure and stability. We have observed IgG1 variants containing at least one unformed intra-chain disulfide bond in a few therapeutic MAbs, i.e. the cysteines (Cys) remain as free thiols. These variants often elute as distinct peaks in reversed-phased chromatography. The presence of unpaired Cys in the hydrophobic core of a therapeutic MAb raises potential concerns regarding MAb drug safety and efficacy due to 1) potential altered structure, 2) change in dynamics, 3) loss of stability, and 4) consequently impaired function. We have used MAb A as a model system to investigate the consequences of unpaired Cys in antibody. About 32% of MAb A molecules contain an unformed disulfide bond in the V H domain. This MAb A variant was first observed by reversed-phase chromatography and later confirmed by mass spectrometry and peptide map analyses. With an ion-exchange chromatography method, we have separated the Fab fragment of the MAb A variant containing unpaired Cys from its intact form with the disulfide linkage. The isolation of free thiol containing Fab from MAb A enabled the characterization of its crystal structure, dynamics and antigen-binding activity. We have also explored the possible causes of unpaired Cys in antibodies by comparing MAb A to two other MAbs, MAb B and MAb C. Approximately 54% of MAb B molecules contain the same unformed disulfide bond in the V H domain as found in MAb A. By contrast, no significant amount of unpaired Cys was found in the V H domain of MAb C. A series of mutations introduced into the heavy chain CDR III region revealed that a few key residues in this region are critically linked to the amount of variants containing unpaired Cys in these three MAbs. We hypothesize that the unformed intrachain disulfide bond in MAb A is caused by a sequence dependent fast protein folding process that traps Cys residues in the reduced form during protein synthesis. In order to test this hypothesis, thermodynamic and kinetic folding properties of the MAb A V H domain and its mutants were studied by standard biophysical methods (see a separate poster by Cohen et al.) . Understanding the causes for unformed disulfide bonds in IgGs could provide valuable insights for rational MAb design in pharmaceutical drug development. Bacterial division is initiated by the formation of the Z-ring and the later sequential addition of around 12 other proteins. FtsZ is the unit of this ring that polymerizes into single filaments. On one hand, a dimer has been proposed to be the nucleus of this polymerization and on the other hand the unfolding pathway showed the presence of an intermediate. To explain these processes we investigated the influence of the self-assembly of FtsZ on its unfolding pathway characterizing its oligomerization and unfolding thermodynamics. The assembly was studied using size-exclusion chromatography and fluorescence spectroscopy and the unfolding using circular dichroism and two-photon fluorescence correlation spectroscopy. The presence of monomers, dimers and tetramers with populations dependent on protein concentration were found by chromatographic analysis. Dissociation constants in the micromolar range for these oligomerizations were found by dilution experiments using fluorescent conjugates. The presence of tetramers at high protein concentrations and monomers at low protein concentrations were confirmed measuring the fluorescence lifetimes and rotational correlation times of the conjugates. We found that the 3-states unfolding of FtsZ was due to the presence of mainly dimeric state and that the monomer unfolds through a 2-states mechanism. The monomer-to-dimer equilibrium characterized here (Kd = 9 μM) showed a significant fraction (~10%) of stable dimers at the critical concentration for polymerization, supporting a mechanism with a dimer as a nucleus for Periplasmic binding proteins (PBPs) are involved in the transport of several molecules inside the cytoplasm of gram negative bacteria and share a common structure, constituted by two α/β domains. Thermodynamic studies on the folding of PBPs show that the histidine binding protein (HisJ) follows a three-state process, while the maltose binding protein (MBP) folds in a two-state way. Thus, PBPs with the same topology can show different folding behavior. In order to explore the structural determinants of such differences, we studied the folding process of the lysine, arginine, ornitine, binding protein (LAO) which shares 70% identity with HisJ. The temperature-induced unfolding of LAO in the pH range from 8.0 to 9.5 showed reversible singlephase transitions followed by fluorescence intensity (FI) and circular dichroism (CD). The CD and FI curves were always coincident. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) endotherms were well fitted to a two state model, the ratio ΔHcal / ΔHVh was approximately 1.0. The ΔCp obtained from the ΔH vs Tm plot was 2.4 ± 0.3 Kcal mol-1. The urea-induced unfolding of LAO, followed by FI and near and far UV CD, showed singlephase coincident transitions. A global fit gave ΔGH2O = 11.3 ± 0.7 Kcal mol-1, m= 3.7 ± 0. For stable globular proteins, the folded and functional state predominates in solution, and the mechanism of action can be approached through study of this state alone. But in other cases, the active configuration may be an infrequently visited member of a conformational ensemble. In such cases the activity mediated by this state is influenced by competition with these other states, and so understanding the distribution of states in the conformational ensemble is necessary to understand the molecule's functional properties. An example of such a protein is the nucleocapsid-binding domain from the mumps virus polymerase. This molecule displays persistent alpha-helical secondary structure in solution but lacks tertiary structure. Nevertheless it can be induced to fold into a three-helix bundle which is structurally very similar to homologs from other viruses. In this work we applied a statistical mechanical model based on helix-coil theory to describe the conformational ensemble of this small helical protein.
