body_text.text: The model was utilized to make an estimate of the average energy of site-specific participation in tertiary contacts in the ensemble. The magnitude of the effect was found to be comparable to solvent transfer energies for the larger hydrophobic sidechains. Spectrin αII is a major cytoskeletal protein contributing to membrane organization and integrity. Controlled spectrin proteolysis has been detected during both apoptotic and necrotic cell death processes, upon cell shape change, during cell differentiation, during lens development in synaptic remodeling, and in dendrite outgrowth, for example. A better understanding of mechanisms that control these processes is required to differentiate these proteolysis events and for developing inhibitors with potential therapeutic value. Spectrin αII contains two sites sensitive to caspase-3 processing. To characterize caspase-3 cleavage sites kinetically and structurally, we have expressed and purified spectrin model proteins of different lengths with either a single site or both sites. In vitro cleavage assay results showed catalytic efficiency of the first site to be 20 times higher than that of the second site in two sites model proteins. Interestingly, the proteins with just the first site exhibits similar increased cleavage than those consisting of just the second site. Furthermore, introducing a mutation at the first site at P1 position reduced the efficiency by 100 fold, but does not affect the processing of the second site. Our results clearly show that these two sites are very different in caspase-3 proteolysis and are independent of each other. To provide a better understanding of the determinants governing different rates of spectrin proteolysis at the two sites, we have solved the crystal structure of a spectrin fragment containing the second caspase-3 cleavage site. Structural studies of proteins consisting of the first site are in progress. Accurately predicting the relationship between protein sequence and structural stability is a significant challenge. We have analyzed this complicated relationship using high-throughput approaches to gain more detailed insight into hypotheses of protein design. Our studies focus on the model four-helix bundle protein Rop through the means of combinatorial repacking of the hydrophobic core and variation of loop residues.
body_text.section: The nucleation of FtsZ polymerization and its 3-state unfolding are explained by the presence of mainly dimers under the critical concentration

body_text.text: Using an in vivo screen for functional variants of Rop that uses green fluorescent protein (GFP) expression as a reporter phenotype, we are able to screen large libraries for folded variants. These functional variants have been sequenced via high-throughput colony sequencing technology to accumulate a statistically significant dataset of unique Rop variants differing in the core and loop regions. To further gain insight into the thermodynamic consequences of such mutations on stability, we have developed a high-throughput thermal scanning (HTTS) assay binding to assess the quantitative thermal stabilities of the variants in 96-well plates. HTTS relies on a fluorescence-based thermal shift assay that utilizes an environmentally sensitive dye. Active variants from combinatorial loop libraries reveal small differences in stability with large diversity in sequence space while an additional residue in the tight loop enhances stability by potential electrostatic interaction. Folded variants from repacking the hydrophobic core reveal that the most stable variants bury volumes similar to the wild-type, but a very broad range of core volumes can result in stability, as can mutations that substantially differ from the canonical pattern of large and small amino acids. Together these results illuminate how limiting "oil droplet" and "jigsaw puzzle" models of stability are both needed to fully understand stability. CaBLAM (Calpha-Based Low-resolution Annotation Method) addresses the challenge of producing stereochemically accurate models from rough chain tracings at low resolution (3-4Å) . Much current excitement in crystallography centers on large complexes and "molecular machines", but the resulting models can be subject to artifacts arising from inherent properties of low-resolution electron density maps. Even at poor resolution, chain tracing can produce full backbone models, achieving the primary objective of locating the amino-acid residues in 3D space. However, structural details like peptide orientation and hydrogen bonding are very often distorted. This wreaks havoc with standard ways of identifying secondary structure, placing side chains, and refining a reasonable model. CaBLAM identifies "disguised" secondary structures from a novel parameter space of overlapping Cα pseudodihedrals, and then uses the less reliable carbonyl oxygen placement to diagnose commonly occurring patterns of correctable errors. At high resolution, when combined with H-bonding patterns, CaBLAM is a powerful tool for exploring and describing structural motifs. At low resolution, CaBLAM can identify secondary structure from a minimum of information. CaBLAM diagnoses incorrect peptide plane orientations, and distinguishes such modeling errors from real irregularities such as helix caps, widened turns, and beta bulges. These methods allow better secondary structure modeling and more effective refinement. Funding: NIH R01-GM088674 Fluorescent proteins (FPs) have, over the last two decades, revolutionized the way biology and biochemistry are studied. However, the obligate oligomerization of many naturally occurring fluorescent proteins has hampered their usefulness as biological markers. Oligomerization of a fusion tag can impair the accuracy of characterizing a target protein, artificially aggregating its target, altering diffusion rates, and causing problems in target transport and trafficking. A monomeric fluorescent protein avoids these problems. In this vein, DsRed, a well-studied red fluorescent protein (RFP), was successfully engineered through directed evolution into monomeric mCherry by Roger Tsien and coworkers. This was the first instance of a monomeric RFP and filled a void in the color spectrum for monomeric molecular labels. DsRed is only one of hundreds of naturally occurring fluorescent proteins, many diverging significantly in fluorescent properties such as absorbance and emission spectra or quantum yields. Repeating the directed evolution process in other proteins would be a long and laborious endeavor, and therefore, a new method is desired for engineering monomerization into fluorescent proteins. We have devised a process through which we can engineer RFP monomers in silica via computational protein design (CPD) of surface positions at the oligomerization interfaces. To validate the method, we first engineered DsRed that had been modified to include mutations made to the core of the protein during its directed evolution to mCherry. CPD predicted sequence variants from which a 96-member library was constructed; a 24-member randomly generated library was also used as a control. The random library allowed hydrophilic residues, but weighted them based on their frequency of occurrence on the surface of bacterial cytoplasmic proteins. The design library maintained fluorescence in 96.8% of cases, whereas only 9.1% of the random library did so. These results demonstrate the power of our design method. The designed proteins were confirmed to be monomeric by gel filtration, homo-FRET, and analytical ultracentrifugation. As expected from the mutations to the core of the protein, the mutants maintained the spectroscopic properties of mCherry and not of DsRed. We hope to repeat these results in other fluorescent proteins that have yet to be monomerized such as HcRed and AQ143, which are both significantly red-shifted from DsRed.
body_text.section: Combinatorial and High-throughput Approaches to Evaluate Sequence-Structure Relationships in the Four Helix Bundle Protein Rop

body_text.text: Insulin-regulated aminopeptidase (IRAP) is a type 1 transmembrane zinc dependant M1 aminopeptidase that plays key roles in both antigen presentation and memory. Inhibition of IRAP by both peptides and selective small molecular weight inhibitors has been shown to dramatically improve memory in both normal animals, and in animal models of memory loss. When expressing recombinant IRAP using the baculovirus system, we observed that IRAP contained 2 zinc molecules per mole of IRAP. This was interesting as only one characteristic zinc binding site had been reported previously. Utilisation of a range of protein fragments revealed one binding site was consistent with the active site zinc, while the other was located in a C-terminal domain. Generation of molecular models of IRAP, and virtual screening for zinc binding sites using the Stanford Feature metal scanning algorithm confirmed our preliminary results, predicting not only the catalytic zinc binding site, but also two potential C-terminal binding sites; one coordinated by a group of three histidines and the other via two cysteines. Characterisation of the zinc binding properties revealed the approximate pKa of both zinc binding sites was around the approximate pKa of histidine residues. Subsequent mutation of all histidine residues to alanine confirmed zinc binding to the previously characterised HEXXH motif near the N-terminus, and to a cluster of three histidine residues near the C-terminus. Interestingly, in the presence of peptide inhibitors this second zinc is lost and a dramatic increase in resistance to proteolysis was seen. This was further characterised and modelled to show that these changes were a result of a large conformational change within the C-terminal domain upon binding of inhibitors to the catalytic N-terminal domain, and that this acts as an important regulator of IRAP activity. Using this knowledge, we have identified several novel selective small molecule inhibitors of IRAP which are being explored as potential new treatments for dementia. Endoplasmic reticulum aminopeptidase 1 and 2 (ERAP1 and ERAP2) are 120 kDa membrane-bound zinc M1 aminopeptidase's that play a central role in the final processing of MHC class I antigens. They are responsible for trimming precursors to antigenic peptides in the endoplasmic reticulum, which is essential to customise the longer peptides to the correct length for presentation on MHC class I molecules. Here we show that recombinantly purified ERAP1 and ERAP2, while monomeric in isolation, readily and specifically form a stable heterodimer through their N-terminal catalytic domains, with the active sites facing each other (face-toface) and the C-terminal domains acting as a molecular gate above the active sites. While the individual enzyme's substrate specificity is quite limited, the heterodimer shows broad substrate specificity and a cooperatively enhanced level of activity, particuarly against native substrates requiring multiple residues to be removed. The heterodimer also produced a greater proportion of fully processed products, and less of the intermediates, although this was dependent on the presence of the C-terminal domains which help retain the intermediate products within the dual active site environment, enabling more complete proteolysis. While the ERAP heterodimer is unique among the M1 aminopeptidases, it is an effective mechanism to efficiently and completely process a broad range of substrates to their appropriate lengths for antigen presentation.
body_text.section: Regulation of Insulin Regulated Aminopeptidase by the C-terminal Domain: A Novel Zinc Binding Domain That Undergoes Extensive Conformational Changes David Ascher, Michael Parker Biota Structural Biology Laboratory, St. Vincent's Institute, Fitzroy, VIC, Australia

body_text.text: Canola proteins fractions albumin (Alb), globulin (Glo), and glutelin (Glu), extracted from industrial meal were compared to commercial soy protein isolate (SPI) in terms of their emulsifying properties at various pH values. Glo fractions had higher emulsifying capacity (EC) and emulsifying activity index (EAI), and the droplet size of emulsions it stabilized was consistently smaller irrespective of pH compared to Alb or Glu fractions. In comparison to SPI, Glo also had higher EC at all pH tested, higher EAI at acidic pH, and smaller or comparable average emulsion droplet size at both pH 4 and 7. Emulsions stabilized by Alb, Glo, and Glu showed good stability at most pH values (except for the emulsion stabilized by Glu at pH 4), and this stability was comparable to SPI-stabilized emulsions with no significant (p>0.05) changes in droplet size during storage for up to 7 days at room temperature. With the exception of Glu-and SPI-stabilized emulsions at pH 9, these emulsions, however, experienced separation into the emulsion and serum phases after 24 h storage at room temperature. Within the range of protein concentration studied (0.1-2%), minimum average droplet size of Alb-, Glo-, or Glu-stabilized emulsions were achieved at only low protein concentration (0.3-0.5%), although bigger than minimum average droplet size of SPI-stabilized emulsion which occurred at higher protein concentration (2%). This study demonstrates that emulsifying properties of canola protein fractions are comparable to the commercially available SPI, suggesting the potential use of fractionated canola proteins in food application.
body_text.section: Dimerisation and Co-operativity of Endoplasmic Reticulum Aminopeptidase 1 and 2: A Process Essential for Antigen Recognition

body_text.text: Measuring the kinetics of conformational sampling during binding with NMR spectroscopy David Ban, T. Michael Sabo, Karin Giller, Stefan Becker, Donghan Lee, Christian Griesinger NMR based Structural Biology, Max-Planck Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Am Faßberg 11, Göttingen, 37077, Germany Molecular recognition is typically described as either following a conformational selection (CS) or inducedfit (IF) mechanism. In the CS model, a protein samples a subset of structural configurations which mimic structures from the bound form. An important facet of this is that the sampling of different conformations limits the on-rate for binding. In the IF model, a free conformation is altered to a bound conformation induced upon binding and the on-rate is governed by the rate of this conformational change. For ubiquitin, a protein that forms many different interactions with various proteins, large heterogeneous conformations are sampled in the free form on a timescale of about 2-38 μs at room temperature (1, 2) . Here, we evaluate the role of this sampling event during the molecular recognition process using ubiquitin complexed with the UBA domain of Dsk2p (Dsk2) (3) by utilizing Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. For this purpose, concentration dependent CPMG relaxation dispersion, which is sensitive to lowly populated intermediates, has been used for evaluating the efficacy of CS and IF (4). In brief, data fit with a simple two-state model are in contradiction with HSQC-based titration results and indicate that the binding scheme is more sophisticated. Techniques on how to fit the data to higher order models and results from expanded kinetic schemes will be presented as well as a comparison of both CS and IF binding models for the ubiquitin and Dsk2 interaction. This approach can provide pivotal information regarding molecular recognition mechanisms. The localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) peak of SoPRano nanorods in solution can be used to monitor protein-protein interactions in real-time. One protein is immobilized onto the gold nanorod surface through standard amine coupling methods. Complex formation with a protein-binding partner causes a red shift in the absorbance spectra which can be monitored using a standard spectrophotometer. A glycerol concentration series was used to establish that the change in response is linear with respect to the change in refractive index. Equilibrium and kinetic studies on antibody fragments binding to immobilized antigens demonstrate the potential of the technology to characterize the binding constants for protein-protein interactions. Absorbance based plate readers can be used to multiplex the assay in 96-and 384-well formats making it possible to run highly parallel assays. The nanorod technology can open up new applications for label-free SPR analysis.

Interacting networks of proteins carry out the majority of biological functions. Thesefunctionally-linked interactions (FLIPs) occur at specific interfaces. Many such contacts are identified via X-ray crystallography; however the majority of contacts in such structures are crystal contacts, sites of aggregation, or otherwise functionally un-correlated (FunCs). Here, we use our Energy Centrality Relationship (ECR) concept, which assesses amino acid energetic variation as a function of distance from the interface, to characterize and classify different categories of protein aggregations and associations. We hypothesize that in order to maintain FLIPs, evolutionary pressure produces signature characteristics that can be identified by computational alanine scanning and Evolutionary Trace methods. Here we show that geometric, energetic, and sequence conservation patterns, when clustered, can differentiate between proteins belonging to differentFLIP/FunC categories. In addition, by generating and testing docking decoys for structures representative of these categories, we demonstrate that ECR can reduce false positives in quaternary structure prediction. In the past years there was an increasing interest in the study of tertiary components of the allosteric transitions and their coupling to the quaternary MWC classic T-R conformational change. The enzyme glucosamine-6-P deaminase from E. coli (GlcN6P deaminase, E.C. 3.5.99.6) has shown to be a useful experimental model to approach this topic. It is a homohexameric allosteric enzyme, activated by N-acetylglucosamine-6-P (GlcNAc6P), catalyzing the conversion of GlcN6P into Fru6P and ammonia. Its cooperative kinetics and allosteric activation by GlcNAc6P can be accounted for the allosteric MWC model, but spectral and crystallographic evidences suggests the existence of local conformational changes. With the aim of investigating the tertiary-quaternary coupling in this deaminase, we encapsulated it in wet silica sol-gels under conditions that constrains the T-R conformerization and abolishes the cooperative binding of ligands. For experiments, gels were used as monolithic slabs or particles in suspension. Spectral studies and kinetic experiments show that the allosteric activation of the nanoencapsulated enzyme is independent of the allosteric transition and linked to local non-concerted structural changes. The kinetic study of nanoencapsulated ligand-free T and R forms of the enzyme and its activation by GlcNAc6P reveals the existence of pure tertiary states at high or low affinity for GlcN6P, whilst the intermediate forms of the enzyme display negative cooperativity, thus suggesting the existence of tertiary structural heterogeneity. It is also apparent that the time-course of the enrichment in the high-affinity tertiary state (r) is dependent on the enzyme quaternary state. Our results are consistent with the existence of at least two tertiary states with different apparent K M GlcN6P values for each t or r state, which are independent of the quaternary T-R state. On the other hand, GlcNAc6P can be bound with similar affinity to the allosteric site in either quaternary state of the enzyme. These results are analyzed in the framework of the TTS model by Henry and Eaton (Biophys Chem 2002:98, 149-164) , a model is proposed for GlcNAc6P binding in T and R states and also on the origin of cooperativity for the free enzyme. Supported by CONACyT, 99857-Q and PAPIIT (UNAM) IN206009 and IN213312. SZS is recipient of a CONACyT Ph.D. scholarship.
body_text.section: FLIPs AND FunCs: Classification of Protein Interactions Using Energetic and Evolutionary Criteria Sanjana Sudarshan, Brian Beck Texas Womans University, Denton, TX, 76204

body_text.text: Biochemistry, Western University, London, ON, Canada S100 proteins are small acidic proteins of the EFhand family characterized by cell and tissue specific distributions and modified levels of expression in diseases such as Alzhemier's and cancer. Structural and sequence comparisons show that S100 proteins have similar patterns of hydrophobic residues on their binding surfaces and selectivity and specificity is conferred in part by differences in side chain interactions. In general, detailed structures have shown how some S100 proteins interact with a target. However much less is known about the forces driving these biomolecular associations in solution. To gain insights into to the specificity and energetic contributions that stabilize S100-target complex formation, the thermodynamics of several S100 proteins with peptides derived from their target molecules were studied using isothermal titration calorimetry. We compared representative S100-target complex formation to evaluate the thermodynamics of same target protein (annexin A2) interacting with multiple S100s (Ca-S100A11 and S100A10) and binding of a single S100 member to different target molecules (Ca-S100B with CapZ and dopamine receptor; CaS100A11 with annexins A1 and A2, and S100A10 with annexin A2 and virus protein NS3). Energetics of Ca-S100A11annexin A1 and S100A10-annexin A2 interactions exhibited similar characteristics in agreement with the structural resemblance reported for these complexes. On the contrary, binding of annexin A2 to Ca-S100A11 and S100A10 were significantly different with entropic contributions favoring the interaction of annexin A2 with Ca-S100A11, while the S100A10 interaction proceeds as a result of important enthalpic contributions. Based on our analysis S100-target interactions can be divided into two groups according to the driving force for complex formation: those enthalpically driven (Ca-S100A11annexin A1; S100A10-annexin A2 and NS3) where there is a large entropy cost as a result of the induction of the α-helical structure of the peptides, and those entropically driven (Ca-S100B complexes and Ca-S100A11-annexin A2) where the burial of hydrophobic residues is the major driving force. These studies provide an energetic rationale towards understanding the specificity and redundancy among S100 members. In combination with structural data, this work may help in the design of S100 inhibitors that could regulate calcium signaling events. Staphylococcus aureus is a pathogenic bacteria that has acquired resistance to many modern antibiotics. Biotin protein ligase (BPL) is a ubiquitous enzyme that acts to covalently attach biotin onto biotindependent carboxylases required in fundamental life processes such as lipogenesis, gluconeogenesis and amino acid metabolism. Certain bacterial BPL also have a secondary role in transcriptional repression of the genes code for the protein involved in the synthesis of biotin. Due to BPL's importance in bacterial cell survival and maintenance, it has been proposed that the Staphylococcus aureus BPL (SaBPL) is a potential target for a novel antibiotic. Compounds targeting the active site of the catalytic domain have been specifically designed based on a previously determined structure of SaBPL in complex with the native ligand biotinyl-5'-AMP. Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) was used in determining the binding activity of these inhibitors against SaBPL. X-ray crystallography structures of these potential inhibitors in complex with SaBPL have also been obtained, and provide an insight as to how the inhibitors bind SaBPL and is a starting point for the development of more efficient drugs against this enzyme.
body_text.section: Insights Into The Energetics Of S100-Target Complex Formation Liliana Santamaria-Kisiel, Gary Shaw

body_text.text: Purification and characterization of a soluble diacylglycerol-3-phosphate phosphohydrolase, EC 3.1.3.4, from bottle gourd Lagenaria siceraria Abul Ullah, Kandan Sethumadhavan, Casey Grimm, Jay Shockey Southern Regional Research Center, ARS, USDA, 1100 Robert E. Lee Boulevard, New Orleans, LA, 70124

Phosphatidic acid phosphatase (PAP), EC 3.1.3.4, is the penultimate step in Kennedy pathway of triacyl glycerol (TAG) synthesis leading up to the formation of diacyl glycerol (DAG), which is a key intermediate to efficient TAG synthesis. We partially purified a soluble PAP from mid maturing seeds of bottle gourd, Lagenaria siceraria. The steps include both anionic and cationic ion exchanger columns. Catalytic characterization of the partially purified PAP revealed that the optimum pH and temperature for activity were at 5.5 and 45 °C. Under optimum assay condition using dioleoyl phosphatidic acid (DPA) as the substrate, the Vmax and Km were 0.36 η Kat/mg of protein and 200 µM, respectively. For the synthetic substrate, ρ-nitrophenylphosphate, ρ-NPP, the Vmax and Km were 33.0 ηKat/mg of protein and 140 µM, respectively. The activity was neither inhibited nor enhanced by the presence of Mg++ at a concentration range of 10 to 50 mM. Two major protein bands at 42-KDa and 26-KDa were visible in SDS-PAGE after partial purification. Bioinformatics studies with trypsinized PAP have showed partial sequence homology of bottle gourd seed PAP to soybean purple acid phosphatase, polyphosphate kinase, fructose biphosphate aldolase, enolase, methionine synthase from various dicotyledonous plants including Arabidopsis thaliana.

Structure of an AKAP79/PKA/CN Scaffolding Complex Jeffrey Copps 1, 2 , Patrick Hogan 4 , Susan Taylor 1, 2, 5 , Donald Blumenthal 3 1 Pharmacology, UC San Diego, La Jolla, CA, 2 Chemistry and Biochemistry, UC San Diego, La Jolla, CA, 3 Pharmacology and Toxicology, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, 4 La Jolla Institute for Allergy and Immunology, La Jolla, CA, 5 Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Chevy Chase, MD Large multi-protein signaling complexes frequently include cell surface receptors, ion channels, and their primary effectors, initializing signaling cascades that extend deeper into the cellular interior. A-kinase anchoring proteins (AKAPs) are scaffolding proteins which target cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) and other signaling enzymes to various substrates and organelles within the cell. AKAP79 plays important roles in signaling complexes in the heart and brain, and is an integral part of protein complexes linked to calcium channels and glutamate receptors, recruiting PKA and the phosphatase calcineurin (CN) to regulate Ca2+ influx. Well regulated Ca2+ currents are essential for proper neurotransmitter signaling and regulation of cardiac contractility; pathological alterations in Ca2+ handling can lead to neuronal hyperexcitability, seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and heart failure. We hypothesize that AKAP79 does not simply target PKA and CN to receptors to regulate Ca2+ influx, but assembles these enzymes such that their signaling output is different from that of the unscaffolded enzymes. This hypothesis implies that PKA and CN interact upon the scaffold to mediate each other's activity, in turn raising the possibility that the AKAP79/CN/PKA complex forms a structure whose components interact dynamically, as opposed to a "beads on a string" model where there is a lack of significant interaction between the enzymes. As a first step towards full characterization of this potential signaling complex, we have studied the structure and interactions of recombinant, purified PKA holoenyzme, truncated CN, and AKAP79 using a variety of methods, among them peptide array overlays and small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), to analyze an AKAP79/CN/ PKA complex that is stable to gel filtration. Binding of the recombinant proteins to arrayed synthetic peptides revealed multiple candidate sites of interaction between CN and PKA, as well as a novel interaction of CN with peptides within the PKA binding site on AKAP79. SAXS studies of the AKAP79/CN/PKA complex showed a remarkably compact structure with a diameter not much larger than that of the PKA holoenzyme. Together, these data suggest a strong likelihood of on-scaffold interaction between PKA and CN, and a tight integration of cAMP and Ca2+ signals within the complex. This research was supported by the NIH/ NIDDK Training Grant 5T32-DK007233 and NIH grant GM34921-20. One of the most widely used tags expressed to facilitate purification of recombinant proteins is the histidine-tag, which commonly consists of six consecutive histidine residues added to the C-or N-terminus of the protein.

The function/characteristics of histidine-tagged proteins are easily studied using Biacore systems. Histidinetagged proteins are captured on a sensor surface and the analyte binding characteristics can be explored. Capture of histidine-tagged proteins is an attractive approach for protein attachment in Biacore systems as physiological conditions can be used during the procedure. Another advantage is the possibility to perform the analysis in crude sample environments prior to purification. In addition, capture of tags ensures a directed structural orientation of the molecule on the surface giving an optimal site exposure. In this poster we present His Capture Kit, NTA Reagent Kit and NTA Sensor Chip, products that support the two different approaches for interaction studies of histidine-tagged proteins using Biacore systems. We also provide guidelines and recommend assay conditions to get the best data out of your interaction studies. We have developed several cell-free methods for producing soluble membrane proteins supported in nanolipoprotein particles (NLPs) that may potentially support free-electron laser technology (FEL) for the structural determination of membrane proteins. NLPs have shown great promise as a biotechnology platform for solubilizing and characterizing membrane proteins and may make many more membrane proteins accessible for biophysical and biochemical study. By the simple addition of a few constituents to cell-free extracts, this approach provides a rapid process for the production of functional soluble membrane proteins that eliminates the need for cell growth, cell lysis, and subsequent purification, refolding etc. We have demonstrated this process on multiple membrane proteins important for rhodopsin-related proton pumps, drug transporters, host-pathogen interactions, the herceptin receptors and G-coupled protein receptors. Proteins have ranged in size from 10 -200 kDa, with 2 or more transmembrane domains and have been shown to be biochemically functional. Crystallization of the proteins directly within the NLP appears to be generally applicable to membrane proteins associated with NLPs. Our approach represents a unique solution to the inherent challenge of generating soluble and functional polytopic membrane proteins, facilitating the structural and functional characterization of these critical, yet poorly understood molecules. Contact: coleman16@llnl.gov. ( Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDP's) are characterized by a lack of a stable tertiary structure under physiological conditions. The discovery of IDP's challenged the traditional protein structure theory that a well-defined structure is required for the correct function of a protein. It is now known that proteins in a globular state are fully functional and are essential for cellular processes. Some develop a stable tertiary structure when bound to their target. The tertiary structure of FlgM was determined when bound to Sigma-28. In this study, the four-helix protein FlgM, from the thermophilic organism Aquifex aeolicus was characterized. FlgM is an IDP that inhibits the RNA transcription factor Sigma-28, which is involved in the late stage genes of flagella synthesis. It has been previously shown that the C-terminus in FlgM from Salmonella typhimurium becomes ordered when bound to Sigma-28. In contrast, all four helices in FlgM from A. aeolicus become ordered when bound to Sigma-28. Although these proteins serve similar function, their primary structure is only 36% similar, and their structures upon binding are different. We examined peptides of the single helix regions (H1-H4) as well as combinations of the helices in FlgM using circular dichroism (CD) and fluorescence anisotropy. We found that as the percentage of TFE increased, so did the alpha-helical signal of each helix and as temperature increased the helices exhibit a less ordered state. H3 showed the strongest amount of alpha-helical content with and without TFE, suggesting that H3 is the initial binding site with Sigma-28. Fluorescence anisotropy is being used to probe the binding between various truncations of FlgM and Sigma-28.

Here we describe a method to tag, enrich and identify secreted proteins in a cell-selective manner. Labeling is restricted to the cells of interest by introducing a mutant methionyl-tRNA synthetase that charges tRNAMet with azidonorleucine, which can be tagged by click chemistry. Proteins made by cells that do not express the mutant synthetase are not labeled. Applications of this approach to the identification of secreted proteins will be discussed.
body_text.section: Identification of proteins secreted by specific subpopulations of cells is an important step in studies of cell-cell interaction.

body_text.text: Are CDRs the key determinants for the formation of amyloid fibrils by camelid heavy-chain antibody fragments? Chloé Chavignon 1 , Els Pardon 2 , Lode Wyns 2 , Serge Muyldermans 2 , Mireille Dumoulin 1 1 Centre for Protein Engineering, University of Liège, Liège, Belgium, 2 Department of molecular and cellular interactions, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Brussel, Belgium

Amyloidoses are diseases associated with the deposition of protein aggregates organized into amyloid fibrils in different organs. About forty amyloidoses are known so far, amongst which Alzheimer's disease, type II diabetes and immunoglobulin amyloidosis [1] . Although the mechanism of amyloid fibril formation at the molecular level is not yet completely understood, it has been shown that the capacity to form amyloid fibrils in vitro is an intrinsic property of all polypeptide chains [1] . The choice of model proteins to investigate the aggregation process in vitro is therefore not restrained to proteins involved in amyloidoses but can be settled on a wide variety of proteins. We have chosen to investigate the mechanism of amyloid fibril formation using as model two variable domains of camelid heavy-chain antibodies (referred to as V H Hs or nanobodies), cAb-HuL6 and cAb-BcII10, for which variants with mutations located at the disulfide bond and the Complementary Determining Regions (CDRs) [2] are available. The purpose of this work is to study the impact of these structural elements on the aggregation process and thereby gain more insight into the molecular mechanism of amyloid fibril formation. In order to determine conditions in which cAb-HuL6, cAb-BcII10 and one of their mutational variant are more susceptible to form amyloid fibrils, heat-induced unfolding experiments at several pHs have been carried out. Then, aggregation experiments have been performed in the selected conditions and the presence of amyloid fibrils has been acknowledged due to thioflavin T fluorescence experiments and electron microscopy. Aggregation and seeding experiments supported the hypothesis that aggregation of these V H Hs into amyloid fibrils is a nucleation-dependant process. An interesting result is that, despite their close sequences, cAb-HuL6 and cAb-BcII10 have not been able to cross-seed. Based on cross-seeding experiments of cAb-HuL6, cAb-BcII10 and one of their mutational variant, we determined that the CDRs were having a key role in the fibrillation process of the V H Hs studied. This work has been supported by the F.R.I.A. [1] Chiti and Dobson, Annu. Rev. Biochem., 75, 2006, 333- A number of germline Ras mutations have been found in a series of developmental disorders collectively known as neuro-cardio-cutaneous conditions (NCFCs), including Cardio Facio Cutaneous Syndrome (CFCS: K-ras), Noonan Syndrome (NS: K-ras and N-ras) and Costello Syndrome (CS: K-ras and H-ras). NCFCs are characterized by a set of distinct phenotypes that include facial dysmorphism, cardiac anomalies, delayed growth and mild to severe mental retardation. Germline mutations have also been discovered in GEFs, GAPs, and Ras effector proteins involved in the Ras-MAPK cascade, suggesting that the mechanism of action that promotes aberrant development may be due to changes in the activation of this particular pathway. Furthermore, biochemical analyses have revealed that most of the NCFC-associated Ras mutations confer a lesser degree of over-activation than oncogenic Ras proteins and, in some cases, loss of function. We hypothesized that the mechanism by which NCFC Ras mutations alter MAPK activation, presumably by causing structural and dynamic changes, may be similar to those of oncogenic Ras mutations. To test this hypothesis, we characterized the conformational redistributions caused by NCFC mutations relative to the wild-type and oncogenic variants of Ras. We focused on the catalytic domain of a number of K-ras and H-ras proteins carrying NCFC as well as oncogenic point mutations, and used all-atom molecular dynamics simulations to study their dynamics in the presence of the cognate substrate GTP. Initial results revealed that several NCFC mutations alter the preference of Ras for the two major conformational states that differ in effector recognition. Further investigation into the various ensemble-of-conformers provided insights into how some mutations restructure the catalytic domain into a form that favors effector binding while others lead to conformations that disfavor effector binding. We also found structural clues into the biochemical effect of these mutations by correlating the pattern of conformational sampling with the severity of the syndrome caused by a given mutation. Blood coagulation factor VIII is a non-enzymatic glycoprotein cofactor that is essential for proper regulation of the blood coagulation cascade. Genetic deficiencies in factor VIII cause hemophilia A, which affects 1 in 5,000 males worldwide. Treatment for hemophilia A consists of repeated infusions of recombinant or plasma-derived factor VIII, which can result in the development of inhibitor antibodies that arise in approximately one-third of the hemophilia A patient population receiving therapy. The C-terminal "C2" domain of factor VIII is essential for proper interactions with von Willebrand factor (vWF) and the membrane surface of activated platelets, and is a major epitope that is recognized by inhibitory antibodies. Classical antibodies inhibit factor VIII in vitro by blocking the ability of the C2 domain to properly interact with both activated platelet surfaces and vWF, and non-classical antibodies inhibit the proteolytic activation of factor VIII by thrombin, thereby preventing its release from vWF in circulation. Here, we are characterizing the structural epitopes of a classical (3E6) and a non-classical (G99) pair of antibodies that bind to the C2 domain, which also function cooperatively in vitro, yielding a stable ternary complex. Purification of each binary C2/Fab complex, as well as the stable ternary complex, is completed, and we are currently attempting to produce crystals of each complex for x-ray crystallographic studies. Small angle x-ray scattering studies have previously been employed to allow low-resolution characterization of each complex. In this study, the C2/(Fab)2 ternary complex displays an extended structure, where each antibody binds to opposing sides of the C2 domain globular fold. These data allow for low-resolution modeling of specific epitopes for each class of antibodies, and further study to obtain x-ray crystal structures at atomic resolution will allow characterization of the mechanism of the immune response to factor VIII replacement therapy in hemophilia A patients.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a prevalent opportunistic human pathogen. Individuals who are immunocompromised are especially susceptible to infections by this bacterium, such as cancer and AIDS patients. Additionally, P. aeruginosa is the principal bacterial agent responsible for persistent drug refractile lung infections, sepsis in burn patients, and morbidity and mortality among individuals suffering from cystic fibrosis. It is also a major nosocomial pathogen responsible for many hospital outbreaks and is notorious for its high resistance to antibiotic treatments. P. aeruginosa is known to establish a bacterial cell-to-cell communication named quorum sensing to resist host immune system, leading to full-fledged virulence. The enzyme PqsE is essential for the regulation of quorum sensing and the full virulence of this bacterial species. The enzyme regulates the synthesis of pyocyanin, a toxic compound only produced by P. aeruginosa. As a result, this enzyme is an important drug target showing considerable promise for the design of new inhibitors directed against this opportunistic human pathogen. Based on its structural investigation, we present preliminary enzyme characterization and mutagenesis experiments aimed at altering the biological function of PqsE, allowing the characterization of key amino acid positions involved in the molecular function of the enzyme. This functional mapping will be exploited for designing potential inhibitors through a computational method using a large set of small pharmaceutical compounds. The positive hits will be tested on the purified enzyme to evaluate their potency and to better characterize the role and molecular function played by PqsE in P. aeruginosa. This research should provide new insights and means to counter bacterial infections. (TG2) is an enzyme that exists in two dramatically different conformational states, each with a unique activity. In the open, extended form, the transglutaminase active site is exposed, allowing TG2 to catalyze formation of an isopeptide bond between the sidechain of a peptide-bound glutamine and a primary amine. Upon GTP binding to a separate GTPase active site, TG2 adopts a heavily favored and compact closed conformation, which obstructs the glutaminase active site, and only allows GTPase activity. TG2 has been linked to Huntington's disease, as well as to many other cellular processes, both physiological and pathological. However, TG2's two conformational states, each with its own activity, have made it difficult to elucidate how this enzyme functions in disease progression. In addition, because TG2 heavily prefers the closed state, attempts to screen for inhibitors that may bind the transglutanimase site exposed in the open conformation, and attempts to obtain co-crystals of the enzyme with these inhibitors have proven difficult. The purpose of this study is use computational protein design to engineer TG2 variants locked in either the open or closed conformation. Multistate and single-state design calculations were successful in predicting multiple active variants with 1-4 mutations that preferentially stabilized the open conformation. Closed-locked variants are beginning to be designed. These variants then will be used in Huntington's disease studies to isolate the effects of each of TG2's activities and to assist in rational drug design. Tank Binding Kinase (TBK1) plays a central role in innate immunity: it serves as an integrator of multiple signals induced by receptor-mediated pathogen detection and as a modulator of interferon levels. Efforts to better understand the biology of this key immunological factor have intensified recently as growing evidence implicates aberrant TBK1 activity in a variety of autoimmune diseases and cancers. Nevertheless, key molecular details of TBK1 regulation and substrate selection remain unanswered. Here structures of phosphorylated and unphosphorylated human TBK1 kinase and ubiquitin-like domains, combined with biochemical studies, indicate a molecular mechanism of activation via trans-autophosphorylation. These TBK1 structures are consistent with the tripartite architecture observed recently for the related kinase, IKKβ, but domain contributions toward target recognition appear to differ for the two enzymes. In particular, both TBK1 autoactivation and substrate specificity are likely driven by signal-dependent co-localization events. Finally, insights gained from these inhibitor-bound TBK1 structures may aid the design of more selective TBK1 compounds, which would serve as important tools for further dissecting the intricacies of TBK1-mediated signaling events as well as potential therapeutics.
body_text.section: Pseudomonas aeruginosa Benjamin Folch, Éric Déziel, Nicolas Doucet INRS-Institut Armand-Frappier, Université du Québec, Laval, QC, Canada
