body_text.section: Investigation of Specific Conditions for Inducing a Nonamyloidogenic Protein to Form Fibril-like Polymers Jason Collins, Lesley Greene

body_text.text: The transition of native proteins into amyloid fibrils is associated with many prevalent diseases. The investigation into the determinants of protein misfolding and amyloid fibril formation is an increasingly expanding and important field of research. The transformation of a functional folded protein into a fibril-like polymer composed of β-sheet structure is a fascinating transition. Proteins can be induced to alternatively fold into amyloid fibrils in vitro using a variety of factors such as mutations, concentration, agitation, temperature and pH. In this poster we present the identification of a specific set of conditions required to induce the transition of the all α-helical Fas-associated death domain, a nonamyloidogenic protein, into an amyloidlike morphology composed of a rich β-sheet structure. The transition to fibrils is monitored using a broad range of spectroscopic techniques which include atomic force microscopy, fluorescence spectroscopy and circular dichroism. In summary, we show that out of ninetyfive conditions attempted only one condition produced fibril-like structures which indicates, that proteins are robust against the amyloid conformation.
body_text.section: Investigation of Specific Conditions for Inducing a Nonamyloidogenic Protein to Form Fibril-like Polymers Jason Collins, Lesley Greene

body_text.text: Institute for Bioscience and Biotechnology Research, 9600 Gudelsky Drive, Rockville, MD, 20850
body_text.section: Absolute Quantification to Study Neurodegenerative Diseases by QconCAT Strategy Junjun Chen, Illarion Turko

body_text.text: Defining the total amount of proteins in cell by mass spectrometry requires known amounts of internal standards. However, absolute quantification was hampered by the availability of standard labeled signature peptides in accurately known amounts. In this project, we designed peptide standards containing concatenated sequences of specific proteotypic peptides that are derived from various neuron disease related proteins. The concatenated peptides were generated in in vitro translation system. Isotopically labeled Lys and Arg were introduced to produce stable isotopelabeled peptides. A known amount of isotope-labeled peptides standards were co-digested with tissue samples containing target proteins. Absolute quantification of these neuron disease related proteins was performed by multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) with a triple quadrupole mass spectrometry. To date, a variety of anti-prion compounds have been reported that are effective in ex vivo and also in vivo treatment experiments. However the molecular mechanisms of most of these compounds remain unknown. Here we classified anti-prion mechanisms into four categories; I: conformational stabilization, II: interference with the interaction between the cellular form of prion protein (PrPC) and the scrapie form (PrPSc), III: precipitation of prion proteins, and IV: interaction with proteins other than PrPC. To characterize the anti-prion compounds according to this classification, we determined their binding affinities to PrPC and their binding sites in PrPC using the surface plasmon resonance and NMR spectroscopy, respectively. GN8 and GJP49 bind specifically to the hot spot in PrPC, and act as 'medicinal chaperones' to stabilize the native conformation and interfere with the interaction between PrPC and PrPSc. Thus mechanism I & II are predominant. While quinacrine and epigallocathechin bind to PrPC rather non-specifically. They may mainly interfere with the intermolecular interaction, and mechanism II may be applied. On the other hand Congo red and pentosan polysulfate bind to PrPC and cause its precipitation reducing the effective concentration of prion protein. So, mechanism III is appropriate. Finally CP60, an edarabone derivative etc. never bind to PrPC but may interact with PrPSc or other relevant proteins, and can be explained by mechanism IV, whose details must be elucidated further. The proposed characterization of diverse anti-prion compound would help understanding their anti-prion activities as well as facilitating further effective anti-prion drug discovery. HIV-1, the causative agent of AIDS, remains a global epidemic. According to UNAIDS, an estimated 34 million people worldwide are living with HIV/AIDS. Although a vaccine remains elusive, the development of Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART) has proven effective in reducing viral loads. HAART primarily targets two HIV-1 encoded proteins (protease and reverse transcriptase). Despite HAART's success, drug resistant strains have begun to emerge, making the discovery of antiretroviral agents that target other viral components necessary. One target that has yet to be exploited is the N-terminal domain of the Gag polyprotein, the retroviral matrix (MA) protein. MA functions as the sole mediator of Gag targeting to viral assembly sites, at the plasma membrane. This targeting is regulated by (1) MA binding to phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate [PI(4,5)P2], which induces subtle conformational changes that (2) expose a sequestered myristate group for tight membrane association. In efforts to target MA for the development of novel antiviral therapies, we use nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) to screen potential molecules that bind MA (MA inhibitors, MAI's). Here, we report a novel class of small molecules that bind MA and alter the critical MA-MA and MA-PI(4,5)P2 interactions that occur during viral assembly. Furthermore, preliminary data illustrate that MAI's bind MA and inhibit exposure of the myristate moiety. Finally, we will test our inhibitors in HIV-1 transfected T-cells to determine if they do exhibit antiviral activity. These data will provide support for the development of anti-viral drugs that specifically target the HIV-1 viral assembly. This work is funded by: NIH/ NIAID 5R37AI30917 and NIGMS R25GM055036 More than 33 million people worldwide are currently infected with HIV-1. Efforts to develop HIV therapies remain limited by the use of suitable animal models for clinical studies. We propose the use of felines as an animal model in HIV and hypothesize that the behavior of FIV matrix protein is structurally and functionally similar to HIV matrix protein. It has been shown that myristylated [myr(+)] HIV-1 matrix binds to membrane phospholipid PI(4,5)P2 and causes the matrix protein to undergo a conformational change, anchoring it to the plasma membrane for viral budding. Comparatively, preliminary studies show that unmyristylated [myr(-)] FIV matrix protein has a similar secondary structure to HIV-1 matrix and has an interaction with PI(4,5)P2. Current efforts seek to solve the structure of myr(+) and myr(-) FIV matrix protein and identify its interaction with biologically relevant cofactors. FIV matrix protein was expressed and purified using an E. coli expression system. Due to the hydrophobic nature of FIV matrix, solubility studies were performed to identify conditions to keep the protein stable. Using the OptiSol protein solubility screening assay, two factors-pH and temperature-were shown to significantly improve the solubility of FIV matrix protein. Once these factors were identified, a series of NMR experiments were performed to refine the structure of myr(-) FIV MA and begin to solve the structure of myr(+) FIV MA. Future experiments will determine the structure of myr(+) FIV matrix protein bound to PI(4,5)P2. Characterizing the structure of FIV matrix protein and elucidating its interaction with biologically relevant phospholipids will provide a better understanding of the FIV life cycle and broaden our understanding of lentiviruses and HIV animal models.
body_text.section: Absolute Quantification to Study Neurodegenerative Diseases by QconCAT Strategy Junjun Chen, Illarion Turko

body_text.text: During the late phase of the retrovirus life cycle the Gag polyprotein assembles at the plasma membrane. We have expressed and purified the capsid and nucleocapsid domains together as a unit (CANC) for the Moloney murine leukemia virus. Viral genome packaging specificity is mediated by the nucleocapsid domain of assembling Gag polyproteins and the RNA packaging element located in the 5' UTR, known as the Ψ site. The minimum region required for packaging is called the core-encapsidation signal (Ψces). Here, we employ isothermal titration calorimetry and electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) to characterize the interaction between CANC and Ψces. Our findings suggest that, the Ψ site functions as a RNA structural scaffold that marks nucleation sites for Gag assembly by exposing a cluster of conserved UCUG elements for binding to the cognate nucleocapsid domains of assembling viral Gag proteins. This work is supported by NIH grant number R37AI03097-22. The Mixed Lineage Leukemia protein (MLL), a large H3K4 methyltransferase that maintains HOX gene expression during development, is a frequent target for the creation of in frame chimeric fusion proteins, the most common being AF4 or AF9 of the possible 60 different fusion partners. These N-term MLL fusion proteins cause the upregulation of HOX gene expression, as seen in MLL-AF9. We have shown AF9 is a 'signaling hub' and binds to several proteins implicated in transcriptional elongation, one of which is AF4. We have also found preferentially blocking the AF9:AF4 interaction results in a loss of transformation of hematopoetic progenitor cells. In aggressive mixed lineage leukemias, MLL-AF9 controls its gene expression through Positive-Transcription Elongation Factor b. P-TEFb is a complex of cyclin dependent kinase 9 (CDK9) and Cyclin T1/2 that regulates transcriptional elongation by phosphorylating the C-terminal domain of RNA polymerase II, leading to the production of RNA transcripts. AF4 is suggested to directly interact with Cyclin T2 of P-TEFb, similar to the mechanism of HIV. Both HIV and leukemogenesis have been implicated in using the AF4 family of proteins to hijack P-TEFb machinery and upregulate their respective gene expression. Our goal is to biochemically validate and structurally characterize this AF4:P-TEFb interaction. The 15N HSQC of AF4 is consistent with an unstructured protein with minimal peak dispersion and may undergo a coupled folding and binding upon interaction with Cyclin T2. This binding interface may lead to potential targeted therapeutics important to both HIV and mixed lineage leukemia.
body_text.section: Characterization of anti-prion compounds according to the binding properties to the prion protein

body_text.text: Calcium and redox dependent conformational change is necessary for the catalytic activity of Formylglycine-Generating Enzyme (FGE): Insights into the mechanism of formylglycine generation Md Sarfaraz Alam, Karthikeyan Radhakrishnan, Bernhard Schmidt Biochemistry 2, Georg-August University, Gottingen, Germany Formylglycine generating enzyme (FGE) is localized in endoplasmic reticulum and is involved in the activation of sulfatases by unique co-translational protein modification. A severe reduction in sulfatase activation leads to a lysosomal storage disease known as Multiple Sulfatase Deficiency (MSD), a fatal autosomal recessive syndrome in human. FGE modifies a critical cysteine residue in CXPXR motif of nascent sulfatase polypeptide to Cα-formylglycine (Fgly). The core domain of FGE harbors the substrate-binding groove lined by two catalytically active cystienes, stabilized by two disulfide bridges and two calcium ions. FGE needs a thiol based reductant and calcium ions for Fgly generation. The requirement of molecular oxygen during Fgly generation indicates that FGE could act as a monooxygenase but unlike other monooxygenases FGE does not seem to require a cofactor, indicating that it acts via a novel mechanism. But, the precise mechanism of Fgly generation by FGE is unclear. To gain insights into the mechanism, we analyzed the role of DTT and Ca2+ ions, which are required for Fgly generation in vitro. We find that FGE exists in two redox dependent conformations open (reduced) and closed (oxidized). Further we demonstrate that in the presence of DTT, FGE is predominantly in the open (reduced) state and Ca2+ is necessary to maintain FGE in the closed (oxidized) state. The finding that the bound Ca2+ of FGE is dynamic in nature and can be exchanged by externally supplied Ca2+ indicates that Ca2+ plays an important role in conformational switch. A conformational switch is necessary for activity. The synergistic effect of DTT and Ca2+ is required for maintaining equilibrium between closed and open conformation during activity. We conclude from our findings that a redox dependent conformational switch between open and closed conformations of FGE is facilitated by Ca2+ exchange is a necessary step for formylglycine-generation. Recent studies show that Alzheimer's disease is triggered by beta amyloid (Aβ) precursors which further aggregate in larger molecular structures, known as fibrils, and lead to amyloid plaques formation in brain tissue. As a consequence, research efforts are directed away from traditional targets, such as amyloid plaques, and towards early detection of the Aβ precursors. Here we present data showing that Dielectric Relaxation Spectroscopy (DRS) is a very sensitive technique to detect the Aβ precursors. The dielectric response of amyloidogenic Aβ(1-42) and non-amyloidogenic Aβ(42-1) proteins as a function of frequency (10^-3 Hz to 10^7 Hz), temperature (193K to 283K), and incubation time (0-24 h) was measured. To mimic "in vivo" like conditions, the proteins were measured in blood plasma. Our results show that the dielectric signal of amyloidogenic Aβ proteins shifts towards the dielectric signal of the background, as predicted by theoretical calculations. No such shift is observed for the non-amyloidogenic Aβ proteins. In addition, the dielectric signal of both the Aβ and the Aβ(42-1) shows two relaxation processes over the measured temperature range. We used two Havrilik-Negami functions plus conductivity to fit the two relaxation processes. We determined the relaxation time for both processes and calculated the corresponding activation energies. We found that for the alpha relaxation process the activation energies of the amyloidogenic Aβ(1-42) proteins decreases over time while for the nonamyloidogenic Aβ(1-42) proteins it does not change.

In the case of the beta process we observe an initial increase of the activation energy followed by a decrease for amyloidogenic Aβ proteins. However, for the non-amyloidogenic Aβ(42-1) the activation energies remain constant over time. These results show that the DRS technique could provide a viable methodology for identifying Aβ oligomers in biological fluids such as blood plasma, and therefore be the groundwork for the development of an instrument capable of testing for early development of Alzheimer's disease. A major mechanism for achieving specificity in PKA signaling is through isoform differences and through targeting of PKA holoenzymes to macromolecular signaling scaffolds through A Kinase Anchoring Proteins (AKAPs). There are four functionally non-redundant PKA regulatory (R) subunits (RIα, RIβ, RIIα, RIIβ), and each have a stable helical dimerization domain at the N-terminus. The cyclic nucleotide binding domains are at the C-terminus. In the absence of cAMP the R-subunit dimers bind to two catalytic subunits creating a catalytically inactive holoenzyme. The hallmark feature of every AKAP is an amphipathic helix (A Kinase Binding motif or AKB), which binds with high affinity to the dimerization/docking (D/D) domain of the R-subunits. Most AKAPs prefer RII subunits and target the PKA holoenzyme to channels, transporters and receptors. The RI subunits are thought to be more dynamic and are disperse in the cytoplasm often becoming targeted only in response to an extracellular signal. Some AKAPs such as DAKAP1 and DAKAP2 bind to both RI and RII and were thus termed dualspecific. Several AKAPs have been discovered recently that are specific for RI subunits. One of these is a small membrane anchored AKAP termed mmAKAP. The mmAKAP has enhanced specificity for RI (5-8 nM) vs RII subunits (50-60 nM). To understand the specificity requirements that allow for high affinity binding of RI-subunits to AKAPS, we crystallized the A Kinase Binding (AKB) motif from mmAKAP bound to the D/D domain of RIα. We compare this 2.0Å structure to structures of the DAKAP2 AKB bound to both the RIα and RIIα D/D domains. The helical D/D domain provides an extended hydrophobic surface for binding to the AKAP. The mmAKAP(55-78) binds as a long helix to this D/D surface and shields those highly conserved hydrophobic residues. This structure defines the novel features that create high affinity binding for RI and allows us to understand the molecular basis why mmAKAP is a PKA RI-specific AKAP in vivo. branched-chainα-ketoacid dehydrogenase kinase (BDK) down-regulates activity of the branched-chainα-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC), which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of branched-chainα-ketoacids derived from branched-chain amino acids leucine, isoleucine and valine. BCKDC is deficient in patients with inherited Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), resulting in often fatal ketoacidosis, neurological derangement and mental retardation. A known BDK inhibitor phenylbutyrate (PB) was recently shown to increase residual BCKDC activity, lowering branchedchain amino and α-ketoacid levels in MSUD patients. However, PB is a non-selective BDK inhibitor and has pleiotropic effects in cells. Using high-throughput screening, we have identified a group of benzothiophene (BT) compounds that specifically inhibit BDK kinase activity. Compound BT-3 functions as a prodrug, and is converted to BT-2 in cells; the latter is the actual BDK inhibitor. Both BT-2 and PB bind to a 13-Å deep pocket gated by Arg-171 in the N-terminal four-helix bundle of the BDK structure. The bound BT-2 attenuates BDK binding to the BCKDC scaffold, thereby preventing the formation of active BDK. Compounds BT-3, BT-2 and their analogues robustly stimulate BCKDC activity in mouse embryonic fibroblasts, primary hepatocytes and animal tissues by thwarting phosphorylation of the enzyme complex. Structure-based design and chemical synthesis are in progress to increase the selectivity and binding affinity of these novel BDK inhibitors for potential use in MSUD therapy. ( Protein-protein and protein-ligand interactions play fundamental roles in biological systems. Being able to accurately predict these interactions and their affinities remains an elusive but desirable goal. In vitro and in vivo investigations focused on understanding these interactions are critical areas of investigation because of their potential value in identifying novel native biochemical interactions and in guiding drug design. Our lab is focused on understanding the fundamental features that determine the affinity and specificity of such interactions employing techniques such as molecular biology, bioinformatics, enzyme kinetics, proteomics, and molecular modeling. Our ultimate goal is to use our improved understanding of these interactions to make meaningful and accurate predictions leading to the elucidation of biological function and the design of molecules that mimic or interfere with these interactions in a therapeutically meaningful way. The primary focus of our lab is on two homologous human proteases, BACE1 and BACE2, which form a small family of membrane-bound aspartyl proteases. The full length forms of these enzymes were initially identified as a result of to their key roles in the Alzheimer's disease amyloid cascade while alternatively spliced mRNAs that could lead to different protein isoforms were described later. Both enzymes have similar tertiary structures and overlapping protein substrate preferences but distinct tissue expression profiles and subcellular localization. Though a few in vivo substrates have been identified, the physiological functions of this family and its members remain elusive. We will describe our success in confirming that the recombinant BACE1 and BACE2 isoforms are indeed active. In addition, we will report our progress in elucidating the physiological functions of these two enzymes by identifying potential native substrates using in vitro and computational methods followed by in vivo methodologies.
body_text.section: Studies of the Collective Dynamics of Aβ (1-42) Amyloid Precursors Using Dielectric Relaxation

body_text.text: Department of Medicine, The George Washington University and Medical Faculty Associates, Washington DC NBCe1-A co-transports sodium and bicarbonate across basolateral membranes in the nephron and thereby serves to maintain acid-base homeostasis by regulating both intracellular and blood pH. Previously, we have demonstrated the N-terminal domain of NBCe1-A (Nt) is in a pH-sensitive monomer-dimer equilibrium. At neutral pH, bicarbonate binds the Nt, stabilizing dimerization and intermolecular self-associations of dimers. Here, we determine the X-ray crystal structure of the Nt as a dimer at 2.4-Å resolution by noncrystallographic methods. The structure reveals that R298 implicated in the disease proximal renal tubule acidosis is part of a putative conduit that transverses the Nt. The conduit opens to the transmembrane domain (TMD) on one end and an apparent foyer entrance on the opposite end. The human mutation R298S disrupts an electrostatic pocket within the conduit that disables substrate binding. We also report similar conducts in family member Ae1 (Band 3) when analyzing its crystal structure. Further, we identify by mutational data that the autoregulatory domain (ARD) at the N-terminus of the Nt is responsible for self-associations. We propose a model where the ARD is a gate for the foyer. When selfassociated, the foyer entrance is accessible, allowing substrate entry into the conduit. Objective: Optimization and application of a disulfide mapping method to detect scrambling in stressed protein therapeutics by mass spectrometry. Formation of non-native disulfides (disulfide scrambling) within a protein directly impacts its structure. The ability to detect disulfide scrambled species by mass spectrometry requires a method that is tailored to the specific protein of interest. We have developed a method optimized for the protein glucocerebrosidase (GCase), which has a cysteine dense region in its N-terminal segment. Employing this method, we have confirmed the disulfide linkage pattern of the four Cys residues in this region to the known pattern established by x-ray crystallography. Searching stressed samples of GCase we were able to identify minor disulfide scrambled species. Proteolytic digestion of GCase by AspN was used to generate the N-terminal disulfide containing fragment designated L1A1. Another protease, thermolysin, was then used to introduce cleavages within each Cys residue in order to produce disulfide linked peptides distinct to all possible disulfide scrambled species. LCMS data is collected during RP-HPLC purification of the N-terminal fragment. This allows the screening of partially reduced species by searching for these expected masses. The successful complete digestion of the N-terminal fragment by thermolysin requires carefully controlled conditions. These extra cleavage sites complicate downstream data interpretation but make it possible to identify minor disulfide scrambled species that would otherwise be missed. The method has been applied to a control and stressed sample: GCase incubated for 5years at 4°C. Electron capture dissociation (ECD) and electron transfer dissociation (ETD) techniques will also be employed due to their ability to provide complementary sequence information.
body_text.section: Crystal Structure & Biophysical Studies of the N-terminal Domain of NBCe1-A: Illumination of the Human R298S Mutational Defect Harindarpal Gill

body_text.text: Engineering the p19 protein as a delivery agent for short interfering RNAs Dana Danielson 1, 2 RNA interference, the phenomenon where exogenous double stranded RNA induces sequence specific gene knockdown mediated by cellular Argonaute proteins, has enormous potential for both biotechnology and therapy. Short interfering RNAs (siRNAs) are widely used in cell biology to effect gene knockdown in cell and animal-based systems and siRNA-based therapeutics are currently being used to treat a number of diseases, with more in clinical trials. The major obstacle in widespread use of siRNA-based therapeutics is in achieving efficient, non-toxic delivery of the molecules across the cellular membrane thus there is a large effort to develop effective delivery vehicles for siRNA. The p19 protein is expressed by tombusviruses as a suppressor of RNA silencing where it binds siRNAs size-selectively and sequence-independently with nanomolar affinity, thereby preventing their incorporation into the RISC complex and allowing viral propagation in the host plant. We report the engineering of the p19 protein to function as a novel siRNA delivery agent, mediated by a fused cell-penetrating peptide, and its successful use to mediate gene knockdown in situ. Dysregulation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) has been well established as a factor in the development of many types of cancer, making it a strong candidate for targeting in anti-cancer therapies. Existing EGFR-based therapies, while initially successful in certain cases, become ineffective due to the emergence of secondary resistance mechanisms in the tumor. ErbB3, another receptor in the EGFR family, has been implicated in many of these resistances, and presents a new target for the development of more effective EGFR-based treatments. We have previously designed binders against EGFR using the tenth domain of type 3 fibronectin (Fn3) as a protein scaffold, and have developed a novel antibody-like construct in which these EGFR binders have been joined to an existing EGFR-targeting antibody. This triepitopic antibody-Fn3 fusion has been shown to control the growth of tumors in preclinical studies. Our current studies aim to expand the established antibody-Fn3 platform through the engineering of novel antibodies with dual specificity for EGFR and ErbB3, which will be used with our existing EGFR Fn3 binders. Through use of in vitro experiments assaying signaling and receptor levels, as well as in vivo experiments observing efficacy in controlling tumor growth, we will validate these therapeutics' success as a means of subverting resistance to EGFR-based treatments. Thymosin beta4 (Tb4) is a conserved acidic polypeptide (5 kDa) present in all tissues and fluids of human body. Tb4 stimulates angiogenesis and regeneration processes, acts as an anti-inflammatory agent; therefore, it has been tested in clinical trials as a therapeutic preparation to treat chronic ulcers, epidermolysis bullosa, and corneal epithelial defects. Tb4 was also shown to activate hair follicle stem cells and promote hair growth in normal rodents. Earlier, we have shown that under conventional conditions aging CBRB mice spontaneously develop staphylococcal recurring folliculitis followed by alopecia and ulceration reproducing distinct features of human chronic dermatitis. The aim of the present study was to investigate the therapeutic potential of Tb4 in this mouse model; we were especially interested to reveal long-term effects of this polypeptide formulation. Tb4 formulation (Tb4F) was prepared as 20 mkg/ml solution in glycerol/ water. CBRB females (aged 15±1 week, n=17) showing alopecia and ulcerations on the skin of the back were used. Tb4F was applied on the skin of the experimental group (n=8) at days 0, 2 and 7. Mice of the control group (n=9) received glycerol/water solution in the same manner. The level of skin ulceration and alopecia, the square of damaged skin of the back were monitored as dermatitis manifestations. The long-term effects of drug application were registered 2 and 3 months after peptide application. All mice were followed individually during 2 months after Tb4F application without symptomatic treatment and then they were treated with a standard antimicrobial anti antimycotic therapy. Treated mice showed decreased extent of ulceration and the square of damaged skin of the back after two applications of Tb4F comparing with the parameter values in the control mice (p=0,001). Treated mice showed rapid hair follicle recovery; 2 weeks later no hair damage was revealed in treated mice. In the control mice all dermatitis manifestations severed. 2 months after Tb4F application all the three manifestations of chronic dermatitis in the treated mice were still less expressed than in control group (p<0,001). Moreover, the ulcerations in treated mice were less intensive than in control mice 3 months after drug application (p=0,017). Thus, we showed that Tb-4 reduced the severity of dermatitis manifestations and, therefore can be used as a component of skin disease therapy. Human Fibroblast Growth Factor-1 (hFGF-1) is a heparin binding protein that is biologically important in mitogenesis, angiogenesis, and differentiation. Understanding of the effects of hFGF-1 on these biological processes could have wide ranging applications from cancer metastasis to enhanced wound healing. Activation of the FGF receptor requires hFGF-1 to bind to cell surface proteoglycans, such as heparin sulfate. Inhibition of the high affinity of hFGF-1 to heparin could potentially inhibit the FGF signaling process. Based on preliminary cell proliferation assays, it is believed that His35, located in the heparin binding pocket of hFGF-1, is critical for heparin binding and the thermodynamic stability of the protein. In this context, in this study, the role of His35 in the structural stability of hFGF-1 has been examined using site-directed mutagenesis and a variety of biophysical experiments, including multidimensional NMR spectroscopy. Results of this study suggest that His35 is critical for the thermodynamic stability of hFGF-1 both in the absence and presence of heparin. These results will be presented in detail.

Anchoring stem cells to the sites of the ischemic heart injury with the polyspecific antibodies Bianca Malecki 1 , Marek Malecki 2 1 JUMC, Sw. Anny 12, Krakow, 31-008, Poland, 2 PBMEF, San Francisco, CA Stem cells carry a great promise of the regenerative therapy for the patients suffering from the heart attacks. Our goal was to develop the means for targeted delivery and retention of the stem cells at the site of the heart injury. We accomplished this goal by engineering polyspecific tetrabodies. Since, the contractile and skeletal systems were exposed as the result of the heart muscle death, we used them as the anchoring points. Since the stem cells have specific molecules on their surfaces, we used them as the anchors. From our human library of the sequences coding CDRs against contractile proteins (cardiac muscle myosin, actin, alpha-actinin, titin) and SSEA3,4 and TRA160,181, we selected the clones with the highest affinity and specificity. Thereafter, we engineered the constructs fusing coding sequences for CDR targeting muscle apparatus (e.g., cardiac myosin) with the CDR coding stem cell markers (e.g., SSEA3) through the flexible linkers. We further fused such pairs to yield the sequences coding Fv, which were targeting domains of the cardiac muscles and the biomarkers of the stem cells. We expressed them in myelomas, as the integrated antibodies targeting four different molecules -tetrabodies. We further modified them with the fluorochromes and chelates for superparamagnetic ions as reporters. In tests on the isolated cardiac myofibibrils with the laser confocal fluorescence, flow cytometry, western, and native blotting, we revealed their high specificity and affinity. In tests on the cultured cardiac cells, following the exposure to the ischemic stress, in media spiked with the induced stem cells, we demonstrated their high efficiency in anchoring the stem cells to the injured cardiac muscle cells. This novel strategy creates a promising avenue for stem cell based regenerative therapy of the injured heart muscle. Bio-layer interferometry (BLI) has gained popularity in recent years as a reliable, yet simple method for analyzing protein-protein and other biomolecular interactions. BLI has the advantage of probing unmodified proteins, thus eliminating potential perturbation of the interactions being studied, and, avoiding the time-consuming and expensive steps required by the use of labels. To further enhance the ease with which label-free analysis can be performed, we have developed new methods using BLI that allow for rapid identification, quantitation and characterization of expressed protein from a very low volume of sample. New methods and data will be presented to illustrate the ease of incorporating BLI into a lab workflow.

Chemistry & Biochemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR Human Fibroblast Growth Factor-1 (hFGF-1) is a 16kDa heparin-binding protein that is involved with many cellular processes including mitogenesis and cell differentiation, thus enabling the application of hFGF-1 in tissue repair and wound healing. However, hFGF-1 has a short half-life and is quite unstable under room temperature conditions. It has been shown that heparin stabilizes hFGF-1 against thermal denaturation and decreases susceptibility to proteolysis. The quadruple point mutation Q54P/S61L/H107S/K126N is being examined with expectations of increasing overall thermodynamic stability of hFGF-1. The quadruple mutation was achieved by PCR and over-expressed in Escherichia coli in high yields (15mg/L). Biophysical techniques used for examination of the protein include Fluorescence Spectroscopy, Circular Dichroism (CD), Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC), Isothermal Titration Calorimetry (ITC), Two-dimensional NMR Spectroscopy, and ANS (8-anilino-1-naphthalene sulfonate) binding experiments. Results from Fluorescence Spectroscopy and CD show that the mutant protein has not undergone significant conformational change. ANS binding results show an increase in the solvent-accessible hydrophobic surfaces in the hFGF-1 mutant. ITC and DSC results show that the mutant protein has a significantly lower affinity for sucrose octasulfate (SOS), a heparin analog, than the wild type, but the thermodynamic stability of the protein is significantly enhanced in the presence of SOS. Results of this study suggest that the thermodynamic stability of the quadruple mutant of hFGF-1 is enhanced through compensatory structural interactions. Details of these results will be presented. Source of research support: NIH, NSF, and DOE A strongly desirable pulmonary delivery of a potent immunomodulator interferon¬γ (IFNγ) is limited by its high hydrophilicity and thus poor permeability through the hydrophobic barriers of the respiratory epithelium which in turn results in low bioavailability of the protein. Earlier, we used a genetic construct consisting of parts of the genes coding for IFNγ and surfactant C protein (SpC) to produce a recombinant IFN-SpC fuse protein*. The notable α-helix of the SpC part of the chimeric protein comprising 10 valine residues is designed to promote the protein penetration from the airway surface through the surfactant layer down to the immune cells residing in the epithelium. Old CBRB mice under conventional conditions were shown to mimic some characteristics of human chronic dermatitis spontaneously, resembling distinct characteristics of folliculitis, impetigo, ectyma, and some others. The aim of the present study was to investigate the effect of intranasal application of various interferon formulations on mouse chronic dermatitis manifestations. The formulations IFN-SpC fuse protein were applied 4 times daily via intranasal route (20 mkl/ mouse/application). The following parameters and symptoms of dermatitis were monitored: the level of skin ulceration and alopecia, the area of damaged skin on the back, and the animal weight. The degree of ulceration and the area of damaged skin in FS (small dose) and FL (large dose) treated mice decreased one week post drug application comparing with the parameter values in control mice. *A Chimeric Interferon-Surfactant Protein for Medical Applications, patent No. 391403 of the Russian Patent Office .
body_text.section: Characterization of a Thermostable Quadruple Mutant of Human Fibroblast Growth Factor-1 Arshan Dehbozorgi, Rebecca Kerr, Suresh Kumar

body_text.text: Partitioning efficiency during biopanning is essential for optimal selection of internalized phage clones Xia Cao, Jennifer Liberal, Oscar Betancourt, Gang Chen, John Dwyer Biotherapeutics R&D, Pfizer, Inc., 9381 Judicial Drive, San Diego, CA, 92112 Biopanning against living cells using phage display is a powerful approach for selection of novel peptide ligands for surface receptors. However, selection of peptides that are specifically internalized into the cell is more difficult. Partitioning of internalized versus surface bound phage is necessary for enrichment of relevant clones and requires stringent washing conditions and efficient internalization. Using a peptide directed against EGFR as an example, a phage pool was spiked with different percentages of a winning clone to mimic enrichment, and a panel of internalization and washing schemes was assessed to quantify partitioning and identify optimal conditions for biopanning. Recovered phage as a function of time was used to identify the rate of internalization. We then applied the spiked phage pools at 37 C and at 4 C (where internalization should be minimal) and compared the eluted phage titers after washing. Clones from the recovered phage were sequenced and this information was used to estimate the partitioning efficiency as a function of enrichment. We demonstrate that in the early rounds of selection, very little phage is internalized, partitioning is poor, and selection is driven predominantly by receptor binding. Similarly, inefficient scrubbing of the cell surface reduces partitioning in highly enriched phage pools. We also show that pre-enrichment of phage libraries with recombinant protein does not necessarily avoid the lack of partitioning in the early rounds of selection. These results should aid in the optimization of phage selection strategies for receptor-mediated delivery of therapeutic payloads.

body_text.text: Design and characterization of a TPR-peptide interaction Elizabeth Speltz, Lynne Regan Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry, Yale University, New Haven, CT Protein-protein interactions regulate many cellular processes such as signal transduction, protein degradation and metabolism. Our goal is to develop a set of orthogonal protein-peptide pairs that can be used to manipulate existing cellular processes. We base our design on the tetratricopeptide repeat, a 34-amino acid helix-turn-helix motif. In cells, tandem tetratricopeptide repeats bind peptides and regulate many protein-protein interactions. Our template TPR recognizes the C-terminal residues MEEVD. Here, we alter the specificity of our template to recognize the C-terminal residues MEEVV. We screen a small hydrophobic TPR library for binding to MEEVV using the in vivo split GFP assay. We further characterize the affinity and specificity of the designed TPR-peptide interactions using quantitative pulldowns and isothermal titration calorimetry. Our designed TPRs recognize MEEVV with a 1 μM Kd. However, they also bind other hydrophobic peptides such as MEEVΦ (where Φ is I, L, V and M) equally well. Therefore, the free energy is independent of ligand size and shape. Interestingly, however, the thermodynamic signature depends on ligand size and shape. Therefore, these designed interactions are an interesting system to study hydrophobic protein interactions. They may also be used to modify existing protein interactions in vivo.

body_text.text: In vivo activity of a photo-switchable DNA-binding Photo-switchable DNA-binding proteins enable researchers to perturb gene expression using light -a signal which is reversible, rapid, and non-invasive (1) . A light-switchable DNA-binding protein was previously made by fusing the bZIP region of GCN4 with the light-sensing photoactive-yellow protein (PYP) from Halorhodospira halophila, a marine bacterium (2, 3) . This chimera, designated as GCN4PYP, has 3-4 times higher affinity for DNA when irradiated with blue light in vitro (3) . In this study, the photo-switching ability of GCN4PYP was recapitulated in vivo using red-fluorescent protein (RFP) reporter. By inserting the target DNA sequence upstream of the gene coding for the RFP, GCN4PYP's binding to DNA would interfere with RFP expression. Several strains of E. coli were tested to optimize the RFP reporter system. Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorting (FACS) was able to detect varying levels of RFP transcription in individual cells. The potential for using this system to artificially evolve a superior light-switchable DNA-binding protein is discussed. 1. Fenno, L. et al. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. (2010) Nevertheless, the first step in this direction was attained by engineering bispecific antibodies, which were capable for targeting two different epitopes. The goal of our work was biomolecular engineering of polyspecific antibody platform, capable of hosting multiple combinations of the CDRs targeting many different molecules. Herein, we report successful engineering of such the platform and using it for assembling of polyspecific antibodies targeting four different epitopes -tetrabodies. We selected the epitopes of the cardiac muscle myosin, actin, alpha-actinin, titin as test targets. Based upon our human library of the cDNAs for complementarity determining regions (CDRs), we expressed these CDRs in human myelomas under CMV promoters. We selected the clones with the highest affinity and specificity. We fused them into the constructs for the CDRs joined through the flexible linkers. We expressed them also in human myelomas. Finally, we bioengineered their linear and closed, circular versions. On the tests on cardiac muscle cryosections, native myofibrils, Western, and native blots, these tetrabodies assured the high specificity and sensitivity of the labeling for each of the four targeted domains, as demonstrated by the strong and specific labeling. Our tetrabody technology advances the new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies aimed at interfacing different biomolecules into mutlimolecular clusters.

body_text.text: Reversibly switchable Enhanced Green Fluorescent Protein (rsEGFP): a novel photochromic fluorescent protein enables RESOLFT-type microscopy of living cells at low light intensities Tim Grotjohann 1 , Ilaria Testa 1 , Marcel Leutenegger 1 , Christian Eggeling 1 , Stefan Hell 1 , Stefan Jakobs 1, 2 1 Department of NanoBiophotonics, Max-Planck-Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Am Fassberg 11, Göttingen, 37077, Germany, 2 Neurology, University of Göttingen Medical School, Göttingen, Germany Reversibly Switchable Fluorescent Proteins (RSFPs) can be repeatedly switched between a fluorescent Onstate and a non-fluorescent Off-state by light of two different wavelengths. These switching properties make RSFPs interesting labels for super-resolution microscopy, most notably in RESOLFT (REversibly Saturable OpticaL Fluorescence Transition) -type microscopy. However, the pronounced photobleaching, low brightness, slow switching speed and high switching fatigue of most previously reported RSFPs limited their use for RESOLFT-type microscopy. We report on the generation of a novel RSFP, namely rsEGFP. This bright and photostable protein exhibits fast switching characteristics and can be photoswitched more than a thousand times between the On-state and the Off-state enabling for the first time RESOLFT-type microscopy of living cells and tissue. In living cells, an optical resolution <40 nm was attained using light intensities of ~1 kW/cm2, which is a million fold less than the intensities generally used in Stimulated Emission Depletion (STED) super-resolution microscopy. Mitochondrial and gyloxysomal forms of malate dehydrogenase are thought to be subject to allosteric regulation by citrate. To explore the mechanisms of citrate effects on the enzyme we have used a combination of initial rate kinetics, site directed mutagenesis, circular dichroism (in conjunction with thermal melts) to follow effects on secondary and tertiary structure, dynamic light scattering and size exclusion chromatography to follow effects on quaternary structure and limited proteolysis to explore local flexibility/accessibility changes. Citrate, which binds to only one of the two otherwise identical active sites, is a partial inhibitor under all circumstances examined (varied pH, forward or reverse reaction) and does not affect the potent substrate inhibition observed at high oxaloacetate concentrations. Citrate shows a dramatic pH dependence for its affinity, binding approximately 10 fold better at pH 6 than pH 7 or 8. It has little or no effect on the stability of tertiary structure as assessed by thermal melts and has no effect on the quaternary structure of the protein. Citrate does however induce changes in local flexibility/accessibility in a loop near the subunit interface. Several mutations at the subunit interface (V195A, L269A, E256Q, H90Q)also impact citrate inhibition. Together these results suggest that citrate exerts its effects on activity by binding to the "empty" active site in a reciprocating subunit mechanism, eliciting altered subunit interactions that contribute to overall catalysis. The green fluorescent protein and its homologues have become essential tools for the visualization of protein distributions and of dynamic processes in living cells and organisms. In the last decade members of a new subclass of fluorescent proteins, namely the reversibly switchable fluorescent proteins (RSFPs) have attracted widespread attention for their unique property that they may be repeatedly photoswitched between a fluorescent and a non-fluorescent state by irradiation with light of two distinct wavelengths. However, the full potential of these conventional RSFPs has been curtailed for many applications since switching and fluorescence read-out in these proteins is strictly coupled. To overcome this limitation we generated the RSFP Dreiklang, which enables reversible photoswitching independently from fluorescence excitation. In Dreiklang, fluorescence is excited at ~515 nm, whereas reversible on-and offswitching is accomplished at illumination wavelengths of ~365 nm and ~405 nm, respectively. High resolution X-ray analysis of single Dreiklang protein crystals in the photoswitched off-and on-states demonstrate that switching in Dreiklang is based on a reversible hydration/dehydration reaction of the chromophore. This molecular reversible switching mechanism was further supported by mass spectrometry data. The unique switching properties of Dreiklang enabled far-field fluorescence super-resolution microscopy in living mammalian cells using both an ensemble and a single molecule based switching approach. Dreiklang represents a new class of RSFPs opening up new possibilities in light microscopy. Identification of reliable biomarkers in the blood requires access to technologies with sufficient specificity and sensitivity to meet the complexity of blood proteomic. In addition, the focus on proteins as biomarker has now being expanded to other biomolecules such as high molecular weight microvesicles and exosomes. We have recently developed a variant of proximity ligation assay (4PLA) in which target molecules to be detected are captured via affinity binders immobilized on a solid support while other components in the sample are washed away. The target molecules are then recognized by four PLA probes -four antibodies each extended by a unique DNA oligonucleotide. When these four probes bind proximally to a common target molecule the DNA oligonucleotides of the probes are brought sufficiently close so that in the presence of a cassette DNA oligonucleotide they create an amplifiable reporting DNA molecule via two enzymatic ligation events. The combined use of five binding reagents and efficient PCR amplification provide very high specificity and sensitivity, which distinguishes the 4PLA method from conventional protein detection methods. Here, we illustrate the application of 4PLA for sensitive detection of high-order protein complexes, such as prostasomes, as biomarkers for prostate cancer. References 1. Darmanis S. et al. Mol. Cell. Proteomics, 9:327 (2010 ). 2. Tavoosidana G. et al. PNAS. 108:8809-14 (2011 .

body_text.text: In the course of protein evolution, the interactions between side chains are optimized for overall organism fitness. An enzyme must both be stable and fulfill its metabolic role within certain kinetic parameters. Because the preferred environment of organisms can vary widely across phylogenies, homologous enzymes can have similar backbones but different side chain packing, thereby fine-tuning interaction strength and dynamic mechanisms for environmental conditions. This evolution-driven varying of side chain packing can create positional correlations in multiple sequence alignments. It has been shown that these correlations may reflect stabilizing interactions, but do not necessarily do so. We present here correlation-guided mutations made in the adenylate kinase enzyme of Bacillus subtilis bacteria (bsADK) which, in the context of a destabilized variant, affect kinetic activity without altering stability. The folded lid domain of bacterial ADK closes over the active site following substrate binding. This domain is stabilized by either a zinc-chelating motif in grampositive species or by a network of hydrogen bonds in gram-negative species. Mutating the four chelating residues of bsADK to their counterparts in Escherichia coli ADK (ecADK), abolishing metal-binding, results in a severe drop in global stability and the loss of enzymatic activity. Using mutual information analysis, we located two positions in the lid domain strongly correlated to chelating motif. Further mutations were made in bsADK at these positions. These additional mutations were found to have little effect on global stability, but served to partially rescue enzymatic activity. Although it is understood that loss and gain of stability can directly alter the dynamics of adenylate kinase, the fact that these variants do not vary in stability suggests that they could serve as an experimental system for further studying the kinetic pathway of this enzyme. We are currently pursuing biophysical strategies to further characterize these variants and elaborate on their kinetic differences. structure of the enzyme has been characterised from several bacterial species, including, Escherichia coli, Thermotoga maritima, Vibrio cholerae and Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The enzyme forms different oligomeric structures in the crystal form depending on the species. Moreover, DAPDC from the Gram-negative eubacteria E. coli and T. maritima is monomeric, while the enzyme from the Gram-negative eubacterium V. cholerae is dimeric, and the eubacterium M. tuberculosis produces DAPDC as a tetramer in the crystal form. We hypothesise that the diversity of the enzyme's quaternary structure is linked to species diversity and/or the environment in which the enzyme functions, and that dimerisation is required for activity. Accordingly, the aim of this study is to characterise the quaternary structure of DAPDC in solution and crystal forms from diverse eubacterial species. We have thus cloned, expressed, and purified DAPDC from Bacillus anthracis and are currently conducting structural studies comparing B. anthracis DAPDC with the enzyme from Psychromonas ingrahamii, T. maritima, V. cholerae, and M. tuberculosis. Presently, we have found that recombinant DAPDC from B. anthracis, V. cholerae, and M. tuberculosis form dimers in solution from analytical ultracentrifugation studies at various concentrations. Interestingly, DAPDC from the thermophile T. maritima forms tetramers in solution.

Using genomic data to uncover bacterial microcompartment organelles with novel metabolic functions Julien Jorda, David Lopez, Todd Yeates DOE-MBI, UCLA, Los Angeles, CA Bacterial microcompartments (BMC's) are polyhedral organelles made of a protein shell that confines sequentially acting enzymes involved in specific metabolic processes. To date, different BMC's carrying out just three distinct types of metabolic processes have been characterized. In the present work we use comparative genomics to explore the possible existence of BMC's carrying out a broader variety of metabolic pathways. The operons coding for these supramolecular BMC assemblies share a canonical genomic signature: multiple paralogous protein shell genes -i.e. structural proteins of the shell -interspersed with genes coding for enzymes responsible for distinctive metabolic pathways. Based on this property, we developed an approach to investigate the likelihood that additional pathways might be housed within BMC's in various bacteria. In particular, we designed an automatic clustering algorithm that groups together enzymes that show a strong tendency to be encoded in chromosomal proximity to each other when they are also near genes encoding BMC shell proteins. The results highlight new types of putative BMC's, including one based on pyruvate utilization (referred to here as the Put microcompartment), while also illuminating specific variations among the well-known BMC's. A general view is that BMC's appear to host a small number of core pathways, which in some cases can be extended beyond their minimalistic function by integrating other enzymes or regulatory proteins into the BMC operon. Based on these new considerations, we propose a more articulated classification of microcompartments and their metabolic variants than previously recognized.

Characterization of W-WAP and Overexpression of full length human Anosmin in Pichia pastoris Beatrice Kachel, Jacqueline Morris, Srinivas Jayanthi, T.k.s. Kumar Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR Anosmin-1, a protein encoded by KAL-1, is associated with the Kallmann syndrome when defected. Being an ECM protein Anosmin-1 interacts with various other members of the ECM. Recent studies using GST pull downs and co-Immunoprecipitation showed that Anosmin-1 directly interacts with the D2-D3 domains of the FGF-Receptor 1 which is mediated by Heperan sulfate and FGF-2. It was proposed that the WAP domain (whey acidic protein-like) and the FnIII-1 of Anosmin-1 are critical for this interaction. There is no evidence of the structural details of this interaction, full length (FL) Anosmin-1 and the independent domains need to be overexpressed and purified in large quantities to perform various biophysical experiments. The present study is focused on cloning, overexpression and purification of the FL-Anosmin-1 as well as the combination of domains. Of all the recombinant constructs only WAP domain expressed in the soluble fraction in E.coli. Due to the lack of any aromatic amino a Tryptophan residue was introduced at the extreme c-terminus of WAP and purified to homogeneity using one step GSH Sepharose affinity chromatography. A detailed biophysical characterization of the W-WAP is presented here. Due to the poor expression of FL-Anosmin-1 from the bacterial expression system, an attempt is made to clone and express in yeast (Pichia pastoris) which helps in a better expression and serves the post-translational modification.

Insights into the structure and assembly process of a fibril-forming fungal protein Vanessa Morris 1, 2 , Ann Kwan 2 , Joel Mackay 2 , Margaret Sunde 1, 2 1 Department of Pharmacology, University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia, 2 School of Molecular Bioscience, University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia

Hydrophobins are small fungal proteins that self-assemble into amphipathic monolayers at hydrophobic:hydrophilic interfaces. They play diverse roles in fungal development, including providing a hydrophobic coating to spores. DewA is a class I hydrophobin that forms monolayers composed of laterally assembled fibrillar structures called rodlets that are functional amyloid (figure). DewA is highly stable is solution and only forms the fibrillar monolayers at air:water interfaces or on surfaces. This protein is of great biotechnological interest, but in order to be fully utilised, its solution and interface behaviours must be well understood. We have solved the solution structure of DewA in its monomeric soluble form, and it has a unique fold that is different to that of other hydrophobin structures. In addition, we are probing the mechanism of the self-assembly process. We have found that DewA has two conformational states in solution that form rodlets at different rates, and have found that DewA can form a dimer that is off-pathway to rodlet formation. We have prepared a number of DewA glycine-substitution mutants in order to identify residues which play a critical role in intermolecular association and rodlet formation. These studies will allow a greater understanding of the conformational changes that take place and the driving forces associated with the formation of these fascinating and unique structures.

New nanomaterials: Amyloid fibrils from waste proteins Laura Domigan 1, 2, 3 , Susie Meade 3 , Richard Blaikie 4, 2 , Juliet Gerrard 1, 2, 3 1 School of Biological Sciences, University of Canterbury, Private Bag 4800, Christchurch, 8041, New Zealand, 2 MacDiarmid Institute for Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology, Christchurch, New Zealand, 3 Biomolecular Interaction Centre, Christchurch, New Zealand, 4 University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand

The current landscape of nanotechnology has focussed attention on materials that self-assemble. The search for such materials has unsurprisingly led to the biological world, where nanoscale biomolecular assemblies are in abundance. Amyloid fibrils are one such selfassembling biological structure, formed when native proteins misfold into insoluble fibrous quarternary structures. This research has explored the use of amyloid fibrils formed from waste proteins, namely crude crystallin proteins from fish eye lenses, as biological nanowires. The use of amyloid fibrils as nanowires was investigated by examining the ability to control their dimensions and arrangement, along with analysis of their properties, such as stability and conductivity. TEM and AFM studies on the model amyloid forming protein, bovine insulin, showed that a number of fibril length distributions can be achieved, by systematically altering fibril growth and storage conditions [1] . Crystallin fibrils can also be produced on a range of length scales [2] . Amyloid fibrils can be manipulated and aligned in a controlled manner by dielectrophoresis (DEP); this tool could later be used to incorporate amyloid fibrils into a biosensing or bioelectronics device. DEP was also used to immobilize fibrils between electrode pairs, in order to investigate the conductivity of small numbers of fibrils. These experiments complemented work carried out on the conductivity of amyloid fibril networks, using fabricated interdigitated electrodes. In the unmodified state, amyloid fibrils formed from bovine insulin, fungal hydrophobins, and crude crystallins were all shown to have low conductivity, with current values in the range of 10-8-10-10 A recorded at bias voltages of 0-2 V. Amyloid fibrils were used as a template for the synthesis of conductive nanowires, by modification with conducting polymers, increasing conductivity by up to four orders of magnitude. The functionalisation of fibrils with glucose oxidase enabled the creation of a very simple glucose sensing device, which showed an electrochemical response in the presence of glucose and the mediator FcOH. Future work is necessary to optimise the use of amyloid fibrils in this way; however, this study confirms a role for amyloid fibrils from a low cost source in bionanotechnology. The steroid receptors (SRs) are a family of transcription factors that control genes involved in development, endocrine signaling, reproduction, immunity, and cancer. The entire hormone-receptor system is driven by the binding of small lipophilic ligands, making SRs ideal pharmaceutical targets. However, even the best clinically used synthetic steroids are prone to crossreactivity and off-target pharmacology, and as such their use carries the risk of side-effects. This promiscuity is due to the fact that all modern SRs are descended from a common evolutionary ancestor, and share common structural features derived from this relationship. Rational attempts to probe steroid drug selectivity are frequently complicated by the inherent instability of the extant SRs, hindering detailed mutational analysis and preventing the crystallization of key receptor-ligand complexes. We have taken a unique approach to address this problem by using resurrected ancestral proteins to determine the structure of a previously intractable complex, identifying the structural mechanisms that confer activation and selectivity for mometasone furoate (MOF), a widely used synthetic glucocorticoid. The X-ray crystal structure of the ancestral glucocorticoid receptor AncGR2 in complex with MOF and a TIF2 coactivator fragment was solved to 2.5 Å. This structure was compared to the structures of other SRs, and to functional data obtained from ligand binding and activation assays, in order to explain the selectivity of MOF for the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) over the androgen (AR) and mineralocorticoid (MR) receptors, and its cross-reactivity with the progesterone receptor (PR). Moreover, we identify a single residue located outside of the ligand binding pocket that enables activation of MR by MOF when mutated to its ancestral state.

Understanding the Binding Interactions of the 43kDa subunit of cpSRP with the C-terminal Domain of Alb3 Jake Usery 1 , Srinivas Jayanthi 1 , Ananthamurthy Koteshwara 1 , Alicia Kight 2 , Shobha Mysoreswamy 1 , Rory Henderson 1 , Robyn Goforth 2 , Ralph Henry 2 , Suresh Kumar 1 Chloroplast Signal Recognition Particle (cpSRP) plays a crucial role in the post-translational targeting of the Light Harvesting Chlorophyll Binding Protein (LHCP). Albino3 (Alb3), an integral membrane protein, has been shown to act in cooperation with cpSRP to facilitate the targeting and insertion of LHCP into the thylakoid membrane. Recent studies have shown that the soluble C-terminal domain of Alb3 (C-term Alb3) interacts with the 43 kDa subunit of cpSRP (cpSRP43). The ankyrin domains and the C-terminal chromo domains (CD2-CD3) of cpSRP43 have been demonstrated to contribute to the binding of C-term Alb3. This study is aimed at characterization of the structural forces governing the interaction of the CD2-CD3 domains of cpSRP43 with C-term Alb3. In this context, the three-dimensional solution structure of CD2-CD3 has been determined using multi-dimensional NMR spectroscopy. The 3D structure of CD2-CD3 consists of two helices and six anti-parallel beta-strands. The C-term Alb3 interaction sites on CD2-CD3 were mapped using isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) experiments. One of the C-term-Alb3 peptides (CM4) showed significant binding (Kd ~ 8 µM) to CD2-CD3 but not to the isolated CD2 or CD3 domains. Results of the Far UV and intrinsic fluorescence experiments show that moderate conformational changes occur in the CD2-CD3 domain on binding to CM4. 1H-15N chemical shift perturbation experiments suggest that E59 and E88 in CD2-CD3 contribute significantly to the binding of CM4. ITC results reveal that mutation of E88 completely abolishes the binding of CM4 to CD2-CD3. Additional experiments suggest that the interaction between CM4 and CD2-CD3 is predominantly electrostatic. The synthesis of proteins by the 70S ribosome involves a variety of translation factors with ribosome-dependent GTPase activity. Of current interest is the role that ribosomal protein L7/L12 plays in the interaction of these factors, and their subsequent GTPase activation, with the 70S ribosome. We have shown that selective removal of L7/L12 causes a reduction in the GTPase activity of the translation factors, most dramatically for elongation factor G (EF-G). Current work focuses on further elucidation of the mechanism of L7/L12 on stimulation a variety of GTPase translation factors (EF-G, RF3, EF4, BipA and IF-2). To quantify the GTPase activity of these factors, an optimization of an assay that measures the amount of inorganic phosphate in solution using Malachite Green has been underway. Additionally, this assay is being employed to investigate the inhibitory effects of the antibiotics thiostrepton and micrococcin on the activity of EF-G and EF4 in the presence of the ribosome. Our previous work has shown that a mutation removing EF-G domains IV and V results in a protein that is no longer sensitive to thiostrepton, which has been hypothesized to block the interaction of domain V with the ribosome. Current investigations, however, have indicated that a mutant lacking only domain V is sensitive to thiostrepton, in contrast to previous speculation. Further studies using affinity-purified 70S ribosomes will allow for further characterization of the role of L7/L12 in the activation and various thiopeptide antibiotics in the inhibition of translation factors that possess ribosome-dependent GTPase activity.

Purification and Characterization of a Novel Affinity Tag Emily Crossfield, Srinivas Jayanthi, Suresh Kumar Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR Fibroblast growth factors (FGFs) are cytokines which regulate key cellular processes such as cell proliferation, cell differentiation, wound healing and tumor growth, Heparin, a highly sulfated polysaccharide, binds to fibroblast growth factors (FGF) and triggers the FGF signaling process. Heparin facilitates the dimerization and activation of the FGF receptor. Large number of proteins containing positively-charged arginine and lysine have high binding affinities to heparin. In the present study, we have developed a novel clone where the fusion protein HCW was overexpressed in E. coli with an N-terminus Heparin affinity tag and was subjected to one-step purification using heparin affinity chromatography. The purified Hep-tag, was characterized using various biophysical tools to understand structure and mode of interaction with heparin. Isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) results showed that HEP-tag binds to heparin with nanomolar affinity (Kd ~ 150 nM), and far-UV CD spectral analysis suggested that the peptide was predominantly in random coil conformation in solution. However, upon binding to heparin, the affinity tag folded into a helical conformation. Steady state fluorescence suggested that the Hep-tag binds to heparin in a 1:1 stoichiometry. Multi-dimensional NMR data suggest that the binding between the HEP-tag and heparin is predominantly electrostatic. These results will be discussed in detail.

body_text.section: Stock solution management and web-enabled protein formulation generation Peter Nollert

body_text.text: The use of liquid handling instrumentation in protein science laboratories has dramatically increased the quantity and quality of research output. Such instruments require a constant supply of reagents and buffers, and interrupting this supply hampers research output. This poster presents 5 best practices to avoid stock solution management issues in a protein laboratory. Our recommendations are based on years of experience in supplying our own farm of Matrix Maker instruments with stock solutions for the production of protein crystallization reagents. This poster covers the fundamentals of proper stock solution management and how to apply it practically, making liquid handling instrumentation a successful component in the lab. We also present a web-enabled online solution design tool, E-screen builder (http://www.emeraldbiosystems.com/ escreentoolkit/escreen.html) that allows any user to quickly design two dimensional optimization matrices. Users first select a starting formulation and the system automatically generates a two-dimensional, 96-well based formulation optimization matrix which can be adjusted with respect to upper and lower concentration boundaries. The component information of such designed formulation matrices can be downloaded as PDF or CSV files or in the form of a pipetting plan. Burkholderia cenocepacia is an opportunistic pathogen of the lungs with remarkable natural antibiotic resistance and a significant cause of fatality among cystic fibrosis patients, among others. A better understanding of the metabolic processes of this bacterium could provide novel avenues for combating these dangerous infections.
body_text.section: Stock solution management and web-enabled protein formulation generation Peter Nollert

body_text.text: We have recently expressed and purified 3-hydroxy-3methylglutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase from Burkholderia cenocepacia. This enzyme is wellknown as the first committed and rate-limiting step in the mevalonate pathway for biosynthesis of isoprenoids and the target for statin drugs for lowering serum cholesterol levels. However, a search of the B. cenocepacia genome strongly indicates that this organism lacks the other enzymes of the mevalonate pathway, while expressing the enzymes of the nonmevalonate pathway for isoprenoids. Several other bacteria appear to have a similar organization, and may represent a unique subclass of bacterial HMG-CoA reductases (HMGRs) not used for isoprenoid biosynthesis. Kinetic data for B. cenocepacia HMG-CoA reductase shows that this enzyme uses only NAD(H), not NADP(H), as the hydride donor/acceptor, indicating that the enzyme likely runs in an oxidative, rather than reductive, direction in vivo. Additional kinetic and structural characterization suggests that this enzyme is unusual among HMG-CoA reductases in possible regulatory properties as well. Ongoing progress toward a HMGR gene knockout in B. cenocepacia will also be presented. Immobilized metal affinity chromatography (IMAC) purification of secreted histidine-tagged proteins in eukaryotic cell culture supernatants is often problematic. Incompatibility with the cell culture media appears as stripping of the immobilized metal ions required for binding of target proteins. . Due to low target protein concentration in cell culture supernatants, large sample volumes are often needed, aggravating the stripping effect. In this study, purifications of histidine-tagged proteins were performed using two novel Sepharose™ based IMAC media; Ni Sepharose excel and magnetic His Mag Sepharose excel. Both media have a new type of chelating ligand with exceptionally strong binding of nickel ions. Data showing successful purification of histidine-tagged proteins from CHO cell culture supernatants will be presented. In comparison, conventional IMAC medium showed no recovery of target protein. Furthermore, the characteristics of new media enabled purification of target protein from insect cell culture supernatants. The purification was easily scaled up from 20 µl His Mag Sepharose excel beads to 1 mL pre-packed columns.
