body_text.text: The Role of Conformational Flexibility in 3-phosphoglycerate Dehydrogenase: Do the Inter-Nucleotide Domain loops act as an Entropy Sink in Catalytic Activity and Allosteric Regulation Ellis Bell 1 , James Marion 2 , Cristina Meehan 1 , Donnie Berkholz 1 , Bradley Falk 1 , Jessica Bell 2 1 University of Richmond, 28 Westhampton Way, Richmond, VA, 23173, 2 Biochemistry, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA Proteins can take on an array of conformations determined by regional flexibility of the protein.

This may play critical roles in catalysis and allosteric regulation. The relationship between structure and function was studied to determine the contributions particular amino acids at the cofactor interface and the central inter-domain loops in 3phospho-glycerate dehydrogenase. (3pGDH), may play in flexibility and the protein's function. Multiple techniques show significant changes in local protein flexibility upon serine binding, including limited proteolysis, a sophisticated analysis of crystallographic B-factors, and normal-mode analysis using Gaussian and anisotropic network models. The results suggest the active form is flexible and populates multiple conformers including both active and inhibited conformations, whereas once serine binds, PGDH becomes rigid and is locked into an inactive, open conformation. Although much of the protein rigidifies upon serine inhibition, the tetrameric core becomes flexible; this suggests a reallocation of conformational entropy that breaks an Asn190 intersubunit interaction, which may be involved in serine cooperativity. Local conformation was probed by collisional quenching using positive, negative and neutral quenching agents, limited proteolysis and dynamic light scattering. Based upon available crystal structures a number of amino acids were identified by analysis of the temperature factors that may show altered flexibility in response to serine binding. In addition in conjunction with analysis of the temperature factors of bound cofactor (NAD(H)) we observe that two of the 4 central loops in the tetramer structure are more flexible than the other two and that this correlates with increased affinity for the cofactor. This creates an entropy sink that can be used to harness flexibility changes for catalysis and allosteric regulation. Various point mutations of specific amino acid residues involved in this "entropy sink" were created and the expressed proteins purified using Ni-NTA affinity chromatography. Preliminary results suggest significant effects on activity as well as serine allosteric effects. Our observations suggest the presence of an entropy sink which contributes to cofactor binding cooperativity and possibly catalysis and serine regulation. This work is supported by NSF Grant MCB 0448905 to EB The histidine-tag is widely used to facilitate purification of recombinant expressed proteins. For immobilized metal-ion affinity chromatography (IMAC) the most used metal ion is Ni2+. Also Co2+ has been shown useful in obtaining high purity with good yields of histidine-tagged proteins. Prepacked HiTrapTM TALON® crude column facilitates scalable, fast and easy protein purification of histidine-tagged proteins. Unclarified samples can be loaded directly to the column reducing the total purificationtime which helps to ensure high concentrated pure and intact target proteins with minimal degradation. Two proteins (produced in E.coli and P. pastoris) were purified ending up in >90% purity and yields of 90%. An automated purification of a kinase was done by IMAC and gel filtration. SDS-PAGE analysis showed that the obtained purity of the kinase was above 90% and the amount purified protein was 3 mg. Further, four purification cycles, without cleaning and Co2+-recharging between the runs, show that the HiTrap TALON crude columns can be used several times without loosing performance. Purity and yield was unchanged.

Repeat-protein templates for assembly and patterning of nanostructured materials Tijana Grove 1 , Rachael Parker 1 , Lynne Regan 2 , Aitziber Cortajarena 3 1 Chemistry, Virginia Tech, Department of Chemistry, Blacksburg, VA, 24060, 2 Molecular Biophysics & Biochemistry, Yale University, New Haven, CT, 3 IMDEA Nanociencia, Cantoblanco, Madrid, Spain Fundamental advances in biotechnology, medicine, environment, electronics and energy require methods for control of structure on nanometer scales. Assemblies that rely on highly specific biomolecular interactions are an attractive approach for the tailoring of nanostructure and bottom-up design of materials with sophisticated properties. Here, we use the intrinsic self-assembling properties of the designed, rod shaped, superhelical consensus sequence tetratricopeptide repeat protein, CTPR to generate a nanostructured biomaterials. X-ray scattering experiments confirm macroscopic alignment of the CTPR molecules within the material and CD and FTIR measurements show that the individual CTPR molecules retain their secondary structure in the film. Furthermore, CTPRs maintain their ligand binding functionality within the material. We will discuss structural and physical properties of nanostructured material, and its ability to impose order on the otherwise disordered molecules such as quantum dots and fluorescent dyes. This work opens the door to generation of innovative biomaterials with tailored structural and functional properties. Enzyme activity can be conditionally regulated by introducing a self-splicing intein into the target enzyme. Inteins are protein domains that self-splice from a protein structure, covalently linking the N-and C-terminally adjacent residues of the protein host. Inteins can be developed into an efficient binary switch where intein insertion results in loss of activity, and splicing regains activity. We are exploiting this technology to express cell wall hydrolytic enzymes as inactive precursors in plants to reactivate the enzymes after harvest. This strategy decouples enzyme production from hydrolysis and enables high level expression without detrimental effects. This technology has utility in the auto-hydrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass and in other industrial and agricultural applications. To develop glycoside hydrolases with regulated intein splicing, the location and identity of the intein were varied within target enzymes. For certain intein-enzyme combinations, intein splicing was trained for either temperature or pH inducibility and catalytically active enzymes were recovered after splicing. Intein variants with conditionally regulated splicing were produced using random and site-directed mutagenesis. Proteins that showed conditional activation at splicing induction conditions were further optimized in successive rounds of mutagenesis and screening. These enzymes are now being introduced into transgenic crops to decrease the cost of cellulosic biofuel production. This research was funded in part by the United States Departments of Agriculture (USDA) and Energy (DOE ARPA-E). The soluble periplasmic fumarate reductase (FccA) permits anaerobic growth on fumarate as the terminal electron acceptor for numerous gram negative bacteria, but in the metabolically versatile Shewanella, an additional role has become apparent, i.e., in electron transfer to mineral phase Fe3+ at the cell surface. Moreover, highly abundant FccA acts as an "overflow buffer", storing excess electrons when electron transfer rates are slow. Induced anaerobically, FccA protein abundance is diminished under aerobic conditions. Further, we find that in the presence of oxygen the remaining FccA becomes highly oxidized with formation of methionine sulfoxides at methionine residues proximal to both the active site and heme groups involved in electron transfer into the active site. In vitro exposure to hydrogen peroxide and the subsequent methionine oxidation results in a loss in reductase activity which is prevented by the presence of methionine sulfoxide reductase B-A, a fused enzyme capable of reduction of both R-and S-steroisomers of methionine sulfoxide. These results suggest that reversible methionine oxidation provides a mechanism by which FccA retains sufficient levels of inactive protein in the periplasm under aerobic conditions that permits its rapid re-activation upon re-establishment of anaerobic conditions that precedes the synthesis of new protein. Such a redox regulatory mechanism is critical to the organism's ability to retain metal reduction capacity without extensive cellular damage from reactive oxygen species generated as a result of the high content of transition metal cytochromes within the oxidizing environment of the Shewanella periplasm. In classic studies, different Ras isoforms were shown to be directed to different localization pathways by divergent C-terminal hypervariable regions. More recently, N-terminal GFP fusions have become an established method to study Ras localization. GFP fusions have been used to test how deletions in the Ras isoforms or small fragments of them affect localization in a variety of cell lines. Substitutions in the hypervariable region have been used to identify the role of individual amino acids. Here, we present an alternative approach to investigate localization via chimeragenesis between NRas and KRas4B to test the localization motifs within the context of a complete Ras protein. When fused to GFP and introduced to COS-7 cells, our chimeras have confirmed the necessity of the polybasic region in KRas4B for plasma membrane localization and that of the secondary cysteine in NRas (the site of palmitoylation) for Golgi localization. Furthermore, statistical modeling of the data demonstrates a significant effect for the previously proposed role of the catalytic G-Domain of NRas in Golgi localization. Since NRas is localized to the Golgi in COS-7 cells, we could not confirm a role for the proposed linker motif in the partition between Golgi and plasma membrane. Application of these chimeras to activated cell lines should reveal any role for the combination of these determinants in localization changes associated with activation. Palladin is a recently discovered actin-associated protein that appears to be involved in both normal cell migration and invasive cell motility. Recently, we demonstrated that palladin is able to both bind and bundle actin filaments directly and revealed that one of the immunoglobulin-like domains of palladin (Ig3) is a novel actin-binding domain. These results indicate that palladin occupies an unusual functional niche, as it possesses the properties of both an actin-crosslinking protein and a molecular scaffold that binds to multiple other actin-regulating proteins. In the work presented here, we determined the NMR solution structure of palladin's Ig3 domain and identified two basic patches that are critical for actin-binding and bundling. The results we have obtained provide insight into the manner in which palladin binds and crosslinks actin filaments and suggest the importance of electrostatics in this interaction. Electrostatics are also a major determinant in actin polymerization, therefore we further present preliminary kinetic data that indicates palladin may also be capable of inducing actin polymerization. In addition, we examined whether the Ig3 domain of palladin is required for actin organization in a cellular context. In cells transfected with a full-length palladin construct containing a deletion of the actin-binding domain we observe dramatically altered cellular distribution of both palladin and actin, which suggests that this interaction is critical. These findings are critical for understanding the mechanism that palladin utilizes in promoting cell motility by identifying residues within the palladin Ig3 domain that are important for actin binding and bundling, but also points to a mechanism for actin filament crosslinking. Source of research support: NIH grants F32 CA139926-01 (MRB), 5RO1GM081505 and NSF MCB-1121365 (CAO) and 5RO1GM080568-04 (SLC) and COBRE (8P20GM103420), KINBRE (P20RRO16475), Flossie West Memorial Foundation Trust (MRB). How do sequence dependent molecular properties of proteins and their homeostasis interplay in shaping the fitness landscape of an organism? To address this question, E. coli's cells were presented with a set of defined destabilizing mutations introduced in a controlled manner into the coding sequence of folA gene encoding an essential dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). This approach allows to relate the mutationinduced changes in the biophysical properties of the endogenously expressed DHFR protein molecules to the observed in vivo changes in the fitness of strains carrying these mutations. Further, to discern which components of the protein quality control (PQC) system specifically interact with the mutant DHFR proteins, we perturbed intracellular concentrations of its major representatives. Specifically, we over-expressed key chaperone GroEL/S and knocked-out out several non-essential ATPdependent proteases (ClpAP, ClpXP, ClpAPX, HslUV, and Lon) and monitored the resulted change in fitness of DHFR mutant strains. Lon appeared to be the only protease deletion of which affected fitness in a mutantdependent manner. GroEL/ES over-expression or Lon deletion had a symmetrical effect on 27 DHFR mutant strains tested: all strains with near-lethal phenotypes were rescued (some back to the wt-like level), whereas the effect on strains with near-neutral phenotypes was either neutral or deleterious. We show that the observed symmetry in the activity of the two opposite arms of the protein homeostasis machinery, chaperonins GroEL/ ES and Lon protease, stems from the competition for binding to the compact folding intermediate of DHFR affected by the destabilizing mutations introduced into the protein. Kinetic steady-state model highlights the difference between the effects of mutations on proteins in solution as opposed to active cytoplasm: In solution, mutations redistribute a fixed amount of protein between its thermodynamic states, while in cytoplasm, energy-driven components selectively interact with the thermodynamic states and affectively change total protein abundance, thus contributing to the fitness effects of mutations. Previously, the attempts to generate transgenic mice ubiquitously expressing tetrameric DsRed (a coral red fluorescent protein of Discosoma genus) were failed probably due to the toxicity of aggregated red fluorescent proteins in embryonic stem cells. Thus, the physiological outcome of expressing DsRed tetramers in adult mice was not explored. In this study we generated the transgenic red mouse by first generating a green to red switchable mouse with a vector containing loxP-EGFP-loxP cassette preceding the DsRed sequence, and the red mouse was resulted by cross the switchable mouse with a Cre mouse. The resulted mouse expressing DsRed tetramers was normal in development, size, and husbandry. However, mice with homozygous DsRed alleles developed respiratory distress, carditis, ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis, left atrium thrombosis, dilated heart failure, and death at the age averaging 5.5 months old. The hemizygote mice developed similar symptoms at an average 12 months old. To confirm the heart origin of the morbidity in red mice, we induced DsRed expression specifically in cardiac tissues and the results confirmed the same diseased phenotypes by expressing DsRed only in the heart. To explore the cause of carditis and the underlying association with aggregated DsRed, we performed the molecular analysis on red mice at earlier stages and found that expression of myopathy and fibrosis related genes were significantly altered at 8 wk, long before the appearance of pathological abnormality and clinical onset of the diseases. Interestingly, expression of the proliferation and senescence related genes were also altered in cardiac tissues and in the primary skeletal myoblasts of the red mice. While the direct molecular evidence for the toxicity of tetrameric DsRed proteins remains unclear to us and that the red mice intriguingly managed the protein aggregates without symptoms until 5 months old, the transgenic mouse with DsRed expression can suffice a valuable in vivo model for failed protein quality control and can be utilized in the studies on protein aggregate toxicity and on the cardiac myopathy that relates to senescence and autophagy of myocytes. This research is supported by National Health Research Institutes, Taiwan, intramural grants.

Environmental contaminants perturb fragile protein assemblies and inhibit normal protein function Sarah Lawrence, Trevor Selwood, Eileen Jaffe Developmental Therapeutics, Fox Chase Cancer Center, 333 Cottman Avenue, Philadelphia, PA, 19111
body_text.section: Chemical Biology (307 -314) 307

body_text.text: The molecular mechanisms whereby environmental contaminants cause physiological effects are often unknown. The essential human enzyme porphobilinogen synthase (HsPBGS, a.k.a. 5-aminolevulinate dehydratase, ALAD) functions in heme biosynthesis and is well known as a primary target for the environmental toxin lead. Unrelated to enzyme inhibition by lead, the activity of HsPBGS is regulated allosterically via an equilibrium of inactive hexamers and active octamers. Genetic variations that perturb this equilibrium can result in the inborn error of metabolism know as ALAD porphyria. Furthermore, small molecules can inhibit HsPBGS in vitro by stabilizing the hexamer. We address whether components of the National Toxicology Program library of putative toxins can stabilize the HsPBGS hexamer and inhibit activity in vitro. Native polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis was used to screen the library (1,408 compounds) for those that altered the oligomeric distribution of HsPBGS. Freshly purchased samples of 37 preliminary hits were used to confirm the results and determine the dose-dependence of the effects on oligomeric distribution and inhibition of HsPBGS catalytic activity. Seventeen compounds were identified which alter the oligomeric distribution and catalytic activity of HsPBGS, including the most potent HsPBGS inhibitor yet characterized (Mutagen X, IC50 = 1.4 µM). Analogs of Mutagen X were utilized to further characterize the structure-activity relationship of this inhibitor. We have established that some toxins stabilize the inactive hexamer of HsPBGS and also inhibit catalytic activity. Allosteric regulation of activity via an equilibrium of alternate oligomers may occur for other proteins. Based on the precedent set herein, perturbation of these oligomeric equilibria by small molecules (such as toxins) can be considered as a mechanism of toxicity. Funding Information: This work was supported, in whole or in part, by National Institutes of Health Grants R01ES003654 (to E.K.J.), R56AI077577 (to E.K.J.), and P30A006927 (to the Fox Chase Cancer Center).
body_text.section: Chemical Biology (307 -314) 307

body_text.text: Stromelysins MMP-3 and MMP-10 and their inhibition by TIMPs: crystal structures and binding studies Jyotica Batra 1 , Alexei Soares 2 , Evette Radisky 1 1 Department of Cancer Biology, Mayo Clinic Cancer Center, 4500 SanPablo Road, Jacksonville, FL, 32224, 2 Biology Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are a family of zinc endopeptidases that are known for degrading the extracellular matrix protein components. Beyond normal physiological function, MMPs have been implicated in number of diseases including cancer, atherosclerosis, and arthritis. The activity of MMPs is regulated by tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs). MMP-3 (stromelysin-1) and MMP-10 (stromelysin-2) possess 85% sequence identity throughout the catalytic domain but are very distinct in their physiological functions. MMP-10 in particular is implicated in lung tumorigenesis and tumor progression, specifically in non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).

To understand the inhibition of the MMP-10 catalytic domain (MMP-10cd) by TIMPs, we have measured the equilibrium inhibition constant K i of physiological inhibitors TIMP-1 and TIMP-2 for the active catalytic domain of human MMP-10. TIMP-1 inhibits MMP-10cd with a K i of 1.1 ×10 -9 M; this interaction is 10fold weaker than the inhibition of the similar MMP-3 (stromelysin-1) catalytic domain (MMP-3cd) by the physiological inhibitor TIMP-1. Similarly, TIMP-2 inhibits MMP-10cd with a K i of 5.8 ×10 -9 M, again almost 10-fold weaker than the inhibition of the MMP-3cd (5.5 ×10 -10 M) by TIMP-2. The X-ray structure of the MMP-10cd/TIMP-1 complex was solved at 1.9 Å resolution (PDB: 3V96) by molecular replacement and refined with an R-factor of 0.215 (R free 0.266) 1 . Despite high sequence homology among stromelysin family members, comparing our structure of MMP-10cd/ TIMP-1 complex with the previously solved structure of MMP-3cd/TIMP-1 (PDB: 1UEA), we see subtle conformational differences at the binding interface that can account for the differential binding of stromelysins to TIMP-1. Efforts to crystallize stromelysins in complex with TIMP-2 are also in progress; these structures along with our existing data can offer important information for designing strategies to selectively increase the affinity of TIMPs towards individual members of the stromelysin family.

Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Caltech, Pasadena, CA MicroRNAs (miRs) are small non-coding RNAs that are predicted to regulate more than 50% of all human protein-coding genes by targeting mRNAs for degradation or translational repression. Most targets of miRs are identified by assessing changes in the transcriptome. While transcriptome analysis is successful in capturing mRNAs that are targeted for degradation, it fails to identify targets regulated via translational repression in which mRNA abundance is unaltered. Therefore, a method to systematically identify targets at the proteomic level is needed. Bio-orthogonal non-canonical amino acid tagging (BONCAT) is a method that labels the cellular proteome using the cell's endogenous machinery, co-translationally incorporating non-canonical amino acids into newly synthesized proteins. Azidohomoalanine, a methionine analogue, has been used to tag newly synthesized proteins, presenting azide groups at methionine positions. An alkyne-functionalized purification tag can be attached via copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition to selectively enrich newly synthesized proteins from the pre-existing protein pool, reducing sample complexity and making the proteome amenable to temporal characterization by mass spectrometry. Here we combine BONCAT with stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture (SILAC), to identify protein targets of miR-126 in the human metastatic breast cancer cell line mda-mb-231. MiR-126 has been proposed to suppress metastasis, and is down-regulated in many types of cancers; however, only a few of its targets have been identified. The results of this study will help elucidate the mechanism of suppression and provide insight into the design of epigenetic therapies that restore expression of tumor suppressor genes.
body_text.section: Identifying Protein Targets of a Tumor Suppressor MicroRNA in Human Metastatic Breast Cancer Cells Ying Lu, David Tirrell

body_text.text: Recognition of lignin degradation products by ABC transporters Karolina Michalska 1, 2 , Changsoo Chang 1, 2, 3 , Jamey Mack 1, 2 , Sarah Zerbs 2 , Andrzej Joachimiak 1, 2, 3 , Frank Collart 2 1 Midwest Center for Structural Genomics, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 S Cass Av., Argonne, IL, 60439, 2 Biosciences Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, 3 Structural Biology Center, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL Lignin, found in plant cell walls, is the second-most abundant polymer on Earth. This highly heterogeneous aromatic material is extremely resistant to breakdown. The biodegradation of lignin is facilitated by fungal and bacterial extracellular oxidative enzymes. They perform free-radical-based random depolymerization producing small-molecule aromatic compounds that are metabolized in vivo by aerobic and anaerobic pathways. However, the import of these chemicals to the cell has not been thoroughly characterized. We used a library of lignin degradation products and a fluorescence thermal stability assay to study ligand-binding profiles for a set of solute-binding proteins (SBPs) of ABC transporters from Alphaproteobacteria. The results enabled us to distinguish a subset of proteins (so-called cluster I) that recognize benzoate derivatives. For four homologs, we have obtained seven high-resolution crystal structures in complex with four different benzoate-derived compounds. The protein-ligand pairing observed crystallographically correlates well with the binding experiments. Structural data enabled us to identify residues lining the binding pocket and provide details of molecular recognition that can be used to infer ligand specificity. The ligand-binding characterization allows for the assignment of the functional roles of several SBPs, many of which have been mis-annotated as branched-chain amino acid-binding proteins. The results demonstrate that Alphaproteobacteria contain a broad spectrum of transport capabilities for ligninderived compounds. A detailed analysis of this new class of transporters will advance genomic annotation projects and provide insight into the metabolic potential of soil bacteria. This research was funded by a grant from the National Institutes of Health GM094585, and by the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Biological Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTK) are activated by ligand binding to induce receptor dimerization at the cell surface and subsequent phosphorylation of the cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase domain. Characterization and elucidation of such protein complexes may provide insights into receptor activation mechanism and new therapeutic strategies. In this report, we describe the study of homodimer and heterodimer formation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) family of RTK, EGFR and Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2 (HER2), on the surface of living cells. By employing SNAP/CLIP-tag technology, EGFR:EGFR homodimer and EGFR:HER2 heterodimer can be selectively captured by covalent linkage with a crosslinker containing specific reacting groups for SNAP-tag or CLIP-tag. Subsequent analysis by Western blotting allowed differentiation of dimer forms and analysis of the dimer/monomer ratio. This approach also enables the investigation of transient receptor interactions at the cell surface and ligand-independent receptor activation. Furthermore, this selective crosslinking system has also been applied to validate the effect of a drug Gefitinib on receptor dimerization and kinase activity. Kirk Hevener, Kent Truong, Teuta Boci, Bernie Santarsiero, Michael Johnson University of Illinois at Chicago, 900 S. Ashland Ave, Chicago, IL, 60607

cite_spans.text: Kirk Hevener, Kent Truong, Teuta Boci, Bernie Santarsiero, Michael Johnson

body_text.text: Enoyl ACP reductase or FabI is an important component of the fatty acid biosynthesis pathway in bacteria as it catalyzes the final rate-limiting step in the elongation cycle. In Gram-negative bacteria FabI is an attractive target for the development of antimicrobials due to its essentiality for bacterial survival. Our laboratory has recently reported a novel and potent series of benzimidazole compounds with promising antibacterial activity against F. tularensis. We report here the crystal structure of the most active compound bound to FabI along with the cofactor NADH. Enzyme kinetic studies indicate that this inhibitor is competitive with respect to the substrate and uncompetitive with respect to the cofactor NADH. These studies also confirm that this series of inhibitors does not form slow, tight-binding interactions with the enzyme unlike other known inhibitors. Details regarding the characteristics of enzyme inhibition and the structural analysis of the binding mode of the compound will be presented. Computational protein design (CPD) is developing as a practical alternative for solving problems in enzyme catalysis and stability. CPD and protein engineering methods have been applied to improve enzyme stability and enzyme catalysis. Stability is a vital parameter for applying an enzyme in industrial applications, allowing for higher process temperatures, which in turn bestow favorable effects on reaction rates, reactant solubility, and more efficient industrial processes. Adenylate kinase (AK) was selected as a model enzyme since its ubiquitous importance in the catalysis of living cells makes it a provocative design target. Previous studies on chimeric forms of AK have shown that the CORE domain determines thermostability and the AMP and LID domains determine the activity. Diverging from canonical protein design studies where a single protein structural template is selected and multiple structures are designed from this template, we have investigated a novel aspect of enzyme design by selecting seven highly similar AK mutant structures as input for computational thermostabilization, toward the production of 100 redesigned enzyme variants. Our computational design approach leverages knowledge of a mutationallypredisposed region of the CORE domain to optimize the amino acid composition for thermostability. Each of the computational designs were purified and characterized for thermostability using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The designed enzymes all increased thermostability, up to 22° C relative to the wild-type AK, such that the activity maxima (of a given AK) is proportional to the variant's Tm. Interestingly, the ability to computationally confer stability in a given starting template was found to be dependent upon the stability of the parental structure. This observation reveals the presence of an underlying thermostabilization limit imposed by hydrophobic packing of core residues, and the data set introduces a novel a priori metric valuable to protein engineers for evaluating the ability to further enhance the thermal properties of a given structure.
body_text.section: Enzymatic Inhibition and Structural Studies of a Novel Inhibitor of Enoyl ACP Reductase (FabI) Shahila Mehboob,

body_text.text: Biochemistry, SFSU, San Francisco, CA Altered Nitrite Reductase Activity in Diabetics Tsebaot Beraki, Kay Saw, Troy Low, Damon Robles and Raymond M. Esquerra Although the correlation between elevated blood sugar levels and decreased cardiovascular health is clear, the mechanism by which elevated blood sugar levels result in cardiovascular dysfunction is unresolved. Recent evidence shows that hemoglobin acts as a nitrite reductase, reducing nitrite to nitric oxide (NO) and contributing to vasodilation under low oxygen conditions. Our objective is to determine how increased nonenzymatically glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) disrupts normal nitric oxide physiology. To determine the effect of glycation on the nitrite reductase activity of hemoglobin, we compared the nitrite reductase activity of non-glycated hemoglobin (HbA0) to the nitrite reductase activity of hemoglobin with a covalently linked sugar (HbA1c). The molecular basis for this difference is also explored, primarily focusing on difference in allostery. Understanding how glycation alters normal nitric oxide physiology is fundamental to designing therapies that will reduce cardiovascular dysfunction in diabetics.
body_text.section: Altered Nitrite Reductase Activity in Diabetics Tsebaot Beraki

body_text.text: Department of Chemistry, Vanderbilt University, 7330 Stevenson Center, Nashville, TN, 37235 It has been demonstrated previously that symmetric, homodimeric proteins are energetically favored, which explains their abundance in nature. It has been proposed that such symmetric homodimers underwent gene duplication and fusion to evolve into protein topologies that have a symmetric arrangement of secondary structure elements-"symmetric superfolds". Here, the ROSETTA protein design software was used to computationally engineer a perfectly symmetric variant of imidazole glycerol phosphate synthase and its corresponding symmetric homodimer. The new protein, termed FLR, adopts the symmetric (βα)8 TIM-barrel superfold. The protein is soluble and monomeric and exhibits two-fold symmetry not only in the arrangement of secondary structure elements but also in sequence and at atomic detail, as verified by crystallography. When cut in half, FLR dimerizes readily to form the symmetric homodimer. It is further hypothesized that protein domains evolved from smaller intrinsically stable subunits via combinatorial assembly. Illegitimate recombination of fragments that encode protein subunits could have quickly led to diversification of protein folds and their functionality. Guided by computational design, we optimized the interface between fragments of the (βα)8-barrel and the flavodoxin-like fold with five targeted mutations yielding a stable, monomeric protein whose predicted structure was verified experimentally. We further tested binding of a phosphorylated compound and detected that some affinity was already present due to an intact phosphate-binding site provided by one fragment. The affinity could be improved quickly to the level of natural proteins by introducing two additional mutations. These studies demonstrate progress in our understanding of the underlying principles of protein stability and presents an attractive strategy for the in silico construction of larger functional protein domains from smaller pieces.
body_text.section: Symmetry and Fragment Recombination in Evolution and Rational Design of Proteins Jens Meiler

body_text.text: Enzymes with the ability to catalyze commonly-used synthetic reactions on arbitrary chemical substrates would enable complex syntheses to be carried out bio-catalytically. Here we describe the development of a sub-millimolar reactive enone protein binder with catalytic activity for the Morita-Baylis-Hillman reaction. Recent computational work has created catalysts for simple unimolecular reactions, and more recently for a bimolecular reaction. The Morita-Baylis-Hillman (MBH) reaction is a carbon-carbon bond forming reaction that creates products in which multiple functional groups have been preserved for subsequent synthetic steps. No enzyme or catalytic antibody catalyzes the reaction, raising the question of whether the MBH reaction can be accelerated by a protein in aqueous solution. The MBH occurs via formation of two distinct enzyme-substrate intermediates and via four transition states. The design of a protein catalyst for the MBH would represent a major step forward in enzyme design, the first multistep reaction catalyzed by a designed protein, and an example of a useful synthetic reaction accelerated by a protein. Here we demonstrate the design of a protein capable of tightly binding cyclohexenone in the first step of an MBH reaction with p-nitro-benzaldehyde (with kM of 500 micromolar for cyclohexenone), and two proteins capable of accelerating the full MBH reaction but without a tight binding of the second reactant (kM > 4 mM). Crystal structures of both designs show an active site positioned to bind cyclohexenone, but without the catalytic and binding components for the second step of the MBH intact. Using these designs we demonstrate a selection scheme for the first step of the reaction, by fluorescent labeling of the covalent intermediate, and a screen for the full reaction, that could be used to customize the catalysts for new substrates or to enhance catalytic activity in a broader screen.
body_text.section: Symmetry and Fragment Recombination in Evolution and Rational Design of Proteins Jens Meiler

body_text.text: A docking server, surFit, was developed that automatically and semi-automatically docks a pair of protein molecular surfaces. It consists of several procedures arranged as a linear pipeline: 1. Binding site prediction. Binding propensities are computed for each residue in each monomer, using the Empirical method Pinup [1] or using the evolutionary trace method [2] . Manually assigned interface information from the literature can also be added. The propensities are then mapped onto the protein molecular surfaces; 2. Surface docking. The molecular surfaces are docked with a score to maximize the geometrical surface complementarity, using an extension of the geometric hashing algorithm, which rapidly provides thousands of complex structures after clustering; 3. Scoring. The docked surfaces are scored by a function that considers shape and electrostatic complementary, as well as binding site propensity; 4. Refinement. High-scoring candidates are then refined by energy minimization, weakly restraining the entire backbone structure. Steps 1-4 have been automated and implemented in the web server surFit (http://sysimm.ifrec.osaka-u.ac.jp/surFit/). 5. Re-refinement for flexible docking. Molecular dynamics simulation [3] with explicit water molecules is carried out to relax the complex structures and to allow flexibility for the interfaces and the solvent molecules. The first steps 1-2 roughly produce as many as 10,000 possible candidates complexes, and the following steps 3-4 select the better ones. The final step 5 can identify the stable complex structures, with satisfactory interfaces with solvent molecules. The current protocol succeeded in building many acceptable predicted complex structures at the recent CAPRI targets, T51, 53, and 54, in addition to accurate estimation of solvent water positions at the interface for CAPRI target T47. References: [1] Liang et al. (2006) Heterobinuclear metalloenzymes are an important class of enzymes with important functions. Hemecopper oxidases (HCO) contains a heme-copper center that catalyzes important O2 reduction in respiration while nitric oxide reductases (NOR) contains a hemenon-hem iron center that reduces NO to N2O in denitrification. NORs are structurally homologous to subunit I of HCOs; however, the copper site (CuB) in HCO is replaced with a non-heme iron site (FeB) in NOR. An interesting question is why the protein, when using copper (as in HCO), is proficient at O-O bond cleavage and when using iron (as in NOR), is efficient at N-N bond formation. We are addressing this question by designing a CuB site or a non-heme FeB site in myoglobin by rational design using computer modeling and energy minimizations. X-ray crystallography, spectroscopic studies and activity assays have shown the designed proteins are both structural and functional models of HCO and NOR. Through the protein design and characterization processes,1-8 we have elucidated the roles of a) CuB and FeB in HCO and NOR reactivities; b) heme types (i.e., a/ o or b types) in regulating O2 binding and reduction; c) the covalently linked His-Tyr in modulating the binding affinity and geometry of CuB and FeB, the reduction potentials, and reactivities; and d) non-covalent interactions such as the presence of hydrogen bonding and water in conferring and fine-tuning the enzymatic activities. Finally, we have also made progresses toward designing a hememanganese center cytochrome c peroxidase that mimic that in manganese peroxidase, which has been shown to catalyzes degradation of lignin, the second most abundant biopolymer on earth at ambient conditions. Recent results will be presented.
body_text.section: Symmetry and Fragment Recombination in Evolution and Rational Design of Proteins Jens Meiler

body_text.text: Generation of a dual-functional split reporter protein for monitoring membrane fusion using selfassociating split GFP Hirohito Ishikawa 1 , Fanxia Meng 2 , Naoyuki Kondo 3 , Aikichi Iwamoto 1 , Zene Matsuda 1 1 Institute of Medical Science, The University of Tokyo, 4-6-1 Shirokanedai, Tokyo, 108-8639, Japan, 2 Institute of Biophysics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China, 3 Department of Pediatrics, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA Self-associating split proteins have a wide variety of biomedical applications such as monitoring of a membrane fusion process. Designing a pair of split proteins, especially the selection of appropriate split points, however, is rather serendipitous. Furthermore, some split proteins do not self-associate each other. Here we describe a new methodology to generate a split protein of interest with split GFP as a self-association module. In this method, we first inserted the whole GFP module at one of several candidate split points in the protein of interest, and chose clones retaining a relatively high activity of the original protein as well as GFP signal. Once such chimeric clones were identified, a final pair of split proteins was generated by simply splitting the GFP-inserted chimera within the GFP domain. Applying this strategy to Renilla reniformis luciferase, we identified a new split point which gave ten times higher activity than the previous split point. We also successfully identified new split points for HaloTag protein and firefly luciferase to generate a pair of selfassociating split proteins. These proteins recovered functions of both GFP and the original proteins. This simple method of screening will facilitate the designing of split proteins which are capable of self-association via the split GFP portions. With a new pair of split reporter proteins, the process of the membrane fusion can be monitored with a higher sensitivity. This work was supported by the Japan Initiative for Global Research Network on Infectious Diseases (J-GRID) sponsored by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT), Japan. Ligand-dependent activity has been engineered into enzymes for purposes ranging from controlling cell morphology to reprogramming cellular signaling pathways. Where these successes have typically fused a naturally allosteric domain to the enzyme of interest, here I instead describe an approach for designing a de novo allosteric effector site directly into the catalytic domain of an enzyme. This approach is distinct from traditional chemical rescue of enzymes in that it relies on disruption and restoration of structure, rather than active site chemistry, as a means to achieve modulate function. I will present two examples in which we engineer indoledependent activity into enzymes by removing a buried tryptophan sidechain that serves as a buttress for the active site architecture, leading to loss of function. The subsequent addition of indole then restores structure, and thus enzyme activity. Disruption and recovery of protein structure may represent a general technique for introducing allosteric control into proteins, and thus serve as a starting point for building a variety of bioswitches and sensors. This work was supported by grants from the National Center for Research Resources (5P20RR017708-07S1 and 5P20RR017708-09) (J.K.), the National Institute of General Medical Sciences (8 P20 GM103420-10) (J.K.), the NIH Dynamic Aspects of Chemical Biology Predoctoral Training Grant 2T32GM008545-17 (K.D.), and the Alfred P. Sloan Fellowship (J.K.).
Expanding the Zinc-Finger Recombinase Repertoire Shannon Sirk, Thomas Gaj, Carlos Barbas The Scripps Research Institute, 10550 North Torrey Pines, La Jolla, CA, 92037

The field of genome engineering has advanced considerably over the past several years, but the need remains for molecular tools with superior sequence specificity. Zinc-finger nucleases (ZFNs) are widely favored for genome modification, but offer sub-optimal accuracy and precision due to enzyme architecture and interaction with the target sequence. Tal-nucleases (TALENs) have recently emerged as an addition to the gene-targeting toolbox, but off-target activity has yet to be thoroughly examined. Alternatively, engineered zincfinger recombinase (ZFR) fusion proteins offer a more tightly targeted approach for genetic modifications. ZFRs are artificial DNA-modifying enzymes composed of zinc-finger proteins fused to highly selective catalytic domains derived from the serine resolvase/invertase family of enzymes. By combining the sequence-specific recognition of the zinc-fingers with the sequencedependent catalysis of the recombinase, these fusions demonstrate cooperative sequence specificity, resulting in genomic target sites of >50 bases. An additional benefit of ZFRs lies in the mechanism of action employed on the target sequence; ZFRs catalyze specific recombination events with predictable product sequences, as opposed to the unpredictable assortment of "indels" that result from ZFN-and TALEN-induced double-stranded breaks. ZFRs demonstrate exceptional efficiency and selectivity in the context of both exogenouslyintroduced target sites as well as endogenous genomic sites. Extensive biochemical and functional studies have been carried out with the Gin invertase and our current efforts look to expand the breadth of the targeting capability of ZFR-based technology to include the recombinases Sin and Beta. Activated variants of Sin and Beta capable of catalyzing recombination in the absence of their requisite accessory factors have been identified. Alanine-scanning and structure-guided mutagenesis have revealed details of the molecular interactions governing Sin and Beta recombinase sequence specificity. Our results suggest that thoughtful manipulation of the DNA recognition arm of the Sin and Beta recombinases will allow selective targeting of genomic DNA sequences, thus expanding the repertoire of the ZFR platform. The project described was supported by Grant Number DP1OD006990 from the Office Of The Director, National Institutes Of Health and also by the Skaggs Institute of Chemical Biology. We have previously reported that very basic physicchemical principles could be applied to computationally design a short (~75 amino acid residues) Kemp eliminase, nicknamed AlleyCat (PNAS, 2011, 108, 6823) . AlleyCat relies on calcium-binding domains (EF-hands) to provide the necessary energy to stabilize a single glutamate in the middle of a hydrophobic pocket. Computational designs often serve as starting points for directed evolution to further improve activity. However, directed evolution of proteins is often hindered by poor stability of protein folds as a result of multiple mutations introduced to improve the desired function. Additionally, small proteins are generally believed to be less suitable for directed evolution, since a fairly limited number of mutations will disproportionally affect their stability. Here we show that the stabilizing effect of metal-binding loops allows for improving activity by directed evolution even in small proteins. A single round of saturation mutagenesis in the positions adjacent to the substrate binding site identified two mutations (H107I and M144R) that produce additional 12-fold increase in k cat /K M bringing the overall rate acceleration of Kemp elimination to more than a 1,000,000-fold over background.

Engineering of zinc finger nucleases for optimal and selective cleavage activity So-Young Park, Xu Zheng, Yang-Gyun Kim Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University, 300 cheoncheondong, Suwon, 440-746, Republic of Korea Zinc finger nucleases (ZFNs) are chimeric artificial restriction enzymes made of C2H2-type zinc finger domains and the FokI nuclease domain (1) . ZFN technology has received much attention because it is envisioned as a powerful tool for genome editing (2). For wider use of the rapidly progressed ZFN technology, it is required to overcome many technical obstacles. In this study, we aim to develop a rapid and facile screening and assay systems for producing reliable ZFNs that possess high sequence-specific recognition and cleavage activities. Previously, we demonstrated our mix-and-match strategy, which complete ZFNs are non-covalently reassembled from separately expressed zinc finger domain and FN that fused to one of anti-parallel leucine zippers, respectively. Our result showed that these reconstitutable ZFNs (reZFNs) assembled by help of formation of anti-parallel dimeric leucine zippers and successfully cleaved target sites in a sequence-specific manner. We has investigated several approaches to improve DNA cleavage activity of reZFNs. One of them is to optimize the length of linker between the anti-parallel leucine zipper and the FN. We examined different linkers ranging from 7 to 15 amino acids to improve the cleavage efficiency. As a result, It appeared that the 11-amino acid linker showed the best cleavage efficiency among reZFN constructs. Our work will contribute to creating optimized ZFN technology to apply in various applications such as gene manipulation and gene therapy. The long-term goal of this project is to develop a reducing catalyst capable of generating molecular hydrogen from aqueous protons. We are using a bioinspired approach to design artificial proteins that recapitulate all components of the natural [FeFe] hydrogenases in an integrated system: a catalytic center containing a diiron complex, the activity of which is modulated by the protein matrix in which it is embedded; a chain of redox active centers, in Nature [Fe4S4] clusters, which forms the conduit to transfer electrons to the active site; and a designed protein interface, which connects the catalyst to a source of reducing equivalents, in this case an electrode. Towards this goal we designed a family of coiled-coil helical proteins, which we functionalize with organometallic active sites. One of this modules, DSD-[Fe4S4], contains multiple -[Fe4S4] clusters and acts as a molecular wire that we interface with other functional protein modules via specific protein-protein interactions. By introducing additional organometallic centers into related modules and by designing specific protein-protein interfaces, we aim to reconstruct reaction chains to convert the collected solar energy into a fuel, mimicking the function of natural photosystems. DSD-[Fe4S4] contains two iron sulfur clusters in the core of a closed dimeric three helix bundle (DSD). Experimental characterization confirms complete cluster incorporation; EPR-ELDOR experiments demonstrated a cluster to cluster distance of 36 A, in agreement with the design. Having successfully designed the molecular wire component, we turned our attention to the catalytic site. In [Fe-Fe] hydrogenase, the site contains an asymmetric diiron site coordinated by a dithiolate bridging ligand and by carbon monoxide (CO) and cyanide (CN) ligands. The protein matrix presents several highly conserved residures, which stabilize the cluster and are critical for activity. We designed a model hydrogenase in which the diiron site is covalently anchored tot he protein via an unnatural amino acid, and demonstrated direct incorporation into the helical framework of an intact (μ-SRS)[Fe(CO)3]2 cluster. The model protein efficiently catalyzes hydrogen production in mild aqueous conditions. Current work is focused on improving catalytic efficiency by engineering second sphere interactions. .

Chemistry and Biochemistry, Seattle Pacific University, Seattle, WA We increased the affinity of MICA for the dominant immunoreceptor NKG2D by 50-fold using seven rationally designed mutations found through a stepwise process similar to affinity maturation. Four design strategies guided experiments designed and carried out by undergraduates in both research and teaching labs. The challenges of adapting protein design and affinity testing to the undergraduate laboratory are more than compensated for by the rewards of practical, transferable student learning and of the large number of proteins produced by multiple parallel student groups. Protocols for accomplishing recombinant protein production and purification in the undergraduate teaching laboratory, as well as a system for the students to submit and share data, are available at geni-science.org. Our four design strategies were as follows: First, we evaluated the stability of amino acid mutations in MICA located beneath the interface with NKG2D using RosettaDesign. Three mutations increased MICA affinity for NKG2D as measured by surface plasmon resonance (SPR) by 20-fold through ground-state destabilization. The second design strategy optimized MICA residues that contact NKG2D. Ten single mutations proposed by RosettaDesign increased MICA-NKG2D affinity by 2-fold to 8-fold. Most combined surface mutants were subadditive, but some enhanced binding through enthalpic stabilization. A combination of four of the five best single mutants increased affinity by 19fold from wild-type. In a third strategy, we combined the best results from the two previous strategies in a MICA variant that bound NKG2D with 50 nM affinity. The fourth design strategy used HyPare to locate and optimize electrostatic hotspots in the context of the third-strategy septuple mutant, providing two sites for electrostatic optimization. Binding of these mutants appears strong by qualitative SEC binding assay, and quantitative binding constants will be obtained by SPR in the physical chemistry lab. RosettaDesign predicts that a glycine mutant will provide increased affinity through ground-state destabilization, which is similar to our first strategy. These results demonstrate that an integration of protein design into the undergraduate curriculum can produce many student-designed mutant proteins in parallel, testing many possibilities and resulting in novel high-affinity protein binding reagents. This research has been supported by NIH R15 grants AI 058972-01/2.
body_text.section: Protein-Protein Interactions Rationally Redesigned by Undergraduates: Four Strategies for Enhancing MICA-NKG2D Affinity Benjamin McFarland, Melissa Hale, Samuel Henager

body_text.text: The Active Site Dynamics of Computationally Designed Enzymes Gert Kiss 1 , Kendall Houk 2 , David Baker 3 , Vijay Pande 1 1 Chemistry, Stanford University, Clark Center, S221, Stanford, CA, 94305, 2 Chemistry and Biochemistry, UCLA, Los Angeles, CA, 3 Biochemistry, University of Washington, Seattle, WA Recent developments in computational chemistry and biology have come together in the inside-out" approach to enzyme design. Proteins have been designed to catalyze reactions not previously accelerated by natural enzymes. Some designs fold and act as catalysts, but the success rate is still low. Here we give an overview of the various projects from a computational biochemistry point of view. Achievements and limitations of the current technology are highlighted. We focus on the dynamic features of these new catalysts and compare them to naturally evolved enzymes.

A complete transition of enzyme function in the laboratory evolution Nobuhiko Tokuriki Michael Smith Laboratories, University of British Columbia, 2185 East Mall, Vancouver, BC, V6T 1Z4, Canada Like other optimization processes, evolution is governed by diminishing returns -the closer the optimum, the smaller the benefit per mutation, and by tradeoffsthe optimization of one property at the cost of others. Although these constraints have been addressed, their effects on evolutionary trajectories, and specifically on protein evolution, remain largely unknown. We generated a complete transition of enzyme function, starting from a naturally occurring phosphotriesterase, eighteen iterative rounds of random mutagenesis and selection were performed, yielding an efficient arylesterase. The resulting trajectory led to >10^9fold change in the enzyme's selectivity, yet exhibited strong diminishing returns. The increase in the evolving arylesterase activity dropped from >4.8-fold per substitution at the start of the trajectory, to ~0.18-fold at its end. Further, initially, a 1,600-fold gain in the newly evolving arylesterase activity was accompanied by 28fold loss of the original activity. However, at the final stages, a 21-fold gain traded off with ~1,400-fold loss. Structural analysis indicated that the diminishing returns appear to be the result of the early mutations mediating a new mode of substrate binding and catalysis, whereas the late ones provide a second shell of interactions that reinforce the early mutations and stabilize the evolving enzyme. The likelihood that a mutation will fixate is proportional to its fitness gain. The strong diminishing returns and tradeoff underlining the late evolutionary stages therefore suggest that the catalytic efficiency and specificity of many natural enzymes, particularly those in secondary metabolism may be far from optimum and might be further refined.

body_text.text: In Vitro Evolution of an Enzyme by cDNA Display Method Naoto Nemoto, Shingo Ueno Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Saitama University, 255 Shimo-Okubo, Saitama, 338-8570, Japan

The artificial evolution of enzymes is one of the ultimate goals of evolutionary molecular engineering (directed evolution). Display technologies, such as phage display, mRNA display and ribosome display, have been widely used for affinity selection against various targets in the last two decades 1 . Conversely, although some groups have been able to evolve enzymes using phage display 2 , there are only a few examples describing mRNA display 3 and ribosome display 4 . One of the reasons for the limited number of these examples may be the lability of the mRNA moiety in the protein-mRNA conjugate molecules used in these technologies. Recently, we have developed cDNA display technique that involves covalently bridging the cDNA and its coded protein via a puromycin linker 5 . The protein-DNA conjugated library generated by cDNA display using this linker should be more stable against degradation by ribonucleases and can be used under several screening conditions, including in blood, serum and the cytoplasm for medical enzymes, and under various physical conditions such as high-temperature, alkaline pH and organic solvents required for industrial enzymes. In this study, to evolve the protease "subtilisin" as a model enzyme, we designed a selection system with a new puromycin linker of the cDNA display for in vitro selection in the same manner as ribozyme selection. We will discuss the The evolution of new enzymatic activities is generally thought to be initiated from promiscuity in substrate binding or catalysis, followed by mutation and selection to optimize this nascent activity. However, the majority of examples of enzymatic promiscuity involve fairly subtle changes in the activity or substrate specificity of hydrolytic enzymes such as esterases. The evolution of firefly luciferase presents a more complicated example. This enzyme is thought to have evolved from fatty acyl-CoA synthetases, and retains their ability to activate fatty acids as AMP esters and convert them to fatty-acyl CoAs. While these enzymes share ~40% identity, fatty acyl-CoA synthetases fail to yield bioluminescent light emission upon treatment with the native luciferase substrate D-luciferin. So how did this activity develop? We have synthesized a family of rigid firefly luciferase substrates as bioluminescence imaging probes. Remarkably, we have found that several of these luciferins reveal latent luciferase activity in a fatty acyl-CoA synthetase from the non-luminogenic organism Drosophila. These heterocycles differ considerably in structure from the native fatty acid substrates. Moreover, the mechanism of luciferase light emission requires oxidation and decarboxylation of the intermediate luciferyl-AMP ester, steps not known to be carried out by fatty acyl-CoA synthetases. This result suggests that nascent luciferase activity is already present in fatty acyl-CoA synthetases, and supports the idea that the evolutionary appearance of a new enzyme substrate can unmask latent enzymatic activity by taking advantage of promiscuity in both substrate binding and catalysis. Furthermore, the inherent chemical properties of the substrate itself can direct enzyme function: in this case, luciferase activity requires that the oxidized substrate can access and emit light from an excited state. Beyond the implications for evolution and protein engineering, this result suggests that related enzymes in other species are candidate latent luciferases whose activity could be revealed by treatment with synthetic luciferin analogs, potentially allowing fruit flies and other non-luminous organisms to glow like fireflies. This work was supported by the NIH (EB013270 Noninvasive imaging methods to observe brain activity at a molecular level would be of significant benefit to neuroscience and the study of neurological disorders. To this end, we report several advances toward sensing biomolecules important in neurotransmission, neuromodulation, and inflammation by proton magnetic resonance imaging . These approaches rely on exploiting the biomolecular specificity of naturally and artificially evolved protein binding pockets, as well as the natural and augmented proton spin relaxation effects of paramagnetic metalloproteins. Cytochrome P450 hemedomain mutants have been screened to reveal a set of turn-off MRI sensors for monoamine neurotransmitters with micromolar to submicromolar affinity, for which specific Type II ligand binding confers as much as a 93% change in T1 contrast enhancement at 4.7 T. Through crystallographic analyses, we show that these mutants exhibit selectivity among structurally similar monoamine neurotransmitters by the introduction of orthogonal binding modes into the P450 active site. By examining the NMR field-dependence of T1 relaxation rates, we propose that improved paramagnetic T1 relaxivities of these mutants over wild type are explicable by increased solvent exchange rates, an observation that is consistent with changes in solvent-associated active site electron density in crystals. To further augment the basal T1 contrast effect of P450-based sensors, we have developed a recombinant bacterial expression system for metalloporphyrin-substituted hemoproteins based on overexpression of the E. coli heme transporter ChuA. We demonstrate that ChuA is a promiscuous metalloporphyrin transporter, allowing for incorporation of synthetic exogenous porphyrins with high yield into nascent overexpressed P450 heme domains, yielding Mn(III)-substituted P450 variants with as much as 2.6-fold higher T1 relaxivity than the native ferric wild type protein. Applying ChuA-mediated metalloporphyrin substitution to a range of previously reported thermostable chimeric P450 variants, we report a manganic variant with high affinity for arachidonic acid, an important neuronal and inflammatory signal. Finally, we discuss recent advances toward sensing intracellular neuronal signaling events using genetically encoded contrast sensors expressed in situ. This work was generously supported by grants from the NIH and the Jacobs Institute at Caltech. Insertions and deletions (indels) are allegedly highly deleterious mutations because they are more likely to disrupt the structural integrity of proteins than substitutions. On the other hand, indels also appear as important sources of diversity in many natural evolution processes, such as the modification of active site loops to generate new enzyme functions (Tawfik, 2006) or the emergence of new protein structures (Grishin, 2001) . Therefore, indels may induce significant structural changes that substitutions only cannot cause and are believed to be key players in natural protein evolution. However, these mutations have usually been overlooked in directed evolution and, more generally, protein engineering experiments. We aimed at establishing a method enabling random incorporation of indels into proteins in order to systematically examine the effect of these mutations and to perform directed evolution experiments combining both substitutions and indels. So far, few protocols have been developed to introduce randomly indels in a target protein. Moreover, these approaches lack flexibility regarding the control of indels' size and sequence. Based on a previously reported methodology (Jones, 2005) , we have further developed new genetic engineering tools to construct and screen indels mutant libraries. Using transposition mutagenesis, our approach enables to delete and/or insert oligonucleotides of desired length and sequence randomly in a gene of interest, thereby leading to the generation of protein libraries with single, double or triple triplet (codon) insertion or single triplet deletion. We also constructed a set of expression vectors that will be used both for the generation of indels mutant libraries and for their subsequent screening. We thus provide a novel reliable protein engineering methodology that will allow us to perform a systematic analysis of the effects of indels on proteins and carry out directed evolution experiments incorporating indels. Preliminary results suggest that, while being probably more destabilizing than substitutions, indels will be an innovative source of diversity to evolve new functions and follow alternative evolutionary trajectories. This work is supported by a Marie-Curie Intra-European Fellowship.

Soluble oligomerization provides a beneficial fitness effect on destabilizing mutations Shimon Bershtein, Wanmeng Mu, Eugene Shakhnovich Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA Genetic diversity is generated by mutations-induced perturbations of microscopic properties of proteins (stability, activity, and solubility), yet the evolutionary "readout" of these properties by natural selection takes place on the macroscopic level (phenotype, fitness). Understanding the rules that govern the interactions between these micro-and macroscopic levels, the genotype-phenotype map, remains one of the fundamental problems of modern biology. Experimental approaches used to address this problem so far generated rather dense genotype map that, in most cases, precluded from relating a single substitution event to a particular phenotypic trait. Here we explore the genotype-phenotype relationship by introducing controlled substitutions into the E. coli's chromosome and measuring the fitness effect of a single amino acid change at a time. Specifically, 27 strains carrying mutations in the essential folA gene encoding dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) were generated by a site-directed chromosomal mutagenesis. The effect of each of the introduced mutations on the biochemical/ biophysical properties of DHFR was evaluated in vitro, thus allowing to pinpoint fitness effects measured by competition between wt and mutant DHFR strains to specific changes in protein stability, activity or intracellular abundance. We found no significant correlation between protein stability and its catalytic activity and between catalytic activity and fitness in a limited range of variation of catalytic activity observed in mutants. Strong correlation found between stability of mutants and their intracellular abundance suggests an active role of protein homeostatic machinery in maintaining intracellular concentration of proteins. Significant correlation between intracellular abundance of soluble DHFR and fitness was observed when cells grew at 30oC. The picture was quite different at 42oC: mutant DHFR proteins in a few strains aggregated rendering them nonviable but the majority exhibited fitness higher than wild type. We found that mutational destabilization of DHFR proteins in E. coli was counterbalanced at 42oC by soluble oligomerization that restored their structural stability and protected from aggregation. This finding adds a completely underappreciated new dimension to our understanding of genotype-phenotype relationship: protein stability mediates fitness effects through perturbations in solubility. Determining how enzyme specificity evolves will provide guiding principles for protein engineering and function prediction. Two features of the o-succinylbenzoate synthase (OSBS) family make it an excellent model system for identifying these principles. First, the OSBS family is extraordinarily diverse; some members share <15% identity. Second, some OSBS family members catalyze another reaction, N-succinylamino acid racemization (NSAR). While OSBS catalyzes a step in Vitamin K synthesis, NSAR is in a pathway that converts D-amino acids to L-amino acids. NSARs cannot be segregated into a separate family by sequence similarity because they are more similar to some OSBSs than many OSBSs are to each other. Also, all characterized NSARs catalyze both OSBS and NSAR reactions, regardless of their biological function. Genome context shows that some OSBS/NSARs are even bifunctional in vivo. As a result, the OSBS family offers an opportunity to determine how new protein functions evolve through promiscuous intermediates. The only residues that are conserved in all OSBS family members participate directly in catalysis. These residues are also conserved in many homologous enzymes that do not have OSBS activity, so they are not sufficient to determine specificity. We hypothesized that the OSBS family could be divided into subfamilies which each use a different set of residues to bind and orient the substrate for catalysis. To test this, we used bioinformatics to identify sequence differences between OSBS subfamilies and experimentally determined the roles of the variable amino acids in catalysis. Mutating R159 and G288 in the active site of E. coli OSBS decreases activity 200-1000-fold. These residues are conserved in most OSBS subfamilies. However, they are not conserved in the subfamily containing the promiscuous OSBS/NSAR enzymes. This subfamily binds the substrate in a different orientation, eliminating selective pressure to retain glycine and arginine at these positions. This supports a model in which mutations at different positions in different OSBS subfamilies compensated for deleterious mutations. These compensatory mutations may have preadapted one subfamily to catalyze NSAR activity, which was opportunistically recruited into a new pathway for scavenging D-amino acids. This research is supported by the Welch Foundation. MonoTcTIM is an interface loop 3 mutant of triosephosphate isomerase (TIM) from Trypanosoma cruzi (Tc). This protein was characterized by several biophysical techniques including size exclusion chromatography, dynamic light scattering, X-ray crystallography, fluorescence and circular dichroism, as well as denaturation/renaturation assays and ANS binding. The functional, structural, folding and stability properties of this new monomer are discussed and compared with another monomeric TIM variants, in order to address the dimeric nature of the wild-type enzyme. The presence of Proline 44 a residue located in the loop 2 of this enzyme is discussed in terms of their possible participation in enhance the catalytic activity of TIM after monomerization.
