body_text.text: IκB PEST sequence plays a pivotal role in the IκB-NFκB binding interaction Holly Dembinski, Hector Gonzalez, Elizabeth Komives Chemistry and Biochemistry, UCSD, 9500 Gilman Dr., La Jolla, CA, 92093-0378

Nuclear factor kappa B (NFκB) transcription factors are responsible for the regulation of more than 150 target genes, their expression is induced by many classes of stimuli, and NFκBs play essential roles in the healthy regulation of cellular development and proliferation in inflammatory and immune responses. Diseases such as cancer, heart disease, Alzheimer's disease, and AIDS can be attributed to the wayward regulation of NFκB. The transcriptional activity of NFκB is controlled by its inhibitor-IκB. Two major isoforms of the inhibitor-IκBα and IκBβ-are structurally similar (i.e., crystal structures of the two exhibit a six ankyrin repeat domain followed by a largely unstructured, C-terminal PEST sequence), yet their inhibitory activities markedly differ. It has been shown that IκBα can actively "strip" NFκB from DNA in vitro, but IκBβ cannot. To probe the role of the IκB PEST sequence in the regulation of NFκB, we have constructed a panel of "PEST swap" mutants, tested the binding affinity of these mutants to NFκB, and found that the binding affinity of either IκB "PEST swap" mutant is approximately one thousandfold weaker than its respective wild type. The role of individual residues within the IκBα PEST sequence in the "stripping" phenomenon is also being analyzed, and these "stripping" experiments will show the importance of the PEST domain in the IκB-NFκB interaction. Protein kinases have a conserved catalytic core but have variable N-and C-terminal extensions that regulate their activity. In most AGC-family kinases, a floppy C-terminal tail allosterically activates the kinase activity through binding to a hydrophobic motif site on the N-lobe. Protein Kinase A (PKA) is perhaps the beststudied AGC kinase and is an excellent model system due to the plethora of experimental data available, including NMR. The rate-limiting step in the kinase catalytic cycle is product release. NMR relaxationdispersion experiments suggested that the active site opening part of product release was rate-limiting, based on relaxation-dispersion experiments that found slow motions on the same millisecond timescale involving a number of residues in the N-and C-lobes. As pre-steadystate kinetics have shown the chemical step to be quite fast, we wondered why PKA's activity is rate-limited by slow dynamics. To study the slow dynamics in PKA's catalytic cycle at an atomistic level, we performed long 5μs MD simulations of PKA using the Anton supercomputer, starting from apo, ATP-bound open, and ATP-bound closed conformations of the kinase. These simulations are shorter than the slow motions measured by NMR, they enabled us to see dynamics that were not rate-limiting. We found that from the simulation of the open form, active site closing was faster than expected based on the NMR-suggested 100s-1 because excursions to the closed form were only transient and not maintained, due to the fact that the C-terminal tail was disordered. We find the C-terminal tail to be entropically frustrated because there are many conformations it can take in the open form, but only one conformation it takes in the closed form. We hypothesized that motion of the C-terminal tail would be sufficient to promote active site opening, and found using a pulling simulation that starting from the closed form and lifting the C-tail and then restraining it in an open-like conformation allowed the active site to open, while a similar pulling simulation lifting instead the Gly-rich loop caused the kinase to buckle. Furthermore, we apply our previously-reported MutInf method to identify correlated motions coupling important regions of the kinase. This study highlights the use of slow order-disorder transitions in regulating enzyme kinetics and should shed insight on how other AGC-family kinases are regulated. Apolipoprotein A-I (apoA-I) plays important structural and functional roles in plasma high-density lipoprotein (HDL) that is responsible for reverse cholesterol transport. However, a molecular understanding of HDL assembly and function remains enigmatic. The 2.2Å crystal structure of Δ(185-243)apoA-I reported here shows that it forms a half circle dimer. The backbone of the dimer consists of two elongated antiparallel prolinekinked helices (5 AB tandem repeats). The N-terminal domain of each molecule forms a four-helix bundle with the helical C-terminal region of the symmetry related partner. The central region forms a flexible domain with two antiparallel helices connecting the bundles at each end. The two-domain, dimer structure based on helical repeats suggests the role of apoA-I in the formation of discoidal HDL particles. Furthermore, the structure suggests the possible interaction with lecithincholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), and may shed light on the molecular details of the effect of the Milano, Paris and Fin mutations.

Misfolding and aggregation of human β2microglobulin probed by chemical protein synthesis Vladimir Torbeev, Donald Hilvert Laboratory of Organic Chemistry, ETH Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland Human β2-microglobulin (β2m) deposits as amyloid fibrils within joints during long-term hemodialysis treatment. Despite the devastating effects of dialysisrelated amyloidosis, a full understanding of how fibrils form from soluble β2m remains elusive. Previously, it was inferred that cis-to-trans amide bond isomerization of the cis-Pro32 residue triggers a transition of the native form of β2m into an aggregation-prone conformer. We used chemical synthesis to prepare a series of analogues of β2m in which Pro32 residue was systematically substituted with several analogues, including 4-(R)fluoroproline (fpr), 4-(S)-fluoroproline (Fpr), α-methylproline (Mpr) and D-proline (Dpr), which have different propensities to adopt either a cis or trans conformation of the prolyl amide bond. We find that such substitutions indeed affect cis-to-trans populations of conformers when inserted into the β2-microglobulin polypeptide chain, and the resulting molecules exhibit different tendencies to aggregate with a gradually increasing trend Pro ≈ fpr < Fpr < Mpr < Dpr. Thus, our data confirm the hypothesis that amide bond isomerization of Pro32 plays a key role in this process. The effects of Pro32 substitutions on the early stages of protein aggregation by unnatural amino acids as well as structural features of the chemically synthesized proteins will be presented.

Mutated Thermostable Direct Hemolysin from Grimontia hollisae Affects Its Hemolytic Activity, Membrane Binding, and Protein Quaternary Structure Tung-Kung Wu, Wan-Ting Huang Biological Science and Technology, National Chiao Tung University, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan Thermostable direct hemolysin (TDH), a pore forming toxin, has been recognized as a virulent factor in Vibrio parahaemolyticus. It exists as a homo-tetramer in solution. The homologous TDH from Grimontia hollisae (Gh-TDH) shows 87% similarity to Vp-TDH, but displays a distinct interface structure between protomers than that of Vp-TDH. Notably, the Gh-TDH and equinatoxin II from sea anemone exhibit a highly structural similarity and interact with the lipid membrane via specific regions. In this study, we describe identification and characterization of critical residues involved in the hemolytic activity, membrane binding and quarternary structure. Interestingly, no hemolytic activity and cytotoxicity were observed from the Gh-TDHY87A and Gh-TDHY87A/Y107A mutants, which are different from Gh-TDH wild-type (Gh-TDHWT) protein. On the other hand, the protomer-interface related Gh-TDHY53D and Gh-TDHF159D mutants formed dimer conformation, as observed from the Native-PAGE. Furthermore, the Gh-TDHY53D and Gh-TDHF159D mutants exhibited slightly lower hemolytic activity as compared to that of Gh-TDHWT. Thus, the Gh-TDH proteins might form dimer-based tetramer and display variant extent of hemolytic activities, depending on different conformational structures. In summary, the Y87 and Y107 residues might play a role participating in the protein-membranes binding while both the Y53 and F159 show their importance in directing protein quaternary structure formation. Other residues, critical for the TDH structure as well as the interactions between TDH and lipid membrane, will also be discussed. Activity of the de-ubiquitinating enzyme USP7 is pivotal in regulating the stability of the E3 ligase MDM2 and the proto-oncogene p53. Previous research has also demonstrated the function of USP7 in signaling pathways involving cell cycle and mitosis through PTEN, and cell death and survival through Claspin/ Chk1. Given the significance of USP7 in these pathways, it is surprising that little is known about the regulatory mechanisms of USP7 itself and the regulatory activity of the seven structural domains of USP7: a N-terminal TRAF domain, a catalytic ubiquitin cleaving domain and five C-terminal Ubiquitin-Like (UBL) domains. In this work we present biochemical data on the UBLregulated activity of USP7 against mono-ubiquitin and K11-, K48-and K63-linked di-ubiquitin. We also show cellular data describing the the ubiquitin linkages on the USP7 substrate MDM2. Further, using isolated ubiquitinated substrate, both the USP7 -TRAF and UBL domains are shown to be essential for substrate targeting. To support this hypothesis, a novel crystal structure of the USP7 catalytic domain, together with several regulatory domains is shown. This structural model allows synergistic interactions of both the TRAF and the UBL domains in substrate recognition and supports the biochemical data for linkage independent recognition of ubiquitinated substrate. In addition the model provides insight into the function of the USP7 C-terminus in the regulation of USP7 enzymatic activity. Our findings demonstrate essential regulatory functions for the non-catalytic domains of USP7 that will have implications in both cancer development and infectious disease. Most cellular responses to extracellular stimuli have a common component of regulation arising from selective recruitment of a network of signalling complexes to membranes. However, studying these systems remains a daunting task. We have made unprecedented progress in understanding these systems by applying a synthesis of deuterium exchange mass spectrometry (DXMS), X-ray crystallography and FRET spectroscopy. Our application of this synthesis to phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) signalling represents one of the largest (> 200 kDa) complexes studied using DXMS, and elucidates novel aspects of PI3K regulation as well as a unifying mechanism of how diverse oncogenic PI3K mutants upregulate activity. DXMS provides information on the conformation and solvent accessibility of protein amide hydrogens, and has become a powerful tool for analysing protein dynamics in complex assemblies. PI3Ks are lipid kinases that are involved in a variety of cellular functions, including growth, proliferation, differentiation, migration, and metabolism. In their basal inactivated state they are maintained in the cytosol. They can be activated by recruitment to the membrane surface via binding membrane bound activators such as receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) and Ras. The importance of regulating PI3K activity is highlighted by the fact that the PI3K p110α catalytic subunit (PIK3CA) is one of the most frequently mutated genes in cancer. Activating mutations exist in every domain, with many distant from the active site and/or membrane binding site. Using DXMS we have examined the activation of wildtype p110α/p85α and a spectrum of oncogenic mutants in three enzyme states: basal, RTK phosphopeptide activated, and membrane bound. Differences in amide exchange rates upon activation show that for wild-type p110α/p85α the natural transition from an inactive cytosolic conformation to an activated form on membranes entails four distinct conformational events. DXMS results for cancer mutants show that all upregulate the enzyme by enhancing one or more of these dynamic events. Protein-lipid FRET and lipid kinase assays showed that all mutations increased binding to membranes and basal lipid kinase activity, even mutations distant from the membrane surface. Our results elucidate a unifying mechanism in which diverse PIK3CA mutations stimulate lipid kinase activity by facilitating motions required for catalysis on membranes. The Protein Structure Initiative:Biology-Materials Repository (PSI:Biology-MR; MR; http://psimr.asu. edu) sequence-verifies, stores, and distributes the protein expression plasmids and vectors created by the Protein Structure Initiative (PSI). DNASU (http:// dnasu.asu.edu), a freely searchable database, stores the plasmid annotations, which include the fulllength sequence, vector information, and associated publications for over 145,000 plasmids created by our laboratory, by the PSI and other consortia, and by individual laboratories for distribution to researchers worldwide. Each plasmid links to external resources, including the PSI Structural Biology Knowledgebase (http://sbkb.org), which facilitates cross-referencing of a particular plasmid to additional protein annotations and experimental data. As of April 2012, over 55,000 protein expression plasmids and 90 empty vectors from the PSI are available upon request from DNASU. Overall, the MR's repository of expression-ready plasmids allows the research community to dissect the biological function of proteins whose structures have been identified by the PSI. With the added biological focus in PSI:Biology, the distribution of these materials will help researchers expand the knowledge of the role of proteins both in normal biological processes and in disease.

The molecular basis of islet amyloid induced cell death Andisheh Abedini 1 Amyloid formation by islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP or Amylin) leads to beta cell death, contributing to type 2 diabetes and islet transplant failure. The mechanisms of IAPP-induced toxicity are not known and the nature of the toxic species is controversial. We show that the toxic species are transient, soluble, pre-fibrillar oligomers with no significant beta sheet content. Altering the time course of amyloid formation by mutation, the use of amyloid inhibitors or changes in solution conditions reveals a correlation between the rate of amyloid formation and duration of toxicity; suggesting that toxic intermediates are "on-pathway". The toxic intermediates up-regulate MCP-1 and IL-1beta mRNA and are ligands of the receptor for advanced glycation endproducts (RAGE). Soluble RAGE is an inhibitor of IAPP amyloid formation and of toxicity to beta cells, pancreatic islets and smooth muscle cells. Deleting RAGE or blocking RAGE-IAPP interactions protects cells from toxicity. The findings are consistent with a RAGE-mediated mechanism of IAPP toxicity and have implications for the treatment of diabetes.

Mapping α-synuclein-glucocerebrosidase interaction on the membrane interface Thai Yap 1 , Arash Velayati 2 , Ellen Sidransky 2 , Jennifer Lee 1 1 biochemistry and biophysics center, NHLBI, NIH, Bethesda, MD, 2 Medical Genetics Branch, NHGRI, NIH, Bethesda, MD The most common genetic risk factor for parkinsonism is mutation of glucocerebrosidase (GCase), the lysosomal enzyme deficient in Gaucher disease. Importantly, autopsy studies of GD patients and carriers with synucleinopathies reveal the presence of mutant GCase in α-synuclein(α-syn)-rich Lewy bodies, pathological hallmarks of Parkinson disease (PD). While these studies have provided strong correlations to PD suggesting a potential relationship between α-syn and GCase, the molecular mechanisms for disease association remain elusive. In prior work, we identified that α-syn and GCase interact selectively under lysosomal solution conditions and mapped the interaction site to the α-syn C-terminal residues, 118-137. Immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies verified this interaction in patient brain samples and neuronal cell culture, respectively. Because the lysosome plays an important role in protein degradation, this newly identified interaction between α-syn and GCase can potentially influence α-syn homeostasis in neurons. Currently, we are studying how membranes modulate this interaction since the substrate for GCase is found in intra-lysosomal vesicles. We are using small unilamellar vesicles as membrane mimics and site-specific fluorescence and Förster energy transfer probes to map protein-enzyme interaction. The α-syn-GCase complex forms with comparable affinity in the presence of vesicles as in buffer solution. However, our data suggest that the interaction site on the membrane surface comprises a much larger α-syn region beyond its C-terminus. Lastly, we have examined GCase enzymatic activity in the presence of α-syn. α-Syn inhibits GCase activity with an apparent IC50 in the submicromolar range; it is a mixed inhibitor, where α-syn can bind either to the free enzyme or the enzyme-substrate complex. The estrogen receptor alpha (ER-a) regulates expression of target genes implicated in development, metabolism, and breast cancer. Calcium-dependent regulation of ER-a is critical for activating gene expression and is controlled by calmodulin (CaM). Although much is known about the structures of ER-a and CaM, the structural mechanism of how CaM activates ER-a was not known. By using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) and other biophysical techniques (e.g. Isothermal Titration Calorimetry (ITC), etc), here we present the NMR structures for the two lobes of CaM each bound to a localized region in ER-a (residues 287-305). A model of the complete CaM/ER-a complex was constructed by combining these 2 structures with additional data. The two lobes of CaM both bind at the same site on ER-a (residues 292, 296, 299, 302 and 303), which explains why full-length CaM binds two molecules of ER-a in a 1:2 complex and stabilizes ER-a dimerization. Exposed glutamate residues in CaM (E11, E14, E84, E87) form salt bridges with key lysine residues in ER-a (K299, K302 and K303), which is likely to prevent ubiquitination at these sites and inhibit degradation of ER-a. Mutants of ER-a at the CaM binding site (W292A and K299A) weaken binding to CaM, and I298E/K299D disrupts estrogen-induced transcription. We conclude that CaM facilitates dimerization of ER-a in the absence of estrogen, and stimulation of ER-a by either Ca2+ and/or estrogen may serve to regulate transcription in a combinatorial fashion. Figure 1 . Structural model of CaM bound to dimeric ER-a (residues 287-552). The main chain structure of CaM/ER-a(287 -552) complex was generated using the determined NMR structures of two lobes each bound to a localized region in ER-a (residues 287-305) attached to the dimeric LBD crystal structure (residues 305 -552; PDB code: 1A52). One polypeptide chain of ER-a dimer (orange) is bound to the CaM N-lobe (CaMN, cyan) and the other ER-a chain (white) is bound to the CaM C-lobe (CaMC, magenta). E2 is bound to the dimeric LBD (green), Ca2+ is bound to CaM (yellow) and the dotted line (white) represents the flexible loop between two lobes. This work was supported, in whole or in part, by National Institute of Health Grant EY012347 and NS059969 (to J.B.A.) and by the Intramural Research Program.

Mutual molecular influence between α-synuclein and glutathione peroxidase Jee Eun Yang, Gayoung Park, Hee Jung Koo, Daekyun Lee, Seung R. Paik School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul, Republic of Korea α-Synuclein is main component of Lewy bodies (LBs), abnormal protein aggregates known as the pathological hallmark of Parkinson's disease. Recently, glutathione peroxidase (GPx), cellular antioxidative defense system removing reactive oxygen species, was reported to be co-localized with α-synuclein in LBs. By employing a coupling GPx assay, the enzyme was shown to be stimulated by α-synuclein via the molecular complex formation. Dissociation constant obtained with a double-reciprocal plot of the stimulated GPx activity in the presence of α-synuclein was 17.3 nM. This interaction was further confirmed using in vitro coimmunoprecipitation and immunocytochemical analysis with neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells. Since GPx was found to exist in α-synuclein-enriched LBs, we investigated GPx effect on the fibrillation of α-synuclein. GPx not only accelerated the fibrillation kinetics of α-synuclein by shortening lag phase, but also increased overall quantity of the final fibrillar products. This acceleration of α-synuclein fibrillation was demonstrated to be dependent upon GPx activity. Transmission electron microscopic analysis of the immunogold stained fibrils revealed that the GPx molecules were entrapped in clusters within α-synuclein fibrils. In addition, the GPx was shown to be slowly released from fibrils in active form. Our data suggest novel physiological functions of α-synuclein as an activator of GPx and the α-synuclein fibrils as a functional depot for the active GPx. This gives us new insight into physiological roles of α-synuclein in cellular antioxidative defense system.

Secreted aspartic proteases of pathogenic Candida spp. are temporarily retained in the cell wall and cleave the extracellular substrates Iva Pichova, Zuzana Vinterova, Miloslav Sanda, Jiri Dostal, Olga Hrusková-Heidingsfeldová Biochemistry, Institute of Organic Chemistry and Biochemistry, ASCR, Flemingovo n. 2, Prague, 166 10, Czech Republic Pathogenic yeast of the genus Candida produce secreted aspartic proteases (Saps) that play an important role in virulence. The SAP genes of pathogenic Candida spp. encode pre-pro-enzymes. The signal peptide is removed in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, the zymogen is activated in the Golgi apparatus, and mature protease is transported via the secretory pathway to the cell surface and has to pass through the protective cell wall. It has been assumed that Saps hydrolyze host proteins after their release. To study the final stage of protease passage through the cell wall, we focused on Sapp1p protease secreted by Candida parapsilosis and performed labeling of cell wall proteins with biotin followed by analysis of extracted cell wall proteins by mass spectroscopy. We also examined proteolytic activity of cell-wall associated Sapp1p. We found that Sapp1p displays enzyme activity prior to secretion, which indicates that protease is properly folded within the upper layer of the cell wall. Analysis of biotinylated Sapp1p revealed that the protease has a preferred orientation in the cell wall and a sufficient population of Sapp1p molecules has the active sites accessible to external substrates. The ability of yeast cells to retain active Sap molecules in the cell wall before their secretion into extracellular space might provide a great benefit for pathogenic Candida spp., mostly during biofilm formation, but also during adhesion and colonization of host tissues. Over 20% of European population suffers from respiratory allergies. Many factors can cause these immune dysfunctions, which can be classified into three categories: -Internal environmental factors, which refer to all potential allergens inhaled indoors: dust mites, molds, cat fur dog fur etc. -External environmental factors, which refer to all potential allergens inhaled outdoors: pollens, molds. -Factors of air pollution: there is a triangular relationship between pollution, pollen and allergy. Pollution can affect pollens by changing their external biochemical structure and thus their allergenicity, but also the human respiratory mucosa by changing its immunological sensitivity to pollen particles. Pollen grains contribute to the development of the vegetation by ensuring oxygen regeneration and playing a vital role in food. However, 10 to 20% of the population suffers from allergenic rhinitis, conjunctivitis or asthma, caused by the pollens. The increase of this kind of allergy, which would have doubled in 10 years, justifies the control of air quality. As a proof of concept, we focused on birch pollen which proteins are known to be strongly allergenic. Birch pollen allergen was detected in real-time by Surface Plasmon Resonance Imaging (SPRi). Owing to this optical technique, the interaction between birch pollen allergen and an antibody directed against this allergen was monitored. From a calibration curve, the quantity of allergen in one pollen grain was determined and compared to results obtained in ELISA by J. Buters et al [1] , [2] . Then, the affinity of the interaction was calculated from the kinetic curves. The aim of the next experiments will be to take full advantage of the SPRi multiplex interaction performance to detect and identify multiple pollens allergen on the same microarray.

Mapping the α-Synuclein-Glucocerebrosidase-Saposin C Interface using Saturation Transfer NMR Spectroscopy James Gruschus 1 , Thai Leong Yap 1 , Arash Velayati 2 , Ellen Sidransky 2 , Jennifer Lee 1 1 NHLBI, NIH, 50 South Drive, Bethesda, MD, 20892, 2 NHGRI, NIH, Bethesda, MD Glucocerebrosidase (GCase) is a lysosomal enzyme that cleaves glucosylceramide to glucose and ceramide, facilitated by the protein, saposin C (sap C). Mutations in the GCase gene are associated with Gaucher disease (GD), the most common of the lysosomal storage disorders. Surprisingly, patients with Parkinson disease (PD) are over five times more likely to have a mutation in the gene encoding GCase, rendering it the most common known genetic risk factor for PD. Parkinson pathology is commonly associated with Lewy bodies, proteinaceous inclusions composed primarily of α-synuclein (α-syn), a protein that is also genetically linked to familial PD. In our prior work, we established that α-syn and GCase interact under the acidic conditions found in the lysosome and mapped the binding site to residues 118-137 in the C-terminal region of α-syn by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. We have since explored the effect of α-syn on GCase activity. While α-syn is inhibitory, the addition of sap C rescues activity. To test whether sap C displaces α-syn from GCase, we measured the NMR spectrum with all three proteins present in solution. Unexpectedly, both sap C and α-syn bind GCase simultaneously, though the α-syn binding site is reduced to residues 125-137. Since the large size of GCase (~60 kD) precludes standard NMR perturbation techniques, we are employing Saturation Transfer NMR spectroscopy and perdeuterated sap C to identify sap C residues at the interaction interface in order to elucidate the mechanism by which sap C facilitates GCase activity. This work was supported by the Intramural Research Program at the National Institutes of Health, NHLBI & NHGRI.

Structural study of Disease-Specific-Epitope monoclonal antibodies that recognize misfolded superoxide dismutase, one of the causes of familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis Feiyang Liu 1 Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease that is characterized by massive destruction of motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. About 20% of familial ALS cases are attributed to mutations in the gene SOD1 that encodes the copper/zinc superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1). Disease-Specific-Epitope 2 (DSE2), corresponding to residues 125-142 of SOD1, is normally buried in native WT SOD1 but accessible to the immune system in the misfolded isoform. The monoclonal antibody 3H1 IgG was developed against the DSE2. It recognizes only misfolded SOD1 but not native WT SOD1 [1] . The G85R mutant of SOD1 exhibits a template-directedmisfolding activity to wtSOD1, a crucial feature of prion disease. WtSOD1, upon contact with G85R, becomes misfolded and is recognized by 3H1 IgG [1] . To study the binding between DSE2 and 3H1 IgG, co-crystallizations of the antibody with both the epitope peptide and fulllength G85R were performed. 3H1 IgG was digested by papain to obtain the Fab fragment. 3H1 Fab's antigen binding ability was compared to that of intact IgG using competitive ELISA techniques. Pure 3H1 Fab was then mixed with 1 mM epitope peptide (residues 132 to 138 of DSE2) and was screened for crystallization hits. Platelike crystals were observed that diffracted X-rays to a resolution of 4 Å on a rotating anode source. Refinement of the crystallization conditions is underway to produce well diffracting crystals that can reveal the structure of the DSE2 peptide-3H1 antibody complex. The G85R mutant of SOD1 was produced using an E. coli protein expression system. Through competitive ELISA, it was confirmed that purified G85R was recognized by 3H1 IgG. Its metal-binding ability was compared to that of wtSOD1. The G85R mutant binds copper as tightly as wtSOD1 but its zinc binding was decreased by 58%. This is consistent with a crystallization study done by Cao et al [2] : Three individually grown G85R crystals showed significant absence of metal at the Zn binding site. The presence of zinc was seen as critical to the ordering of the "electrostatic loop", which includes DSE2. This could mean that the recognition of DSE2 by the monoclonal antibody 3H1 might be dependent on the presence of zinc at the Zn-binding site. Remetallation of G85R experiments are ongoing to test if antibody recognition is metal dependent. [1] . Leslie I. The large and growing body of experimental data on biomolecular binding is of enormous value in developing a deeper understanding of molecular biology, in developing new therapeutics, and in various molecular design applications. However, most of these data are found only in the published literature and are therefore difficult to access and use. BindingDB is a public web-accessible database of measured binding affinities for various molecular types. The BindingDB allows queries based upon a range of criteria, including chemical similarity or substructure, sequence homology, numerical criteria and reactant names. The data specification includes significant experimental detail. The time and expense required to extracting data from the literature, for this and many other databases, highlight the importance of moving toward machinereadable components of publications.

The Crystal Structures of the α-Subunit of the α2β2 Tetrameric Glycyl-tRNA Synthetase Kemin Tan The aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases (AARSs) are ligases (EC.6.1.1.-) that catalyze the acylation of amino acids to their cognate tRNAs in the process of translating genetic information from mRNA to protein. Their amino acid and tRNA specificity are crucial for correctly translating the genetic code. Glycine is the smallest amino acid and the glycyl-tRNA synthetase (GlyRS) belongs to Class II AARSs. The enzyme is unusual because it can assume different quaternary structures. In eukaryotes, archaebacteria and some bacteria, it forms an α2 homodimer. In some bacteria, GlyRS is an α2β2 heterotetramer and shows a distant similarity to α2 GlyRSs. The human pathogen eubacterium Campylobacter jejuni GlyRS (CjGlyRS) is an α2β2 heterotetramer and is similar to Escherichia coli GlyRS; both are members of Class IIc AARSs. The two-step aminoacylation reaction of tetrameric GlyRSs requires the involvement of both α-and β-subunits. At present, the structure of the GlyRS α2β2 class and the details of the enzymatic mechanism of this enzyme remain unknown.

Here we report the crystal structures of the α-subunit of CjGlyRS and its complexes with ATP and ATP+glycine. These structures provide detailed information on substrate binding and show evidence for a proposed mechanism for amino acid activation and the formation of the Acceleration of genome sequencing and high-throughput determination of the 3D structures of gene products bring promise for new approaches to the diagnosis and treatment of disease. In order to realize this potential, the next step is to understand the biochemical functions of the newly determined structures of these gene products. To address this important and timely problem, a new approach is presented based on functional residue prediction with Partial Order Optimum Likelihood (POOL), using chemical and electrostatic input from THEMATICS, geometric data from ConCavity, and phylogenetic information. POOL has been shown to predict functional residues with high recall and specificity, and is now extended to prediction of biochemical function. Predicted functionally important residues for a protein of unknown function are structurally aligned with those of proteins with well characterized functions. These Structurally Aligned Local Sites of Activity (SALSAs) show spatial patterns that are characteristic of biochemical function. A 3D structure match at the predicted, local functional site then serves as a more reliable predictor of biochemical function than an overall structure match. The method is validated with sets of well-characterized proteins with similar 3D structures but different functions, including the ribulose phosphate binding barrel (RPBB), six hairpin glycosidase, and ClpP/crotonase superfamilies, and the enzymes with the concanavalin A-like lectins/glucanases fold. Then, the SG members of these superfamilies, whose functions are unknown or uncertain, are analyzed by POOL and SALSA. Selected examples from structural genomics are shown, including instances of correct and incorrect annotation. We find that for the SG members of the RPBB superfamily, most of the putative annotations are likely to be correct. However, for SG members of the ClpP/crotonase superfamily, over 60% of the putative annotations are very likely incorrect. In one particular example, the SALSA prediction was different from those made by standard bioinformatics methods, specifically 3D structure matching and sequencebased phylogenetic analysis; direct biochemical assays proved that the SALSA prediction is correct. Some additional examples with experimental verification of predicted function are given. This work is supported by the National Science Foundation under grants MCB-0843603 and MCB-1158176.

Conformational dynamics of the N-terminal actin binding domain of dystrophin probed using pyrene excimer fluorescence Krishna Mallela, Surinder Singh Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, Aurora, CO Mutations in dystrophin trigger muscular dystrophy, however its structure-function relationship is poorly understood. Dystrophin interacts with F-actin using its N-terminal actin binding domain (N-ABD), which is a tandem repeat of calponin-homology (CH) domains. Previous X-ray structure indicated that the N-ABD is a domain-swapped dimer, with each monomer in an 'open' conformation in which the two CH domains do not interact. Here we investigated the conformation of dystrophin N-ABD in solution using pyrene excimer fluorescence. Pyrene-labeled single cysteine mutants did not show excimer fluorescence indicating the absence of either parallel or anti-parallel dimers. Pyrenelabeled wild-type protein showed excimer fluorescence indicating that the two native cysteines are close in space which is only possible if dystrophin N-ABD exists in a 'closed' conformation with significant interactions between the two CH domains. Upon binding to F-actin, excimer fluorescence increased indicating that this domain transitions to a more compact closed conformation. This study demonstrates for the first time the conformational transition of a dystrophin domain during its function, and suggests that such structural dynamics might play an important role in controlling dystrophin function. In the current project, we used relaxation dispersion and titration experiments to investigate glycan recognition by OAA, a cyanobacterial lectin with potent anti-HIV activity. CPMG relaxation dispersion experiments indicate that in the glycan-free OAA, lowly populated states are present. Fitting the dispersion curves at 277 K to a simple two-state model yields a chemical exchange rate of 922 ± 44 s-1 between the major state and an alternative state, populated at 2% ± 1%. Comparing the chemical shift differences derived from this CPMG relaxation dispersion with those derived from titration experiment with the glycan, suggests that the alternative conformations adopted in the absence of sugar may not resemble the sugar-bound state. Our current data represent the first steps in a detailed characterization of OAA dynamics, aimed at understanding its function.

Structural basis for the substrate selectivity of a HAD phosphatase from Thermococcus onnurineus NA1 Hye-Yeon Hwang 1 Haloalkaloic acid dehalogenase (HAD) superfamily represent one of the largest enzyme families, the majority of which mediate the transfer of phosphoryl groups. The diverse substrate recognition modes of HAD proteins are of the particular interest in understanding their evolutionary expansion. Among the 17 putative HAD members from Thermococcus onnurineus NA1, HAD56 was identified as a phosphatase with a substrate preference for 6-phosphogluconate. The crystal structures were determined in free state and in complex with a magnesium ion or a ligand. From the conservation of the catalytic scaffold of HAD superfamily in the core domain and the analyses of the ligand-binding cavity, HAD56 was proposed as a sugar or nucleotide phosphatase. The complex structures with 6-phosphogluconate or glucose-6-phosphate are marked by the rotation of the aromatic ring of Trp58 in the cap domain to sandwich the ligand between Trp58 and Trp61, and the replacement of these Trp residues reduced the phosphatase activity, thus confirming their roles in substrate recognition. Prion diseases are a class of transmissible neurodegenerative diseases, caused by an infectious protein, that afflict humans and other mammals. The infectious agent is a host encoded protein known as PrP that has adopted a misfolded conformation termed PrP Sc . The diseases have been shown to manifest by 3 different pathologic processes including sporadic/spontaneous, genetic, and infectious. In addition to genetic origin of prion disease, differences in the prion gene (PRNP) have been shown to influence incubation time and in some cases confer near absolute resistance in instances of infectious transmission. Despite the protein only nature of the infectious agent, the various prion diseases exist in many different strains, which depending upon the strain, can be differentiated by tissue distribution, brain lesion profiles, as well as glycoform analysis and molecular weight profile using western blot. In rodent adapted models, prion strains have also been shown to confer differences in the stability of PrP Sc as determined using GdmCl denaturation. In addition, PrP Sc stability has been shown to correlate well with incubation time such that the shortest incubation times result from the least stable prion strains. In natural host species, a priori predictions of incubation time based upon an in vitro assay are relevant for studies of pathogenesis and holds practical implications for disease management. Toward this goal, we assess the stability of PrP Sc derived from age matched Holstein steers inoculated with 3 different strains of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) (H-type, L-type, and classical) as well as Transmissible Mink Encephalopathy (TME).* Each BSE strain is differentiable using glycoform analysis and molecular weight profile on a western blot, and the observed incubation time for TME, H-type BSE, and L-type BSE is considerably shorter than that for classical BSE. Preliminary PrP Sc stability measurements do not correlate with incubation time implicating a mechanism for the differences in incubation time not derived from fibril stability. *All work was performed with the approval of the institutional review board of the sponsoring institution.

Use of an ELISA Stability Assay to examine host genotype, PrP Sc stability, and incubation time relationships in U.S. livestock prion strains Catherine Vrentas, Eric Nicholson, Justin Greenlee National Animal Disease Center, United States Dept. of Agriculture, 2300 DAYTON ROAD, Ames, IA, 50021

Transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) are caused by the misfolding of cellular prion protein (PrP C ) into a disease-associated version (PrP Sc ) that accumulates in certain tissues, leading to pathological changes in the brain and eventual death. Different strains of TSEs cause different brain lesion and PrP Sc accumulation profiles, as well as different incubation times, upon inoculation into a mouse host. Based on the "protein only" model for TSEs, the unique properties of each strain are "encoded" in PrP Sc higher-order structure, even if the primary structure is the same in each case. One method of probing PrP Sc structural differences is treatment with guanidinium chloride (GdmCl). When the level of PrP Sc remaining is plotted as a function of [GdmCl] , the [GdmCl] 1/2 , or the concentration at which half of the PrP Sc has been denatured, is used as a measure of strain stability. Previous work has demonstrated a tight correlation between the [GdmCl] 1/2 of a strain and its incubation time in mice. Here, we employ a commercial ELISA-based assay to examine the stability of PrP Sc from TSE-infected livestock, including scrapieinfected sheep and chronic wasting disease-infected elk. We retrospectively examine correlations between host genotype, incubation time, and PrP Sc stability of strains in the U.S. livestock population.* In sheep, we examine the impact of the host genotype at PRNP codon 136, a known scrapie susceptibility locus, on host susceptibility to different scrapie strains, including a fastacting scrapie isolate called 136-VDEP. We observe a correlation between incubation time and strain stability, and determine that the residue present at codon 136 does not inherently affect stability of PrP Sc aggregates. We demonstrate the use of the stability assay as a means of tracking the presence of different scrapie strains through the process of stabilization in a livestock host. In elk, we observe correlations between the genotype at elk PRNP codon 132 (a known susceptibility locus, also important in human infection), CWD incubation time, and PrP Sc stability. Finally, we compare the results of the stability measurements on elk PrP Sc to structural differences probed by the protease cleavage pattern of PrP Sc and describe an effect of the method of brain tissue homogenization on these results. *All work was performed with the approval of the institutional review board of the sponsoring institution. Nitric oxide (NO) signaling pathways play important roles in blood pressure regulation, platelet aggregation, and angiogenesis. Dysfunction of NO signaling has been linked to cardiovascular disease, inhibition of cell proliferation and migration, and problems with wound healing. NO is an activator of the heterodimeric enzyme soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC) through binding to the ferrous heme. sGC is also directly regulated by CD47, thrombospondin-1 (TSP-1), and vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-2 (VEGFR2). Binding partners of integrin associated protein CD47 include αvβ3 and VEGFR2. A C-terminal fragment of trimeric matricellular protein TSP-1, called E3CaG1, was shown to downregulate sGC by inhibiting NO signaling through an increase in Ca2+. TSP-1 is also known to abolish the interaction between CD47 and VEGFR2, thereby providing an anti-angiogenic effect. Although there is evidence suggesting the existence of these interactions, little is know about specific binding characteristics and structure/function relationships between CD47 and TSP-1. To explore binding of TSP-1 to CD47, we are employing a variety of approaches, including plasmon waveguide resonance spectroscopy (PWR), flow cytometry and calcium imaging. These studies indicate that the C-terminal fragment of TSP-1 (E3CaG1) binds to multiple signaling complexes involving CD47 on membrane surfaces, including αvβ3 and VEGFR2. E3CaG1 can bind with nM and pM affinities to the membrane surface; however, which of these leads to an increase in Ca2+ levels is not yet known and the subject of investigation. We hypothesize that knocking out various glycosylation sites in the extracellular portion of CD47 will impact binding of TSP-1 to CD47. Testing this will involve mutagenesis in knocking out glycosylation sites as well as flow cytometry and cell imaging to probe binding characteristics. CD47 has an extracellular IgG domain, is heavily glycosylated, has 5 transmembrane helices and a short alternatively-spliced C-terminal domain in the cytosol. We are exploring which of those are important for ligand binding, complex formation and Ca2+ signaling using recombinant proteins in immortalized human cell lines. Replication Protein A (RPA), the major eukaryotic single-strand DNA (ssDNA) binding protein, is essential for replication, repair, recombination, and cell cycle progression. Defects in RPA-associated cellular activities lead to genomic instability, a major factor in the pathogenesis of cancer and other diseases. RPA is a heterotrimeric complex with the largest subunit, RPA1, containing the major ssDNA-binding activity. The high affinity DNA binding domain interacts with ssDNA via a series of polar residues and four conserved aromatic residues. Mutation of the aromatic residues does not dramatically decrease ssDNA-binding activity of RPA, but results in a cell cycle defect. We have used a combination of biochemical analysis in vitro and knockdown and replacement studies in HeLa cells to characterize the contribution of these aromatic residues to RPA function. Cells expressing these mutant forms of RPA accumulated double-strand breaks and possibly other DNA damage. In contrast the aromatic mutants were able to function in DNA replication and checkpoint activation. Examination of the pathways affected showed that the aromatic residue mutants were unable to support DNA repair. Both nucleotide excision and double strand DNA break repair were disrupted. Biochemical characterization of these separation-offunction mutants revealed that mutation of the aromatic residues severely decreased binding to short ssDNA regions. We conclude that altering the ssDNA-binding properties of RPA results in inadequate protection of short ssDNA regions exposed during normal cellular processes and causes defects in DNA repair. These studies suggest RPA is more reliant on the high affinity DNA-binding domains of RPA1 when binding to the short exposed ssDNA regions that occur after DNA damage. We conclude that DNA replication and DNA repair require different RPA-DNA interactions and that these differences may depend on the length of exposed ssDNA intermediates. These studies are defining functions of RPA in DNA repair and are contributing to understanding how human cells maintain genome integrity. Research supported by AHA Fellowship 09PRE2160147 to CSH and NIH GM44721. In vitro translation (IVT) using mammalian cell extracts is an alternative method to in vivo mammalian protein expression. Using a modified HeLa cell line, we prepared highly translation-competent extracts for expressing a variety of genes from mammals, bacteria or protozoa. The Thermo Scientific 1-Step Human In Vitro Translation (IVT) System provides protein expression through the addition of a DNA or mRNA of interest to a mixture of HeLa cell lysate, accessory proteins and reaction mix followed by incubation for 1-6 hours at 30°C. The system is optimal for protein expression in microtubes (batch mode), microwell plates for high-throughput screening (HTS) studies and nucleic acid programmable protein arrays (NAPPA). NAPPA is an in situ protein expression and capture system that enables researchers to produce and display proteins as needed in a highly multiplexed fashion. In NAPPA arrays, the 1-Step system showed consistency between lots and average protein expression levels that were 5-to 10-fold greater on a genome-wide scale when compared to a rabbit reticulocyte lysate-based cell-free system. Combining dialysis with our 1-Step system increases protein expression to >250µg/mL by replenishing amino acids, nucleotides, salts and energy regeneration components, while eliminating inhibitory byproducts. Significantly higher activity of several proteins, including luciferases, was observed when using the 1-Step system versus a standard E.coli system. In addition, we developed a series of pT7CFE1based expression vectors, which are optimally suited as alternative pathways for purification and detection of the expressed proteins.

Sigma receptor-1 (SR-1) is a 223 amino acid eukaryotic membrane protein that is now recognized as chaperone and inter-organelle signaling modulator. Sigma receptor-1 is predicted to have two transmembrane domains and is categorized as a transmembrane protein.
body_text.section: Human In Vitro Translation Systems for Rapid and High Yield Expression of Functional Proteins

body_text.text: Knowledge of the SR-1 3-dimensional to structure may provide clues to new therapeutic pathways for treatment of many human central nervous system and peripheral diseases like Alzheimer's disease and addiction. The guinea pig SR-1 (gpSR-1) was recently expressed as a properly folded and active protein in a bacterial host strain. In collaboration with Professor Ruoho's team at the UW-Madison, we have expressed and purified gpSR-1 for functional studies and structure determination. To stabilize the protein, it is expressed and purified with maltose binding protein (MBP) that contains a periplasmic export sequence fused to the N-terminus of gpSR-1. The expressed fusion protein (MBP-gpSR-1) is anchored in the E. coli cytoplasmic membrane. We have designed a series of vectors with short linkers consisting of 0 to 5 alanine residues between the N-terminal MBP and the gpSR-1 receptor. All of these constructs were expressed in a series of E. coli expression host strains and purified at large scale (cell paste obtained from 4 L growth). To facilitate X-ray crystallography studies, MBP-gpSR-1 fusion is expressed as selenomethionyllabeled protein, using modified defined medium and IPTG induction. Our current purification procedure consists of (1) extraction from membrane fraction by application of detergents; (2) purification by affinity chromatography (amylose resin); and (3) gel filtration and subsequent concentration using centrifugation concentrators. We are able to obtain up to 13 mg of purified MBP-gpSR-1 protein, with the final yield depending on the individual construct's linker. The MBP-gpSR-1 fusion protein retains ligand binding activity typical of native SR-1. Crystallization screens are being performed by our crystallography team and also at PSI:Biology Membrane Protein Structural The growing demand and acceptance of the use of protein therapeutics has created the need to quickly and accurately measure their binding characteristics and functional activity throughout the entire therapeutic discovery, development and production cycle. Real-time, label-free analysis is a useful tool for characterizing protein therapeutics based on relevant biophysical parameters, such as kinetics and affinity. For high-throughput quantitative measurements, instrument performance and robustness are paramount; however, the critical parameters for integrating these essential requirements have been incompatible, to date. To evaluate the practical and efficient use of real-time, label-free analysis for high-throughput screening and the subsequent kinetic characterization of thousands of samples per day, a panel comprised of crude and purified potential antibody therapeutics was tested. The samples were subjected to an initial screening assay to identify 'hits' or a 'kinetic screen' designed to estimate association (k a ) and dissociation (k d ) rates. Highresolution, high-throughput kinetic experiments were conducted for all of the antibody samples in the panel. Kinetic values obtained from multiple binding cycles compared favorably with results from a single injection binding cycle, thereby increasing sample throughput. High-throughput assay development and optimization augmented the overall high quality of the data used to calculate the kinetic results. The study outcome further supports the feasibility of using real-time, label-free analysis for high-throughput characterization of protein therapeutics. This research project was supported by Sierra Sensors GmbH. The causative agent of African sleeping sickness, Trypanosoma brucei, goes through an unusual mitochondrial RNA editing process essential for its survival. RNA editing terminal uridylyl transferase 2 of T. brucei (TbRET2) is an indispensable component of the editosome machinery responsible for the U addition in the editing process. Although not an integral part of the editosome, there is another essential enzyme that catalyzes the U addition: Mitochondrial Editosome-like complex Associated TUTase 1 (a.k.a. TbMEAT1). Both TbRET2 and TbMEAT1 are required for the insect as well as the bloodstream forms of the parasite, and, with their high-resolution crystal structures, they pose as promising pharmaceutical targets. Neither the exclusive requirement of UTP for catalysis nor the RNA primer preference of these enzymes are well understood. Using all-atom molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, we investigated the effect of UTP binding on the enzymes' structure and dynamics as well as the determinants governing exclusive UTP preference 402 Protease Engineering Brent Iverson Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX Appropriately engineered proteases could be used for a variety of applications ranging from molecular biology research reagents to human therapeutics. The latter could be envisioned as catalytic replacements for antibodies, provided the therapeutic target is a serum accessible protein. Key to the successful application of engineered proteases will be the ability to alter substrate specificity in precise fashion while maintaining a high level of overall catalytic activity. We have been developing a range of protease engineering strategies over the past decade with an emphasis on directed evolution approaches incorporating a catalytic turnover based high throughput screen. Most of our work has incorporated E. coli as a host organism and a FACS dependent library screening. Using the model protease OmpT, we have been able to alter both the P1 and P1' substrate specificity in a surprisingly general way while maintaining a relatively high level of substrate specificity as well as high overall catalytic activity. We have also used directed evolution to generate OmpT variants specific for substrates with modified amino acids such as nitro and sulfo tyrosine. In addition to the E. coli based strategies, we have begun to explore the use of other host organisms and proteases. We recently were able to alter the P1 specificity of the TEV protease by over 5000-fold in a single round of directed evolution. With the implementation of the quality by design (QbD) concept to drug development, monitoring product quality attributes (PQAs) of therapeutic proteins during process and product development has become increasingly critical. Mass spectrometry has been widely used for quantification of modifications in therapeutic proteins. In addition the use of internal standards provide unique benefits for accurate and precise quantification, since all variability in sample handling is minimized as the internal standard is introduced into the sample for analysis prior to any sample handling steps, such as proteolytic digestion and chromatographic separation, etc. Here, we describe the introduction by in vivo metabolic labeling of a stable isotope to produce a stable isotope labeled internal standard (SILIS) protein with 15N enriched media. The SILIS protein is the foundation for a novel strategy for automatically monitoring multiple PQAs in a single LC/ MS analysis. The 15N labeled therapeutic protein was used as an internal standard to monitor multiple PQAs of in-process samples. Precise and accurate quantitation was achieved on a Thermo Scientific LTQ Orbitrap Velos high-resolution mass spectrometer. MassAnalyzer, an in-house developed software at Amgen, was used for automated identification and quantitation of multiple modifications identified in a single peptide map. An important property of antimicrobials is the ability to reach the chosen target, which can be achieved through the "Trojan-horse" strategy. In this regard, microcin E492 (MccE492), a channel-forming bacteriocin, utilizes receptors that are normally used for iron uptake masking itself as a beneficial iron chelator. The modular structure of MccE492 allows the design of hybrid molecules that would permit the entry to the cell to reach the target. MccE492 is synthesized as a precursor with three domains: the leader peptide necessary for the export, the toxic, and the uptake domain, that is post-translationally modified with a salmochelin-like molecule involved in the recognition by the siderophore receptors FepA, Fiu and Cir. For the design, the selected target was aimed to the divisome, a supramolecular complex essential for bacterial division. The divisome elements localize in an ordered fashion, both at cytoplasm and periplasm, being the complex formed by FtsQ, FtsL and FtsB the main periplasmic component, that works as a bridge coupling the cytoplasmic with the periplasmic events in the division. FtsL constitutes an interesting target because it is a checkpoint in the bacterial division, and the introduction of exogenous periplasmic region of FtsL would displace by competition the equilibrium in the formation of the FtsQ/FtsB/FtsL complex. Based on a model of the FtsL complex developed for this purpose and exploiting the modularity of MccE492, we replaced the central module with the FtsL periplasmic region (H56 to K121). This was flanked to the N-terminal with the 22 first amino acids of MccE492 encompassing the leader peptide, and to the C-terminal with the uptake module (G67 to S84). This construction was placed under a pBAD promoter and its expression was monitored after induction. The chimeric protein could not be exported, therefore a procedure to purify it from a cytoplasmic extract was developed. This preparation presented a strong antimicrobial activity assessed either by growth inhibition of an E. coli lawn or by survival counting after the treatment. The chimeric peptide did not have antimicrobial activity on strains lacking the siderophore receptors involved in the translocation of the peptide to the periplasm space. We have developed a successful strategy in the design and construction of new antimicrobial peptides. Supported by FONDECYT grants 1095121 and 1100141 Synthetic Biology (405) 405 Studies of designer zinc finger enzymes and applications for genome editing and modification Wataru Nomura 1 , Akemi Masuda 1 , Asami Kondo 2 , Kenji Ohba 3 , Naoki Yamamoto 3 , Akihide Ryo 2 , Hirokazu Tamamura 1 1 Tokyo Medical and Dental University, 2-3-10 Kandasurugadai, Tokyo, 101-0062, Japan, 2 Yokohama City University, Yokohama, Japan, 3 National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore Artificial zinc finger proteins (ZFPs) consist of Cys 2 -His 2 -type modules composed of about 30 amino acids with a ββαstructure that coordinates a zinc ion. ZFPs that recognize specific DNA target sequences can substitute for the binding domains of enzymes that act on DNA to create designer enzymes, such as nucleases, recombinases, and methylases, with programmable sequence specificity. Genome editing and modification by the enzymes could be applied for many fields of basic research and medicine. Some zinc finger nucleases (ZFN) are currently in human clinical trials that aim at therapeutic gene editing. A more recent strategy that aims at addressing the shortcomings of ZFNs are zinc finger recombinases (ZFRs). A thorough understanding of ZFRs and methods for their modification promises powerful new tools for gene manipulation in model organisms as well as in gene therapy. In this presentation, the studies about design of ZFNs and ZFRs will be discussed. For ZFNs, the studies of antiviral effects of targeting viral genomes by ZFNs will be shown. In design of ZFRs, the effects of DNA binding affinity of the zinc finger domains and the linker sequence between ZFPs and recombinase catalytic domains have been assessed. A plasmid system containing ZFR target sites was constructed for evaluation of ZFRs with variable linker lengths and numbers of zinc finger modules. Recombination efficiencies were evaluated by restriction enzyme analysis of isolated plasmids after reaction in E. coli and mammalian cells. The results provide information relevant to the design of ZFRs that will be useful for sequence-specific genome modification. The above mentioned technologies will be powerful tools for creation of cell lines with artificially modified phenotypes. Furthermore, the strategy in application of genome editing by zinc finger enzymes for study of synthetic biology will be discussed. The ankyrin and SOCS box containing (ASB) proteins form the largest family of SOCS box proteins. There are 18 known human variants that are implicated in diverse biological functions. The ASB proteins have two domains a C-terminal SOCS box domain and an N terminal Ankyrin repeat (AR) domain. The C terminal SOCS box has been shown to interact with Elongin B & C and cullin5 and play a role in ubiquitination and targeting proteins for degradation to the 26S proteasome. The N terminal AR domain functions to bind and target specific substrates for ubiquitination and degradation. ASB9 has been shown to interact with creatine kinase brain (CKB) type and ubiquitous mitochondrial creatine kinase (CKuMt) and target these proteins for degradation. The AR domain of ASB9 has 6 ARs that align well with the consensus sequence and a small linker between the AR domain and the SOCS box domain that also folds into an AR-like structure. We have been able to successfully clone and purify several AR domain constructs of human ASB9 and the creatine kinases and are exploring the interaction of ASB9 with creatine kinase brain type (CKB) using biochemical and biophysical techniques. ASB9 binds CKB with strong affinity based on in vitro pull down experiments and size exclusion chromatography. Isothermal calorimetry experiments have shown that the complex formed between ASB9 and CKB has very high affinity and the interaction is mainly entropic with a small enthalpic contribution. Biacore experiments to determine ka and kd values and hydrogen deuterium exchange (HDX) mass spectrometry (MS) studies are being performed to reveal the exact site of interaction between the two proteins. Creatine kinases play a major role in maintenance and regulation of cellular energy stores in tissues with high and rapidly changing energy demands. Altered expression and regulation of CKB is displayed in several neurodegenerative diseases and cancers. ASB9 deregulation has also been implicated as a marker in cancer progression. Understanding the mechanism by which ASB9 helps maintain CKB levels will be important to understanding the role of both these proteins in these diseases.
