body_text.text: Predicting bZIP Coiled-Coil Interaction Specificity Vladimir Potapov, Aaron Reinke, Amy Keating Department of Biology, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA, 02139

The coiled-coil motif mediates interactions in a large number of protein families involved in key cellular processes. The question of how a high degree of interaction specificity is encoded in the relatively simple structure of this motif is of fundamental importance. Predictive models for coiled-coil interactions would find applications in basic biology, biotechnology, synthetic biology and other areas. The coiled-coil motif has been intensively studied and its general features are known. A variety of methods have been proposed for modeling coiled-coil interaction, however, their accuracy is still limited. In this work, we have used a new set of 2,683 coiled-coil interactions measured experimentally for basic-leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor coiled coils to deduce important determinants of coiled-coil specificity and transform them into a predictive model. We use a machine-learning framework that exploits knowledge of conserved residue-residue interactions in the coiled-coil motif. Our model is easily interpretable and allows us to pose testable hypotheses about factors contributing to coiled-coil specificity. We find that incorporating higher-order terms into the model is critical for the best predictions, which achieve a correlation with experimental binding free energies of R = 0.69. We demonstrate the superiority of this approach over other sequence-based and structurebased methods. We are currently applying this model to a range of problems related to leucine-zipper coiled-coil interaction specificity. This research is supported by the NIH award R01 GM06768. High-resolution structures of proteins provide valuable information for rational drug design. Prerequisite to obtain such structures are well-ordered threedimensional crystals. Some proteins have proven to be very difficult or even impossible to crystallize, and for such examples a number of ways have been developed to improve the chances for successful crystallization. Genetic engineering of the protein, either by the introduction of surface mutations or by the variation of the protein construct length, is often effective. Cocrystallization of proteins with other proteins may be a good alternative. Classically, antibodies or antibody Fab-fragments which might stabilize the target protein were used for co-crystallization and often result in an improved overall crystal quality. Recently the focus has also been on novel classes of very versatile binding proteins such as Darpins, Fynomers or Nanobodies. In order to evaluate the potential of such small scaffold proteins for crystallization we tested in parallel classical Fab-fragments, Fynomers derived from the SH3 domain of Fyn from Covagen, Nanobodies from Xaperones and a surface mutant approach for crystallizing BACE-2. BACE-2 is an aspartyl protease whose exact physiological function is unknown, but for which a role in the early stages of diabetes has been postulated. Its structure has only been published at 3.0 Å resolution, possibly because BACE-2 conformational heterogeneity limits a better diffraction. The parallel use of these different "crystallization facilitators" allows us to establish different crystals systems to test this tool molecules in a direct comparison and finally to efficiently support the drug discovery process using the obtained structural information. Treatment of sound wave shows an obvious effects on the growth and development of plants. Researchers found that sound wave effects on the production of hormones. The effects of music on plants have been controversial because the precise experimental conditions were not specified. In addition, music is a mixture of different frequencies and amplitudes, which makes more difficult to interpret the effects of sound waves. Despite the importance of sound wave in plant growth and development, little is known regarding the molecular physiological mechanisms underlying such a response. In this study, we investigated the changes in the omes of Arabidopsis (transcriptome, proteome and metabolome) in response to various frequency-specific sound waves in the controlled environment. This study was performed based on Affymetrix gene chip, twodimensional gel electrophoresis (2-DE) and HPLC, respectively. The differentially regulated transcripts, proteins and metabolites could be classified into photosynthesis, stress and defense, nitrogen metabolism and carbohydrate metabolism. To our best knowledge, this is the first report for the analysis of ome changes in response to sound wave in Arabidopsis. In addition, our findings provided a comprehensive omics view on the coordination of sound wave responses in Arabidopsis.

Integrating high-throughput proteomics approaches for functional characterization of proteins Charles Ansong 1 , Si Wu 2 , Eric Merkley 1 , Erin Baker 1 , Aaron Wright 1 , Ernesto Nakayasu 1 , Roslyn Brown 1 , John Cort 1 , Ljiljana Pasa-Tolic 2 , Joshua Adkins 1 1 Biological Science Divison, Pacific Northwest National Lab, Richland, WA, 2 Environmental Molecular Sciences Laboratory, Pacific Northwest National Lab, Richland, WA While advances in sequencing technologies have resulted in an exponential increase in the number of sequenced genomes and subsequently protein sequences in sequence databases, no function can be assigned to a significant portion of these proteins, indicating major gaps in our understanding of biological systems. To realize the full value of these sequenced genomes for systems and synthetic biology efforts requires functional characterization of mature protein products in a high-throughput fashion. However, no single approach to functional characterization is likely to be successful for any given protein. We are developing a suite of experimental approaches designed to identify characteristics of proteins that could provide clues to their function. These include elucidation of protein activities using chemical probes, identification of biomolecular interaction partners, and characterization of post-translational modifications. All of these are being applied in a high-throughput fashion using mass spectrometry methods to enable rapid characterization. The idea is that at the most basic level the almost any protein will bind and possibly chemically modify one or more other molecules, or possibly be modified itself. These proto-functions underlie the real biochemical and cellular function. Moreover, they can be screened for and identified in a high-throughput fashion. Particularly when combined with existing data from whole cell transciptomics, proteomics, and structural genomics campaigns, our approaches may reveal one or more clues that point toward a biochemical function that can be confirmed using traditional hypothesis-driven investigation.

Bioquimica, Instituto Nacional de Cardiologia, Juan Badiano No. 1, Col. Secc. XVI, Del. Tlalpan. Mexico D.F., Mexico, 14080, Mexico Aldehydes such as malondialdehyde, acrolein and 4-hydroxy-2-nonenal (4-HNE) are generated as products of lipid peroxidation in the organisms. It has been proposed that these compounds are part of the pathogenesis of diseases associated with oxidative stress like Alzheimer, Parkinson and diabetes, among others. These compounds are detoxified by aldehyde dehydrogenases (ALDHs). However, previous reports indicated that ALDH2 is inactivated by 4-HNE. The aim of this work was to investigate the susceptibility of ALDH1A1, ALDH2 and ALDH3A1, to inactivation by lipid peroxidation products. ALDH2 showed the highest affinity for the three aldehydes, followed by ALDH1A1. The activity of ALDH3A1 with these aldehydes was 6 to 10 fold higher compared with the other enzymes, but the affinity for these compounds was low. Although ALDH2 was the most efficient enzyme, it was inactivated by acrolein and 4-HNE at concentrations above 5 and 10 μM, respectively, while ALDH1 was inactivated by acrolein at concentrations higher than 1 mM. Surprisingly, ALDH3A1 was resistant to inactivation by these aldehydes, even at concentrations as high as 20 mM. It was previously reported that the order of reaction of 4-HNE with nucleophylic amino acids was Cys >> His > Lys and suggested that the target for the inactivation was the reactive cysteine in ALDH2 (Cys302). Since ALDH3A1 is resistant to inactivation by the aldehydes assayed, the reactive cysteine may not be the target for the inactivation of ALDHs. Thus, the amino acids sequence of the active site of the ALDHs was compared in order to identify residues susceptible to react with the aldehydes. It was observed that ALDH1 had an extra cysteine aside Cys 302, while ALDH2 possessed 2 cysteines flanking cys302 and ALDH3 only had the reactive cysteine. In the NAD+ binding site, ALDH1 and ALDH2 had an exposed lysine (Lys352), while ALDH3A1 had an arginine in the equivalent position. Assays of protection by substrates indicated that propionaldehyde slightly protected the enzyme from inactivation, while NADH showed a higher protection, indicating that the binding site of NAD+ is also a target for the inactivation. In conclusion, the extra cysteines in the aldehyde binding site and a lysine in the NAD+ binding site, may be the targets for inactivation by lipid peroxidation products in ALDH1 and ALDH2. This project was supported by CONACyT-México grant No. 166463.
body_text.section: Differential Effect of Lipid Peroxidation Products on Human Aldehyde Dehydrogenases Jose Rodriguez-Zavala

body_text.text: High cell-density medium applicable to protein labeling Craig Fuller 1 , Antti Vasala 1 , Heli Alanen 2 , Lloyd Ruddock 2 1 BioSilta, Oulu, Finland, 2 Biochemistry, University of Oulu, Oulu, Finland

We describe a novel nitrogen-free medium, EnMR medium, which can help streamline the process of target cloning, protein expression, screening and preliminary protein folding/aggregation assessment by NMR spectroscopy and other methods that require 15N protein labeling. This 15N-labeling EnMR medium applies the fed-batch like cultivation system, EnBase (Enzymebased glucose-delivery), and provides high cell densities (DCW > 8 or OD600 > 24), reduces accumulation of growth-inhibiting compounds (by overflow metabolism), and additionally potentiates the control of the protein synthesis rate. EnBase medium has been shown in several publications to give enhanced yields of soluble protein in comparison to mineral salt medium or rich medium compositions. A robust cultivation protocol with low hands-on activities was developed. This protocol consists of overnight cultivation yielding induction cell density of OD600 of 1.5 to 3.0, induction by IPTG without any intermittent cell harvesting or medium change, and few additions of the glucosereleasing enzyme. Cell harvesting is typically done 24 h after induction. Studies with several recombinant constructs showed that with NH4Cl-supplemented EnMR medium, specific productivity (recombinant protein per cell) comparable to the performance of the standard M9 medium could be achieved. Additionally, the volumetric yields obtained using the EnMR medium were much higher. Protein by protein comparisons showed that EnMR medium could in some cases give soluble recombinant protein, while M9 could not. This newly-developed system is flexible and has been shown to be scalable providing high yields both in deep well plates and shake flask cultivations.

Enzyme-based Glucose Delivery System Enhances Recombinant Protein Production in Shaken Cultures of Pichia pastoris Russell Golson 3 , Rahul Nanekar 1 , Antti Isomursu 1 , Veli-Pekka Jaakola 1 , Craig Fuller 3 , Johana Panula-Perälä 2 , Antti Vasala 3 1 Biochemistry, University of Oulu, Oulu, Finland, 2 Process and Environ. Eng., University of Oulu, Oulu, Finland, 3 BioSilta, Oulu, Finland Enzyme-based glucose-delivery system (EnBase) is a fed-batch-like method applicable for simple shaken cultivations. Since the glucose-feeding rate can be adjusted by enzyme dosing to match the cultivation conditions (especially oxygen transfer rate and cell density), EnBase technology can provide a level of growth control, which is normally applicable only in bioreactor cultivations. Additionally, glucose-limiting conditions create the possibility to maintain a favorable pH level by applying a balanced mixture of organic and inorganic nitrogen sources. An efficient cultivation protocol was developed for Pichia pastoris using the new EnBase yeast medium composition, EnPresso Y Defined tablets. Slow glucose-delivery does not prevent the induction of AOX1 or AOX2 promoter by methanol, but can instead prevent starvation between methanol pulses and provide higher cell yields and product yields. Both intracellular proteins such as a plant-lectin binding protein, Mpv17 (human integral membrane protein), Erp18 (human endoplasmic reticulum protein), and secreted proteins like lipases of Rhizopus or Candida spp. showed 3-to 10-fold improved volumetric protein production in comparison to routinely used cultivation media. Optimization of the cultivation protocol for a GFP-tagged construct expressing human adenosine receptor A3 suggests that this EnBase medium can also reduce the metabolic stress caused by methanol or by frequently changing conditions observed in shaken cultures; thus, improve the quality of synthesized protein. EnPresso Y Defined medium, which feeds low amounts of glucose throughout the cultivation, can provide stable conditions, which are ideal for protein production in Pichia pastoris. The major benefits include that the amount of the toxic inducer methanol can be minimized, starvation between methanol pulses can be avoided, medium change is no longer required and the medium can be easily prepared from pre-sterilized tablets. Enzymatic "co-feed" of glucose can also significantly shorten the cultivation time in methanolinducible systems. In comparison to YPD-medium, EnPresso Y Defined gave higher product yields in 3 days than YPD-medium in 7 days. This cultivation protocol, which includes occasional addition of the glucosereleasing enzyme together with methanol addition, can be easily adapted to any vessel or shaking condition.

Effect of Engineered Nanostructure on partial unfolding of Fibronectin and its role in Enhanced Biointegration Fereydoon Namavar 1 , Alexander Rubinstein 1 , Renat Sabirianov 2 1 Department of Orthopaedic Surgery and Rehabilitation, University of Nebraska Medical Center, Omaha, NE, 2 Department of Physics, University of Nebraska at Omaha, Omaha, NE We performed adhesion and proliferation experiments with a bona fide mesenchymal stromal cell cell line (OMA-AD) on nano-structured cubic zirconia coatings and compared them to CoCr, Ti and HA. Our experimental results indicated that nanoengineered coatings are superior in supporting growth, adhesion, and proliferation. The improved biocompatibility of nanostructured coatings, we believe, is due to improved initial adsorption of the fibronectin (FN) adhesive protein on the artificial surface with simultaneous induced protein unfolding (converted compact FN to its extended counterpart form). Absorption experiments with FN from human plasma using an ELISA-based technique resulted in higher FN adsorption on nanoengineered surfaces as compared to other conventional orthopedic materials. Pure cubic ZrO2 coatings are fabricated with 2-25 nm grain size which is comparable to the protein dimensions by applying ion beam assisted deposition [1] . These experiments indicate a clear correlation between cell adhesion and FN adsorption. Motivated by experimentally-observed biocompatibility enhancement of nanoengineered cubic zirconia (ZrO2) coatings to mesenchymal stromal cells, we implemented Monte Carlo simulation methods [2] and carried out computational analysis of causes for partial unfolding of 1FN3-2FN3 domains compact complex on the surface. These domains are very important for FN-FN binding, FN matrix assembly initiation, and understanding of the physicochemical mechanisms for FN activation on the surface. Our calculations showed that disruption of the considered domain complex can be promoted due to rather strong selective (attractive and repulsive) electrostatic interactions between negatively charged surface patches and ionogenic groups of the negative and positive charged domains. As the above domains contain FN-binding sites, one can suggest that these sites become exposed and effective for FN matrix assembly. Thus, a nanostructured negatively charged surface may facilitate activation for adsorbed FNs (in extended form) and their binding with other FNs adhered on the cell surface. Thus, we suggest a rather simple electrostatic mechanism for FN activation due to its immobilization on the nano-structured oxide surface. This process will facilitate formation of ECM on the surface and promote the focal cell adhesion. Research support provided by the Department of Energy, Biological & Environmental Research.

Protein crystallography using X-ray free-electron lasers Mark Hunter 1 , Brent Segelke 2 , Matthew Coleman 2, 3 , W. Henry Benner 2 , Matthias Frank 1 1 Physical and Life Sciences Directorate, Physics Division, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, 2 Physical and Life Sciences Directorate, Biosciences and Biotechnology Division, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, 3 Radiation Oncology, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA X-ray crystallography is the workhorse of structural biology for determining the structure of proteins. Two major obstacles to protein crystallography are the growth of large, well-ordered crystals and X-ray induced radiation damage. Smaller, yet still well ordered, crystals can often form in a crystallization experiment. Unfortunately, the integrated intensity within a Bragg reflection scales with the number of illuminated unit cells. As a result, for a given protein crystal, more dose must be given to the crystal, in the form of higher intensity or longer exposures, to achieve similar resolutions with smaller crystals. The increased dose has the negative effect of generating additional X-ray-induced radiation damage, potentially making the interpretation of electron-density maps around radiation-damage-susceptible groups difficult, if not impossible to interpret. The advent of the X-ray freeelectron laser (XFEL) may allow the use of smaller protein crystals by breaking the nexus between dose and radiation damage. The success of crystallography at XFELs will be predicated on diffraction before destruction, meaning the necessary information for reconstructing electron-density maps would be recorded before the onset of the damage processes. Ultimately, protein crystallography at XFELs could pave the way for structure determination from protein nanocrystals and microcrystals, from radiation-damage-susceptible proteins, and from pump-probe experiments utilizing the intrinsic temporal resolution offered by the source.

The Spectroscopy and Mathematics of Spinning Disc Interferometry David Webster ddw2, LLC, Fishers, IN Spinning Disc Interferometry is an instrument which measures protein quantity and developed by Quadraspec. A 635 nm laser scans the wells of a BioCD as it spins. Spinning Disc Interferometry measures changes in relative optical absorption/refraction based upon: i) Relative number of absorbent amino acids {W, Y, F, P, and H} in the correct orientation; ii) The amount protein bound or equal to protein "height"; iii) The amount of protein is an estimated from standard curve. The other amino acids do absorb light but the aromatic character of the five are the main contributors. Firstly, a disc spins while a narrow band width of an optical light source refracts light. Light which is refracted and directly proportional to the amount of protein present passes over the wells. More specifically, the highly absorbent amino acids mainly W,Y,F,P,and H whose R groups are aromatic and are the significant contributors. If they are properly spatially orientated to absorb light, the amino acid will be directed related to amount of protein. However, each particular oriented species (protein stack can bind in an infinite number of conformations to the solid phase) they will determine the limits of detection and slope of your standard curve (extinction coefficient). Furthermore, the orientation of an aromatic ring, take Phe for instance, can be attached to the solid phase in the protein backbone in two totally non-light absorbing species one with the aromatic ring parallel to the solid phase and the other horizontal to the solid phase. So in other words, the absorbance is dependent upon the relative number of highly absorbent amino acids {mainly W,Y,F,P,and H}. These five amino acids have the aromatic R groups. Interesting a labeled fluorescent binding partner stacked, measured and read with Interferometry is directly proportional to amount of protein captured. However, in a label free protein stack this is not true. This is due to the inherent issues mentioned above. Additionally, one of the relative limits of the system are your protein sample competes for binding sites whether they be full or partial transcripts. Label free kinetic analysis has become an indispensable tool for academic and industry researchers in the fields of protein engineering and drug discovery. SPR is the flagship technique for this analytical tool, but despite its prominence in industry has not managed to significantly increase its throughput across platforms since its inception 20 years ago. The array format unlocks the true potential of this technology by allowing researchers to simultaneously monitor 96 or more discrete interactions to a series of analytes in real time. This not only vastly increases the throughput of general kinetic analysis, but it gives the user powerful new experimental design options by staging massively parallel interaction assays. One of the most exciting target applications for this multiplexed approach is epitope mapping, where antibodies are screened based on their ability to bind an antigen in the presence of an antibody or compound already bound to a specific site on that antigen. The one-on-many, highly parallel nature of this technique provides an elegant way of maintaining the consistency of experimental parameters across diverse ligand species in the array. This has enabled us to perform a binning experiment in 3 hours that would have taken the industry standard 3 days to complete. Using SPR, the yield and activity of solubilized GPCRs can be tested to identify the best conditions under which to study the kinetics of interactions with these important but highly fragile molecules. The array format allows you to run your analyte over the 96 conditions in a single injection, dropping your run time down to 30 min (compared to 48 hours) giving the greatest probability of the GPCRs maintaining consistent binding activity.

Using fluorescence cross-correlation spectroscopy for antibody characterization Ted Laurence 1 , Sonny Ly 1 , Feliza Bourguet 1 , Sang Thai 2 , Brian Kay 2 , Matthew Coleman 1 1 Physical and Life Sciences, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, L-470, Livermore, CA, 94550, 2 Department of Biological Sciences, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL Fluorescence cross-correlation spectroscopy (FCCS) provides an excellent way to monitor protein-protein interactions in solution-based experiments. We are currently applying this technique to characterizing single-chain fragment antibodies (scFv) that we have isolated via phage-display against membrane proteins involved in emerging host-pathogen interactions. Membrane proteins can be solubilized by integrating them into nanolipoproteins, which serve as an antigenpresenting scaffold and for monitoring antigen-scFv interaction using FCCS. The entire workflow can occur within a single week by taking advantage of rapid protein production using cell-free technologies. We will present the methods used to characterize the antibody-antigen interactions using FCCS, along with examples of their use. Alternating laser excitation and spike removal algorithms are used to prevent spurious cross-correlations the otherwise prevent quantitative measurements of concentrations. Examples shown will include monitoring of sandwich assays and direct antibody-antigen interactions.

Secretome analysis of endophytic fungi grown in minimally-treated lignocellulosic biomass feedstocks Eizadora Yu 1 , Kevin Turner 1 , Mary Tran-Gyamfi 1 , Huu Tran 1 , Gary Strobel 2 , Craig Taatjes 1 , Masood Hadi 1 1 Sandia National Labs, PO BOx 969 MS9292, Livermore, CA, 94551, 2 Dept of Plant Sciences, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT A promising alternative strategy for fuel production from cellulosic biomass involves the direct conversion of cellulose to fuels by microbial biotechnology. Ideally, cultivation of biofuel-producing microorganisms should be supported by biomass feedstocks obtained from energy crops or agricultural wastes. Endophytes are a class of organisms that colonize intercellular spaces in plants; and as such contain the requisite hydrolytic enzymes needed to deconstruct lignocellulose. We focused our efforts on four endophytic fungi that have the added ability to produce VOCs with fuel potential. In this study, we aim to identify and characterize the secreted lignocellulolytic fungal enzymes through genomics and proteomics methods. Four strains (a Daldinia (EC12) and 3 Hypoxylons (CI-4A, CO27-A and EC38)) were obtained from the Mycological Collection of the Department of Plant Sciences at MSU. Fungal isolates were grown in liquid medium containing supplemented M9 media and sterile feedstock (milled corn stover, switchgrass, or arbog eucalyptus) as the sole carbon source. All feedstocks were able to support growth, but mycelium growth was fastest in corn. EC12 achieved comparable growth rates in all feedstocks. For secretome analysis, cultures were grown in liquid medium at room temperature and the culture media were harvested after 2 weeks. To remove contaminants, the supernatant samples were further filtered and protein concentrated by ultrafiltration. Total protein concentration was determined by BCA protein assay and proteins were separated and visualized by SDS-PAGE. EC12 extracts had more proteins than the other species and in general, fungi grown on corn stover media contained more proteins than those grown on other media. Secretomes were assayed for cellulolytic activity using the DNS assay, and showed enzyme activity over a wide pH and temperature range (25-50oC) for all extracts. Secretomes were also assayed for ligninolytic activity using standard spectrophotometric assays (ABTS & guaiacol oxidation) and showed laccase and Mn peroxidase activity. In collaboration with JGI, the genomes of the four fungal strains have been assembled and annotated. Most of the ORFs were annotated using the KOG, KEGG, and Blast analogues. Functiondirected proteomics (in-gel digestion coupled with LC-ESI-MS) to identify the set of CAZY and ligninmodifying enzymes is underway. This work is supported by the LDRD program at Sandia National Laboratories.
body_text.section: LB1

body_text.text: Modeling bacteriophage lambda site-specific recombination Yi-An Lai 1 , Steven Esquivel 1 , Ismael Perez 2 , Peter Salamon 2 , Anca Segall 1 1 Biology, San Diego State University, 5500 Campnile Dr., San Diego, CA, 92182, 2 Mathematics and Statistics, San Diego State University, San Diego, CA Bacteriophage lambda is a temperate phage that establishes lysogeny by inserting its genome into that of its host, E. coli. Both integration into and excision from the chromosome of the host entail a site-specific recombination event, performed by the phage-encoded Integrase (Int) protein. The decision to integrate or to excise appears to be largely irreversible: once the decision is made, the phage would compromise its ability to survive if it does not complete the reaction. The recombination starts with DNA substrates (which we collectively refer to as A) that undergo one round of catalytic events -DNA cleavage, strand exchange, and ligation -to generate the first Holliday junction isomer (B). This B Holliday junction isomerizes to a different conformation, which we call C. Finally, the C Holliday junction isomer undergoes another round of catalytic events to generate the products, which we collectively refer to as E. Whether the pseudosymmetric intermediate, Holliday junction is in the B or C conformation appears to determine whether the reaction proceeds forward to products E or backwards to regenerate substrates A. Ultimately, we would like to understand how the Integrase protein accomplishes Holliday junction isomerization at the molecular level, and what features regulate this event. To address this goal, we are combining biochemical assays with mathematical modeling approaches to determine the equilibrium constants of each of the reaction steps. With the model, we can characterize the effect of Int mutant proteins on interactions with HJ and HJ isomerization by seeing how different mutations affect the equilibrium constants. We have isolated radiolabeled Holliday junction intermediates, re-loaded them with proteins, and monitored the resolution of the junctions either into the "substrates" attL and attR (collectively known as A) or into the products attP and attB (collectively known as E). The kinetics constants were then solved by fitting differential equations to the experimental data. We also used two HJ isomers whose conformation is biased towards either the B or the C conformation. The mathematical model has generated stable kinetics constants that are informative in describing the difference between wild-type and the two biased HJ isomers during catalytic events. While analyzing all available protein structures for the presence of knots and slipknots we detected a strict conservation of complex knotting patterns within and between several protein families despite their large sequence divergence. Since protein folding pathways leading to knotted native protein structures are slower and less efficient than those leading to unknotted proteins with similar size and sequence, the strict conservation of the knotting pattern indicates an important physiological role of knots and slipknots in these proteins. Although little is known about the functional role of knots, recent studies have demonstrated a protein-stabilizing ability of knots and slipknots. Some of the conserved knotting patterns occur in proteins forming transmembrane channels where the slipknot loop seems to strap together the transmembrane helices forming the channel. Polar-to-hydrophobic amino acid substitutions can lower the structural specificity of proteins, allowing for the population of alternate folds and oligomeric states. In the dimeric ribbon-helix-helix protein Arc repressor, a single polar to hydrophobic substitution on the surface of the ribbon (Arc-N11L) transforms the region into a 3 10 helix, thereby burying the new hydrophobic sidechain. When two additional polar-to-hydrophobic mutations are introduced (Q9V and R13V; Arc-VLV), the protein adopts both dimeric states observed in Arc-N11L, and in addition populates an octamer with a distinct folding topology. To carefully investigate the sequence determinants of higher order oligomer formation, we have substituted various combinations of polar and hydrophobic residues at positions 9, 11, and 13 using sitedirected mutagenesis. Size exclusion chromatography shows that three aliphatic hydrophobic substitutions are necessary and sufficient to induce oligomerization, although variations in elution volume suggest that the specific oligomeric state(s) vary depending on the particular substitutions. Interestingly, residues 9-13 of Arc-VLV and other variants are predicted to be highly amyloidogenic, but do not form larger oligomers than octamer under any conditions tested. To investigate whether any sequence could induce amyloid formation in Arc, we substituted the highly amyloidogenic LVFFA region of Aβ for residues 9-13 (Arc-Aβ). Surprisingly, Arc-Aβ forms a stable dimer exclusively, suggesting that this region of Arc can be radically remodeled by hydrophobic mutations but is also highly resistant to more conventional misfolding/aggregation processes.
body_text.section: LB2

body_text.text: Taken together, the mutability of the Arc repressor ribbon region indicates that simple hydrophobic mutations may serve as an avenue to open new areas of protein structure space, allowing the population of novel folds. This work is supported by NIH grant GM066806 to MHJC.
body_text.section: LB2

body_text.text: Crystal structure of the Rna14-Rna15 Complex Ashley Paulson, Liang Tong Columbia University, 703 Fairchild Building, New York, NY, 10027 A large protein machinery is responsible for 3'end cleavage and polyadenylation of pre-mRNA in eukaryotes. Many of the factors in this machinery are conserved from yeast to mammals. In yeast, cleavage factor IA (CF IA) is required for both cleavage and polyadenylation of nascent pre-mRNA, and is comprised of four proteins: Rna14, Rna15, Clp1 and Pcf11. Rna14 and Rna15 are the fungal homologs of CstF-77 and CstF-64, respectively, in the cleavage stimulation factor (CstF) of mammals. Rna14 contains an N-terminal HAT (Half-A-TPR) domain, and a C-terminal 'monkeytail' that interacts with Rna15. Rna15 contains an N-terminal RNA-Recognition Motif (RRM), followed by the central hinge region that interacts with Rna14, and a C-terminal domain which interacts with Pcf11. We report the first crystal structures of Rna14 in complex with the hinge domain of Rna15, as well as the crystal structures of the HAT domain of Rna14 in two different crystal forms. The Rna14 HAT domain forms a stable dimer, both in solution and in the crystal structure. In the Rna14-Rna15 complex crystals, the HAT domain of Rna14 is connected to the C-terminal 'monkeytail' of Rna14 by a disordered linker. The HAT domain does not have strong interactions with the complex between the Rna14 'monkeytail' and the Rna15 hinge, which may indicate that these two domains function independently. The HAT domain of Rna14 has significant differences from the crystal structure of the CstF-77 HAT domain. The HAT domain exhibits varying conformations in the different crystal forms, which indicates that the dimer has inherent confirmational variability.
body_text.section: LB5

body_text.text: Evaluation of Static Light Scattering as an Approach to Epitope Mapping using Interleukin-12 Model System Lena Liang, Colin Garvie, Alvin Stern Protein Biochemistry, Discovery Technologies, pRED, Hoffmann-La Roche, Nutley, NJ Traditional methods for epitope mapping can often become a laborious effort requiring the generation of peptide libraries or chemical modifications of the reactants. Here we present an alternative approach to epitope mapping with the use of size exclusion chromatography (SEC) and static light scattering (SLS). SEC-SLS provides an attractive alternative as the proteins do not need to be modified and the interactions are directly observed in solution. In this approach two monoclonal antibodies and their common antigen are incubated together to form immune complexes. The complexes formed in the reaction mixture are separated by a size exclusion column and then analyzed as they elute from the column using a SLS detector. The SLS detector provides a direct method to determine the mass of the eluted species and therefore, taking into account the mass of the individual components, its likely identity. Under conditions where the two antibodies have epitopes that are identical or spatially related, only complexes consisting of one antibody and two antigens would be observed. Alternatively, if the two antibodies in the mixture recognize different epitopes, larger immune complexes could form. As proof of concept, we used Interleukin-12 (IL-12) and four anti-IL-12 monoclonal antibodies as a model system. Our results suggested that two of these antibodies recognized related epitopes on IL-12 while the remaining combinations recognized different epitopes. SEC-SLS analysis of IL-12 incubated with the two antibodies that recognize similar epitopes gave rise to a single eluted species with a molecular weight equivalent to a single antibody bound to two antigens, as would be predicted. Alternatively, the SEC-SLS analysis of IL-12 incubated with any other combination of two antibodies gave rise to multiple larger immune complexes. These preliminary findings demonstrate that SEC-SLS as a promising tool for epitope mapping. Aberrant expression and signaling of multiple proteins in the NF-kappa B pathway are commonly associated with inflammatory and stress induced diseases, including many cancers. Understanding how NF-kappa B signaling impacts disease progression is important to the development of novel therapeutics. Cell signaling events are routinely assessed using traditional Western blot analysis. Although a widely accepted methodology, the Western has it challenges. The technique is very labor intensive and generally yields results that are semi-quantitative. In addition, the generally required 5-10 μg of total protein per lane on a Western yield only one data point of information each, thus requiring large amounts of material when performing comprehensive pathway characterization experiments. Sally, the new instrument platform that runs Simple Western assays completely automates the manual steps involved in traditional Western blot protocols and can analyze up to 96 samples in a single experiment. Because Simple Western protocols consume only microliter sample volumes, reproducible (CV<20%) and quantitative results can be generated from precious or quantitylimited samples. In addition, Sally can generate in one run, eight different data points from the same 5μL lysate sample hence yielding eight times more information than a traditional Western using the same amount of sample. Moreover, this number of data points can be doubled by reusing the same sample in two consecutive runs on 2 days thereby maximizing the data collection from precious samples. Data shown will illustrate the capability of the Simple Western to map a time course for TNF alpha activation in Jurkat cells. Targets from the NF-kappa B pathway, including I kappa B,NFkappa B subunits c-Rel, p65, and p50/p105 from both Jurkat whole cell and nuclear lysates were screened on the Simple Western platform with normalization to a loading control (alpha-tubulin). In response to TNFalpha treatment, statistically significant changes in signal and localization were clearly observed for each of the key targets. Results and workflow comparisons indicate a distinct advantage of the Simple Western when compared to traditional Western methods.
body_text.section: LB6

body_text.text: Investigating the functional long-range order of human Pin1 Jill Bouchard 1 , David Case 3, 4 Modular (multi-domain) proteins figure prominently in the interaction networks regulating the cell cycle. The human peptidyl-prolyl isomerase Pin1 is a modular protein well-recognized for mitotic regulation, and is of therapeutic interest for both cancer and Alzheimer's disease. We have investigated the inter-domain motions of Pin1 by measuring backbone (15N-1H) residual dipolar couplings (RDCs) by Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. To revel the atomic basis for these RDCs, we have developed a methodology in the molecular dynamics suite, Amber, to perform rigid-body motion of the two domains of Pin1, enabling us to determine their relative orientations consistent with NMR RDC data. This work provides insights into how the inter-domain mobility of Pin1 assists the biochemical signaling regulating proper cell division.
body_text.section: LB8

body_text.text: Structural and biochemical study of Orf57 a KSHV protein Fariborz Nasertorabi 1 , Rajakannan Venkatachalam 1 , Kit Yeung 1 , Sue-Li Dahlroth 1 , Josefine Karlsson 1 , Pär Nordlund 1, 2 1 School of Biological sciences, Nanyang technological University, Singapore, Singapore, 2 Department of Medical Biophysics and Biochemistry, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden Many Herpes viruses are living inside our bodies in a latent phase, waiting for a opportunity to become active. Kaposi's sarcoma associated herpesvirus (KSHV) belong to gamma-herpes virus family and its lytic replication plays a prominent role in Pathogenesis, tumorogenesis and also supporting the viruses in their survival at the latent phase. In many patients with compromised immunodeficiency like HIV patients or solid organtransplant recipients the risk of developing Kaposi sarcoma is high, mainly due to pre-existing infections. To understand how the lytic replication is regulated, is of great importance and may lead to effective therapeutic solutions that can bring the KSHV's associated diseases under control. Moving from a latent phase, where the virus produces only few proteins, to a lytic phase when it is fully activated starts with expression of few important proteins. The virus replicates in the host cell nucleus and has to circumvent the highly regulated system for mRNA processing in the host cell, in order to export its own intronless mRNA. To do this the virus is encoding a multi functional early protein, Orf57 that plays several roles in RNA processing and transport. Orf57 is shown to interact both with human proteins as well as viral proteins involved in RNA processing and export. Our current focus is on the structural and biochemical studies of Orf 57 and potential interactions with other viral proteins. Up to date, we have successfully purified Orf57, and obtained crystals that have diffracted up to 2.8Å. We are currently in the final stage of solving the phases for this protein. Recombinant proteins generated for therapeutic use potentially contain traces of proteins from the host cell line used for their production. These impurities need to be minimized to prevent adverse immune reactions. The presence of host-cell proteins (HCP) is usually assayed by ELISA using a polyclonal antibody mixture directed against a wide range of host cell proteins, and the specificity of this assay should be characterized prior to adoption. A recommended method for this characterization involves twodimensional electrophoretic separation followed by Western blotting (1) . Although this method allows a straightforward determination of the range of reactivity of the antibody mixture, adoption of this methodology has been hindered by the perceived lack of sensitivity, lack of reproducibility and overall laborious nature of the 2-D electrophoresis and blotting workflow. Tools that simplify, standardize and accelerate 2-D electrophoresis and blotting have become available. Advanced electrophoresis and blotting instrumentation, stable and reproducible pre-cast gels, next-generation imaging and image analysis software all allow this assay to be performed in a reproducible manner in a relatively short time. We have undertaken to demonstrate this using secreted proteins and cell lysate derived from Chinese Hamster Ovary (CHO) cells. Three commercial anti-CHO cell HCP antisera were compared with regard to their range of reactivity as determined by 2-D electrophoresis and Western blotting. The 2-D electrophoresis procedure resulted in highly reproducible spot patterns and the tested antisera were clearly distinguishable on the basis of their reactivity against distinct protein populations in both the secreted protein and lysate samples. References: 1. Wang, X. et al. Biotechnol Bioeng (2009) . 103:446-458.

cite_spans.text: Wang, X. et al. Biotechnol Bioeng (2009)

body_text.section: LB9

body_text.text: Synthetic Biology Approaches to Study Chromatin Structure and Dynamics Bryan Wilkins, Heinz Neumann Molecular Structural Biology/Applied Synthetic Biolgy Lab, University of Göttingen, Göttingen, Germany Correct segregation of chromosomes during cell division relies on their appropriate condensation in early stages of mitosis. This compaction of the genetic material is achieved by a complex and little understood process. Already at the level of the 30 nm fibre there is an ongoing debate about its precise structure and even about its in vivo relevance. Nucleosome-nucleosome interactions within and between fibres are mainly mediated by the protruding, flexible N-terminal domains of the core histones. Most prominently, the N-terminus of histone H4 is able to contact the negatively charged, 'acidic' patch on the surface of a neighbouring nucleosome. This interaction is critical to the formation of higher order structures in vitro and has been shown to be regulated by posttranslational acetylation of H4 K16. However, so far all evidence that this interaction mediates the condensation of chromatin in vivo is indirect. Here we present an approach that employs genetically encoded, UV-activatable crosslinker amino acids to trap histone-histone interactions in living yeast cells with site specificity. We identify a crosslink product that corresponds to the interaction of the histone H4 tail with the acidic patch proving the relevance of this interaction in vivo. By synchronizing yeast cells we demonstrate the predominance of this crosslink in mitosis, suggesting an important role in the condensation of chromatin. Support: Free-Floater Program Georg August University Göttingen, Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, Emmy Noether-Program (DFG)

body_text.text: An innovative and straightforward method for the generation of protein-based optical sensors for small molecules Estevão Peroza, Nicola Zamboni ETH Zurich, Wolfgang-Pauli-Str. 16, Zurich, 8093, Switzerland Biosensors based on Förster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET) are a powerful tool for reading out levels of small molecules or metal ions in living cells. By providing real-time information with sub-cellular resolution and being minimally invasive, FRET sensors represent an excellent method for investigating dynamics of, for example, metabolites, signaling molecules or nutrients [1] . Genetically-encoded FRET sensors are chimeric proteins expressed recombinantly by the host organism in which a ligand-binding protein is flanked by two fluorescent proteins (e.g. CFP and YFP). Despite the potential of FRET-based sensors as a method for studying biological systems, the development of new sensors remains laborious, often relies on the availability of three dimensional structure of the candidate ligand-binding protein, and is primarily driven by trial and error [2] . Thus, to date there are FRET sensors available for only a handful of molecules and metal ions. We are currently establishing a fast and efficient way for the development of new FRET sensors. Our new method generates thousands of versions of FRET sensor constructs, which are then screened in a high throughput fashion and the best sensor variants are selected. Additionally, the affinity and selectivity of the sensor for its ligand can be tuned if desired. We

body_text.text: Ornithine decarboxylase and antizyme interaction interface shows critical residues that are important for ornithine decarboxylase inhibition of activity and binding Udesh de Silva 1 , Manas Chattopadhyay 2 , Herbert Tabor 2 , David Davies 1 1 LMB/NIDDK, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, 2 LBG/NIDDK, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD Ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) is a key rate limiting enzyme in polyamine biosynthesis. These cationic polyamines are important for cellular proliferation, protein synthesis and gene regulation and are found in organisms ranging from bacteria to humans. In various organisms ODC activity is post-translationally regulated by its inhibitory protein antizyme (AZ), which is synthesized as a result of a ribosomal frameshifting due to increasing polyamine concentrations. Monomeric AZ inhibits dimeric ODC enzymatic activity by interacting with a single ODC protomer and it's degraded by an ubiquitin independent manner. While ODC is highly homologous in different species, AZ protein shows a wide diversity. The structure of mammalian ODC and a partial structure of rat antizyme are known. Although the structural information of ODC-AZ complex is unknown, a recent in silico experiment has shown residues that are involved in mammalian ODC-AZ binding. We have purified and characterized the ODC:AZ inhibitory complex from Saccharomyces cerevisiae. In the current experiments we present a detail study of the yeast ODC:AZ heterodimer. We used hydrogen deuterium exchange to identify the interface residues that are significant in forming the heterodimer. Three peptides in the AZ and four peptides in ODC were identified from H/D experiments that are present in the interface of ODC:AZ complex. We used systematic site-directed mutagenesis to verify the critical residues of AZ that are important for heterodimer interaction in both in vivo and in vitro assays. Using a pull down assay, an equimolar AZ protein was tested for its ability to bind ODC. We observed that different AZ mutants have varying affinities to ODC. In AZ inhibition assays, various AZ mutants showed a reduced inhibition of ODC as compared to the wild type AZ showing the importance of these residues. In contrast to wild type AZ, the mutant AZ showed reduced degradation of ODC in vivo. The in vivo samples were tested for ODC activity and found that AZ mutants had greatly diminished the ability to inhibit ODC activity. Polyamine content of the AZ mutants were analyzed; it showed increased polyamine content compared to the wild type, further supporting the reduced activity and degradation of ODC in AZ mutants. Our study demonstrates that yeast AZ contains evolutionary conserved interface residues that are important for heterodimerization and are essential for its binding and inhibitory activity both in vitro and in vivo. The 190kDa multi-domain scaffold protein IQGAP1 has been reported to be involved in cell signaling, cytoskeleton reorganization, cell-cell adhesion, cytokinesis and exocytosis via its dynamic interactions with various binding partners including F-actin, Calmodulin, Cdc42, Rac1 and beta-catenin. IQGAP1 contains a single copy of a Type-3 Calponin homology domain at its amino terminus (residues 46-160). Recent studies have shown that N-terminal fragments of IQGAP1 (residues 2-210, 1-216 and 1-232) are able to bind to F-actin, and one of these fragments can also bind to Calmodulin (CaM) in the present of calcium. Here we have determined the crystal structure of human IQGAP1 residues 1-191 (henceforth referred to as the CHD). The overall structure of the CHD is very similar to other Type-3 Calponin homology domains such as those found in Calponin, Vav-3 and the yeast IQGAP1 ortholog Rng2. In the crystal, two CHD molecules form a head-to-head homodimer predominantly through hydrophobic interactions across an interface displaying a high degree of surface-shape complementarity. In solution, the CHD can also form a dimer at high protein concentration. Isothermal titration calorimetry and F-actin co-sedimentation assays show that the CHD can bind to Ca2+-CaM and F-actin, respectively. The Calmodulin Target Database identifies a potential CaM binding site within residues 91-103 of the CHD. Site-directed mutagenesis in combination with isothermal titration calorimetry provide further evidence that 93LKKI94 is critical for Ca2+-CaM binding. Sequence alignment with other Calponin homology domains predicts an F-actin binding site on the dimer interface. We introduced a disulfide bond to stabilize the dimer and mask potential F-actinbinding residues at the dimer interface. Two mutants, K161C and A154C are able to form dimers even in the presence of 10mM beta-mercaptoethanol, and these two mutants show reduced F-actin binding consistent with the importance of interface residues in F-actin binding. Interestingly, another interface mutant, L157D, disrupts dimer formation but still binds to F-actin similar to wild type CHD. Our results suggest that residue cluster 93LKKI94 contributes to Ca2+-CaM binding, and that F-actin binding utilizes residues located at the dimer interface. In addition, our results also indicate that the self-association of full-length IQGAP1 may be a parallel homodimer.

body_text.text: Proteomic analyses of adrenal and pituitary gland of rat exposed fenitrothion Narumi Hirosawa 1 , Takeshi Sakamoto 2 , Yasushi Uemura 3 , Yasushi Sakamoto 1 1 Biomedical Research Center, Saitama Medical University, 38 Morohongo, Moroyama-Machi, Saitama, 350-0495, Japan, 2 Faculty of Pharmaceutical Scieneces, Josai University, Saitama, Japan, 3 Div.of Immunol, Aichi Cancer Ctr. Res. Inst, Aichi, Japan A possibility in which an exposure of organo phosphoric pesticide fenitrothion to children affects their nervous and endocrine systems was indicated [1] . Especially, a sensitivity of children to organic phosphorous compounds seems to be higher than adults, and it is feared that the compounds irreversibly influence for reproduction and endocrine system of children. Therefore, we studied the following in order to biochemically examine the effect of the fenitrothion to the endocrine system. The fenitrothion was administered to male rat of the 3 weeks-old at ratios of 0.1, 1, 10 and 30 mg/kg/day. Each concentration in the serum Testosterone, FSH, Progesterone and ACTH was measured, after the administrations were continued for 2 months. Sera testosterone in the fenitrothion treated groups of 1, 10 and 30 mg/kg/day were significantly higher than a control group without administration of fenitrothion. Sera FSH in the treated groups of 1 and 10 mg/kg/day were significantly higher. Sera progesterone in the treated groups of 1 and 10 mg/kg/ day were significantly lower. Sera ACTH of 1, 10 and 30 mg/kg/day treated groups were significantly higher. It seemed to be very effective to carry out the proteomic analyses for adrenal and pituitary gland for examining effects of the fenitrothion to the endocrine system. As the result of analyses, Nucleoside diphosphate kinase A, Ubiquitin conjugating enzyme E2 N, Peroxiredoxin-6 and Cytochrome B were detected as interest proteins in the pituitary gland. The present time, a relationship between expression level changes of these proteins and hormone concentration fluctuations of the pituitary gland is being examined. HSP-90(decreased) and apolipoprotein A-1, prohibitin, proteasome activator complex subunit-1, 6-phosphogluconolactase were detected as interest proteins in the adrenal gland. The change of the expression level of these proteins seemed to reflect load of a stress of the fenitrothion to the adrenal and the progesterone secretion reduction from the adrenal cortex. 1. body_text.text: Regulation of EGF Receptor Activation as Revealed by Thermodynamics Nick Bessman, Mark Lemmon Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics, Perelman School of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA Structural characterization of the EGFR/ErbB/Her family of receptor tyrosine kinases has provided important mechanistic insight, but critical gaps in our understanding remain apparent. Structures of the human extracellular receptor domains (ECD) suggest a minimal model in which ligand-induced receptor dimerization activates the kinase domains and thus initiates downstream signaling. Useful in many respects, this minimal model nevertheless fails to explain patterns of ligand-receptor binding specificity, ligand-dependent diversity in signaling outputs from identical receptor complexes, and the extent of coupling between the symmetric dimer seen in active ECDs and the asymmetric dimer seen in the intracellular portion of the activated receptor. Furthermore, bona fide auto-inhibitory interactions in the ECD have yet to be identified. Calorimetric data presented here demonstrates that ligand binding to EGFR is strongly entropically-driven, as is receptor dimerization. This simple observation rationalizes our difficulty thus far in explaining receptor phenomena based on available crystal structures, which speak primarily to enthalpic terms. By analyzing the thermodynamics of ligandbinding and dimerization for a series of receptor mutants and ligands, we elucidate a model of receptor activation that reveals important auto-inhibitory motifs and a basis for ligand specificity.
body_text.section: LB19

body_text.text: determined the X-ray crystal structure of the human Pellino2 substrate recognition domain and found that it contains a non-canonical example of a wellcharacterized phosphothreonine (pT)-binding domain, the forkhead-associated (FHA) domain. In an attempt to determine the specific substrate-binding motif of Pellino2, we identified an IRAK1 truncation variant (aa that interacts with Pellino2 in a phosphorylation dependent manner. Substitution of each threonine in IRAK1-197 with alanine identified T141 as the critical phosphorylated threonine on IRAK1-197 that Pellino2 specifically recognizes. A synthetic phosphopeptide corresponding to the sequence centered on T141 of IRAK1 (pT141 peptide) binds to Pellino2 with a Kd value in the 1μM range; this data was assessed in a fluorescence polarization binding assay, and independently verified using isothermal titration calorimetry. Binding analyses of other mammalian Pellino isoforms (Pellino 1, 3A, and 3B) to the pT141 peptide reveals differences in binding affinities and specificities. These differences are hard to reconcile due to the high degree of sequence identity among the Pellino isoforms, and cannot be readily explained by the Pellino2 FHA domain crystal structure. Thus, to further explore the molecular basis of these differences, we are working towards determining the X-ray crystal structures of the other Pellino isoforms. This work is supported by the American Heart Association and the NIH. Tail-anchored (TA) proteins are ubiquitous in eukaryotes and fulfill various important functions in the cell, such as the mediation of cell-cell contact and apoptosis signaling. Because they are anchored to the membrane by a short transmembrane domain (TMD) at the C-terminus, they cannot utilize the cotranslational signal recognition particle (SRP) pathway. Recent biochemical and structural studies have helped us identify and elucidate the details of the TA protein targeting pathway in yeast, also known as the Guided Entry of TA protein (GET) pathway. A homologous pathway, the TMD Recognition Complex (TRC) pathway, has been identified but details of this pathway remain elusive. In this study, we have structurally and biochemically characterized Bag6 and Ubl4Apreviously shown to be crucial in the recognition and delivery TA proteins from the ribosome to TRC40.
body_text.section: LB19

body_text.text: Extracting mechanistic information about the Hsp90 molecular chaperone with a model unfolded protein substrate Timothy Street, Laura Lavery, David Agard Biochemistry, UCSF, 600 16th St, San Francisco, CA, 94158 The Hsp90 molecular chaperone is critically required for the maintenance and regulation of highly diverse substrate proteins ("clients"). Despite its fundamental biological importance, the underlying mechanism is poorly understood. The challenge is that Hsp90 preferentially interacts with partially folded, non-native states of its client proteins. In response to this limitation, I developed a method exploiting a model unfolded protein, Δ131Δ, a truncation variant of staphylococcal nuclease studied extensively because it is amenable to NMR. Δ131Δ binds to Hsp90, alters the chaperone conformation, and activates its ATPase function. Hsp90 binds a highly structured region within the non-native Δ131Δ, revealing that Hsp90 behaves very differently from chaperones such as Hsp70 that recognize fully unfolded protein regions. SAXS and modeling revealed that Δ131Δ alters the conformational landscape of Hsp90, coordinating structural changes between the two different subunits within the Hsp90 dimer. By FRET I have found that Δ131Δ catalyzes a dramatic structural transition that is rate-limiting for ATP hydrolysis by the chaperone, with significant ramifications for how ATP hydrolysis energy is coupled to client maturation. These findings suggest that model unfolded proteins may be able to elucidate mechanisms of other poorly understood chaperone systems.

body_text.text: Chemistry, Vanderbilt, Nashville, TN Partial covalent interactions (PCI) such as hydrogen bonds, salt bridges, cation-π, and π-π interactions contribute to protein thermostability. Algorithms that identify PCIs rely on pairwise atom-atom angles and distances, neglecting that PCIs occur between an electron deficient hydrogen and an electron orbital of the accepting atom. Accurate chemical representation of PCIs will improve protein thermostabilization via computational protein design. We have introduced orbital based chemical descriptors for PCIs into the Rosetta Suite of Protein Structure Prediction Algorithms. Native-like geometries of hydrogen bonds, salt bridges, cation-pi, and pi-pi interactions are recapitulated during minimization of protein conformation. Additionally, the accurate chemical definition of PCI increases sequence recovery by 7% in RosettaDesign benchmarks.
body_text.section: Partial Covalent Interactions in Protein Design Steven Combs, Jens Meiler

body_text.text: Changes in tertiary and secondary structure driven by temperature and related to monomer-dimer transition in solution: The case of monomeric TIM of Trypanosoma brucei brucei Azucena Jimenez-Corona, Juanita Damián-Almazo, Gloria Saab-Rincon, Enrique Rudiño-Piñera Cellular Engineering Department and Biocatalysis, Biotechnology Institute. National Autonomous University of Mexico, Av. Universidad 2001, Col. Chamilpa., Cuernavaca, 62210, Mexico
body_text.section: LB26

body_text.text: The monomerization of natural dimeric enzymes, particularly Triosephosphate isomerase (TIM) from T. brucei, has been part of different experiments of protein engineering. MonoTIM, an engineered monomeric version of TIM is 1000 times less active than the natural dimeric enzyme from Trypanosoma brucei [Borchert, et al., (1994) Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 15(4): . This enzyme has been further engineered by random mutagenesis to increase its catalytic activity, giving place to a new variant (RMM0-1) with increased activity [Saab-Rincón, et al., (2001) Protein Eng 14 (3):149-55]. The resulting variant carries the mutations: Ser43Pro, Thr44Ala and Ala179Thr. An X-ray crystallographic study of this protein, showed a temperature-dependent equilibrium between two inter-convertible crystalline forms. Analysis of crystalline contacts in both refined models suggests the existence of a dimeric enzyme when the crystals grow at 30 °C (space group P212121), while a more-active monomeric form of the enzyme is found at 18 °C (space group C121). Surprisingly, this protein retained a tendency to dimerize, but did so in a manner quite different from that found naturally. Also, dimerization did not contribute to an increase of the activity, suggesting that it is the monomer the active species. Likewise, we carried out equilibrium folding studies, following the formation of secondary structure using circular dichroism and of tertiary structure by fluorescence. These studies were performed at three different temperatures (18, 25 and 30 degrees), to determine the folding mechanism of MonoTIM and to corroborate if at the higher temperature there is a concentration-dependant transition that can be attributed to the formation of a dimeric species in solution. We found that the folding mechanism MonoTIM in solution is totally dependent on temperature, following a twostate folding mechanism at 18°C, whereas at 25 and 30°C the presence of an intermediate state is evident following a three-states folding mechanism.

body_text.text: Takayuki Tsuduki 1 , Ayana Tomita 2 , Shin-ya Koshihara 3 , Shin-ichi Adachi 2 , Takahisa Yamato 1 1 Physics, Graduate School of Science, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan, 2 Institute of Materials Structure Science High Energy Accelerator Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan, 3 Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
body_text.section: LIGAND-PROTEIN INTERACTION STUDIED BY COMPUTER SIMULATION AND TIME-RESOLVED X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY

body_text.text: Recently, high-resolution x-ray crystallography demonstrated breathing motion of internal cavities in concert with ligand migration in myoglobin (Mb) [1] . Continuous pulsed illumination of carbomonoxy-Mb crystals at low temperatures has illustrated structural changes around each cavity in response to ligand migration. In the present study, we examined the effect of the breathing motion on the potential of mean force (PMF) for ligand-protein interactions by using molecular dynamics simulation and experimental data [1] . Conformational sampling of Mb was performed by NPT molecular dynamics simulation for 92 ns. We introduced three-dimensional lattice of regularly spaced grid points, and evaluated PMF at each point by the implicit ligand sampling method [2] . The effect of the breathing motion on the ligand-protein interaction was quantitatively represented by the change of PMFs before and after flash photolysis. Our calculations demonstrated molecular mechanisms of ligand-migration, which include ligand escape via Xe1 to protein exterior and gate opening between Xe2-and Xe3 pockets [3] (http:// www.tb.phys.nagoya-u.ac.jp/~yamato/PMF3D.pdf http://www.tb.phys.nagoya-u.ac.jp/~yamato/PMF3D. zip). References Formulation of protein drugs involves optimisation of buffer conditions to maximise the stability of the protein molecule. In this study the thermal stability of an IgG protein was determined using dynamic multimode spectroscopy (DMS) under a number of different pH conditions from pH2.2 to pH7.8. Automation of DMS using the Chirascan™-plus automated CD spectrometer (ACD) allowed a large number of buffer conditions to be studied quickly and easily. Data were acquired in an overnight, unattended measurement, and the following important results for the IgG in question were derived: Greatest thermal stability occurs at pH>5 Greatest resistance to aggregation is seen at pH<5 Pre-transition conformation changes with pH Aggregation, when it occurs, is easily detected Quantitative results with errors are readily calculated Protein usage per denaturation is low at ~60ug LB29 Using site-directed mutagenesis to elucidate the biological role of the c-type heme Melody Frink 1 Heme is a prosthetic group consisting of a porphyrin ring with a redox active iron atom coordinated at its center. Heme proteins are ubiquitous in biology, examples of which include the cytochrome superfamily of proteins. Cytochromes a and b have heme groups held in place by hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions. Cytochromes c also have heme groups, but their hemes are covalently attached to the rest of the protein by two thioether bonds donated by two cysteine residues. The covalent attachment of the c-heme is energetically expensive and the biological significance of the attachment is unclear. We propose that the covalent linkages of the c-heme prevent heme scavengers such as the pathogenic bacteria nontypable Haemophilus influenzae (NTHi) from stealing heme from those proteins. To test our hypothesis, we prepared several mutants of wild-type cytochrome c (WT) in which the heme protein contained only a single covalent linkage (SM) or no covalent linkages (DM) to the heme. We cultured NTHi in the presence of WT, SM, and DM cytochrome c (along with several positive and negative controls). The results of our study demonstrate that the covalent attachments to the c-heme do prevent NTHi from stealing heme from WT cytochrome c, while both SM and DM readily donate their heme to NTHi. The first author of this study received a fellowship from RIT's Undergraduate Research and Mentoring for Deaf Students in Biological Sciences program which is sponsored by the NSF (grant 0829259); this study was sponsored by the Rochester Institute of Technology. Matrix protein 2 (M2) from influenza A is the target for antiviral agents Amantadine and Rimantadine that obstruct the viral RNA entry into host cytosol by inhibiting the protein's proton transport function. Resistance against these drugs has recently become prevalent through, most predominantly, the S31N mutation in transmembrane domain. Here, we report the 2.1-angstrom resolution crystal structure for fragment 22-46 of the drug-resistant mutant M2 in lipidic cubic phase. Electron density from the current refinement provides a mechanistic view for proton conduction, drug resistance by S31N mutation and structural basis for drug design.

body_text.text: Mapping HIV-1 Env gp120 Residues Important for Peptide Triazole Dual Receptor Site Antagonism Using Multi-site Mutagenesis Rachna Arora 1 , Ferit Tuzer 1 , Andrew Holmes 1 , Arne Schon 2 , Kantharaju 1 , Ernesto Freire 2 , Irwin Chaiken 1 1 Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Drexel University College of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, 2 Biology, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD HIV-1 is responsible for the globally pandemic acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), and there is a continuing need to develop preventive and therapeutic interventions that can either block virus-host cell receptor interactions or inactivate the virus before cell encounter. The virus enters the host cell through interaction of its envelope (Env) spike component gp120/gp41 with both CD4 receptor and a chemokine co-receptor, most commonly CCR5 or CXCR4, on the host cells. Peptide triazoles (PT's) are a novel class of inhibitors that specifically target gp120 and inhibit its interactions at both host cell receptor-binding sites. PT's have been found to neutralize virus infection of cells by a broad range of virus subtypes in both single round and fully infectious virus assays. Some variants of peptide triazoles have been found to cause specific HIV-1 lysis. We have investigated the functional site for peptide triazole antagonism on Env gp120. Site specific alanine mutagenesis identified a cluster of sensitive gp120 residues for which mutations significantly suppress PT binding and receptor site inhibition. Within this epitope, D474 and T257 appear to be the most critical, while nearby residues, in particular M475 and E370, are also important for antagonist function. This cluster of residues is in a conserved region of gp120 that overlaps the CD4 binding site and is distant from the coreceptor/17b binding site, suggesting an allosteric mode of inhibition for the latter. The arrangement and sequence conservation of the residues in the functional epitope explain the breadth of antiviral activity. To examine the specific roles of epitope residues in HIV gp120 for peptide triazole binding, we have embarked on multisite mutagenesis. Double mutants, including D474A/ T257S and M475A/E370A, have been produced, and the interdependence of their sensitivities with intact and truncated peptide triazoles is under investigation. This line of work will test the extent to which the high binding free energy of peptide triazoles results from accumulation of multiple productive interactions distributed over the interaction interface between gp120 and peptide antagonist. This work is supported by the NIH grant P01 GM 56550
body_text.section: LB31

body_text.text: Structures of Glutamate Decarboxylase from Sphaerobacter thermophilus in Complex with PLP and GABA at Atomic Resolution Ruiying Wu 1 , Shonda Clancy 1 , Andrzej Joachimiak 1, 2 1 Midwest Center for Structural Genomics, Biosciences, Argonne National Lab, Argonne, IL, 2 Structural Biology Center, Biosciences, Argonne National Lab, Argonne, IL Glutamate decarboxylase (GAD; EC 4.1.1.15) is a pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP)-dependent enzyme, which catalyzes the irreversible α-decarboxylation of L-glutamate to γ-aminobutyrate (GABA). This enzyme is widely distributed amongst eukaryotes and prokaryotes, but its function varies in different organisms. GAD has a crucial role in the vertebrate central nervous system where it is responsible for the synthesis of GABA, a major inhibitory neurotransmitter. In bacteria, it has been shown that GAD is induced by an acidic environment and contributes to acid resistance and to competitiveness in acidic environments. Bacterial GAD belongs to L-DOPA decarboxylase family which also includes DOPA/tyrosine decarboxylase and histidine decarboxylase. In the current study, we have determined the first crystal structures of GAD from Sphaerobacter thermophilus (StGAD) in two crystal forms: clear and yellow, at 1.9Å and 1.7Å resolutions, respectively. The full length StGAD forms an obligate functional dimer. Each subunit is composed of three domains: N-terminal, PLP-binding and C-terminal. The StGAD structure in yellow form contains PLP at one PLP-binding domain and PLP as well as GABA at the other PLP-binding domain, while clear StGAD crystal contains a PLP-GABA intermediate in one active site and a pyridoxamine 5'-phosphate in another active site. Two loops near the PLP sites are disordered in both structures. Details of the kinetic studies and structurebased GABA synthesis mechanism in StGAD will be presented. This project was funded by a grant from the National Institute of Health GM094585 and by the U. S. Department of Energy, Office of Biological and Environmental Research, under contract DE-AC02-06CH11357. The amyloid fibrils formed by islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) are associated with type II diabetes. The study on the early interactions between the 37-residue monomers is of great importance to a better understanding of IAPP aggregation process. We performed replica exchange molecular dynamics simulations to sample the conformational space of IAPP monomers in the aqueous solution. The free energy surface of IAPP monomer was then constructed. We find that the most populated species in the ensemble are random coils, rather than the dynamic helical structures identified by experiments in literature. The exposed hydrophobic residues of each of the random coil clusters are found to be consistent with the results of the limited proteolysis experiments. We then carried out protein-protein docking to predict the IAPP dimer interface using ClusPro followed by RossetaDock. The aromatic residue F23 is found to be critical to the monomer-monomer interactions. The importance of the hydrophobic interactions is also suggested by various small molecule inhibitors. The hydrophobic interface of the dimer resembles the shape of the antiparellel cross-section bilayer of the IAPP fibril structure resolved by the solid state NMR. Our work suggests an alternative pathway of the initial contacts of IAPP monomers, implying more complicated routes of IAPP aggregation than that was believed. FIGREF71.text: Multi-State Computational Design and ExperimentalCharacterization of Triosephosphate Isomerase Flexible Hinges Jackson Cahn, Bernardo Sosa Padilla Araujo, Stephen Mayo Division of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, California Institue of Technology, Pasadena, CA Traditional computational protein design calculations enable the evaluation and selection of protein sequences in the context of a single native structure. However many proteins natively require multiple distinct conformations for functionality. Recently, a novel algorithm has been developed which considers several structures in a single optimization calculation. This new method could be useful for designing proteins that need to accommodate several conformations. We sought to test this algorithm on triosephosphate isomerase (TIM). Loop 6 in TIM is a lid with open and closed conformations that facilitate substrate binding, product diffusion, and catalysis. It uses two 3-amino acid hinges that provide the flexibility for the open-closed transition. In the present work we use multi-state design (MSD) methods to design the flexible hinges in TIM. We are in the process of assessing the applicability of MSD for the design of flexible protein hinges by exhaustive screening of computationally designed libraries. The results will suggest whether, by considering both conformations of the enzyme instead of purely the open or closed conformations, our methods provide libraries enriched in catalytically active TIMs. This work supported by a DARPA Protein Design Processes grant and a National Security Science and Engineering Faculty Fellowship award to S.L.M. 201 In Silico Screening of Computational Enzyme Designs Bernardo Sosa Padilla Araujo 1 , Thomas Miller 2 , Stephen Mayo 3, 2 1 Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics Option, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, 2 Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, California Institute of Technology, 1200 E California Blvd MC 114-96, Pasadena, CA, 91125, 3 Biology, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA
