TABREF17.text: We are taking a synthetic biology approach in co-localizing pathway enzymes into a complex for improved efficiency. This approach has had varied success for different pathways and current focus is being applied in dissecting the key design principles relating flux improvements. Further, designs for additional control are being engineered.

TABREF18.text: The first two XTEN products, Exenatide-XTEN (Diartis Inc.) and hGH-XTEN (Versartis Inc.) have successfully completed clinical studies in patients. Several additional XTEN products are at in pre-clinical development. To our knowledge, onartuzumab is the first such one-armed antibody to be tested in humans.Early clinical data indicate that MetMAb has been well tolerated and shows promising efficacy in combination with erlotinib in NSCLC tumors with high expression of Met.

TABREF19.text: to the individual interactions and to determine the correlation between in vitro and in vivo function of these complex systems. Studies of the multiple interactions that contribute to the E. coli Biotin Regulatory System have served as the foundation for development of an equilibrium model for the system function. Simulations of the transcription output of the system indicate exquisite sensitivity to relatively small changes in component concentrations or equilibrium binding parameters. In vitro and in vivo test of the model reveal unanticipated system features and good agreement between system behavior in the test tube and the cell. Supported by NIH Grant R01 GM46511

TABREF20.text: Separately, we have developed fluorescent peptides that light up peripheral nerves to show surgeons where not to cut (Whitney et al (2011) Nature Biotech. 29: 352-356).Thus chemical biology and multimodal imaging can improve early detection and accurate resection, which together offer relatively promising avenues to deliver complete cures at relatively low cost.

TABREF22.text: In recent years, we and others have established that the association reaction proceeds through transient complexes, which may be specific or diffusive in nature. To bring binding studies closer to the in vivo environment, we investigated the role of crowding and the cellular environment on binding. For crowding we added various polymers to the solution, including Dextran and PEGs of different molecular weights, used cell extracts or performed real time measurements within living cells. While crowding enhances oligomerization and polymerization of macromolecules, it has only a small effect on the binding rates and affinities of transient protein-protein interactions. Interestingly, also in living cells the rates of association were close to those measured in the test tube in simple solutions. We suggest that the limited effect of crowders, which is much bellow the expected from the increased viscosity of the solutions, is a result of the occluded volume effect in high crowder concentrations. Direct measurements of the stability of the encounter complex shows that crowders have only a minor effect on K1 or k2, and do not change the shape or size of the encounter complex.

TABREF24.text: The interactions are mediated by modular binding events, in which tandem linear motifs in an intrinsically unstructured region of Ldb1 bind to closely spaced LIM domains of the LIM proteins, forming β-zipper motifs in which strands of anti-parallel β-sheets extend β-hairpins within in the LIM domains.

TABREF29.text: More than 80,000 structures of biological macromolecules have been curated in the first four decades of the Protein Data Bank's existence. In this time, marked changes and advances in technologies and methods used for structure determination have enabled both a decrease in the time needed to determine a structure and an increase in quality of the results. By analyzing the corpus of data, it is possible to identify trends in the field of structural biology that are the result of these breakthroughs. In addition to the increasing number of structures being determined, the complexity of the structures has markedly increased. Examination of structures with similar sequences yields information about evolution and protein function. It is becoming clear that by combining structure determination methods with a diverse set of biochemical, computational and biophysical methods, a structural view of biology in now within reach. These trends and what they might mean for the future of biology will be the subject of this talk.

TABREF74.text: To that end, we have solved a series of crystal structures of EutL from Clostridium perfringens (cpEutL). Our crystal structures further elucidate structural features that allow for the observed rearrangement, and suggest that the redox state of disulfide bonds in the EutL protein influences the equilibrium between the open and closed conformations. Additional biochemical experiments demonstrate the presence of disulfide bonds in cpEutL and confirm that the conformational change is promoted by altering the electrochemical environment of the protein. A bioinformatics analysis of BMC domain shell proteins reveals that the structural features we identified as being important for the function of EutL are wellconserved within homologous proteins from eut-type BMCs. Additional computational methods reveal that redox-regulation may be a general feature of the tandem BMC-domain shell proteins.

TABREF79.text: :5606-5617.Investigating the Intramolecular Interaction of the Biotin Carboxyl Carrier Domain with the CarboxylTransferase Domain in Pyruvate Carboxylase Melissa Budelier, Adam Lietzan, Martin St. Maurice Biological Sciences, Marquette University, PO Box 1881, Milwaukee, WI, 53233 Pyruvate Carboxylase (PC) is a tetrameric protein that catalyzes the formation of oxaloacetate (OAA) via a two-step mechanism. In the first catalytic step, biotin is carboxylated in the biotin carboxylase (BC) domain. According to the current paradigm, the biotin carboxyl carrier protein (BCCP) domain subsequently transfers the carboxybiotin from the BC domain to a neighboring carboxyl transferase (CT) domain on a physically separate polypeptide chain. The CT domain then catalyzes the transfer of the carboxyl group from carboxybiotin to pyruvate, forming OAA. When recombinant PC is expressed as a dimer, a neighboring CT domain is not present to accept the BCCP domain. Previous research by our group revealed that this recombinant PC exhibits surprisingly high biotin-dependent activity despite the inability of BCCP to access a neighboring CT domain. This suggests that PC may be capable of stabilizing an interaction between BCCP and CT domains on the same polypeptide chain. To further explore this possibility, we have assessed the catalytic activity of recombinant hybrid dimers with various combinations of inactive BCCP and CT domains. The results of these hybrid dimer experiments offer new insights into the domain interactions in PC and clarify the extent of interaction between the individual monomers of the CT domain.

TABREF99.text: Basic Medical Sciences, Western University of Health Sciences, 309 East 2nd Street, Pomona, CA, 91766-1854, 2 Section de Recherche, Institut Curie, Rosary, France RecQ family helicases function as safeguards of genome. Unlike Escherichia coli, the Gram-positive Bacillus subtilis bacterium possesses two RecQ-like homologues, RecQ[Bs] and RecS, which are required for the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. RecQ[Bs] also binds to the forked DNA to ensure a smooth progression of cell cycle. Here we present the first biochemical analysis of recombinant RecQ[Bs]. RecQ[Bs] binds weakly to single-stranded (ss)DNA and blunt-ended doublestranded (ds)DNA, but strongly to forked dsDNA. The protein exhibits a DNA-stimulated ATPase activity, and ATP-and Mg2+-dependent DNA helicase activity with a 3' to 5' polarity. Molecular modeling shows that RecQ[Bs] shares high sequence and structure similarity with E. coli RecQ. Surprisingly, RecQ[Bs] resembles the truncated Saccharomyces cerevisiae Sgs1 and human RecQ helicases more than RecQ[Ec] with regard to its enzymatic activities. Specifically, RecQ[Bs] unwinds forked dsDNA and DNA duplexes with 3'-overhang, but inactive on blunt-ended dsDNA and 5'-overhanged duplexes. Interestingly, RecQ[Bs] unwinds blunt-ended DNA with structural features, including nicked, gapped, 5'-flap, Kappa joint, synthetic replication fork, and Holliday junction. Furthermore, RecQ[Bs] catalyzes strand annealing and strand exchange. The ability of the RecQ[Bs] helicase to target these DNA intermediates and to catalyze strand exchange may be relevant to its role in maintaining genome stability. Koharudin 2 , David Ban 1 , Adam Mazur 1 , Christian Griesinger 1 , Angela Gronenborn 2 , Donghan Lee 1 NMR based Structural Biology, Max Planck Institute for Biophysical Chemistry, Am Fassberg 11, Göttingen, 37077, Germany, 2 Department of Structural Biology, School of Medicine, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA Molecular recognition is crucial for biological signalling. Currently, two limiting scenarios are invoked when describing molecular recognition: (i) induced fit, in which the binding of one partner leads to conformational changes in the other partner and (ii) conformational selection, where the binding partner selects one of several conformations in the other partner. NMR spectroscopy is a powerful technique for studying conformational ensembles in solution, and recently developed techniques allow for the structural and dynamic characterization of lowly populated states.

back_matter.text: The Protein Structure Initiative Structural Biology Knowledgebase (SBKB, http://sbkb.org) is the scientific web portal that integrates biological, experimental, and structural data about proteins. SBKB delivers comprehensive information, including 3D structures from the Protein Data Bank, annotations from 150+ open biological resources, target history and protocols from TargetTrack, theoretical models in Protein Model Portal, technology reports from the PSI Technology Portal, PSI articles from the PSI Publications Portal, and research and technical highlights from Nature Publishing Group. We will present several examples on how data found in the SBKB and its portals can enable structural and biological research. SBKB is supported by the National Institute of General Medical Science (U01 GM093324).

A cascade of interactions involving the three Min proteins in gram-negative bacteria produces dynamic subcellular structures that help direct the cytokinetic cell septum to the middle of symmetrically dividing cells. This pattern of Min protein oscillation is driven by the MinD ATPase that binds directly to the inner membrane when bound to ATP. Its interactions with MinE stimulate ATP hydrolysis, releasing the complex from the membrane (1) . However, recently determined solution NMR and x-ray crystallography structures have indicated that in order for MinE to bind to MinD, a dramatic conformational change in MinE must take place to expose the binding residues to MinD (2, 3) . According to this model, MinD-binding residues are buried in the dimeric interface, but can be exposed by interactions involving MinE and the membrane (4). The MinE structure that has been proposed to be involved in MinD binding nonetheless remains dimeric, with a new dimer interface being formed by other parts of MinE. However, the persistence of the dimeric state in the MinD-bound form raises new questions regarding the functional role of the MinE dimer. Using a series of MinE mutants and peptide models of the MinD-binding domain from MinE, we investigate the functional importance of the dimeric state of MinE. Since the interactions that give rise to the dynamic Min protein structures are not yet known, findings from this work provide new insight into the role of MinE in dynamic Min protein polymer formation. 1. Hsieh, CW, et al. (2010 Amyloidosis has been found to be responsible for a growing number of misfolding disorders. Although several amyloid diseases are fatal and most are very severe, to date no effective treatment to any of the amyloid related diseases is available. In order to characterize the structural aspects of protein aggregation, the three main species present during amyloid aggregation have to be studied: the starting native fold, the oligomers and the mature amyloid fibrils. Beta-2 microglobulin (b2m) is an amylodogenic protein responsible for Dialysis Related Amyloidosis a disorder resulting in severe movement impairment. Aiming to understand the structural determinants of b2m aggregation propensity, we have characterised the role of the DE loop in the monomeric b2m. Mutations in such loop revealed that modifying the geometry of the DE loop has global effects on b2m: such mutations affect b2m folding, fold stability, structure, amyloidogenic propensity and dynamics under native and denaturating conditions. Such effects have been studied by several techniques such as X-ray crystallography, circular dichroism, intrinsic fluorescence, mass spectrometry and infrared spectroscopy1-7. In order to shed light on the structural details of b2m aggregation, a strategy to form artificial oligomers amenable for crystallographic studies have been designed and it will be shown together with the structures of two artificial oligomers and their propensity to form amyloid fibrils8. Finally ssNMR experiments on double and triple labelled samples of crystalline and fibrillar b2m will be presented9. In particular spectra of crystalline and aggregated b2m reveal that the most In plant cells, soluble proteins reach vacuoles because they contain vacuolar sorting determinants (VSDs) that are recognized by vacuolar sorting receptor (VSR) proteins. All VSR proteins contain an N-terminal lumenal region which is responsible for specific receptor-cargo interactions. The protease-associated (PA) domain contained in this region is believed to be involved in sequence-specific recognition of the Asn-Pro-Ile-Arg (NPIR) motif of cargo-proteins such as aleurain. However, how VSR proteins recognize their cargo-proteins is still poorly understood. In this study, the PA domain of VSR isoform-1 from Arabidopsis thaliana (AtVSR1-PA) will be investigated at both structural and functional levels to address this fundamental question of plant cells. In our recent studies, the PA domain of AtVSR1 (AtVSR1-PA) has been expressed and purified from E. coli. Typical yield of proteins was ~ 2 mg per liter of bacterial culture, which provides sufficient quantity of protein samples for subsequent structural and ligandbinding studies. We show that the purified AtVSR1-PA is properly folded as it can bind the proaleurain peptide in vitro. Preliminary crystallization conditions were identified by screening commercially available kits, and optimized by grid-searching the pH and precipitant concentrations. AtVSR1-PA was crystallized in space group P21. Diffraction data to 1.7Å were collected using an in-house X-ray source. In order to overcome the crystallographic phase problem, experimental phasing and molecular-replacement have been applied. After solving the phase problem, preliminary structure determination of AtVSR1-PA revealed that conserved residues of AtVSR1-PA are clustered in one region of the protein. We hypothesize that these conserved residues form a ligand-binding surface for recognition. The rules derived from our studies will be useful in predicting potential cargo-proteins within the genomes of Arabidopsis or other model organisms in the future. This work is supported by a Strategic Investment Grant from the Research Committee of the Chinese University of Hong Kong.

back_matter.text: Evolution of protein sequence hydrophobicity Ian Borukhovich, Matthew Cordes University of Arizona, 1510 E9th street #101, Tucson, AZ, 85719Studies of natural and model proteins suggest that sequences of foldable proteins are constrained in the local and global distribution of polar and hydrophobic residues, possibly to enhance conformational specificity of the native state. To explore how such a constraint might manifest itself in the evolution of individual protein families, we performed two analyses. First, for 12 common protein families, we compared the standard deviation of local sequence hydropathy in all individual sequences in each family to the same quantity in sets of simulated sequences generated by vertical shuffling of a multiple alignment. In most families, median hydropathy deviations in unshuffled sequences are lower than those of shuffled sequences according to a Wilcoxon rank sum test (P < .05). Second, mutual information analysis of each family showed significant anticorrelation between polar and hydrophobic residues at a relatively small subset of covarying positions. Sequence evolution may favor balanced distributions of hydrophobic and polar residues along a chain, and certain sequence positions may contribute disproportionately to this trend.The application and development of network principles to protein modeling have led to significant advancement in understanding the underlying determinants of protein folds. In this work, we will use a modified version of the network principle 'degrees of separation' we term 'levels of separation' (LOS) to provide insight into the evolution of protein folds. In specific, we propose that long-range tertiary interactions between the transition and native state form in LOS. Rationalizing the formation of longrange interactions in this way provides a means for understanding the mechanism by which the formation of the native tertiary structure can be obtained from the transition-state. We present a theoretical model that visualizes how a protein may fold through a sequence of modifications of the transition state to the native state facilitated by LOS. Our approach is interdisciplinary and unites the fields of network theory, mathematics and biochemistry. A number of proteins are being studied. The model protein system used in our current study is chymotrypsin inhibitor 2; a small mixed α/β-LB20 Structural insights into TDP-43 domain assembly and fibril formation Hanna Yuan 1 , Yi-Ting Wang 1 , Pan-Hsien Kuo 1 , Chien-Hao Chiang 1 , Woei Chyn Chu 2 1 Institute of Molecular Biology, Academia Sinica, 128 Academia Road, Section 2, Taipei, 11529, Taiwan, 2 Institutes of Biomedical Engineering, National Yang-Ming University, Taipei, Taiwan TAR DNA-binding protein 43 (TDP-43) is a DNA/ RNA-binding protein, ubiquitously expressed in various tissues and highly conserved in mammals and invertebrates. TDP-43 has multiple cellular functions, including serving as a transcriptional repressor and functioning as a splicing factor. The domain structure of TDP-43 is similar to the heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoproteins (hnRNP), consisting of two tandem RNA recognition domains, RRM1 and RRM2, followed by a C-terminal glycine-rich region. TDP-43 has been the focus of extensive studies since it had been identified as the major pathological protein in the neuronal inclusions in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD). TDP-43 inclusions are N-terminally truncated 25-kDa fragments, which contain partial RRM2 domain and glycine rich region. The pathogenic mechanism of how the normal functional TDP-43 is truncated and induced to abnormal filamentous inclusions remains unknown. To investigate the domain organization of TDP-43, we analyzed the domain assembly of various TDP-43 constructs by small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), dynamic light scattering (DLS) and gel filtration chromatography. Together with GST pull-down assays, we showed that TDP-43 dimerized in a head-to-head arrangement, with the two RRM2 domains flanking outward. This model suggests how TDP-43 is assemble into a functional protein and provides a structural basis for the future study of TDP-43 proteinopathy.

Proteolytic mechanisms of GATA-6 facilitated by activation of JNK signaling pathway Hironori Ushijima, Kimika Endo, Yuki Nakanome, Masatomo Maeda Molecular Biology, School of Pharmacy, Iwate Medical University, Shiwa-gun, Iwate, JapanThe transcription factor GATA-6 is essential for developmental and differentiation processes in mesoderm-and endoderm-derived organs such as heart and gastrointestinal tract, and regulates the expression of various genes required for tissue specific functions in mammals. Recently, it is reported that GATA-6 is abnormally overexpressed in many clinical tissue samples of gastrointestinal cancers. GATA-6 being expressed in colorectal cancer cells accelerates cell proliferation and degrades upon apoptotic response. However, the molecular mechanisms are not well known how degradation of GATA-6 is regulated. We have previously reported that GATA-6 stably expressed in CHO-K1 cells is degradated by proteasomes in cytoplasm through cAMP dependent protein kinase A (PKA) signaling. However the substitution in the potential PKA site of GATA-6 Ser-290→Ala had no effect on degradation, suggesting that intracellular factors phosphorylated by PKA may be involved in GATA-6 degradation, and other protein kinases, except for PKA, may affect the degradation pathway. In this study, we compared 95 kinase inhibitors since we are expecting that there are multiple cross-talks between PKA and different kinases not being examined by us. Actually we identified 5 kinase inhibitors that prohibit protein kinases other than PKA. Interestingly, we found that SP600125, a JNK inhibitor, strongly inhibited cAMP-dependent proteolysis of GATA-6 and that anisomycin which can activate JNK via endoplasmic reticulum stress response stimulated proteolysis of GATA-6 as well as dbcAMP treatment. Furthermore, we found that anisomycin promoted the export of GATA-6 from nucleus to cytoplasm via CRM1-mediated nuclear export pathway. It seems likely that the JNK activated by anisomycin may stimulate not only the nuclear export of GATA-6 through CRM1 but also the degradation of GATA-6 by cytoplasmic proteasomes. In contrast, A-kinase might activate only the latter process through JNK. Our finding that nuclear GATA-6 is exported to cytoplasm through activation of JNK signaling would be beneficial as a therapeutic approach to regulate the localization of GATA-6 in colorectal cancer cells. The Pellino proteins are one of the several families of E3 ubiquitin ligases that direct ubiquitination events immediately following Toll and interleukin-1 receptor (TIR) activation. Polyubiquitination of known Pellino substrates, such as the interleukin-1 associated kinase (IRAK1), is a necessary step in mediating downstream signaling events that are responsible for eliciting a proper immune response. To elucidate Pellino's role in TIR signaling, we are investigating the molecular basis of Pellino substrate specificity. We previously Abstracts 234 Vibrio cholerae is the causative pathogen for cholera. Fatty acid synthesis enzymes (FAS) from V. cholerae are good targets for developing antibiotics against cholera. Here we report the structural and enzymatic studies of β-ketoacyl-(acyl carrier protein) reductase in the FAS pathway of V. cholerae (vcFabG). FabG catalyzes the essential reductive reaction in the elongation cycle of fatty acid synthesis using NADPH as cofactor. It was observed that some FabGs require binding of NADP(H) to induce the conformation changes from the closed/inactive form to open/active form, which is characterized by the formation of a catalytic triad composed of a set of conserved residues (S142, Y155, K159 in vcFabG). But it was not clear which elements enable the conformational changes of FabG upon cofactor binding. In our study, we obtained several crystal structures of vcFabG which are either in active or inactive forms. Comparison of the vcFabG structures in active and inactive conformations revealed that the binding of NADP(H) induces conformation changes which comprise the rearrangement of loop β4-α4, loop β5-α5, helix α6 and C-terminus. Structure of ternary complexes of vcFabG (soaked with NADPH and Acetoacetyl CoA (AcAcCoA)) showed that this NADP(H) induced rearrangement not only results in the formation of the catalytic triad, but also leads to the proper assemblage of substrate binding residues. This observation is consistent with results from isothermal titration calorimetric (ITC) assays that vcFabG could only bind substrate AcAcCoA in the presence of NADPH. Detailed inspection about the vcFabG structures, together with those of homolog proteins identified two glycine residues which might serve as switch points for changes between inactive/active states of FabG. Kinetic assays revealed that mutations of these glycine residues eliminate the enzymatic activity. ITC assays revealed that the mutations abolish the capability of vcFabG to bind NADPH and AcAcCoA, even though the mutant might also adopt an "open/active" conformation. Conclusion: Two glycine residues serve as switches between inactive/active states of vcFabG upon binding of NADP(H). Heme Oxygenase (HO) is the only known mammalian enzyme that catalyzes degradation of heme. While heme is a required prosthetic group in several electron transfer and redox enzymes and thus inevitable for various physiological processes; free heme can be commensurably toxic. Free heme can undergo fentonlike reactions, producing reactive oxygen species, which in turn induces oxidative stress and cell death. By degrading free heme, HO confers tissue protection. Two forms of HO have been identified in mammals: HO-1 and HO-2. Both HO-1 and HO-2 exhibit similar catalytic properties, however they are expressed in distinct locations in the body and differ in their modes of regulation. While HO-1 is present in most tissues, HO-2 has a narrow tissue distribution and is expressed mainly in brain, testes and carotid body. Additionally, HO-1 is induced under conditions of ischemia, hypoxia and hyperoxia while HO-2 is constitutively expressed. To date, HO-1 has been extensively studied structurally and biochemically and its mechanism of regulation is well characterized. HO-2, on the other hand needs further investigation on how heme binding is regulated. At the sequence level, HO-1 and HO-2 are highly homologous (55% identity, 76% similarity). A significant difference in the sequence lies between residues 240-295 (HO-2 numbering). In this region, HO-2 unlike HO-1, contains two short amino acid stretches comprising a Cys-Pro dipeptide referred to as the heme regulatory motif (HRM). Besides, HO-1 lacks the first 30 amino acid residues present at the N-terminus of HO-2. Earlier studies in our lab have demonstrated that the affinity of HO-2 for heme is regulated by redox conditions. Precisely, the oxidation state of cysteines in HRMs was shown to play a role in modulating the ability of HO-2 to bind heme, which indicated an essential physiological function of HRMs. It therefore becomes imperative to understand the mechanism of HO-2 regulation and in particular address the impact of changes in the oxidation state of HRMs on the overall structure of HO-2. Using NMR and EXAFS, we have now shown that an otherwise disordered C-terminal tail docks onto the core of HO-2 juxtaposed to the heme-binding site, when HRMs in this region exist in the sulfhydryl state. This may explain a decrease in heme affinity of HO-2 under reducing conditions to be the result of a plausible replacement of water network at the distal end of heme with a transient thiolate interaction.
